fact_checked_segment: “Recent computer forecasts suggest that if greenhouse gas emissions continue at a high level, parts of Antarctica could break up rapidly, causing the ocean to rise six feet or more by the end of this century. That is double the maximum increase that an international climate panel projected only four years ago. But those computer forecasts were described as crude even by the researchers who created them. ‘We could be decades too fast, or decades too slow,’said one of them, Robert M. DeConto of the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. ‘There are still some really big question marks about the trajectory of future climate around Antarctica.’”
comment_by_fact-checker: The “recent computer forecasts” referenced here likely refer to the numerical model developed by Rob DeConto1. Different from other ice-sheet models it includes the so-called “Marine Ice Cliff Instability”, which at present is not widely accepted in the ice-sheet modeling community. Including this instability will cause increased rates for resultant sea-level rise projections. On the other hand, DeConto’s model includes simplifications related to how ice sheet slides over the sediment at the base. This ice-sliding parameterization will generally increase ice-sheet stability and cause smaller projections of sea-level rise, as demonstrated in the Nature paper by C. Ritz et al. in 20152. There is still a lot of uncertainty regarding the physical and hydrological processes involved in ice-sheet modeling. Ideally, we prepare for the upper bounds regarding projected rates in sea-level rise, since the scientific community is still far from providing high-confidence estimates. DeConto and Pollard (2016) Contribution of Antarctica to past and future sea-level rise, Nature Ritz et al (2015) Potential sea-level rise from Antarctic ice-sheet instability constrained by observations, Nature Margot Saher, Lecturer, Bangor University, Wales, UK: This is based on a combination of observations and modelling1. Observations show us several glaciers are in decline2 and ice shelves, which serve as a buttress for the glaciers, are thinning due to warmer sea water. This process is seen to be accelerating3. Where ice shelves (like Larsen B) have already vanished, glaciers in the hinterland have indeed sped up4. Numerical models predict that the changes underway now are likely to lead to a full-scale collapse of the west Antarctic Ice Sheet. 1- Joughin et al (2014) Marine Ice Sheet Collapse Potentially Under Way for the Thwaites Glacier Basin, West Antarctica, Science 2- Rignot et al (2011) Acceleration of the contribution of the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets to sea level rise, Geophysical Research Letters 3- Paolo et al (2015) Volume loss from Antarctic ice shelves is accelerating, Science 4- Scambos et al (2004) Glacier acceleration and thinning after ice shelf collapse in the Larsen B embayment, Antarctica, Geophysical Research Letters
label: vagueness
debunk: Antarctica's ice sheets could break up rapidly, causing the ocean to rise six feet or more by the end of this century if greenhouse gas emissions continue at a high level. However, the computer forecasts that predict this outcome are considered crude by the researchers who created them. There are still significant uncertainties about the trajectory of future climate around Antarctica. The researchers warn that the forecasts could be decades too fast or too slow.

fact_checked_segment: “So it’s been a surprise to climate scientists that 2017 has been so remarkably warm — because the last El Niño ended a year ago.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The claim that this is “a surprise to climate scientists” is not correct. In December 2016, climate scientists at the UK’s Met Office Hadley Centre predicted that 2017 would be “another very warm year for global temperatures”. 2017 was forecast to be among the warmest on record, but not as warm as 2016, so what is happening is actually consistent with the prediction.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: El Niño is not the only factor affecting global temperatures
FACT1: El Niño is a natural climate pattern that occurs every few years, characterized by warmer-than-average sea surface temperatures in the Pacific Ocean. It can have a significant impact on global temperatures, but it is not the only factor affecting them. Other factors include greenhouse gas emissions, solar activity, and volcanic eruptions.
MYTH: El Niño is the only reason for the recent warm temperatures.
FALLACY: This statement is an oversimplification, as it implies that El Niño is the sole cause of the recent warm temperatures. In reality, while El Niño can have a significant impact on global temperatures, it is just one of many factors that contribute to climate variability. Focusing solely on El Niño ignores the role of other factors, such as human-caused greenhouse gas emissions, in driving long-term warming trends.
FACT2: Let's not overlook the role of human-caused greenhouse gas emissions in driving long-term warming trends. It is important to recognize the complexity of climate variability and the multiple factors that contribute to it.

fact_checked_segment: “In the U.S. about 9,000 people die from heat each year but 144,000 die from cold.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This suggests that the dependency is not linear, and there is a multitude of factors involved. Hence, “cold deaths” may be a misnomer. The temperature is a moderator combined with standard of living, life-style diseases, pollution, and poverty, in addition to accidents and other weather conditions…
label: no fallacy
debunk: Cold weather is indeed a significant health risk, and it is true that more people die from cold-related causes than from heat-related causes in the United States. However, the statement is misleading because it implies that cold weather is not affected by climate change. In reality, climate change is causing more frequent and severe extreme weather events, including cold snaps, which can have serious health consequences. Additionally, the statement ignores the fact that heat waves are becoming more frequent and intense due to climate change, which poses a growing threat to public health. Let's not downplay the risks of extreme weather and work towards mitigating the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “climate economists see a positive externality, not a negative one, from the human influence on climate. (In technical lingo, the so-called social cost of carbon would be negative.)”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is cherry-picking at its worst. You can always find an economist who will make enough assumptions so that he or she can give you the answer you want. In this case (references the social cost of carbon), you can get a benefit ONLY if you assume a very high discount rate (like 5% so that future generations do not matter), and you ignore equity issues, and you assume that warmer climates in the crop-intensive areas will not include an increase in the intensity and/or frequency of intense weather (drought, floods, etc….), and you do not recognize that warmer temperatures mean more pests and more weeds. see the Summary for Policymakers of the Report of Working Group II to the fourth assessment of the IPCC
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change Can Have Positive Externalities
FACT1: Climate change can have positive externalities, which are benefits that are not reflected in market prices. For example, a warmer climate may increase agricultural productivity in some regions, leading to lower food prices and increased food security. Additionally, some economists argue that the social cost of carbon, which measures the economic damage caused by carbon emissions, could be negative, meaning that the benefits of carbon emissions may outweigh the costs in some cases.

MYTH: Climate Change Only Has Negative Consequences
FALLACY: The myth that climate change only has negative consequences is a false dichotomy, which presents only two options when there may be more. Climate change can have both positive and negative consequences, and it is important to consider both when evaluating the costs and benefits of different policies.

FACT2: It is important to consider both the positive and negative externalities of climate change when evaluating policies to address it. By doing so, we can make more informed decisions that take into account the full range of impacts on society and the environment. Let's not oversimplify the issue and instead strive for a comprehensive understanding of the complex challenges posed by climate change.

fact_checked_segment: The Rio Grande is a classic “feast or famine” river, with a dry year or two typically followed by a couple of wet years that allow for recovery.
comment_by_fact-checker: Weird wording. It’s just an arid river with high inter-annual variability in precipitation and flows.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Rio Grande is a Feast or Famine River
FACT1: The Rio Grande is a river that experiences periods of drought followed by periods of heavy rainfall. This pattern is known as a "feast or famine" cycle. During dry years, the river can become very low, while during wet years, it can flood.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Understanding the feast or famine cycle of the Rio Grande is important for managing water resources in the region. Let's work to conserve water during wet years to prepare for the dry years.

fact_checked_segment: If we halve the carbon dioxide content of the atmosphere, all life dies
comment_by_fact-checker: If we halve the present day carbon dioxide content in the atmosphere, we will end up with the most common CO2 concentrations over the past 2 million years… those during an ice age. Life did not die. All the species we know today (including hominins) actually lived through several cycles of ice ages.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Importance of Carbon Dioxide for Life on Earth
FACT1: Carbon dioxide is a vital component for life on Earth, as it is necessary for photosynthesis, the process by which plants produce food and oxygen. Without carbon dioxide, plants would not be able to survive, and the entire food chain would collapse.
MYTH: Halving the carbon dioxide content of the atmosphere would cause all life to die.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false dilemma fallacy, which presents only two extreme options and ignores the possibility of a middle ground. In reality, reducing carbon dioxide levels to a certain extent could have negative consequences for some species, but it would not necessarily cause all life to die.
FACT2: While reducing carbon dioxide levels too much could have negative consequences, it is important to find a balance that supports both human activities and the health of the planet. Let's work towards reducing carbon emissions and finding sustainable solutions to protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: ” ‘You’ve only got to look at Singapore. It’s two-and-a-half times higher than the worst-case scenario for climate change, and it’s one of the most desirable cities in the world to live in.’ ”
comment_by_fact-checker: Desirability of a location has nothing to do with how safe it is from the effects of climate change.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Singapore's High Sea Levels
FACT1: Singapore is a city-state located on an island with an average elevation of 15 meters above sea level. Due to its low-lying geography, Singapore is vulnerable to rising sea levels caused by climate change. 
MYTH: The high sea levels in Singapore are not a concern because the city is still desirable to live in.
FALLACY: This argument is an example of a false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that because Singapore is a desirable city to live in despite its high sea levels, rising sea levels caused by climate change are not a concern. This ignores the fact that Singapore has implemented extensive measures to mitigate the effects of rising sea levels, and that the situation could be much worse without these measures.
FACT2: Rising sea levels caused by climate change are a serious concern for low-lying cities like Singapore. It is important to acknowledge the potential risks and take action to mitigate them, rather than assuming that a city's desirability is proof that it is not vulnerable to the effects of climate change. Let's prioritize taking action to address the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Recent computer forecasts suggest that if greenhouse gas emissions continue at a high level, parts of Antarctica could break up rapidly, causing the ocean to rise six feet or more by the end of this century. That is double the maximum increase that an international climate panel projected only four years ago. But those computer forecasts were described as crude even by the researchers who created them. ‘We could be decades too fast, or decades too slow,’said one of them, Robert M. DeConto of the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. ‘There are still some really big question marks about the trajectory of future climate around Antarctica.’”
comment_by_fact-checker: This reflects recent research—an important point is that this is about possible future consequences of high emissions, which are hence avoidable if emissions are lower. This is in contrast to the opening sentence and headline, which talk of “unstoppable disintegration” already in progress.
label: vagueness
debunk: Antarctica's ice sheets could break up rapidly, causing the ocean to rise six feet or more by the end of this century if greenhouse gas emissions continue at a high level. However, the computer forecasts that predict this outcome are considered crude by the researchers who created them. There are still significant uncertainties about the trajectory of future climate around Antarctica. The researchers warn that the forecasts could be decades too fast or too slow.

fact_checked_segment: “cold kills many more people than heat.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Lomborg seems unaware of, or more likely is ignoring, the fact that climate change caused by human activities is making the climate not only warmer but more unpredictable: increased intensity and frequency of extreme weather events including drought, heavy downpours, heat waves…
label: cherry picking
debunk:
FACT1: Both cold and heat can be dangerous, but cold temperatures are generally more deadly than hot temperatures. Cold weather can lead to hypothermia, frostbite, and other health problems, especially in vulnerable populations such as the elderly and homeless.

MYTH: The myth is that cold temperatures are not as dangerous as hot temperatures and that cold weather is not a significant health risk.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that two things are equivalent when they are not. While both cold and heat can be dangerous, they affect the body in different ways and have different health risks. Cold temperatures can lead to hypothermia, frostbite, and other health problems, while hot temperatures can cause heat exhaustion, heat stroke, and dehydration.

FACT2: It is important to take precautions in both hot and cold weather to protect your health and safety. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and family and instead educate ourselves on the risks of extreme temperatures and how to stay safe in different weather conditions.

fact_checked_segment: “In the geological past, Earth’s atmosphere had hundreds of times the CO2 content of the modern atmosphere yet there were no carbon dioxide-driven catastrophes. The past shows that climate change is normal, that warmer times and more atmospheric carbon dioxide have driven biodiversity and that cold times kill.”
comment_by_fact-checker: There are many problems with this statement, starting with an entire lack of accuracy. It reads like a series of generic statements that can easily be taken out of context and are entirely irrelevant to the problem at hand. One particularly striking point is the implicitly obvious lack of awareness for timescales. Atmospheric CO2 concentrations are changing at unprecedented rates now, posing a serious threat to biodiversity in rapidly changing ecosystems.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The Normalcy of Climate Change and CO2 Levels in the Past
FACT1: Earth's climate has changed naturally in the past, with fluctuations in temperature and atmospheric CO2 levels. These changes have driven biodiversity and have been a normal part of Earth's history.
MYTH: The belief that because Earth's atmosphere had higher CO2 levels in the past without catastrophic consequences, current increases in CO2 levels are not a cause for concern.
FALLACY: This argument is a false equivalence fallacy, as it assumes that just because Earth's climate has changed naturally in the past, current changes are also natural and not influenced by human activity. It also ignores the fact that the rate of CO2 increase is much faster than in the past, and that the current levels are higher than they have been in millions of years.
FACT2: Let's not use the past as an excuse to ignore the current scientific consensus on climate change. The overwhelming evidence shows that human activity is causing an increase in CO2 levels and driving climate change. It is important to take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “It’s far too early to tell if what we are seeing in the Arctic, and now the Antarctic, is a sharp shift towards warmer poles with less ice. Scientists are quick to point out that weather in these regions can change quickly, but this is another expected result of climate change.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Certainly the loss of sea ice is largely a result of warming from increased atmospheric concentrations of CO2. So it’s not surprising to see the changes in the Arctic. Climate models also predict that Antarctic sea ice will decline eventually, especially once the ozone hole recovers. There is some evidence* that the ozone hole has led to stronger circumpolar winds that spread the Antarctic sea ice cover out from the continent and since there is no land to bound the sea ice (like in the Arctic) it can expand towards the equator until it reaches warmer ocean temperatures. Arblaster and Meehl (2006) Contributions of External Forcings to Southern Annular Mode Trends, Journal of Climate Turner and Overland (2009) Contrasting climate change in the two polar regions, Polar Research
label: hasty generalization
debunk:
FACT1: Climate change is causing a shift towards warmer poles with less ice, but it is too early to tell if this is a sharp shift. Weather in these regions can change quickly.

MYTH: The shift towards warmer poles with less ice is not caused by climate change.

FALLACY: This statement is an example of slothful induction, which is the fallacy of ignoring relevant evidence when coming to a conclusion. The evidence shows that climate change is causing a shift towards warmer poles with less ice, but the speaker is ignoring this evidence and claiming that it is too early to tell.

FACT2: Climate change is real and is causing a shift towards warmer poles with less ice. Let's not ignore the evidence and continue to take action to address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “…climate change will also reduce the number of cold days and cold spells. That will cut the total number of cold-related deaths.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The assertion that warmer winters = less mortality is a schoolboy error. Indeed everyone knows that European countries with warmer climates and milder winters actually have MORE not LESS winter mortality; principally due to adaptation. The current numbers of winter mortality may well be higher than summer heat wave mortality in many temperate to northern countries, however what is crucially important is that evidence points to significant increase in summer heat related mortality and no or very little change to winter mortality as a result of climate change.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change and Cold-Related Deaths
FACT1: Climate change will lead to a reduction in the number of cold days and cold spells, which will ultimately decrease the total number of cold-related deaths. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to acknowledge that while climate change may reduce the number of cold-related deaths, it will also lead to an increase in heat-related deaths. Therefore, it is crucial to take action to mitigate the effects of climate change and protect vulnerable populations. Let's work towards implementing sustainable solutions to combat climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “we should look at all the available information.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Yes indeed, this is exactly what the IPCC does. I agree with Lomborg that having unbalanced views, only showing negative outcomes, is not helpful. But this is also true for this article that attempts to only show positive outcomes. Planet will get greener, less people will die in winter, the developed world is less vulnerable, precipitation will increase … All of these statements are severely biased, only telling half of the story (if not less…).
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The Importance of Considering All Available Information
FACT1: When making decisions or forming opinions, it is important to consider all available information. This includes information that may contradict our preconceived notions or beliefs. By doing so, we can make more informed and accurate decisions.
MYTH: N/A
FALLACY: This statement is not a fallacy, but rather a sound principle of critical thinking. However, it is important to note that simply considering all available information does not guarantee that our conclusions will be correct. We must also evaluate the quality and reliability of the information we are considering.
FACT2: Let's strive to be open-minded and consider all available information when making decisions or forming opinions. By doing so, we can make more informed and accurate conclusions.

fact_checked_segment: “The IPCC reports also don’t fully account for the albedo effect (less ice means less reflected and more absorbed sunlight, hence more warming); more cloud cover (which traps heat); or the dieback of forests and other flora (which extract carbon from the atmosphere). Each of these promises to accelerate warming”
comment_by_fact-checker: I am not sure what the author means here. The climate models whose projections the IPCC reports are based on definitely account for the changes in albedo from reduced sea-ice and snow cover as the world warms (although not necessarily changes in glaciers and ice caps extents—e.g. Greenland—which is maybe what the author means here), as well as the effect of changes in clouds (actually, the largest source of uncertainty in climate models projections); most models also now account for changes in vegetation and include an interactive carbon cycle (for instance, how a reduction in forest diminishes the land carbon sink).
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: IPCC Reports and Climate Change

FACT1: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is a scientific body established by the United Nations to provide policymakers with regular assessments of the scientific basis of climate change, its impacts, and future risks. The IPCC reports are based on the best available scientific evidence and are subject to rigorous review and scrutiny by experts from around the world.

MYTH: The IPCC reports do not fully account for the albedo effect, more cloud cover, or the dieback of forests and other flora, which will accelerate warming.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, where a few factors are highlighted while ignoring the many other factors that are considered in the IPCC reports. The IPCC reports do take into account the albedo effect, cloud cover, and the role of forests and other flora in absorbing carbon dioxide. However, the exact impact of these factors on climate change is complex and uncertain, and the IPCC reports reflect this uncertainty.

FACT2: The IPCC reports are an important source of information for policymakers and the public to understand the risks and impacts of climate change. It is important to rely on the best available scientific evidence and to avoid cherry-picking or misrepresenting the findings of the IPCC reports. Let's use this information to take action to address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: From 1970 until 1998 there was a warming period that raised temperatures by about 0.7 F that helped spawn the global warming alarmist movement. However, since 1998, little warming has occurred while carbon dioxide emissions continue to increase.
comment_by_fact-checker: Warming rate from 1970-1998: +0.15 C/decade, 95 % confidence interval +/- 0.06 C/decade. Warming rate from 1998-2018: +0.18 C/decade, 95 % confidence interval +/- 0.09 C/decade. (Calculated with Berkeley Earth). Odds are that warming after 1998 was faster than warming before 1998. Anyone who looks into the data and has basic analysis skills can see this, so they would not even try to imply that 1970-1998 warming was faster than post-1998 warming. The whole article uses tricks like this to invert reality, and will leave readers deeply deceived.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The Misleading Claim of Little Warming Since 1998
FACT1: The Earth's temperature has continued to rise since 1998, despite claims to the contrary. In fact, the 10 hottest years on record have all occurred since 1998, and the past decade has been the hottest on record. 
MYTH: The claim that there has been little warming since 1998, despite increasing carbon dioxide emissions.
FALLACY: This claim is an example of cherry-picking, where a specific time period is selected to support a particular argument while ignoring the larger trend. By focusing on a short period of time, this claim ignores the long-term trend of rising temperatures and the overwhelming scientific consensus that human activities, including the burning of fossil fuels, are the primary cause of global warming.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. The Earth's temperature has continued to rise since 1998, and it is important to recognize the long-term trend of rising temperatures and the need to take action to address the causes of global warming.

fact_checked_segment: “‘The dry periods are drier and the wet periods are wetter,’ said Jeffrey Mount, a water expert and senior fellow at the Public Policy Institute of California.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is seen in assessments of atmospheric reanalyses, which show a decreasing frequency of rain-producing weather systems over California but higher rain rates over the last 35 years*. Prein et al (2016) Running dry: The U.S. Southwest’s drift into a drier climate state, Geophysical Research Letters
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Climate change intensifies droughts and floods
FACT1: Climate change is causing more extreme weather events, including droughts and floods. As temperatures rise, more water evaporates from the ground, leading to longer and more severe droughts. When it does rain, the increased moisture in the atmosphere can lead to heavier and more frequent downpours, causing floods. 
MYTH: Climate change is not causing more extreme weather events.
FALLACY: The myth is based on a false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that because extreme weather events have occurred in the past, they must be natural and not caused by human activities. However, scientific evidence shows that the frequency and severity of these events have increased due to human-induced climate change.
FACT2: We need to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change. Let's support policies and practices that promote sustainability and resilience in our communities.

fact_checked_segment: “This chart gives you a good idea of the direction of the adjustments.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The chart provides solely a view as to the changes in applied adjustments between consecutive versions of one product. It does not reflect the totality of the adjustments being applied. Showing total adjustments would highlight that these deltas were dwarfed by the existing adjustments applied to the 2008 version. Specifically, the very large spurious warming resulting from biases in the raw marine data record over the late 1930s / early 1940s. The net effect of adjustments in all datasets is to reduce the centennial timescale warming in all the surface temperature products.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding Data Adjustments in Climate Science
FACT1: Climate scientists often adjust raw data to correct for errors and biases, such as changes in measurement methods or urbanization effects. These adjustments are necessary to ensure accurate and consistent data over time.
MYTH: Data adjustments in climate science are made to manipulate the data and support a predetermined conclusion.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of the Straw Man fallacy, as it misrepresents the purpose of data adjustments in climate science. The adjustments are made to correct for known errors and biases, not to manipulate the data.
FACT2: Understanding the reasons for data adjustments in climate science can help us appreciate the importance of accurate and consistent data in understanding our changing climate. Let's not spread misinformation about data adjustments and instead seek to understand the scientific process.

fact_checked_segment: “‘Next year or the year after, the Arctic will be free of ice’”
comment_by_fact-checker: The title is misleading. Wadhams suggests that the central Arctic (only) will be ice free in the summer.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Arctic ice is melting at an alarming rate
FACT1: The Arctic ice is melting at an alarming rate due to global warming caused by human activities. The Arctic sea ice extent has decreased by 13.1% per decade since 1979, and the Arctic is warming at twice the rate of the rest of the world.
MYTH: A warning that a misunderstanding is coming. "Next year or the year after, the Arctic will be free of ice."
FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false prediction. While it is true that the Arctic ice is melting at an alarming rate, it is not accurate to predict that the Arctic will be completely ice-free in the next year or two. Such a prediction is based on a misunderstanding of the complex processes that govern the Arctic climate and ice dynamics.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about the Arctic ice. While the Arctic ice is melting at an alarming rate, it is important to rely on accurate scientific information and avoid making false predictions. We need to take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and slow down the rate of Arctic ice loss.

fact_checked_segment: Computer models of the climate are at the heart of calls to ban the cheap, reliable energy that powers our thriving economy and promotes healthier, longer lives.
comment_by_fact-checker: No. Climate models are one source of information, but the basis of concern about climate change comes from our understanding of the fundamental physics of the atmosphere.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Importance of Climate Models in Understanding Climate Change
FACT1: Climate models are essential tools used by scientists to understand how the Earth's climate system works and how it may change in the future. These models are based on fundamental principles of physics, chemistry, and biology, and are continually tested and refined using real-world observations.
MYTH: Climate models are unreliable and should not be used to inform policy decisions.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of the false equivalence fallacy, which incorrectly claims that two things are equivalent despite notable differences between them. In this case, it equates the scientific consensus on climate change, which is based on decades of research and thousands of peer-reviewed studies, with the opinions of those who reject this consensus without scientific evidence. It also ignores the fact that climate models are continually tested and refined using real-world observations, and that they have accurately predicted many aspects of climate change.
FACT2: Climate models are an essential tool for understanding climate change and informing policy decisions. By using these models, scientists can better understand how the Earth's climate system works and how it may change in the future. Let's trust the scientific consensus and use the best available evidence to make informed decisions about our energy future.

fact_checked_segment: “The Lancet researchers found that about 0.5%—half a percent—of all deaths are associated with heat, not only from acute problems like heat stroke, but also increased mortality from cardiac events and dehydration. But more than 7% of deaths are related to cold—counting hypothermia, as well as increased blood pressure and risk of heart attack that results when the body restricts blood flow in response to frigid temperatures.”
comment_by_fact-checker: I do not want to question the quality of this particular study, but it’s worth looking at how they get such numbers. First, this is a statistical study where they look at data on numbers of deaths and temperatures in various locations: of course, nothing says if, or how, these deaths are really related to temperature (heat or cold). This is an empirical study. Lomborg’s comments suggest that the authors of this study are counting deaths explicitly caused by heat or cold, but this is not the case. Second, they basically fit a temperature-death risk response curve to this data. They then see for what temperature the mortality risk is lowest – and then they aggregate all the deaths below (for cold-related deaths) and above (for heat-related ones) that temperature. Because the temperature of minimum mortality is often high (around 20-25C, or lower 70’s F), for cold-related deaths this leads to integrating the response function (even with low death risks) over much of the temperature distribution. See plots below. The authors indicate as much: “This difference was mainly caused by the high minimum-mortality percentile, with most of the mean daily temperatures being lower than the optimum value.” This methodology also explains why most cold-related deaths appear due to “moderate cold”. This is worth explaining, because I am not sure dying in 15C weather (60F) in Rome or Sydney is really what people will understand when they read about “cold-related deaths”! From Gasparrini et al. figure 1: Exposure–response associations as best linear unbiased prediction (with 95% empirical CI, shaded grey) in representative cities of the 13 countries, with related temperature distributions. Solid grey lines are minimum mortality temperatures and dashed grey lines are the 2.5th and 97.5th percentiles. RR=relative risk. The other thing that is easy to see is that the risk curve generally increases slowly towards cold temperature, but a lot more steeply past high temperatures. So even if one agrees with how this study classifies and counts “cold deaths”, the fact that they outnumber heat deaths, in absolute numbers, does not necessarily mean that increasing temperatures will reduce deaths: based on these plots, it could well be that warming will reduce cold-related deaths less than it increases heat-related ones. And indeed, this is what the studies about future projection of temperature-related deaths that they cite, and that Lomborg discusses, do find.
label: false authority
debunk: Cold weather is more deadly than hot weather, according to a study published in The Lancet. The study found that while about 0.5% of all deaths are associated with heat, more than 7% of deaths are related to cold. This includes deaths from hypothermia, as well as increased blood pressure and risk of heart attack that results when the body restricts blood flow in response to frigid temperatures. The study highlights the importance of taking measures to protect vulnerable populations during cold weather, such as providing warm shelter and ensuring access to heating. Let's prioritize the health and safety of all individuals, especially those who are most at risk during extreme weather conditions.

fact_checked_segment: We have also been told the problem is DEFINITELY NOT a billions-year-old planet running through cycles where the temperature might fluctuate a bit.
comment_by_fact-checker: This entire article’s “proof” is just saying that “higher CO2 happened before humans, therefore humans can’t cause higher CO2“. Here are logically identical arguments: “England scored goals before Harry Kane, so Harry Kane can’t score goals” Or in American English: “The New England Patriots scored touchdowns before Rob Gronkowski, so Rob Gronkowski can’t score touchdowns” Or more simply: “Fires happened before humans, so humans can’t cause fires”. So if you agree with this article’s logic and that humans aren’t causing CO2 to rise, you also have to believe that Harry Kane and Rob Gronkowski never scored anything and could never score anything, and that no fire has been caused by a human ever. Human-caused global warming, goals by Harry Kane, touchdowns by Rob Gronkowski, and fires set by people are all in the same boat. We have enormous evidence that they exist.
label: false cause
debunk:
MYTH: The Earth's current climate change is just a natural cycle that has occurred throughout the planet's history.

FALLACY: This is a false equivalence fallacy, as it assumes that because the Earth has undergone natural climate changes in the past, the current changes must also be natural. However, the current changes are occurring at an unprecedented rate and are primarily caused by human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation.

FACT: The Earth's current climate change is primarily caused by human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation. This is supported by overwhelming scientific evidence, including the fact that the current rate of warming is much faster than any natural climate change in the past. 

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about the causes of climate change. It is important to recognize the role of human activities in causing climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: to avoid runaway climate change
comment_by_fact-checker: I agree, “runaway climate change” is too strong here. It has a precise definition. Warming beyond 2°C, say by 3 or 4°C, is bad, but not the same as “runaway” (which, in my view at least, means that warming would then take a dynamics of its own, stop responding to any emission changes and slip up to several more degrees….).
label: no fallacy
debunk:
{
    "TITLE": "The Urgent Need to Address Climate Change",
    "FACT1": "The Earth's climate is changing at an unprecedented rate due to human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation, leading to a rise in global temperatures, sea level, and extreme weather events.",
    "MYTH": "Climate change is a natural phenomenon that has nothing to do with human activities.",
    "FALLACY": "This is a false equivalence fallacy, as it assumes that because climate has changed naturally in the past, it must be natural now. However, the current rate of change is much faster than any natural climate change in the past, and it is directly linked to human activities.",
    "FACT2": "Let's take urgent action to reduce our carbon footprint, transition to renewable energy, and protect our planet for future generations."
}

fact_checked_segment: “global warming causes about as much damage as benefits.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This claim is not supported by any source. Read the IPCC synthesis report Summary for Policy-Makers (SPM) headlines for a balanced assessment: “Continued emission of greenhouse gases will cause further warming and long-lasting changes in all components of the climate system, increasing the likelihood of severe, pervasive and irreversible impacts for people and ecosystems.” …
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The Benefits and Drawbacks of Global Warming
FACT1: Global warming has both positive and negative effects on the environment and human society. For example, it can lead to longer growing seasons and increased agricultural productivity in some regions, but it can also cause more frequent and severe weather events, sea level rise, and harm to ecosystems and human health.
MYTH: A common myth is that global warming causes about as much damage as benefits.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that two things are equivalent when they are not. While global warming may have some benefits, such as increased agricultural productivity in some regions, the negative impacts far outweigh the positive ones. The scientific consensus is that global warming is causing significant harm to the environment and human society, including more frequent and severe weather events, sea level rise, and harm to ecosystems and human health.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. It is important to understand the full picture of the impacts of global warming and take action to mitigate its negative effects.

fact_checked_segment: “it now seems like three feet is possible only under the rosiest of scenarios”
comment_by_fact-checker: Including the contribution from thermal expansion of seawater, mountain glaciers, and Greenland, three feet is probably a good estimate for the lower bound on the total sea level rise that can be expected from current and past climate change (many studies ask this question, but Pfeffer, 2008* is an oft-cited example). The key phrase here is total sea level rise, which may unfold in the next century or over the next several millennia as ice sheets continue to respond to past climate change for many hundreds to thousands of years. If this phrase refers to three feet of sea level rise from Antarctica by 2100, then it does not accurately represent the findings of DeConto & Pollard (see RCP 2.6 in Figure 5 of that study, above). Pfeffer et al (2008) Kinematic Constraints on Glacier Contributions to 21st-Century Sea-Level Rise, Science
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Sea level rise is a serious threat
FACT1: Sea levels are rising due to global warming, which is caused by human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation. This rise in sea levels is a serious threat to coastal communities, as it can cause flooding, erosion, and damage to infrastructure.
MYTH: Sea level rise is not a serious threat and is only a possibility under the best-case scenarios.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of ambiguity, as it uses vague language to downplay the severity of sea level rise. It also ignores the overwhelming scientific evidence that shows sea levels are rising and will continue to do so in the future.
FACT2: Let's not underestimate the threat of sea level rise and take action to reduce our carbon emissions and protect vulnerable coastal communities.

fact_checked_segment: With that in mind, they propose a plausible and terrifying “2050 scenario” whereby humanity could face irreversible collapse in just three decades.
comment_by_fact-checker: Not to downplay the seriousness of what humanity is facing, but the report in fact doesn’t make this claim. While scientists do expect many of the changes to the Earth system due to global heating to be “irreversible,” and while this should be extremely concerning to any reasonable person, it is different than “irreversible human collapse” which, if you think about it, needs unpacking.
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: The potential for irreversible collapse by 2050 is a plausible scenario, according to experts.

FACT1: Experts warn that humanity could face irreversible collapse by 2050 if we do not take immediate action to address issues such as climate change, biodiversity loss, and inequality. This scenario is not a certainty, but it is a plausible outcome based on current trends and projections.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: None.

FACT2: It is crucial that we take action now to address these issues and prevent the worst-case scenario from becoming a reality. This includes reducing greenhouse gas emissions, protecting biodiversity, and promoting social and economic equality. Let's work together to create a sustainable future for ourselves and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: since 1979 to the most reliable observations — those made by satellites and weather balloons over the vast tropics.
comment_by_fact-checker: Beware of cherry-picking: It is not established that satellites are the “most reliable” observations, that the tropics are the best domain with which to compare observations or models, or that we should only consider post-1979 satellite era data.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The Most Reliable Observations of Global Temperature Trends
FACT1: Satellites and weather balloons provide the most reliable observations of global temperature trends since 1979. These observations cover the vast tropics and are not subject to the biases and errors that can occur with surface temperature measurements.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's trust the most reliable observations of global temperature trends and use them to inform our understanding of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “while it’s true that studies in some regions show polar bears are lighter in weight than they were in the 1980s, there is no evidence that more individuals are starving to death or becoming too thin to reproduce because of less summer ice.”
comment_by_fact-checker: We know that polar bears depend on the ice surface to catch their prey. We know that increasing numbers of ice free days have resulted in poorer body condition in some areas (e.g. Southern Beaufort, Western and Southern Hudson Bay), we know that poorer cub survival has followed both declining ice and poorer body condition, and all the evidence suggests these things are linked. Perhaps this is not “proof” that less available summer ice is the cause (correlation does not necessarily imply causation), but I am not aware of evidence for any other explanation. And I don’t think the female polar bears are intentionally having cubs but not feeding them.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
FACT1: Polar bears are lighter in weight than they were in the 1980s in some regions.
MYTH: There is evidence that more polar bears are starving to death or becoming too thin to reproduce because of less summer ice.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, where only one aspect of the situation is highlighted while ignoring other factors that may be contributing to the weight loss of polar bears. While it is true that polar bears are lighter in weight in some regions, there is no evidence to suggest that this is due to less summer ice. Other factors such as changes in prey availability and hunting pressure may also be contributing to the weight loss of polar bears.
FACT2: Let's not jump to conclusions and instead consider all the factors that may be contributing to the weight loss of polar bears.

fact_checked_segment: “the satellites now show that in recent months global temperatures have plummeted by more that [sic] 0.6 degrees”
comment_by_fact-checker: While true (and not necessarily in agreement with the more robust thermometer records for this period, this has no bearing on the long-term climate trend, which is driven by human emissions of greenhouse gases. It is misleading and a logical fallacy to claim this says anything about climate change, which is the long-term change in temperatures.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The Misleading Claim of Plummeting Global Temperatures
FACT1: Global temperatures have not plummeted in recent months. In fact, 2020 was one of the hottest years on record, and the trend of increasing global temperatures has continued for decades.
MYTH: A claim that global temperatures have plummeted by more than 0.6 degrees in recent months, based on satellite data.
FALLACY: This claim is an example of cherry-picking, where a small amount of data is selected to support a particular argument while ignoring the larger trend. The satellite data in question only covers a short period of time and does not represent the long-term trend of global temperature increase.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about global temperatures. It is important to look at long-term trends and multiple sources of data to understand the reality of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: Some experts think we’re on track to hit 550 ppm by the end of the century, which would cause average global temperatures to rise by 6 degrees Celsius
comment_by_fact-checker: This assumes a very high climate sensitivity compared to most IPCC-class models. Can the authors give a source for where they got this estimate? It appears to be a quote from the previous link, which itself has no reference either. Most estimates tend to fall around 3 ˚C/doubling, and 550 is ~1 doubling of CO2 vs. pre-industrial of 280 ppm. So that would suggest ~3˚C total, of which maybe 1 ˚C has already happened. Maybe one saving grace here is that 550 ppm is perhaps one of the more conservative estimates for the end of the century.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The Dangerous Consequences of Reaching 550 ppm of CO2
FACT1: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is a greenhouse gas that traps heat in the Earth's atmosphere. When there is too much CO2 in the atmosphere, it causes the planet to warm up, leading to climate change. 
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: This statement is based on scientific research and data. If we continue to emit greenhouse gases at the current rate, we are on track to reach 550 ppm of CO2 by the end of the century. This would cause average global temperatures to rise by 6 degrees Celsius, leading to devastating consequences such as more frequent and severe heatwaves, droughts, floods, and storms. 
FACT2: It is crucial that we take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and transition to cleaner sources of energy to avoid the worst impacts of climate change. Let's work together to protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: But experts say the energy transition needs to speed up drastically to head off the worst effects of climate change.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is correct. While many countries show gradual declines in their emissions, global emissions are not yet declining. The past few years, global annual CO2 emissions have not increased as much as they did previously and remained roughly constant. However, to halt global mean temperature rise annual CO2 emissions have to become zero.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Energy Transition Needs to Speed Up to Address Climate Change
FACT1: The transition to renewable energy needs to accelerate significantly to mitigate the worst impacts of climate change. Experts warn that current efforts are not enough to meet the goals of the Paris Agreement and limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's support policies and initiatives that promote the transition to renewable energy, such as investing in clean energy research and development, implementing carbon pricing, and supporting renewable energy infrastructure. We can all play a role in reducing our carbon footprint by making small changes in our daily lives, such as using public transportation, reducing meat consumption, and conserving energy at home.

fact_checked_segment: Atmospheric scientist John Christy developed a global temperature record of the lower atmosphere using highly accurate satellite soundings.
comment_by_fact-checker: The authors are referring to microwave sounding instruments, which provide a measure of tropospheric temperature changes. These records are useful, but have substantial uncertainty. In the State of the Climate Report1, various estimates of tropical tropospheric warming had a range of 0.12 – 0.22 K / decade across four datasets (that all use the same underlying satellite data). This is nearly a factor of two difference in the long-term rate of warming. This “structural uncertainty” results because researchers use different approaches to remove known biases that affect long-term trends. No method is perfect, which leads to widely varying estimates of atmospheric warming. 1- Christy et al (2019): Tropospheric Temperature [in “State of the Climate in 2018”], Bulletin American Meteorological Society
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: John Christy's Global Temperature Record
FACT1: John Christy, an atmospheric scientist, developed a global temperature record of the lower atmosphere using highly accurate satellite soundings. This record provides a reliable and accurate measure of global temperature changes over time.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's trust the scientific community and their rigorous methods of data collection and analysis. By doing so, we can better understand the changes happening in our world and take action to address them.

fact_checked_segment: “Late 20th century and early 21st century global warming, they show, is neither dramatic, nor unusual, nor scary. Here … are just some of the charts to prove it.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The four charts presented in the Breitbart article purport to demonstrate that the industrial epoch warming is simply a giant natural fluctuation. But it shows nothing of the sort; it is based on a complete misunderstanding of the space-time variability of the atmosphere. The article commits two common, but fundamental errors that totally invalidate its claims. The first two charts are both of spatially global scale (the northern hemisphere), they illustrate the time scale error. They show northern hemisphere temperatures with millennial scale fluctuations (changes) of the order of 1°C; the so-called “medieval warming event”. Irrespective of whether these reconstructions are accurate (the global—not European—extent of the warming is the question under debate), the change occurred over time scales much longer than the 1°C warming that occurred over the last century. In the pre-industrial period, typical century long, global scale temperature fluctuations were about 0.2°C (i.e. typical century to century changes, see figure below); therefore if the temperature fluctuations followed the usual “bell-curve”, then a 1°C change in a century would have a probability of about one in 3 million of occurring naturally, the giant natural fluctuation hypothesis could easily be rejected. However, it was found that the bell curve under estimates the extreme 3% of the temperature fluctuations: extreme “black swan” events occur much more frequently than expected, yet, even when these rare extremes are taken into account, the probability of a 1°C change in a century is still less than 0.1%, it can easily be rejected1. The other fundamental error is also a scale error, but now in space rather than in time. This error is well exemplified in the fourth graph which shows data indirectly reflecting temperatures in France. Yet France is only about 0.1% of the global surface area, so that large natural fluctuations are common but are not of global significance. A common “skeptic” talking point is the fact that between 1662 and 1762, the temperature in central England increased by nearly 1 °C, i.e., about the same as the global temperature over the last century. Unfortunately for the “skeptics”, central England (greater London) is about 0.01% of the earth’s surface area so that it is not surprising that over the same period, the Northern Hemisphere temperature only increased by 0.2 °C (equal to the typical centennial change!). Finally, the third graph from China combines the two errors: the times scales are way too long and the spatial scales are way too small; it is doubly irrelevant to the question of anthropogenic global warming. Source Lovejoy (2014) 1- Lovejoy (2014) Scaling fluctuation analysis and statistical hypothesis testing of anthropogenic
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: The Misleading Claim of Unremarkable Global Warming
FACT1: The Earth's temperature has been rising at an unprecedented rate due to human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation. This has led to a range of negative impacts, including sea-level rise, more frequent and severe heatwaves, and more intense storms.
MYTH: "Late 20th century and early 21st century global warming, they show, is neither dramatic, nor unusual, nor scary. Here … are just some of the charts to prove it."
FALLACY: This claim is an example of cherry-picking, where only a select few data points are used to support a predetermined conclusion. The charts presented may show a short-term fluctuation in temperature, but they do not represent the long-term trend of global warming. Additionally, the claim ignores the overwhelming scientific consensus that human activities are causing global warming and its negative impacts.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's rely on the overwhelming scientific evidence and take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the impacts of global warming.

fact_checked_segment: “Last year’s warmth was manifested across the planet, from the warm tropical ocean waters off the coast of northeastern Australia, where the Great Barrier Reef experienced its worst coral bleaching event on record and large scale coral death, to the Arctic, where sea ice hit regular monthly record lows and overall temperatures were also the warmest on record, at least from January through September 2016.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Daniel Swain, Researcher, UCLA, and Research Fellow, National Center for Atmospheric Research: This section accurately describes major 2016 events that occurred in the Earth system, and which most likely would not have occurred without global warming.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Record-breaking warmth in 2016
FACT1: 2016 was a year of record-breaking warmth across the globe. The Great Barrier Reef experienced its worst coral bleaching event on record due to warm tropical ocean waters off the coast of northeastern Australia. The Arctic also experienced record warmth, with sea ice hitting regular monthly record lows.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the reality of climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint and protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: [headline:] Climate Change ‘Heat Records’ Are a Huge Data Manipulation
comment_by_fact-checker: This is the biggest and most ludicrous claim of the article—the claim that will be read most and shared most on social media—and the article provides no evidence the data was manipulated.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding Heat Records and Climate Change
FACT1: Heat records are a measure of the highest temperatures recorded in a specific location over a certain period of time. They are not a manipulation of data, but rather a way to track changes in temperature over time.
MYTH: Heat records are a manipulation of data used to support the idea of climate change.
FALLACY: The fallacy underlying this myth is cherry-picking. By focusing on heat records as a manipulation of data, this myth ignores the larger body of evidence that supports the reality of climate change. Heat records are just one piece of the puzzle, and they are supported by a wide range of other data, including rising sea levels, melting glaciers, and changes in plant and animal behavior.
FACT2: Let's not dismiss the reality of climate change based on a misunderstanding of heat records. Instead, let's look at the full range of evidence and take action to address this critical issue.

fact_checked_segment: The planet’s average ground temperature has risen by around 1.62F (0.9C)
comment_by_fact-checker: The latest estimates would place this closer to 1 degree C. Mainly as a result of the run of recent warm years.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Earth's Average Ground Temperature Has Risen
FACT1: The Earth's average ground temperature has increased by approximately 1.62F (0.9C) over the past century due to human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation. This increase in temperature has led to a range of impacts, including rising sea levels, more frequent and severe heatwaves, and changes in precipitation patterns.
MYTH: The Earth's temperature is not increasing, or if it is, it is due to natural causes and not human activities.
FALLACY: The myth is based on the logical fallacy of false equivalence, which assumes that two things are equivalent despite notable differences between them. In this case, the myth equates natural climate variability with the human-induced warming that has been observed over the past century. This fallacy misleads people by ignoring the overwhelming scientific evidence that human activities are the primary cause of the current warming trend.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's educate ourselves and others about the scientific consensus on climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: running through cycles where the temperature might fluctuate a bit.
comment_by_fact-checker: The Earth’s climate has always varied, even before humans began to influence it. Climate scientists have always been very clear about this. But human-caused emissions of CO2 and other greenhouse gases have now added a new cause of climate change in addition to the existing causes of natural climate variability.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change is Not Just Natural Fluctuations
FACT1: Climate change is a long-term shift in global weather patterns that goes beyond natural fluctuations. It is caused by human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation, which release greenhouse gases into the atmosphere and trap heat, leading to a warming planet.
MYTH: Climate change is just a natural fluctuation in temperature.
FALLACY: This myth is an oversimplification and a slippery slope fallacy. While it is true that the Earth's climate has gone through natural cycles in the past, the current warming trend is happening at an unprecedented rate and is caused by human activities. Ignoring this fact and assuming that the current warming trend is just a natural fluctuation can lead to inaction and further exacerbation of the problem.
FACT2: Let's not ignore the overwhelming scientific evidence and take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “This means that the world is now 1C warmer than it was in pre-industrial times”
comment_by_fact-checker: The temperature is 1°C warmer than in the beginning of the instrumental temperature record (1880). The 19th century was likely a little colder than the pre-industrial period. This difference is not large and currently being studied, but likely we did not cross the 1°C warming relative to pre-industrial yet. Global temperature in the Berkeley Earth dataset from 1850 to 2015
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: The world is 1C warmer than pre-industrial times
FACT1: The Earth's temperature has increased by 1 degree Celsius compared to pre-industrial times. This is a significant increase that has been caused by human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change. Let's work together to protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “It has never been shown that human emissions of carbon dioxide drive global warming.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This sentence essentially ignores many thousands of studies that provide evidence to the contrary (i.e., that human CO2 emissions ARE driving global warming) and is therefore factually wrong. IPCC (2013) Climate Change 2013: The Physical Science Basis
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The Role of Human Emissions in Global Warming
FACT1: Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas that traps heat in the Earth's atmosphere, contributing to global warming. Human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, deforestation, and land-use changes, have significantly increased the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
MYTH: "It has never been shown that human emissions of carbon dioxide drive global warming."
FALLACY: This statement is a form of cherry-picking, as it ignores the overwhelming evidence that human emissions of carbon dioxide are the primary cause of global warming. Multiple lines of evidence, including temperature records, ice core data, and computer models, all point to the conclusion that human activities are responsible for the observed warming.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. The scientific consensus is clear: human emissions of carbon dioxide are driving global warming, and we need to take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “More than half of the 44 studies selected for publication found that raised levels of CO2 had little or no impact on marine life, including crabs, limpets, sea urchins and sponges”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is meaningless… it is not unexpected that several papers published in the issue showed little or no impact because the call for papers specifically welcomed such contributions. The bias is therefore very high. I recommend using the unbiased dataset investigated by Kroeker et al. (2013). It does demonstrate negative impacts on some processes and groups of organisms. Kroeker K. et al., 2013. Impacts of ocean acidification on marine organisms: quantifying sensitivities and interaction with warming. Global Change Biology 19:1884-1896.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
FACT1: CO2 levels have little or no impact on marine life, according to more than half of the 44 studies selected for publication. 

MYTH: None stated.

FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, where only a select few studies are used to support a particular claim while ignoring the larger body of evidence. While some studies may have found little impact of CO2 on marine life, many others have found significant negative impacts, such as ocean acidification, which can harm the growth and survival of many marine organisms.

FACT2: It is important to consider the full body of evidence when evaluating the impact of CO2 on marine life. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: “The most frequently-used range of estimates puts the likely range between 15-25cm (6-10in) above 1992 levels by 2030, and 79-155cm (31-61in) by 2100.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is true that these are commonly used projections in this region. This statement refers to the Unified Sea Level Rise Projection that was produced by the Southeast Florida Regional Compact on Climate Change.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Projected Sea Level Rise
FACT1: Sea levels are projected to rise between 15-25cm (6-10in) above 1992 levels by 2030, and 79-155cm (31-61in) by 2100.
MYTH: There is no evidence of sea level rise.
FALLACY: The myth is a denial of scientific evidence. The projected sea level rise is based on extensive research and data analysis by climate scientists. The myth ignores the fact that sea levels have already risen by about 20cm (8in) since the late 19th century, and that this rise is accelerating due to human-caused global warming.
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the scientific evidence and take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions to slow down the rate of sea level rise.

fact_checked_segment: “Sea level rise is global. But due to a variety of factors – including, for this part of the Atlantic coast, a likely weakening of the Gulf Stream, itself potentially a result of the melting of Greenland’s ice caps – south Floridians are feeling the effects more than many others. While there has been a mean rise of a little more than 3mm per year worldwide since the 1990s, in the last decade, the NOAA Virginia Key tide gauge just south of Miami Beach has measured a 9mm rise annually.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement touches upon several issues that are indeed discussed in the scientific literature and it is essentially correct. Let’s try and disentangle things. It is correct that Virginia Key as well as other locations on the US Atlantic coast have experienced a surge of rapid sea-level rise during the past ten years or so. However, this is a very short period in terms of sea-level variations. The longer-term rise in this region (when corrected for local land subsidence) is actually in line with the global average sea-level rise, both for the past hundred years (~1.8mm per year) or measured since the early 1990s (~3 mm per year). The recent rapid rise is thus likely a short-term natural variation (a possibility mentioned later in the article) and may well be followed by a period of very little rise. In the longer run I would expect that sea-level near Miami would continue to increase roughly in line with the global mean sea-level rise, as is indeed discussed later in the article where the future projections with their uncertainties are covered well. It is correct that local sea-level rise can differ from global sea-level rise due to “a variety of factors”, including a weakening of the Gulf Stream. For the relevant period of rapid rise, the last ten years or so, such a weakening has been documented, e.g. in the direct measurements in the RAPID section at 26 °N. So the rapid sea-level rise and the weakening of the larger Gulf Stream System coincide, and have indeed been linked.* Like with sea level, over the short time scale of the past decade this is likely to be dominated by natural variability, although there are also indications of a longer-term, probably human-caused, downward trend. Greenland melting has not caused this, but likely contributed to it. To what extent the Gulf Stream weakening explains the recent rapid sea-level rise in Miami, and to what extent other factors—like changes in the predominant winds—are responsible remains an open research question. Ezer et al (2013) Gulf Stream’s induced sea level rise and variability along the U.S. mid-Atlantic coast, Journal of Geophysical Research-Oceans
label: no fallacy
debunk: Sea level rise is not uniform across the globe, and some regions are experiencing more significant impacts than others. In South Florida, factors such as the weakening of the Gulf Stream and the melting of Greenland's ice caps are contributing to a higher rate of sea level rise than the global average. While the worldwide mean rise has been a little over 3mm per year since the 1990s, the NOAA Virginia Key tide gauge just south of Miami Beach has measured a 9mm rise annually in the last decade. This highlights the importance of considering regional factors when assessing the impacts of climate change. Let's continue to educate ourselves on the local impacts of climate change and take action to mitigate its effects.

fact_checked_segment: “Ocean acidification is the terrifying threat whereby all that man-made CO2 we’ve been pumping into the atmosphere may react with the sea to form a sort of giant acid bath.”
comment_by_fact-checker: That is incorrect. No peer-reviewed article claim that the ocean will become acid (pH < 7).
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: The Facts About Ocean Acidification
FACT1: Ocean acidification is a process that occurs when carbon dioxide from the atmosphere dissolves in seawater, forming carbonic acid. This process lowers the pH of the ocean, making it more acidic. This can have negative impacts on marine life, including shellfish and coral reefs, which can struggle to build their shells and skeletons in more acidic water.
MYTH: Ocean acidification is a terrifying threat that will turn the ocean into a giant acid bath due to man-made CO2 emissions.
FALLACY: The myth of ocean acidification being a "terrifying threat" is an example of alarmism, which exaggerates the potential impacts of a phenomenon. While ocean acidification is a serious issue that can harm marine life, it is not an immediate threat to turn the ocean into a "giant acid bath." This type of language is misleading and can cause unnecessary panic.
FACT2: It is important to address ocean acidification by reducing carbon emissions and taking steps to protect vulnerable marine ecosystems. Let's work towards a sustainable future for our oceans.

fact_checked_segment: “Sea ice thickness also substantially declined in the latter half of the 20th century, the snow and ice data center said.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is an important change to emphasize because sea ice thickness is also an indicator of sea ice age. While thin sea ice can reform more quickly year to year, thick sea ice requires more time. The loss of thick sea ice is perhaps even more striking than the loss of ice area.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Decline in Sea Ice Thickness
FACT1: The thickness of sea ice has decreased significantly in the latter half of the 20th century.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the fact that sea ice thickness has been declining and take action to reduce our carbon emissions to slow down the rate of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “This article is the result of dozens of interviews and exchanges with climatologists and researchers in related fields”
comment_by_fact-checker: This sentence implies, somehow, that the scientific content of this article comes from these scientists, or that they agree with it. I don’t believe that this is entirely the case—e.g. see Michael Mann’s comments—and, the author should have mentioned that as a caveat here.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Expert Interviews Support Climate Research
FACT1: Expert interviews are a valuable tool for understanding complex scientific topics, such as climate change. By speaking with climatologists and researchers in related fields, journalists and writers can gain a deeper understanding of the science behind climate change and its impacts. These interviews can provide valuable insights into the latest research and help to dispel myths and misconceptions about climate change.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's continue to rely on expert interviews and scientific research to inform our understanding of climate change and its impacts. By staying informed and educated, we can make informed decisions about how to address this critical issue.

fact_checked_segment: “seawater has a large buffering capacity which prevents dramatic shifts in pH;”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is true; however, the amount of CO2 emitted by humans is also massive, a large portion of which has already been absorbed by the oceans. Since pH is relatively insensitive to changes in CO2, it is often not the right parameter to look at in the whole system. For example, over the range of pH values which the author states are found in natural seawater, the surface pCO2 changes from 180 ppm (pH 8.3) to 1500 ppm (pH 7.5). Thus, a mean change in ocean pH of 0.3 pH units represents almost a tripling of seawater pCO2.
label: false authority
debunk:
MYTH: The myth is that seawater has such a large buffering capacity that it cannot be significantly affected by changes in pH.

FALLACY: This is an example of oversimplification, which distorts understanding and leads to erroneous conclusions. While it is true that seawater has a buffering capacity, it is not infinite. The ocean's pH has already decreased by 0.1 units since the Industrial Revolution, which may seem small, but represents a 30% increase in acidity. This has significant impacts on marine life, including the ability of shell-forming organisms to build their shells.

FACT1: Seawater has a buffering capacity that helps to regulate its pH, but this capacity is not infinite and can be overwhelmed by large inputs of acidifying compounds.

FACT2: Let's not underestimate the impact of human activities on the ocean's pH and take action to reduce our carbon emissions and other sources of ocean acidification.

fact_checked_segment: the models predicted seven times as much warming as has been observed
comment_by_fact-checker: The op-ed authors reference the 2017 State of the Climate Report. I helped prepare the “Lower and Mid-Tropospheric Temperature” section and it is unclear where the authors’ statistic comes from (“seven times as much warming…”). The average CMIP5 model warming in the tropical troposphere does outpace observations (by a factor of 1.5 – 3.3, depending on dataset). This issue deserves (and has received) scrutiny.1,2,3,4,5,6 The difference in warming rates between observations and models largely arises in the early 2000s. A number of assessments have concluded that this slowdown in warming in the 2000s is in part due to natural variability (the Earth’s warming was slowed due to climate variability) and forcing (the real world experienced different solar and volcanic aerosol forcing than what was used in the models). Models do simulate natural “hiatus” periods like that experienced in the early 2000s, but, since they are random, they generally do not occur at the same times as in the real world (though some models happened to have a slowdown in warming in the early 2000s). Furthermore, forcing agents (greenhouse gases, aerosols, solar changes) are prescribed to models. Since we do not know the exact evolution of forcing agents for future projections, they are estimated. In this case, the estimated forcing was different than what occurred in the real world. When these issues are taken into account, models and observations are in agreement. Over long periods, when natural variability is a smaller issue, models and observations agree on the rate of warming. Assessments of model projections of climate change show that models have typically been quite skillful (e.g. here). 1- IPCC (2013) Climate Change 2013: The Physical Science Basis (Ch. 9, Box 9.2) 2- Meehl et al (2014) Climate model simulations of the observed early-2000s hiatus of global warming, Nature Climate Change 3- Gleisner et al (2015) Recent global warming hiatus dominated by low‐latitude temperature trends in surface and troposphere data, Geophysical Research Letters 4- Medhaug et al (2017) Reconciling controversies about the ‘global warming hiatus’, Nature 5- Santer et al (2017) Comparing Tropospheric Warming in Climate Models and Satellite Data, Journal of Climate 6- Santer et al (2017b) Causes of differences in model and satellite tropospheric warming
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: The discrepancy between climate model predictions and observations
FACT1: Climate models are complex computer simulations that use mathematical equations to predict future climate conditions based on various factors, such as greenhouse gas emissions and solar radiation. However, these models are not perfect and can have discrepancies between their predictions and actual observations.
MYTH: Climate models have predicted seven times as much warming as has been observed.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, where a small amount of data is selected to support a particular argument while ignoring the larger body of evidence. While it is true that some climate models have overestimated the amount of warming that has occurred, this is not true for all models, and the overall trend still shows a significant increase in global temperatures.
