FACT2: It is important to continue improving climate models and to use them as a tool to inform policy decisions and mitigate the impacts of climate change. Let's not use discrepancies between models and observations as an excuse to ignore the reality of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “over 20 years of almost no change in temperatures”
comment_by_fact-checker: Bastos There has been a slow-down in global mean surface (troposphere) temperatures, but this does not call into question the fact that the Earth-system as a whole is warming. In fact, during the so-called “hiatus”, the net radiation imbalance in the top of the atmosphere persisted (implying that warming would continue even if emissions were to stop). In fact, at the same time that warming in the troposphere stalled, ocean heat content increased, especially in deeper layers: The fact that oceans took more heat from the atmosphere helps to explain the slow-down of warming at the surface. This seems to be, at least partly, explained by natural variability in the ocean (see here). Trenberth* argued, thus, that natural variability in the climate system makes the global mean surface temperature record increase in steps, rather than in a linear way. In another study, Yan and colleagues* analysed the redistribution of heat during the “hiatus” period and concluded that: “[…] the term ‘global warming hiatus’ is a misnomer, although we will continue to use the widely used phrase to describe the slowdown or pause in the increase of GMST in the late 20th to early 21st century, with quotation marks. Alternatively, we would like to suggest to the climate community to use ‘global surface warming slowdown’ instead in the future to avoid confusion. There is no absolute consensus on the specific oceanic sink for the excess heat that led to the slowdown in rising GMST (the Southern Ocean may be worth further attention though), but there is a general agreement in this group and in the literature that rather than a ‘global warming hiatus,’ the slowdown of GMST increase in 1998–2013 was a result of the increased uptake of heat energy by the global ocean during those years.” Trenberth (2015) Has there been a hiatus?, Science Yan et al (2016) The global warming hiatus: Slowdown or redistribution?, Earth’s Future
label: vagueness
debunk:
MYTH: Be wary of claims that suggest that global temperatures have not changed significantly over the past two decades.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, where a small subset of data is selected to support a particular argument while ignoring the larger trend. While it is true that there has been some variability in global temperatures over the past two decades, the overall trend shows a clear increase in temperatures over the long term.

FACT: Global temperatures have been steadily increasing over the past century, with the 10 warmest years on record occurring since 2005. While there may be some short-term variability, the long-term trend is clear: the Earth is getting warmer.

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's focus on the overwhelming scientific evidence that shows that global temperatures are increasing and take action to address this critical issue.

fact_checked_segment: “Next year or the year after that, I think it will be free of ice in summer and by that I mean the central Arctic will be ice-free. You will be able to cross over the north pole by ship. There will still be about a million square kilometres of ice in the Arctic in summer but it will be packed into various nooks and crannies”
comment_by_fact-checker: I would also add that predictions of an ice-free Arctic (also defined as ~1 million square kilometers of remaining ice) are shown to be subject to quite a bit of uncertainty stemming from natural variability – on the order of about two decades.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
Arctic sea ice is melting at an alarming rate, and predictions suggest that the Arctic could be ice-free in summer within a few decades. However, the quote above is a myth that has been taken out of context. The quote is from a 2007 article in The Guardian, in which Dr. Wieslaw Maslowski, a researcher at the Naval Postgraduate School in Monterey, California, was discussing his model's predictions for the future of Arctic sea ice. The quote was not a definitive prediction, but rather a statement about the potential consequences of continued warming. It is important to understand the context of scientific predictions and not take them out of context to support a particular viewpoint. 

FALLACY: Slippery Slope
Dr. Maslowski's quote has been taken out of context and used to support the idea that the Arctic is already ice-free, which is not true. This is an example of the slippery slope fallacy, where a minor action or statement is exaggerated to suggest that it will inevitably lead to major consequences. 

FACT: It is important to understand the context of scientific predictions and not take them out of context to support a particular viewpoint. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: water vapour has been the main greenhouse gas and carbon dioxide has had a minuscule effect on global climate
comment_by_fact-checker: It is true that water vapour is a main greenhouse gas, but the amount of water vapour is also tightly related to temperatures (and should therefore be seen as an enhancing feedback, not a driver). That is, higher CO2 will increase temperatures, which will increase water vapour, which will increase temperatures… To write that “carbon dioxide has had a minuscule effect on global climate” is of course utter nonsense—see other comments.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: The Role of Water Vapor and Carbon Dioxide in Climate Change
FACT1: Both water vapor and carbon dioxide are important greenhouse gases that contribute to the Earth's climate. Water vapor is the most abundant greenhouse gas in the atmosphere, but its concentration is highly variable and short-lived. Carbon dioxide, on the other hand, is a long-lived greenhouse gas that has been increasing in concentration due to human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation.
MYTH: Water vapor is the main greenhouse gas and carbon dioxide has a negligible effect on global climate.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, as it selectively focuses on one aspect of the greenhouse effect while ignoring the role of other greenhouse gases. While water vapor is the most abundant greenhouse gas, its concentration is highly variable and short-lived, meaning that it cannot be responsible for long-term climate change. Carbon dioxide, on the other hand, is a long-lived greenhouse gas that has been increasing in concentration due to human activities, and its warming effect is well-established by scientific research.
FACT2: Understanding the role of both water vapor and carbon dioxide in the Earth's climate is crucial for developing effective strategies to mitigate the impacts of climate change. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and instead educate ourselves on the science of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: Carbon dioxide is a trace gas in the atmosphere.
comment_by_fact-checker: This is the first officially true sentence due to its brevity. The rest of the paragraph shows it is intended to suggest something that is wrong.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
MYTH: Carbon dioxide is a trace gas in the atmosphere.

FALLACY: This is an example of the Red Herring fallacy, which involves diverting attention from the main issue by introducing an irrelevant point. While it is true that carbon dioxide is a trace gas in the atmosphere, this fact is not relevant to the issue of climate change and its causes.

FACT: Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas that plays a significant role in regulating the Earth's temperature. While it only makes up a small fraction of the atmosphere (about 0.04%), it has a powerful warming effect. Human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, have significantly increased the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, leading to global warming and climate change.

FACT2: Let's not use the fact that carbon dioxide is a trace gas as a distraction from the real issue of climate change. Instead, let's focus on reducing our carbon emissions and transitioning to cleaner sources of energy.

fact_checked_segment: “The Alaskan tundra is warming so quickly it has become a net emitter of carbon dioxide ahead of schedule, a new study finds”
comment_by_fact-checker: The study doesn’t really say that. The PNAS study itself focused on 3 years (2012-2014) for which aircraft measurements were taken from April to November, and finds that Alaskan tundra was a source of carbon for 2 of these 3 years (2012 is a small sink). Then these flux estimates are compared to  data from CMIP5 models for those particular years. However,  the PNAS paper does not assess when these CMIP5 models become sources of CO2. One would need to see long time series of the CMIP5 models, along with longer time series of aircraft measurements and inferred carbon fluxes to estimate when each turn from sink to sources.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Alaskan Tundra is a Net Emitter of Carbon Dioxide
FACT1: The Alaskan tundra is warming at an alarming rate, causing it to release more carbon dioxide than it absorbs. This is happening earlier than expected, according to a new study. The tundra is a crucial carbon sink, storing vast amounts of carbon in the soil. However, as temperatures rise, the permafrost thaws, releasing carbon dioxide and methane into the atmosphere.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: The Alaskan tundra is a crucial carbon sink, but it is now releasing more carbon dioxide than it absorbs due to warming temperatures. This is a fact-based observation supported by scientific evidence. The fallacy would be to deny or ignore this evidence and continue to believe that the tundra is not contributing to climate change.

FACT2: Let's take action to reduce our carbon emissions and slow down the rate of global warming. We can do this by reducing our use of fossil fuels, supporting renewable energy, and advocating for policies that address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Entire states and nations have to decide to clean up their energy systems, using every tool available and moving as quickly as they can.”
comment_by_fact-checker: “Using every tool available” is highly debatable, as even tools which are usually perceived to help mitigating climate (e.g. reforestation), may not result in mitigation effects, depending on how they are implemented. A study on European forests* has shown that afforestation since 1750 was responsible for an increase of 0.12 watts per square meter in the radiative imbalance at the top of the atmosphere, rather than a decrease, because of management choices. Naudts et al (2016) Europe’s forest management did not mitigate climate warming, Science
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Urgency for Clean Energy Transition
FACT1: Transitioning to clean energy is an urgent matter that requires immediate action from states and nations. The use of fossil fuels is a major contributor to climate change, which has devastating effects on the environment and human health. Clean energy sources such as wind, solar, and hydropower are readily available and can help reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: The urgency for clean energy transition is often dismissed or delayed due to the misconception that it is too expensive or not feasible. However, the cost of renewable energy has significantly decreased in recent years, making it more affordable than ever before. Additionally, the benefits of transitioning to clean energy far outweigh the costs, as it can create jobs, improve public health, and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

FACT2: Let's prioritize the transition to clean energy by supporting policies and initiatives that promote the use of renewable energy sources. We can also make individual changes such as reducing energy consumption and investing in energy-efficient appliances. By taking action now, we can create a more sustainable future for ourselves and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “Howard Browman, a marine scientist for 35 years, has published a review in the ICES Journal of Marine Science of all the papers published on the subject.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The article that Mr. Delingpole is referring to is not “a review”, but an introduction to a special theme issue on the topic of ocean acidification[…] The introduction does not review all of the nearly 4000 articles on the subject. Rather, it presents an overview of the sub-set of research dealing with biological/ecological effects of ocean acidification.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Marine Scientist Reviews Papers on a Subject
FACT1: Howard Browman, a marine scientist with 35 years of experience, has conducted a review of all the papers published on a particular subject. 
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Conducting reviews of scientific literature is a common practice in the scientific community to ensure that research is up-to-date and accurate. Let's continue to rely on peer-reviewed research to inform our understanding of scientific topics.

fact_checked_segment: “But the new research shows that the amount of oxygen in those shells doesn’t actually remain constant over time.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It’s nothing to do with the amount of Oxygen. It’s CaCO3, so oxygen content is pretty much fixed—it’s the isotopic ratio of the oxygen that is incorporated.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Oxygen levels in shells vary over time
FACT1: The amount of oxygen in shells is not constant over time, contrary to previous assumptions.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: Ambiguity. The previous assumption that the amount of oxygen in shells remains constant over time was based on an incomplete understanding of the process.
FACT2: Understanding the variability of oxygen levels in shells is important for accurately interpreting past climate conditions. Let's continue to update our understanding of scientific processes as new research emerges.

fact_checked_segment: The amount of energy used to construct solar and wind facilities is greater than they produce in their working lives.
comment_by_fact-checker: Numbers for “Energy Return on Investment” (EROI) are all over the place, but a nice summary with references to supporting information was produced for Scientific American by Mason Inman for the April 2013 edition of Scientific American. Mason estimated that wind returns about 20 times the energy input and solar around 6 times their energy input. While these numbers do depend on a range of assumptions, the idea that these ratios are less than one is wrong and not defensible. The construction of wind turbines and solar panels does result in some carbon dioxide emission but far less than would be emitted were that electricity generated using fossil fuels such as coal, gas, or oil. Therefore, if the alternative is fossil fuels, these technologies help avoid carbon dioxide emissions. It should be noted that Energy Return on Investment is likely to increase over time as the economy becomes more efficient and thus economic inputs to the production of energy technologies becomes less energy intensive
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Solar and wind facilities have a positive energy return on investment (EROI), meaning they produce more energy over their lifetime than the energy used to construct them.

MYTH: Solar and wind facilities use more energy to construct than they produce in their working lives.

FALLACY: This myth is based on outdated or inaccurate information. Early studies on the energy payback of renewable energy sources did not take into account improvements in technology and manufacturing processes. Additionally, the energy used to construct renewable energy facilities is typically recouped within a few years of operation, leaving decades of net positive energy production.

FACT2: Renewable energy sources like solar and wind have a positive EROI and are a crucial part of transitioning to a sustainable energy future. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: there has been no systematic increase in the frequency of extreme weather events,
comment_by_fact-checker: This is not as universally true as suggested in this op-ed. Changes in extreme events are difficult to detect and depend on definition and region, but there is evidence for some changes in extreme weather events. For example, evidence is provided for decreases in cold nights, increases in warm days, and increases in heavy precipitation over North America1. 1- IPCC (2013) Climate Change 2013: The Physical Science Basis (Ch. 2, p. 162)
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Extreme Weather Events: Separating Fact from Fiction
FACT1: Extreme weather events have always occurred, but there is no evidence to suggest that their frequency has systematically increased over time.
MYTH: Climate change is causing an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events.
FALLACY: This myth is based on the fallacy of cherry-picking, which involves selectively choosing data that support a particular argument while ignoring other data that contradict it. While some extreme weather events have become more frequent or intense in certain regions, there is no evidence to suggest that this is a global trend.
FACT2: It is important to acknowledge that climate change is still a serious issue that requires urgent action. However, we must also be careful not to spread misinformation about the relationship between climate change and extreme weather events. Let's focus on the facts and work towards finding solutions to mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “In contrast, humans are now emitting about 10 billion tons annually — changing the planet much more rapidly.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is the current rate, but it’s worth pointing out that this rate is the result of exponential growth over the last decades, and that it was “only” 1-2 billion tons in the 50’s, for instance. In drawing the analogy with the PETM, one may also wonder how long the current rates can be sustained – if anything, compared to the 4,000 years of the PETM – given that such emissions are most likely unsustainable over the long-term, either because of fossil fuel availability constraints, or because of the adverse feedback of climate change on human societies.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Human activities are causing rapid climate change
FACT1: Human activities are causing the planet to change much more rapidly than natural processes. In contrast to natural emissions of carbon dioxide, humans are now emitting about 10 billion tons annually. This is causing the Earth's temperature to rise at an unprecedented rate, leading to a range of negative impacts on the environment and human societies.

MYTH: Climate change is a natural process and humans are not responsible for it.

FALLACY: This myth is based on the false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that because climate has changed naturally in the past, what is happening now must be natural. This ignores the overwhelming scientific evidence that human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation, are causing the Earth's temperature to rise at an unprecedented rate. This fallacy also ignores the fact that natural climate change occurs over thousands of years, while the current warming trend is happening in just a few decades.

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's educate ourselves and others about the scientific consensus on climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint. By working together, we can mitigate the worst impacts of climate change and create a more sustainable future for ourselves and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “Global Ocean Circulation Appears To Be Collapsing Due To A Warming Planet”
comment_by_fact-checker: I’m a little hesitant about the title. The slowdown of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation is not the same thing as the “collapse of global ocean circulation”. It might be more accurate to say that the AMOC is at risk of collapsing in a warming world. Also, it’s worth noting that although we understand that there is a connection between AMOC and the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, the mechanisms involved in this connection are still under investigation.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Impact of Global Warming on Ocean Circulation
FACT1: The ocean plays a crucial role in regulating the Earth's climate by distributing heat around the planet. Ocean circulation is driven by differences in temperature and salinity, which create currents that transport heat and nutrients. 
MYTH: Global ocean circulation is collapsing due to a warming planet.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, as it focuses on a single study that suggests a potential weakening of ocean circulation in the North Atlantic, while ignoring the broader picture of ocean circulation patterns around the world. The study in question is also based on computer simulations rather than direct observations, and its findings are still subject to ongoing scientific debate and scrutiny.
FACT2: It is important to continue studying ocean circulation patterns and their potential impacts on the Earth's climate. However, it is premature to conclude that global ocean circulation is collapsing due to a warming planet based on a single study. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and instead rely on peer-reviewed scientific research to inform our understanding of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Using satellite data rather than tide-gauge data that is normally used to measure sea levels allows for more precise estimates of global sea level, since it provides measurements of the open ocean.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This may be a bit of a misrepresentation, as precision is only one part of the story here. The length of the available records is also crucial—hence the need for studies of tide gauge data.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Satellite data provides more precise estimates of global sea level
FACT1: Satellite data is more accurate than tide-gauge data for measuring global sea level because it provides measurements of the open ocean, allowing for more precise estimates.
MYTH: Tide-gauge data is the most accurate way to measure global sea level.
FALLACY: The myth relies on the false assumption that tide-gauge data is the only way to measure sea level. This is a false equivalence fallacy, as it assumes that two methods of measurement are equivalent when they are not. Tide-gauge data is limited to coastal areas and cannot provide measurements of the open ocean, while satellite data can provide a more comprehensive view of sea level changes.
FACT2: Let's use the most accurate and comprehensive data available to measure global sea level and better understand the impacts of climate change on our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “Next year or the year after that, I think it will be free of ice in summer and by that I mean the central Arctic will be ice-free. You will be able to cross over the north pole by ship. There will still be about a million square kilometres of ice in the Arctic in summer but it will be packed into various nooks and crannies”
comment_by_fact-checker: Telegraph, 2011 – “ice free by 2015”; Guardian, 2012 – “ice free by 2015 or 2016”; Financial Times, 2013 – “ice free no later than 2015”.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Arctic sea ice is melting at an alarming rate
FACT1: The Arctic sea ice is melting at an alarming rate due to global warming caused by human activities. The Arctic sea ice has been declining at a rate of 12.8% per decade, and the Arctic could be ice-free in summer by the middle of this century.
MYTH: A paraphrasing of the quote in 30 words or fewer: "The Arctic sea ice will still have about a million square kilometers of ice in summer, but it will be packed into various nooks and crannies."
FALLACY: The quote uses cherry-picking by focusing on the remaining ice in the Arctic, while ignoring the fact that the Arctic sea ice is melting at an alarming rate. This fallacy misleads people into thinking that the melting of the Arctic sea ice is not a significant problem.
FACT2: The Arctic sea ice is melting at an alarming rate due to human activities, and we need to take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions to slow down the melting. Let's take individual actions such as reducing our carbon footprint and supporting policies that address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “‘That isn’t going to sound horribly unmanageable. But remember for the northern hemisphere, for North America, the fact that the location in West Antarctica is where the action is amplifies that rate of sea level rise by up to an about additional 25 percent in a city like Boston or New York.’ That’s because as Antarctica’s mass shrinks, the ice sheet’s gravitational pull on the ocean relaxes somewhat, and the seas travel back across the globe to pile up far away — with U.S. coasts being one prime destination.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This effect is called the gravitational effect, and it is the consequence of one of the basic laws of physics: mass attracts mass. When mass is lost on Antarctica, sea level will fall within a 2,200 km radius due to the loss of gravitational pull. Between 2,200 and 7,600 km, sea level will rise but less than the global average. Beyond 7,600 km, sea level rise will be larger than the global mean, up to 25% extra. For Antarctica, this means that the largest consequences will be in the Northern Hemisphere, with the reverse being true for mass loss in Greenland. The gravitational effect has been known since 18861, was rediscovered in 19762 and again in 20013. It is used in sea-level projections, for instance in the IPCC AR5 report, chapter 13. 1-Woodward (1886) On the form and position of the sea-level as dependent on superficial masses symmetrically disposed with respect to a radius of the Earth’s surface, Annals of Mathematics 2-Farrell and Clark (1976) On Postglacial Sea Level, Geophysical Journal International 3-Mitrovica et al (2001) Recent mass balance of polar ice sheets inferred from patterns of global sea-level change, Nature
label: false cause
debunk: Antarctica's melting ice sheet is causing sea levels to rise, and this rise is amplified in certain areas, such as the US East Coast. As the ice sheet loses mass, its gravitational pull on the ocean weakens, causing the seas to pile up in other areas, including the US. This means that cities like Boston and New York could experience up to an additional 25% increase in sea level rise due to the melting of the West Antarctic ice sheet. This is not a myth, but a fact supported by scientific evidence. It is important to understand the science behind sea level rise and take action to mitigate its effects. Let's not ignore the facts and work towards a sustainable future.

fact_checked_segment: “The melting Greenland ice sheet is already a major contributor to rising sea level and if it was eventually lost entirely, the oceans would rise by six metres around the world, flooding many of the world’s largest cities.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This number [six meters] is quoted in virtually every article published about Greenland (in media and science literature!). It’s really an irrelevant number, and without any context can be very misleading, as it is here. The total loss of the Greenland ice sheet may not happen under any reasonable future scenario, and in any case would take many thousands of years to occur. A more meaningful number would be the current estimate of what the net loss might be by 2100; this could then be given as a percentage of the total ice volume on Greenland, but for the purposes of an article like this, where the reader is thinking about human consequences, quoting the total ice volume will only confuse the issue.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Impact of Melting Greenland Ice Sheet on Sea Level Rise
FACT1: The Greenland ice sheet is melting at an alarming rate, contributing to rising sea levels. If it were to completely melt, it would cause a global sea level rise of about 6 meters.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: This statement is based on scientific evidence and is not a fallacy.
FACT2: It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and slow down the melting of the Greenland ice sheet. Let's work towards a sustainable future to protect our planet and prevent catastrophic sea level rise.

fact_checked_segment: ” ‘and it’s only got to take one sizable volcano to erupt and all the models, everything else, is right off the board’ ”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is completely untrue. In terms of CO2 emissions, all the volcanic eruptions in the world combined put less than 1% of human CO2 emissions into the atmosphere every year. A large volcanic eruption in the tropics can cool the climate significantly for a couple of years (such as Mt Pinatubo in 1991) but climate models capture this extremely well.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Volcanoes can't explain global warming
FACT1: While volcanic eruptions can release large amounts of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, they are not responsible for the current trend of global warming. 
MYTH: Volcanic eruptions can explain the current trend of global warming.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false cause fallacy, which assumes that because two events occur together, one must have caused the other. While volcanic eruptions can contribute to short-term fluctuations in temperature, they do not explain the long-term trend of global warming that has been observed over the past century. 
FACT2: Let's not use volcanic eruptions as an excuse to ignore the overwhelming evidence that human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, are the primary cause of global warming.

fact_checked_segment: it still has not been shown that human emissions of carbon dioxide drive ­global warming.
comment_by_fact-checker: This is so trivially wrong and such old well-established science, that I hope a Wikipedia link is allowed.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Role of Human Emissions in Global Warming
FACT1: Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas that traps heat in the Earth's atmosphere, contributing to global warming. Human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, deforestation, and industrial processes, have significantly increased the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
MYTH: It still has not been shown that human emissions of carbon dioxide drive global warming.
FALLACY: This statement is a form of cherry-picking, where a single piece of information is used to support a broader argument while ignoring the overwhelming evidence that supports the opposite conclusion. The scientific consensus is that human emissions of carbon dioxide are the primary driver of global warming, and this is supported by a vast body of evidence from multiple scientific disciplines.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. The scientific consensus is clear: human emissions of carbon dioxide are driving global warming. It is important to take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The acceleration is making some scientists fear that Antarctica’s ice sheet may have entered the early stages of an unstoppable disintegration.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is true, but referring to West Antarctic ice sheet would be more precise.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Antarctica's Ice Sheet Acceleration
FACT1: Antarctica's ice sheet is experiencing acceleration, which means that it is losing ice at an increasingly faster rate. This acceleration is causing concern among scientists who fear that it may lead to an unstoppable disintegration of the ice sheet.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to continue monitoring and studying Antarctica's ice sheet to better understand the acceleration and its potential consequences. Let's support scientific research and efforts to mitigate climate change to help protect our planet's ice sheets.

fact_checked_segment: “Through decades of research, it has become clear that human civilization, roughly 6,000 years old, developed during an unusually stable period for global sea levels.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The last 6,000 years have been unusually stable for the period of time that we are able to constrain rates of sea-level change particularly well (at sub-millennial timescales): see, for example, Lambeck et al (2014) Sea level and global ice volumes from the Last Glacial Maximum to the Holocene.
label: false analogy
debunk:
FACT1: Human civilization developed during a period of stable global sea levels, which lasted for thousands of years.

MYTH: There is no evidence that sea levels have risen significantly in the past, so current sea level rise must be natural and not caused by human activity.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, as it ignores the fact that sea levels have fluctuated naturally in the past, but have been relatively stable during the period of human civilization. It also ignores the overwhelming scientific evidence that human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation, are causing current sea level rise.

FACT2: Let's not ignore the overwhelming scientific evidence that human activities are causing sea level rise. We should take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and protect vulnerable coastal communities.

fact_checked_segment: Some regions experience more, some less and some no trend. Limitations of data and inconsistencies in patterns prevent confident claims about global trends one way or another.
comment_by_fact-checker: Confidence is often low due to the limited data availability. As also stated by the IPCC, low confidence does not necessarily imply that a link does not exist.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding the Limitations of Climate Data
FACT1: Climate data is complex and can be difficult to interpret. While some regions may experience more warming than others, it is difficult to make confident claims about global trends due to limitations in data and inconsistencies in patterns.
MYTH: Climate change is either happening everywhere or not happening at all.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false choice fallacy, which presents two options as the only possibilities when other possibilities exist. It also ignores the complexities of climate data and the limitations of our ability to interpret it.
FACT2: It is important to acknowledge the limitations of climate data and avoid making overgeneralized claims about global trends. Instead, we should focus on understanding the regional impacts of climate change and work towards finding solutions to mitigate its effects. Let's continue to gather and analyze data to improve our understanding of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Sea level rise is global. But due to a variety of factors – including, for this part of the Atlantic coast, a likely weakening of the Gulf Stream, itself potentially a result of the melting of Greenland’s ice caps – south Floridians are feeling the effects more than many others. While there has been a mean rise of a little more than 3mm per year worldwide since the 1990s, in the last decade, the NOAA Virginia Key tide gauge just south of Miami Beach has measured a 9mm rise annually.”
comment_by_fact-checker: True: Sea-level rise in Florida is the result of a variety of factors. But the influence of a weakening Gulf Stream will be felt more in the northeast of the US than Florida. Furthermore, land level subsidence due to glacial isostatic adjustment is less in Florida than the mid and northeast Atlantic. With respect to melting from Greenland, yes, Florida will feel a greater impact than regions to the North. But the rate of rise will be less than the global average. Focusing on the last decade and one tide gauge could be considered cherry-picking the data. Long-term (>60yrs) tide gauges should be used. Virginia Key has only been operational since 1994. Key West Tide gauge has been operational since 1901 and records a rate of sea-level rise of 2.37 mm/yr.
label: cherry picking
debunk: Sea level rise is not uniform across the globe, and some regions are experiencing more significant impacts than others. In South Florida, factors such as the weakening of the Gulf Stream and the melting of Greenland's ice caps are contributing to a higher rate of sea level rise than the global average. While the worldwide mean rise has been a little over 3mm per year since the 1990s, the NOAA Virginia Key tide gauge just south of Miami Beach has measured a 9mm rise annually in the last decade. It is important to recognize that sea level rise is a complex issue influenced by a variety of factors, and its impacts will vary depending on location. Let's continue to educate ourselves on the causes and effects of sea level rise and work towards finding solutions to mitigate its impacts.

fact_checked_segment: “Climate change might be worse than thought after scientists find major mistake in water temperature readings The sea was much colder than previously thought, the study suggests, indicating that climate change is advancing at an unprecedented rate”
comment_by_fact-checker: This title and subtitle are totally misleading. The question of whether or not some (and I stress some because this only affects one proxy, not the others that suggest warm temperatures) temperature estimates were wrong has no bearing at all on the rate of current climate change.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Study finds major mistake in water temperature readings
FACT1: A recent study has found that there was a major mistake in water temperature readings, indicating that the sea was much colder than previously thought. This mistake has led to an underestimation of the rate at which climate change is advancing.
MYTH: Climate change might be worse than thought due to a major mistake in water temperature readings.
FALLACY: The article uses the fallacy of cherry-picking by focusing on one study that found a mistake in water temperature readings and presenting it as evidence that climate change is worse than previously thought. This ignores the overwhelming evidence from multiple studies and sources that show the significant impact of climate change on our planet.
FACT2: Let's not be misled by cherry-picked studies and instead look at the overwhelming evidence from multiple sources that show the significant impact of climate change on our planet. It is important to take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The arc of global warming will be variously steep and less steep,’ said Richard Seager, a climate scientist at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University. ‘It never stopped.’”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is another important point to make—there will be periods where the Earth warms less quickly (not every year will be a record year) but the heating of the Earth continues.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Global warming never stopped
FACT1: Global warming is a long-term trend of increasing average global temperatures caused by human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation. This trend has not stopped, and the Earth's temperature continues to rise.
MYTH: Global warming stopped at some point.
FALLACY: The myth of global warming stopping is a result of cherry-picking data and focusing on short-term fluctuations in temperature rather than the long-term trend. Climate scientists have consistently shown that the Earth's temperature is increasing due to human activities, and this trend has not stopped.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. It is important to understand that global warming is a real and ongoing phenomenon that requires urgent action to mitigate its impacts.

fact_checked_segment: Globally there’s no clear evidence of trends and patterns in extreme events such as droughts, hurricanes and floods. Some regions experience more, some less and some no trend. Limitations of data and inconsistencies in patterns prevent confident claims about global trends one way or another. There’s no trend in U.S. hurricane landfall frequency or intensity. If anything, the past 50 years has been relatively quiet. There’s no trend in hurricane-related flooding in the U.S. Nor is there evidence of an increase in floods globally. Since 1965, more parts of the U.S. have seen a decrease in flooding than have seen an increase. And from 1940 to today, flood damage as a percentage of GDP has fallen to less than 0.05 per cent per year from about 0.2 per cent.
comment_by_fact-checker: Tropical cyclones are extreme and rare events thus statistically significant changes are difficult to detect especially given the limitations in historical observations before satellite coverage, but overall coastal flooding is becoming much more of a problem under global warming as sea levels rise. This will only get worse in the future.
label: red herring
debunk:
No evidence of increasing extreme weather events
MYTH: Climate change is causing an increase in extreme weather events such as hurricanes, floods, and droughts.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, where only certain data is selected to support a particular argument while ignoring other data that contradicts it. While some regions may experience more extreme weather events, others may experience less or no trend at all. Limitations in data and inconsistencies in patterns prevent confident claims about global trends. Additionally, data shows that there is no trend in hurricane landfall frequency or intensity in the U.S., and flood damage as a percentage of GDP has actually decreased since 1940.
Let's not spread misinformation about extreme weather events and instead rely on comprehensive and accurate data to inform our understanding of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “In fact, all but the one [extinction event] that killed the dinosaurs were caused by climate change produced by greenhouse gas. The most notorious was 252 million years ago; it began when carbon warmed the planet by five degrees, accelerated when that warming triggered the release of methane in the Arctic, and ended with 97 percent of all life on Earth dead.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Other agents of destruction have been invoked for the end Permian extinction, involving toxic fluorine fumes from volcanic emissions or sulfides from the deep sea.
label: post hoc
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change as a Cause of Extinction Events
FACT1: Climate change caused by greenhouse gas emissions has been responsible for most extinction events in Earth's history, including the most notorious one 252 million years ago that wiped out 97% of all life on Earth.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to recognize the significant impact that climate change can have on the planet and its inhabitants. We must take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change to prevent future extinction events. Let's work towards a sustainable future for ourselves and the planet.

fact_checked_segment: “In other words, we have, trapped in Arctic permafrost, twice as much carbon as is currently wrecking the atmosphere of the planet, all of it scheduled to be released at a date that keeps getting moved up, partially in the form of a gas that multiplies its warming power 86 times over.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The author’s facts about methane are generally accurate, but he amps up concern about catastrophic release of methane from permafrost beyond what evidence supports. Scientists also investigate whether methane frozen at the seafloor of some continental shelves can be catastrophically be released to the atmosphere. However, existing evidence suggests that natural processes prevent catastrophe. Marine methane (gas hydrates) are heavily processed in the water column, and no contribution to the atmosphere has yet been observed. See an excellent review by Carolyn Ruppel of the US Geological Survey and John Kessler of the University of Rochester*, which was also summarized in the popular press. Ruppel and Kessler (2017) The interaction of climate change and methane hydrates, Reviews of Geophysics
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The Arctic Permafrost and Carbon Trapped in it
FACT1: The Arctic permafrost contains twice as much carbon as is currently present in the Earth's atmosphere. This carbon is scheduled to be released in the future, and it includes a gas that multiplies its warming power 86 times over. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: This statement is not a fallacy, but it highlights the potential consequences of climate change and the importance of addressing it. The release of carbon from the Arctic permafrost could exacerbate global warming and its impacts, such as sea-level rise, extreme weather events, and loss of biodiversity. 
FACT2: It is crucial to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and limit global warming to prevent the release of carbon from the Arctic permafrost. Let's take individual and collective actions to reduce our carbon footprint and support policies that promote a transition to a low-carbon economy.

fact_checked_segment: “Those who seek to help should keep the bigger picture in mind.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Exactly Mr Lomborg. That’s why focusing on a small component of the story, in an area where many competing forces mask the underlying signal, is such a narrow approach. If one looks at the big picture of climate change, the loss of ice and snow, the increasing high temperature extremes, the already-apparent effects of sea level rise around the globe, the urgency of the problem becomes crystal-clear.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The Importance of Considering the Bigger Picture
FACT1: When trying to help others, it is important to consider the bigger picture. This means taking into account all the relevant factors and potential consequences of our actions, rather than just focusing on one aspect of the situation.
MYTH: N/A
FALLACY: This statement is not a fallacy, but rather a reminder to avoid tunnel vision when trying to help others. Focusing too narrowly on one aspect of a situation can lead to unintended consequences or missed opportunities to make a greater impact.
FACT2: By considering the bigger picture, we can make more informed decisions and take actions that have a greater positive impact on those we seek to help. Let's strive to be mindful of the broader context and potential consequences of our actions.

fact_checked_segment: It is expected the report will focus on required changes to the energy system, rather than forests.
comment_by_fact-checker: This appears to be the motivation for the authors’ statement. I don’t know if it is true that the role of forests will be under-appreciated (in the to-be-released IPCC report)—it would have been useful to get more perspective on this—but it is certainly reasonable to highlight the importance of forests.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Energy System Changes are Key to Addressing Climate Change
FACT1: Addressing climate change requires significant changes to the energy system, including transitioning to renewable energy sources and improving energy efficiency. This is because the energy sector is responsible for a significant portion of global greenhouse gas emissions.
MYTH: The focus of addressing climate change is on forests and land use, rather than the energy system.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false dichotomy, which presents two options as the only possibilities when other options exist. While forests and land use are important in addressing climate change, they are not the only focus. The energy system is a critical area that requires significant changes to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
FACT2: Let's recognize the importance of addressing climate change by making significant changes to the energy system, including transitioning to renewable energy sources and improving energy efficiency.

fact_checked_segment: “One key effect will be albedo feedback”
comment_by_fact-checker: Albedo is one effect, but it is moderated by cloud cover and only is effective during summer (winter gives dark “polar nights”). Other – perhaps equally important – factors involve the effect open sea has on exchange of moisture, the way temperature varies with height, cloud cover …
label: post hoc
debunk:
TITLE: The Importance of Albedo Feedback in Climate Change
FACT1: Albedo feedback is a key factor in climate change. It refers to the way that the reflectivity of the Earth's surface affects the amount of solar radiation that is absorbed by the planet. When the Earth's surface is covered in snow or ice, it reflects more solar radiation back into space, which helps to cool the planet. However, as temperatures rise and ice melts, the Earth's surface becomes less reflective, which means that more solar radiation is absorbed, leading to further warming.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: None.

FACT2: Understanding the role of albedo feedback is crucial for understanding the impacts of climate change and developing effective strategies to mitigate its effects. Let's continue to educate ourselves and others about the importance of albedo feedback in climate change.

fact_checked_segment: But the heads of small island nations, fearful of rising sea levels, had also asked scientists to examine the effects of 2.7 degrees of warming.
comment_by_fact-checker: The UN Report frequently demonstrated that the impacts of climate change (around the world, not just for island nations) are less severe and widespread at 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit compared to 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit. This would have been a useful and easy point to make, given that it was one of the central findings of this report.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Small Island Nations Call for Climate Action
FACT1: Small island nations are concerned about the effects of rising sea levels due to climate change and have asked scientists to examine the effects of 2.7 degrees of warming.
MYTH: N/A
FALLACY: N/A
FACT2: Let's support the efforts of small island nations and take action to address climate change to prevent the devastating effects of rising sea levels.

fact_checked_segment: If warming temperatures brought on by greenhouse gas emissions make wet years less wet and dry years even drier, as scientists anticipate, year-to-year recovery will become more difficult.
comment_by_fact-checker: Climate warming is expected to create intensification of the hydrologic cycle here as well, meaning that heaviest annual rainfall events may become more intense. So, overall—less rain, but the large storms will be even larger and create flash floods.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change Makes Year-to-Year Recovery More Difficult
FACT1: Climate change is expected to make wet years less wet and dry years even drier, which will make it harder to recover from extreme weather events from year to year.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change in order to prevent more extreme weather events and make recovery easier. Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and support policies that address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The particular signature of warming in 2016 was also revealing in another way, Overpeck said, noting that the stratosphere… saw record cold temperatures last year”
comment_by_fact-checker: The troposphere (the lower part of the atmosphere) has also been rapidly warming. A newly updated record from Remote Sensing Systems using data from NASA satellites shows more warming in the troposphere than on the surface since 1979 (when satellite records began):
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Stratosphere saw record cold temperatures in 2016
FACT1: In 2016, the stratosphere experienced record cold temperatures. This is significant because it is the opposite of what is expected during global warming, as the troposphere (the layer of the atmosphere closest to the Earth's surface) warms while the stratosphere cools. This is due to the increase in greenhouse gases trapping heat in the lower atmosphere, causing the upper atmosphere to cool.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Understanding the behavior of the stratosphere during global warming is important for predicting future climate patterns. Let's continue to study and monitor the Earth's atmosphere to better understand the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “And the gist is that when it comes to extreme heat waves in general — heat waves that appear out of the norm in some way, for instance in their intensity, frequency, or duration — while scientists never say individual events are “caused” by climate change, they are getting less and less circumspect about making some connection.”
comment_by_fact-checker: “Climate change” is by definition a shift in the weather statistics, such as the curve that describes the likelihood of temperatures exceeding a certain threshold [see figure below]. The temperature has a statistical character that is close to being bell-shaped (normal distribution), which implies that high temperatures are expected to be more frequent with a global warming – unless the typical range of temperatures (standard deviation) or shape of the curve changes as well. Climate is the typical character outlined by this curve (probability density function) describing the probabilities, whereas weather is each different data point on which this curve is based. When referring to one event – one data point – one talks about weather. Weather is not the same as climate, but they are related: climate is the expected weather. Figure illustrating how a change in climate influences the frequency of extreme heat events: an increase in the average temperature (upper panel) causes a large increase in the probability of extreme hot events; a change in the climate variability (lower panels) can further alter the frequency of extreme events. – adapted from IPCC report (2001)
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Scientists are becoming less circumspect about the connection between extreme heat waves and climate change, but they do not say that individual events are "caused" by climate change.
MYTH: Scientists claim that individual extreme heat waves are "caused" by climate change.
FALLACY: This myth is a straw man fallacy, as it misrepresents the position of scientists. While scientists do not attribute individual events to climate change, they do recognize that climate change is increasing the likelihood and severity of extreme heat waves.
FACT2: Let's not misrepresent the position of scientists. While they do not attribute individual events to climate change, they do recognize the connection between climate change and extreme heat waves.

fact_checked_segment: “While evidence that the earth’s orbital variations impact radiation levels and thus global temperatures does not of course mean that man is not in some way impacting the climate, studies like these highlight that the role man plays on the planet is dwarfed by natural phenomena utterly out of our control.”
comment_by_fact-checker: I’m not sure how they come to this conclusion. The increase in global temperature from the depth of the last glacial (22,000 years ago) to preindustrial times is about 4.5°C. This is less than the warming projected for the end of the century, if we choose to ignore man’s responsibility as the author suggests. Clearly if we do act to limit the warming to 2°C, then the glacial change would be bigger than it, but the timespans involved mean that current climate change is still a happening at a faster rate.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Natural Phenomena Have a Significant Impact on Global Temperatures
FACT1: Natural phenomena, such as the earth's orbital variations, have a significant impact on global temperatures. These variations can impact radiation levels and cause fluctuations in temperature that are beyond human control. 
MYTH: The role of humans in impacting the climate is insignificant compared to natural phenomena. 
FALLACY: This statement is an example of a false dichotomy fallacy, which presents a false choice between two options when other possibilities exist. It is possible for both natural phenomena and human activity to impact the climate. Additionally, this statement is an example of cherry-picking, as it focuses on one aspect of climate change while ignoring the overwhelming evidence that human activity is a significant contributor to global warming. 
FACT2: While natural phenomena do impact global temperatures, human activity is also a significant contributor to climate change. It is important to acknowledge and address the role that humans play in order to mitigate the effects of climate change. Let's work towards reducing our carbon footprint and promoting sustainable practices to protect our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “the WHO measures air pollution by the mean annual concentration of fine suspended particles of less than 2.5 microns in diameter. These are the particles that cause diseases of all sorts and are responsible for most deaths by air pollution. According to the WHO, exposure to particulate matter increases the risk of acute lower respiratory infection, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, heart disease, stroke and lung cancer. The report […] found that the United States was one of the most pollution-free nations in the world.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The particulate matter (PM) discussion is essentially correct. PM is indeed thought to cause far more deaths than any other air pollutant. The United States indeed has lower PM2.5 levels than most other countries, especially when comparing cities. Most of the country outside California attains EPA’s 12 ug/m3 PM2.5 standard. “Most pollution-free” is poorly worded, since of course no populated area is ‘pollution-free’. But yes, PM2.5 levels in urban and rural areas of the United States are lower than those in corresponding areas of many other countries. The article misleads by conflating levels of air pollution with terminology like “most polluting” or “biggest polluters”. Relatively clean air quality in the United States does not negate the fact that we are the world’s second largest emitter of CO2.
label: vagueness
debunk: Air pollution is a serious health concern that can cause a range of diseases and increase the risk of premature death. The World Health Organization (WHO) measures air pollution by the mean annual concentration of fine suspended particles of less than 2.5 microns in diameter, which are responsible for most deaths by air pollution. Exposure to particulate matter increases the risk of acute lower respiratory infection, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, heart disease, stroke, and lung cancer. Contrary to the myth, the WHO has not declared the United States as one of the most pollution-free nations in the world.

fact_checked_segment: it was assumed carbon dioxide had the pivotal role in driving climate change and that the effects of clouds, back-radiation and the sun were trivial.
comment_by_fact-checker: It was not assumed carbon dioxide had a pivotal role, this is calculated using equations based on physics. The effect of clouds… was not assumed, but is a result of equations you get from physics. Here is a 1989 study* that talks about how important clouds are. “Back radiation” is included in all climate models and comes from carbon dioxide, among other gases. The Sun’s activity is included in climate models, although it has been generally cooling if anything over the last 40+ years. Cess et al (1989) Interpretation of Cloud-Climate Feedback as Produced by 14 Atmospheric General Circulation Models, Science
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: The Role of Carbon Dioxide in Climate Change
FACT1: Carbon dioxide is one of several factors that contribute to climate change, but it is not the only one. Other factors include clouds, back-radiation, and the sun. 
MYTH: The myth is that carbon dioxide is the only factor driving climate change, and that the effects of clouds, back-radiation, and the sun are trivial. 
FALLACY: This myth is an example of oversimplification, as it ignores the complexity of the Earth's climate system and the multiple factors that contribute to climate change. It also ignores the scientific consensus that carbon dioxide is a major driver of climate change. 
FACT2: While carbon dioxide is not the only factor driving climate change, it is a significant one. It is important to consider all factors that contribute to climate change in order to fully understand and address the issue. Let's not oversimplify the issue and instead consider the full complexity of the Earth's climate system.

fact_checked_segment: “In the worst-case scenario, this research suggests, the rate of sea-level rise could reach a foot per decade by the 22nd century, about 10 times faster than today.”
comment_by_fact-checker: We published the results of a study in Science Advances last year (Winkelmann et al., 2015; Combustion of available fossil fuel resources sufficient to eliminate the Antarctic Ice Sheet) concluding that in a worst case scenario, sea level could be rising at an average rate of a foot per decade, averaged over the next 1000 years. Our model, however, did not include the mechanical instability of ice sheet cliffs considered by DeConto and Pollard (2016; Contribution of Antarctica to past and future sea-level rise), which could potentially result in sea-level rises of this magnitude. A key word here is ‘could’. More work needs to be done to assess the likelihood of this occurrence, but sea-level rise rates of a foot per decade by year 2100 appear to be a real risk posed by our greenhouse gas emissions.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Alarming rate of sea-level rise predicted by 22nd century
FACT1: Sea levels are projected to rise at an alarming rate of one foot per decade by the 22nd century, which is about 10 times faster than the current rate of sea-level rise.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to take action to mitigate the effects of climate change and reduce greenhouse gas emissions to slow down the rate of sea-level rise. Let's work together to protect our planet and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: Biological, geological and planetary systems are extremely robust. Our evolving dynamic planet has survived sea level changes of hundreds of metres
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a non-sequitur. Just because the physical Earth system still functions after major climatic changes, doesn’t mean that we as humans should not be concerned about its impacts on our civilization.
label: red herring
debunk:
FACT1: The Earth's biological, geological, and planetary systems are highly resilient and have survived significant changes throughout its history.

MYTH: The Earth's systems are fragile and cannot withstand significant changes.

FALLACY: The myth is based on a false assumption that the Earth's systems are delicate and cannot adapt to changes. This fallacy ignores the fact that the Earth has undergone significant changes throughout its history, including ice ages, volcanic eruptions, and meteor impacts, and has still managed to support life.

FACT2: Understanding the resilience of the Earth's systems can help us develop strategies to mitigate the impact of human activities on the planet. Let's continue to study and learn from the Earth's history to ensure a sustainable future.

fact_checked_segment: “Even if we meet the Paris goals of two degrees warming, cities like Karachi and Kolkata will become close to uninhabitable, annually encountering deadly heat waves like those that crippled them in 2015. At four degrees, the deadly European heat wave of 2003, which killed as many as 2,000 people a day, will be a normal summer. At six[…] summer labor of any kind would become impossible in the lower Mississippi Valley, and everybody in the country east of the Rockies would be under more heat stress than anyone, anywhere, in the world today[…].”
comment_by_fact-checker: “At two degrees… at four… at six” What is missing here is a discussion of the probabilities of each target, depending on emission scenarios, etc… It’s fine to discuss high-end scenarios, but mentioning probabilities would add context—without deterring from discussing the extreme risks associated, I believe. In general, the language in this paragraph is dire, but, in my opinion, this is an underappreciated consequence of global warming, and the author does well to highlight it. It’s difficult to extrapolate future impacts from one-time events: the 2003 heatwave killed that many people in Europe because it was so far out from the usual distribution, and populations were poorly prepared. In a warmer future, preparedness and reactivity would arguably be improved, so impacts could be reduced.
label: vagueness
debunk:
Climate change will have severe consequences on human health and well-being, even if we meet the Paris Agreement's goal of limiting warming to two degrees Celsius. At four degrees, deadly heat waves like the ones that hit Karachi and Kolkata in 2015 will become a regular occurrence. At six degrees, it will be impossible to work outside during the summer in the lower Mississippi Valley, and everyone east of the Rockies will experience more heat stress than anyone in the world today. These are just a few examples of the devastating effects of climate change. 

MYTH: Climate change is not a serious threat to human health and well-being.

FALLACY: This myth is a form of denialism, which is the rejection of scientific evidence or established facts. It is a false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that because climate has changed naturally in the past, what is happening now must be natural. This ignores the overwhelming scientific consensus that human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, are causing climate change and its associated impacts.

FACT: Climate change poses a significant threat to human health and well-being, with potentially catastrophic consequences if we do not take action to mitigate it. We must take urgent action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and transition to a low-carbon economy. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and family, but instead, educate ourselves and take action to address this global crisis.

fact_checked_segment: “climate change skeptics and contrarians … have long contended that global warming won’t be all bad, and that plants might help offset any global warming trend.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is not only a skeptic’s argument: the land biosphere does offset part of the warming by taking up 25% of emissions. However, the uncertainty in the durability of this pattern is very large with no clear consensus between earth system models used in the IPCC latest assessment report, see Figure below: From Friedlingstein et al (2014) Uncertainties in CMIP5 Climate Projections due to Carbon Cycle Feedbacks, Journal of Climate
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: Plants can't offset global warming
FACT1: Plants absorb carbon dioxide (CO2) during photosynthesis, which can help reduce the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere. However, this process has limits and cannot fully offset the amount of CO2 emitted by human activities.
MYTH: Plants can offset global warming.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of oversimplification, as it ignores the complex interactions between plants and the environment. While plants can absorb CO2, they also release it through respiration and decay. Additionally, changes in temperature and precipitation patterns can affect plant growth and survival, which can further impact the carbon cycle.
FACT2: Let's not rely on oversimplified solutions to address the complex issue of global warming. Instead, we should focus on reducing greenhouse gas emissions and transitioning to renewable energy sources.

fact_checked_segment: “ ‘Although some researchers doubted the existence of a global warming hiatus because of coverage bias, artificial inconsistency, and a change point analysis of instrumental Ts records,’ a just-published study at Nature.com’s Scientific Reports found, ‘it is now accepted that a recent warming deceleration can be clearly observed.’ ”
comment_by_fact-checker: This article in Scientific American provides context left out by the author on the scientific debate over the warming “hiatus.” By cherry-picking only this line from a single study, the author misrepresents the painstaking process of data analysis and hypothesis testing that led to that conclusion. As the Scientific American article points out, the authors of the study cited by the author were confident in reporting their findings—which do not refute the existence of anthropogenic global warming—because science exists to challenge previous work and is constantly incorporating new information that may alter previous conclusions, a fact which undercuts the author’s claims repeated throughout his article that climate science is a politically-motivated house of cards.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
FACT1: The rate of global warming has slowed down in recent years, but this does not mean that global warming has stopped or is not a serious issue. 

MYTH: Some people believe that the slowdown in the rate of global warming means that it is not happening or is not a significant problem.

FALLACY: This is an example of cherry-picking, where people selectively choose data that supports their argument while ignoring other data that contradicts it. While the rate of warming has slowed down in recent years, the overall trend is still one of warming, and the Earth is still experiencing record-breaking temperatures.

FACT2: Let's not use the slowdown in the rate of global warming as an excuse to ignore the urgent need to address climate change. The evidence is clear that human activities are causing the Earth to warm, and we need to take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and transition to a more sustainable future.

fact_checked_segment: “In the geological past, Earth’s atmosphere had hundreds of times the CO2 content of the modern atmosphere yet there were no carbon dioxide-driven catastrophes. The past shows that climate change is normal, that warmer times and more atmospheric carbon dioxide have driven biodiversity and that cold times kill.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Indeed, climate change is normal, but there are 2 important differences with respect to the geological record: 1) the current rate of increase in CO2 is unprecedented and 2) the current CO2 increase is caused by human emissions.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Normalcy of Climate Change and CO2 Levels in the Past
FACT1: Earth's climate has changed naturally in the past, with fluctuations in temperature and atmospheric CO2 levels. These changes have driven biodiversity and have been a normal part of Earth's history.
MYTH: The belief that because Earth's atmosphere had higher CO2 levels in the past without catastrophic consequences, current increases in CO2 levels are not a cause for concern.
FALLACY: This argument is a false equivalence fallacy, as it assumes that just because Earth's climate has changed naturally in the past, current changes are also natural and not influenced by human activity. It also ignores the fact that the rate of CO2 increase is much faster than in the past, and that the current levels are higher than they have been in millions of years.
FACT2: Let's not use the past as an excuse to ignore the current scientific consensus on climate change. The overwhelming evidence shows that human activity is causing an increase in CO2 levels and driving climate change. It is important to take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Sea level rise is global. But due to a variety of factors – including, for this part of the Atlantic coast, a likely weakening of the Gulf Stream, itself potentially a result of the melting of Greenland’s ice caps – south Floridians are feeling the effects more than many others. While there has been a mean rise of a little more than 3mm per year worldwide since the 1990s, in the last decade, the NOAA Virginia Key tide gauge just south of Miami Beach has measured a 9mm rise annually.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The hypothesis that (a) the Gulf stream has weakened over this time interval and (b) that it is the primary driver of sea level rise acceleration seen farther north along the U.S. Atlantic coast is still debated (see for example, Kopp 2013)*. Kopp (2013) Does the mid-Atlantic United States sea level acceleration hot spot reflect ocean dynamic variability?, Geophysical Research Letters
label: no fallacy
debunk: Sea levels are rising globally, but some regions are experiencing more significant impacts than others. In South Florida, factors such as the weakening of the Gulf Stream and the melting of Greenland's ice caps are contributing to a higher rate of sea level rise than the global average. While the global mean rise has been around 3mm per year since the 1990s, the NOAA Virginia Key tide gauge just south of Miami Beach has measured a rise of 9mm annually in the last decade. This is due to a combination of global and local factors, and it is important to address the issue to mitigate the impacts on vulnerable communities. Let's not ignore the science and take action to address the issue of sea level rise.

fact_checked_segment: “The extreme cycles of dry and wet weather appear to have been intensifying over the last three decades.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Yes, variability in California precipitation appears to have been higher in the past 3-4 decades than the previous decades, but it is not (and cannot be) clear that that the variability in precipitation is actually currently in the act of increasing. I say that it cannot be clear because it takes decades of data (say 2-3) to characterize the current “variability” of the climate. Based on my calculations, variability in annual precipitation totals increased considerably during the second half of the 1900s and then has remained at this relatively high level for the past couple decades, but has not clearly continued to increase. This latest swing from record dry to very wet in the last year is consistent with high variability, but it’s a single event and not necessarily indicative of a trend. There are some logical links, however, that support the inference that wild swings like the current one should be expected to become more likely. First, droughts are becoming increasingly impacted by warming temperatures. Even if precipitation behavior didn’t change at all, years with low precipitation would correspond to less and less water availability for humans and ecosystems. Second, current climate models project variability of California precipitation to increase in the future, with an increase in the frequency of years with very high precipitation totals becoming detectable sometime in the first half of this century, and an increase in the frequency of years with very low precipitation totals becoming detectable in the second half of this century*. It should always be remembered, however, that models have a tough time with California precipitation. California is right on the boundary between projections of drying to the south and wetting to the north. I personally believe the basic expectation that California precipitation should become more variable, but beyond that I don’t yet put much stock in what models have to say about the future of precipitation in California. So, variability has increased overall in the last century, and this is consistent with what models project to occur as a result of greenhouse-gas driven climate change. The increase in variability hasn’t been a monotonic trend, however, and it is not obvious from the data that the trend is continuing now as rapidly as it was in previous decades. This suggests that other low-frequency processes are also at play that influence decade-to-decade changes in the variability and magnitude of annual precipitation totals, making it particularly difficult to determine the degree to which this current event can be attributed to climate change. Nonetheless, California would be wise to prepare for more events like these. Berg and Hall (2015) Increased Interannual Precipitation Extremes over California under Climate Change, Journal of Climate
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Intensifying Cycles of Dry and Wet Weather
FACT1: Over the last three decades, there has been an intensification of cycles of dry and wet weather. This means that periods of drought and heavy rainfall have become more extreme and frequent in some regions.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to recognize the intensification of cycles of dry and wet weather in order to better prepare for and mitigate the impacts of extreme weather events. Let's take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to the changing climate.

fact_checked_segment: “But recent examples from other regions, like the rapidly collapsing Larsen B ice shelf on the Antarctic Peninsula, show that once ice shelves break apart as a result of warming, their parent glaciers start to flow faster toward the sea, an effect that can weaken the stability of ice further inland, too.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Regarding ice shelf stability, it is important to acknowledge (which the author didn’t do here) there are different processes at work on the Antarctic Peninsula, where the Larsen ice shelves reside(d), than on the Amundsen coast (Pine Island and Thwaites ice shelves). The Larsen A and B ice shelves were very thin, and have disintegrated from percolating surface meltwater (hydrofracturing) creating vertical cracks in the ice shelf. Larsen C is thicker and larger, but is also characterised by a relatively warm climate (many melt episodes in summer) and low snowfall (which makes it vulnerable to atmospheric warming). The ice shelves that buttress the Pine Island and Thwaites glaciers are much thicker, annual snowfall rates are very large, and surface melt rates are substantially lower than on the (former) Larsen ice shelves (3-5 times lower). Therefore, it is highly unlikely that surface-based ice shelf instability will occur within the next few decades—instead, these ice shelves would likely thin through contact with warmer oc
label: post hoc
debunk: Melting ice shelves can have a cascading effect on the stability of ice further inland. This is supported by examples such as the Larsen B ice shelf on the Antarctic Peninsula, which collapsed due to warming temperatures. Once an ice shelf breaks apart, the parent glaciers can start to flow faster towards the sea, which can further weaken the stability of ice further inland. This can lead to a rise in sea levels and other negative consequences. Let's continue to monitor and address the impacts of climate change on our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “[CO2] is also a greenhouse gas which helps maintain earth at a habitable temperature.”
comment_by_fact-checker: While the presence of CO2 has warmed the atmosphere to “habitable” temperatures, the additional increase of it will bring temperatures way outside habitable ranges in many regions including the oceans, as well as disturbing the water cycle and acidifying the oceans.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
