fact_checked_segment: “Noaa considers these floods extreme because, based on historical rainfall records, they should be expected to occur only once every 500 years.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This means that such a flood is expected to have a 1 in 500 chance of happening in any given year. It does not imply that such event occurs regularly every 500 years though. That statistic would hold if the climate were not warming. Since warming is occurring, and the amount of moisture in the air is increasing, the odds of getting these floods are getting larger/more likely.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Extreme floods are rare events
FACT1: Extreme floods are rare events that occur once every few hundred years, based on historical rainfall records. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's appreciate the severity of extreme floods and take necessary measures to prepare for them.

fact_checked_segment: “‘Arctic ice conditions have been tracking at record low conditions since October, persisting for six consecutive months’”
comment_by_fact-checker: Timothy Osborn, Professor, University of East Anglia, and Director of Research, Climatic Research Unit: Yes, this is supported by the observations, available at the NSIDC website.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Arctic ice conditions have been at record low levels for six consecutive months since October.

MYTH: None mentioned.

FALLACY: None mentioned.

FACT2: The Arctic ice is melting at an alarming rate, and this is a clear indication of the impact of climate change. We need to take immediate action to reduce our carbon footprint and adopt sustainable practices to mitigate the effects of climate change. Let's not ignore the facts and work towards a better future for ourselves and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: The buoy temperatures, which are measured by precise electronic thermistors, were adjusted upwards to match the questionable ship data. Given that the buoy network became more extensive during the pause, that’s guaranteed to put some artificial warming in the data.
comment_by_fact-checker: The direction of this adjustment does not affect the trends. This has been repeatedly checked and is well known. While the article says “that’s guaranteed to put some artificial warming in the data”, it’s actually guaranteed not to do that. Because mathematics.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Adjusting buoy temperatures does not create artificial warming
FACT1: Adjusting buoy temperatures is a common practice in scientific research to correct for known biases and errors in the data. It is done to ensure that the data accurately reflects the true temperature of the ocean.
MYTH: Adjusting buoy temperatures creates artificial warming in the data.
FALLACY: The myth is based on a misunderstanding of the purpose of adjusting buoy temperatures. The adjustments are made to correct for known biases and errors in the data, not to create artificial warming. The adjustments are based on sound scientific principles and are subject to rigorous peer review.
FACT2: Let's trust the scientific process and the experts who are working to ensure that the data accurately reflects the true temperature of the ocean. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: a study that totally debunks the whole concept of man-made Global Warming,
comment_by_fact-checker: This study does no such thing. This is factually inaccurate.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: No Study Can Debunk the Reality of Man-Made Global Warming
FACT1: The overwhelming scientific consensus is that human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation, are causing global temperatures to rise at an unprecedented rate. This is supported by extensive research and data from multiple sources, including ice cores, tree rings, and satellite measurements.
MYTH: A study has been conducted that completely disproves the idea of man-made global warming.
FALLACY: This myth is based on the fallacy of cherry-picking, where a single study is used to dismiss the overwhelming body of evidence that supports the reality of man-made global warming. It also ignores the fact that scientific consensus is not based on a single study, but on the collective findings of thousands of studies conducted by experts in the field.
FACT2: Let's rely on the overwhelming scientific consensus and continue to take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: Instrumental temperature measurements over the past 150 years show no correlation between human emissions of CO2 and ­temperature.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Instrumental temperature measurements over the last 150 years record weather/climate that is influenced by more than ONLY CO2. Natural variation must also be considered, including semi- to multi-decadal processes involving the ocean and atmosphere (e.g. El Niño-Southern Oscillation)
label: no fallacy
debunk:
MYTH: Human emissions of CO2 have no correlation with temperature, as shown by instrumental temperature measurements over the past 150 years.

FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, as it selectively focuses on a narrow time frame and ignores the broader context of climate change. It also ignores the fact that there is a strong correlation between CO2 emissions and temperature when looking at longer time scales and other lines of evidence, such as ice cores and paleoclimate data.

FACT: The overwhelming scientific consensus is that human activities, including the burning of fossil fuels, are the primary cause of the observed warming of the Earth's climate over the past century. This is supported by multiple lines of evidence, including temperature records, ice core data, and computer models. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has stated that it is extremely likely (95-100% probability) that human activities have been the dominant cause of global warming since the mid-20th century.

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's educate ourselves and others on the overwhelming evidence for human-caused climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: can today’s climate models be trusted when scientists have misrepresented the data in the past?
comment_by_fact-checker: A strangely (deliberately?) vague swipe at climate science. The author presents no evidence that scientists have intentionally misrepresented “the data” in the past, or which data this refers to (either here, or later in the article).
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Trusting Climate Models: Separating Fact from Fiction
FACT1: Climate models are based on fundamental physics and chemistry principles, and they have been developed and refined over decades by thousands of scientists worldwide. These models are used to simulate the Earth's climate system and make predictions about future climate change.
MYTH: Climate models cannot be trusted because scientists have misrepresented data in the past.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of the "Misrepresentation" fallacy, which involves misrepresenting a situation or an opponent's position in such a way as to distort understanding. While there have been instances of scientific misconduct in the past, these are rare and do not invalidate the vast body of scientific evidence supporting the reality of human-caused climate change.
FACT2: Climate models are constantly being tested and refined, and they have been shown to accurately reproduce past climate changes. While no model is perfect, they provide valuable insights into the complex workings of the Earth's climate system and help us make informed decisions about how to mitigate and adapt to climate change. Let's trust the scientific process and continue to support research that helps us better understand our changing climate.

fact_checked_segment: “the climate models have overestimated the amount of global warming and failed to predict what climatologists call the warming ‘hiatus’”
comment_by_fact-checker: Except that the report (the paper published in Nature Geoscience) never said that. The paper does not describe modelled warming vs. observations over the “hiatus” period.
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: The Warming Hiatus is Not Evidence Against Climate Change
FACT1: The warming hiatus refers to a period from 1998 to 2012 where the rate of global surface temperature increase slowed down, but it did not stop. This period was still warmer than any previous decade on record, and the oceans continued to warm. The warming hiatus does not disprove the existence of climate change or the role of human activities in causing it.
MYTH: The climate models have overestimated the amount of global warming and failed to predict what climatologists call the warming ‘hiatus’.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, where a small period of time is used to draw conclusions about long-term trends. The warming hiatus was caused by natural climate variability, such as changes in ocean currents and volcanic activity, and does not contradict the long-term warming trend caused by human activities. Climate models are not perfect, but they have accurately predicted many aspects of climate change, including the overall warming trend.
FACT2: Let's not use the warming hiatus as evidence against climate change. Instead, we should focus on the overwhelming evidence that shows that climate change is happening and that human activities are the primary cause.

fact_checked_segment: A well-known statistical distribution derived from modeling studies summarizes the uncertainties in this method. It shows that ECS is probably between two and 4.5 degrees, possibly as low as 1.5 but not lower, and possibly as high as nine degrees.
comment_by_fact-checker: Uncertainty is not our friend. The fact that the different methods and studies do not fully agree should not be taken as an argument to pick one particular number that one happens to like and discard all the other evidence. As an analogy, when suddenly fog appears on a narrow windy road and the obstacles are hard to see, the normal reaction would be to slow down to be on the safe side, not to accelerate. Greater uncertainty in future warming should be an argument to prepare for the worst case, not to hope for the unlikely case that the impacts will be benign.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The range of estimates for climate sensitivity is wide, but not infinite.

FACT1: Climate sensitivity is a measure of how much the Earth's temperature will increase in response to a doubling of atmospheric carbon dioxide. The range of estimates for climate sensitivity is between 1.5 and 9 degrees Celsius, with the most likely range being between 2 and 4.5 degrees Celsius.

MYTH: There is no consensus on climate sensitivity, and it could be much lower or higher than current estimates.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of the "Bulk Fake Experts" fallacy, which cites a large number of supposed experts to argue that there is no scientific consensus on a topic. While there is some uncertainty in the exact value of climate sensitivity, the vast majority of climate scientists agree that it is likely to be within the range of 1.5 to 4.5 degrees Celsius.

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about climate sensitivity. While there is some uncertainty in the exact value, the scientific consensus is clear that it is likely to be within a certain range. It is important to continue studying and understanding climate sensitivity in order to better predict and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The acceleration is making some scientists fear that Antarctica’s ice sheet may have entered the early stages of an unstoppable disintegration.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is clear that ongoing warming of the climate will pose major risks to the stability of ice sheets. However, this statement seems to have moved the story up a notch from what is actually written later in the article. There are two aspects to this: (1) the size of the area of concern (the whole of Antarctica rather than just parts), and (2) whether irreversible loss has already begun, as opposed to being an imminent risk. The article describes legitimate concerns that parts of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet are becoming vulnerable and hence may soon be at risk of starting an “unstoppable disintegration”, but the suggestion that this is actually already happening (and hence that major Antarctic ice loss is now avoidable) is far more speculative—as indeed the later parts of the article make clear. The phrase “entered the early stages of an unstoppable disintegration” is not the same as “becoming vulnerable to an unstoppable disintegration”, but the latter phrase would better represent what is said later in the article.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Antarctica's Ice Sheet Acceleration
FACT1: Antarctica's ice sheet is experiencing acceleration, which means that it is losing ice at an increasingly faster rate. This acceleration is causing concern among scientists who fear that it may lead to an unstoppable disintegration of the ice sheet.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to continue monitoring and studying Antarctica's ice sheet to better understand the acceleration and its potential consequences. Let's support scientific research and efforts to mitigate climate change to help protect our planet's ice sheets.

fact_checked_segment: “Consider a rigorous study published last year in the journal Lancet that examined temperature-related mortality around the globe.”
comment_by_fact-checker: As the first author of this article, I deem it is worth pointing out that the aim of this study is to establish the association between non-optimal temperature and mortality (in terms of excess deaths) in the recent past, using historical data. The article clearly acknowledges that these results cannot be easily extrapolated to the future, in particular under climate change scenarios, for a series of reasons detailed in the discussion section of the article. For instance, the change in heat and cold-related deaths will depend on changes in future temperature distribution, which is likely to be more complex than a simple upward shift.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Lancet study finds link between temperature and mortality
FACT1: A study published in the Lancet found that there is a link between temperature and mortality rates around the world. The study was rigorous and examined data from multiple countries and regions.
MYTH: None mentioned.
FALLACY: None mentioned.
FACT2: It is important to understand the impact of temperature on mortality rates in order to better prepare for and prevent negative health outcomes. Let's continue to support and conduct rigorous scientific research to better understand the effects of climate change on human health.

fact_checked_segment: “Ice-free means the central basin of the Arctic will be ice-free and I think that that is going to happen in summer 2017 or 2018.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is not clear whether a permanent or a one-year phenomenon is meant here (probably the former), but in any case the scientific support for the claim is weak. In the former case (permanent disappearance), this would not correspond to what most sea ice experts do consider. Indeed, section 11.3.4.1 of the last (2013) IPCC assessment report suggests a very low probability for permanent disappearance within the current decade. In fact, from the scientific literature it seems the phenomenon is more likely to take place during the period 2040-2060. Of course, a very low probability does not necessarily mean a zero probability, and IPCC’s report could possibly underestimate the odds for disappearance within the next few years. But before propagating a marginal view (relative to IPCC conclusions), one should ensure having a very strong argumentation; in this interview no argumentation is put forward to support Peter Wadhams’ central claim. In the other possible case (isolated single-year disappearance), it has to be said sea ice has strong year-to-year variability superimposed on its long-term declining trend, and no one has the tools to precisely predict the outcome one year in advance. Seasonal-to-decadal prediction groups equipped with physically-based models have some potential prediction skill for lead times up to 12-24 months, but they currently cannot guarantee to be right for any specific forecast (e.g.: Seasonal Forecasts of the Pan-Arctic Sea Ice Extent Using a GCM-Based Seasonal Prediction System and Pan-Arctic and Regional Sea Ice Predictability: Initialization Month Dependence). So, if it turns out in 2017 or 2018 that Wadhams was right, it will have been luck more than justified certainty.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Arctic Sea Ice Melting
FACT1: Arctic sea ice is melting at an alarming rate due to global warming caused by human activities. The Arctic sea ice has been declining at a rate of 12.8% per decade since 1979, and the minimum extent of sea ice in the Arctic has decreased by 13.3% per decade.
MYTH: The central basin of the Arctic will be ice-free in summer 2017 or 2018.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of the slippery slope fallacy, which suggests that taking a minor action will inevitably lead to major consequences. The prediction of an ice-free Arctic in 2017 or 2018 is not supported by scientific evidence and is based on a single observation of a low ice extent in 2012. It is important to note that the Arctic sea ice extent varies from year to year due to natural variability and weather patterns.
FACT2: The Arctic sea ice is melting at an alarming rate due to human activities, and this has serious consequences for the global climate system. We need to take immediate action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and slow down the rate of Arctic sea ice melting. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and family, and instead, educate them about the importance of taking action to address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Yet, a new study of 60 climate models and scenarios shows this warning fails to take into account the fact that global warming will mean precipitation increases. Indeed, water flow will actually increase over this century, which is likely beneficial in increasing “water availability in the Indus Basin irrigation scheme during the spring growing seasons.” ”
comment_by_fact-checker: The cited study states that runoff in the Indus basin will increase during the first half of the 21st century, mainly due to increasing glacier melt (not precipitation increase as mentioned here). This increase in flow from glacier melt is projected to decrease during the 2nd half of the 21st century (Immerzeel et al, 2013: Rising river flows throughout the twenty-first century in two Himalayan glacierized watersheds). … Besides, an increase in frequency and magnitude of hydrological extremes (flooding events) is projected. [read more]
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: Global warming will increase water flow in some regions
FACT1: Global warming is expected to increase precipitation in some regions, leading to increased water flow. This is supported by a study of 60 climate models and scenarios.
MYTH: The warning that global warming will lead to water scarcity is not accurate.
FALLACY: The myth is based on a false dichotomy, assuming that global warming will either lead to water scarcity or abundance, when in fact the impact will vary by region. This oversimplification ignores the complex and varied effects of global warming on precipitation and water availability.
FACT2: It is important to consider the regional impacts of global warming on water availability, rather than assuming a one-size-fits-all approach. Let's not oversimplify the issue and instead focus on understanding the complex and varied impacts of global warming on water resources.

fact_checked_segment: “Using paleoclimatic data, studies suggest sea ice is shrinking to levels not seen in thousands of years.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The relevant assessment from the latest IPCC report (Chapter 5 Information from Paleoclimate Archives) is: “There is medium confidence from reconstructions that the current (1980–2012) summer sea ice retreat was unprecedented and sea surface temperatures in the Arctic were anomalously high in the perspective of at least the last 1450 years. Lower than late 20th century summer Arctic sea ice cover is reconstructed and simulated for the period between 8000 and 6500 years ago in response to orbital forcing.”
label: cherry picking
debunk:
FACT1: Sea ice is shrinking to levels not seen in thousands of years, according to studies that use paleoclimatic data. 

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: None.

FACT2: Let's acknowledge the scientific evidence and take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions to slow down the rate of sea ice loss and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: El Niño is characterized by a warming of the surface waters in the tropical Pacific Ocean
comment_by_fact-checker: This should be “in the central and eastern-central equatorial Pacific”.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: El Niño: A Warming of Tropical Pacific Waters
FACT1: El Niño is a climate pattern that occurs when the surface waters in the tropical Pacific Ocean become unusually warm. This warming can have significant impacts on weather patterns around the world, including droughts, floods, and changes in temperature.
MYTH: El Niño is a myth or a hoax.
FALLACY: The myth that El Niño is a hoax is an example of a lack of understanding of the science behind the climate pattern. El Niño is a well-documented and studied phenomenon that has been observed for centuries. The warming of the tropical Pacific waters is caused by changes in ocean currents and atmospheric pressure, and has significant impacts on global weather patterns.
FACT2: Understanding the science behind El Niño is important for predicting and preparing for its impacts. Let's not dismiss this well-documented climate pattern as a myth or a hoax.

fact_checked_segment: “global warming will make the world much greener – by the end of the century, it is likely that global biomass will have increased by forty percent.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is an inaccurate description of the science. The future of global biomass and the land carbon sink is highly uncertain and spans anywhere from a large increase to a large loss of biomass. The paper cited is wildly out of date (from 2001) and models have progressed immensely since then. Furthermore, there is growing evidence that even these more recent models are over-optimistic (e.g. Allen et al 2015)
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Global warming and the greening of the world
FACT1: Climate change is causing changes in vegetation patterns around the world. As temperatures rise, some areas are becoming more arid, while others are experiencing more rainfall. This is leading to changes in the distribution and abundance of plant species, and in some cases, an increase in overall biomass.
MYTH: Global warming will make the world much greener.
FALLACY: This myth is an oversimplification of the complex relationship between climate change and vegetation patterns. While some areas may experience an increase in biomass, others will become more arid and experience a decline in vegetation. Additionally, the increase in biomass may not necessarily be a positive thing, as it could lead to the growth of invasive species and other ecological imbalances.
FACT2: It is important to recognize the complex and varied impacts of climate change on vegetation patterns around the world. Rather than assuming that global warming will simply make the world greener, we should work to understand the specific impacts of climate change on different ecosystems and take action to mitigate its negative effects. Let's work towards a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between climate change and vegetation patterns.

fact_checked_segment: “While transient weather variability is playing a key role here, the widespread record warmth across the U.S. so far this year is part of a long-term trend toward more warm temperature records versus cold ones.”
comment_by_fact-checker: I agree that the year-to-year natural variability can contribute significantly to extreme temperatures, especially at local or regional scales. The disproportionate number of record highs versus record lows over several years-to-decades suggests that the seasonal temperature distributions (or likelihoods of experiencing a given extreme during any given season) are shifting toward warmer temperatures consistent with long-term anthropogenic global warming. How continued warming affects the tails of the distributions (beyond just shifting the location) is an interesting and open question.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Record Warmth in the US: A Long-Term Trend
FACT1: The US has experienced widespread record warmth this year, which is part of a long-term trend towards more warm temperature records than cold ones. This trend is due to a combination of transient weather variability and climate change.
MYTH: The US is not experiencing record warmth, and if it is, it is just due to transient weather variability.
FALLACY: The myth is based on cherry-picking data and ignoring the long-term trend towards more warm temperature records. It also relies on the false dichotomy that weather variability and climate change are mutually exclusive, when in fact they are both contributing factors to the trend.
FACT2: Let's not ignore the long-term trend towards more warm temperature records in the US. It is important to recognize the role of both weather variability and climate change in this trend and take action to mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “enough credible projections have been done to put together a range of scenarios that researchers are confident about”
comment_by_fact-checker: Many projections have been done, but they may very well underestimate the true expected range of scenarios.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Confidence in Climate Projections
FACT1: Climate scientists have conducted numerous projections to understand how the Earth's climate will change in the future. These projections are based on a range of scenarios that take into account different levels of greenhouse gas emissions, economic development, and technological advancements. 
MYTH: There is not enough evidence to support climate projections, and they are not reliable.
FALLACY: This myth is based on the false assumption that climate projections are based on limited or unreliable data. In reality, climate projections are based on a wealth of scientific evidence, including observations of past climate changes, physical laws governing the behavior of the atmosphere and oceans, and sophisticated computer models that simulate the Earth's climate system. 
FACT2: It is important to trust the scientific consensus on climate change and take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Let's work together to create a sustainable future for ourselves and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “Typically, in such an attribution study, scientists will use sets of climate models — one set including the factors that drive human global warming and the other including purely “natural” factors — and see if an event like the one in question is more likely to occur in the first set of models. Researchers are getting better and better at performing these kinds of studies fast, in near real time.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is an accurate description of how extreme event attribution studies are conducted.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Scientists use climate models to determine the likelihood of extreme weather events occurring due to human-caused global warming.
MYTH: Climate models are unreliable and cannot accurately predict extreme weather events.
FALLACY: The myth is based on a misunderstanding of the purpose and limitations of climate models. Climate models are not perfect, but they are the best tools we have for predicting future climate conditions. They are constantly being improved and refined based on new data and scientific understanding. While they cannot predict specific weather events, they can provide valuable information about the likelihood of extreme weather events occurring under different climate scenarios.
FACT2: Let's trust the scientific consensus on climate change and support efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to mitigate the impacts of global warming.

fact_checked_segment: “The new research showed that [oxygen isotopes in foraminifera] can change”
comment_by_fact-checker: There is not enough information here. This research specifically only showed that they could change when heated to 300˚C. By not saying what the circumstances are under which the temperature estimates can be altered, the article throws undue doubt on what is in most settings (despite what the authors of the study seem to be suggesting) pretty robust.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Oxygen isotopes in foraminifera can change
FACT1: Foraminifera are tiny marine organisms that have been used to study past climate conditions. Scientists can analyze the oxygen isotopes in their shells to learn about changes in temperature and ocean chemistry. Recent research has shown that these isotopes can change over time, which has important implications for understanding past climate conditions. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Understanding how oxygen isotopes in foraminifera can change over time is crucial for accurately interpreting past climate conditions. Let's continue to support scientific research that helps us better understand our planet's history.

fact_checked_segment: “So it’s been a surprise to climate scientists that 2017 has been so remarkably warm — because the last El Niño ended a year ago.”
comment_by_fact-checker: 2016 would most likely also have been a record warm year without El Niño. Given the long-term warming trend due to global warming, it was to be expected that 2017 would also be warm.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: El Niño is not the only factor affecting global temperatures
FACT1: El Niño is a natural climate pattern that occurs every few years, characterized by warmer-than-average sea surface temperatures in the Pacific Ocean. It can have a significant impact on global temperatures, but it is not the only factor affecting them. Other factors include greenhouse gas emissions, solar activity, and volcanic eruptions.
MYTH: El Niño is the only reason for the recent warm temperatures.
FALLACY: This statement is an oversimplification, as it implies that El Niño is the sole cause of the recent warm temperatures. In reality, while El Niño can have a significant impact on global temperatures, it is just one of many factors that contribute to climate variability. Focusing solely on El Niño ignores the role of other factors, such as human-caused greenhouse gas emissions, in driving long-term warming trends.
FACT2: Let's not overlook the role of human-caused greenhouse gas emissions in driving long-term warming trends. It is important to recognize the complexity of climate variability and the multiple factors that contribute to it.

fact_checked_segment: “Although the extent of the summer sea ice after 2006 dropped abruptly to levels not expected until 2050, the predicted 67-per-cent decline in polar bear numbers simply didn’t happen. Rather, global polar bear numbers have been stable or slightly improved.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is nonsense. No polar bear scientist has predicted a drop in polar bear abundance based on summer sea ice. We base the assessment of loss on duration of the ice-free period. Papers1,2 from our research group assess this point. The statement about global polar bear numbers is absolutely unfounded. It is a contrived statement using population estimates provided so that children (or the general public) could give a number of polar bears in the world for school reports and the like. Castro de la Guarida1 states, “Sea ice across the Arctic is declining and altering physical characteristics of marine ecosystems. Polar bears (Ursus maritimus) have been identified as vulnerable to changes in sea ice conditions. We use sea ice projections for the Canadian Arctic Archipelago from 2006 – 2100 to gain insight into the conservation challenges for polar bears with respect to habitat loss using metrics developed from polar bear energetics modeling. PRINCIPAL FINDINGS: Shifts away from multiyear ice to annual ice cover throughout the region, as well as lengthening ice-free periods, may become critical for polar bears before the end of the 21st century with projected warming. Each polar bear population in the Archipelago may undergo 2-5 months of ice-free conditions, where no such conditions exist presently. We identify spatially and temporally explicit ice-free periods that extend beyond what polar bears require for nutritional and reproductive demands. CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE: Under business-as-usual climate projections, polar bears may face starvation and reproductive failure across the entire Archipelago by the year 2100.” Both of these studies1,2 assess the threat to polar bears based on projected sea ice loss over the next 3 generations (ca. 33-45 years). It is an issue of fasting duration that causes polar bear population declines and this is well understood in the published literature. Dr. Crockford is following the standard climate change denier approach of picking on a specific detail and then contriving an unsubstantiated fictional account on that point. Loss of sea ice in summer is, by and large, irrelevant. It’s the duration of the ice-free period that matters. If not, polar bears in Hudson Bay would have disappeared hundreds or thousands of years ago but they didn’t because they used to be able to obtain sufficient fat stores while hunting seals on the sea ice in spring. The situation is changing but the best estimate is that we’ll have significant declines in the Western Hudson Bay population (beyond the current ca. 30% decline) by mid-century. By repeating it often enough, it appears that deniers or the uninformed think there’s some merit to the issue Dr. Crockford has raised. Nobody can scientifically rebut the flawed thesis because it isn’t published. My understanding was that the manuscript was rejected by scientific journals so now Dr. Crockford’s manuscript languishes as an unreviewed “Preprint” in PeerJ and she erroneously calls it a “paper”. 1- Castro de la Guardia et al (2013) Future sea ice conditions in western Hudson Bay and consequences for polar bears in the 21st century, Global Change Biology 2- Regehr et al (2016) Conservation status of polar bears (Ursus maritimus) in relation to projected sea-ice declines, Biology Letters
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Global polar bear populations have remained stable or slightly improved, despite a significant decline in summer sea ice after 2006.
MYTH: The decline in summer sea ice has caused a 67% decline in polar bear populations.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, where one piece of information is selected to support a particular argument while ignoring other relevant information. While it is true that summer sea ice has declined significantly, it is not true that polar bear populations have declined by 67%. In fact, global polar bear populations have remained stable or slightly improved, which suggests that polar bears may be adapting to changing environmental conditions.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about polar bear populations. While summer sea ice has declined, global polar bear populations have remained stable or slightly improved.

fact_checked_segment: “Venus, which was once a very Earth-like planet with plenty of life-supporting water before runaway climate change rapidly transformed it into an arid and uninhabitable sphere enveloped in an unbreathable gas”
comment_by_fact-checker: There’s been a lot written about this recently, following the BBC’s publicising of Stephen Hawking’s remarks on it.  I don’t think it is accurate to say that Venus was “once a very Earth-like planet” and hence imply that the runaway greenhouse effect could happen here. For one thing, Venus is much closer to the sun. A runaway greenhouse effect on Earth is not thought to be a plausible threat.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Venus: A Planet Transformed by Runaway Climate Change
FACT1: Venus was once a planet with a similar environment to Earth, with water and a habitable climate. However, due to a runaway greenhouse effect, the planet's climate rapidly changed, causing the water to evaporate and the atmosphere to become thick with carbon dioxide, making it uninhabitable.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: This statement is not a fallacy, but it highlights the dangers of a runaway greenhouse effect, which can occur when a planet's atmosphere traps too much heat, causing temperatures to rise and leading to a positive feedback loop that further increases temperatures. This can cause a planet's climate to rapidly change, making it uninhabitable.

FACT2: It is important to understand the dangers of a runaway greenhouse effect and take action to prevent it from happening on Earth. Let's work towards reducing our carbon emissions and taking steps to mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: there is no relationship between temperature and carbon dioxide emissions by ­humans
comment_by_fact-checker: Actually there is a relationship if you look on the appropriate timescales.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Relationship Between Temperature and Carbon Dioxide Emissions
FACT1: Carbon dioxide emissions from human activities are a major contributor to global warming. The more carbon dioxide we emit, the warmer the planet becomes. This is a well-established scientific fact supported by decades of research and data.
MYTH: There is no relationship between temperature and carbon dioxide emissions by humans.
FALLACY: This myth is a false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that just because there may be other factors that contribute to climate change, carbon dioxide emissions from human activities are not a significant contributor. It also ignores the overwhelming evidence that shows a clear correlation between rising temperatures and increasing carbon dioxide emissions.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's work together to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Global human emissions are only 3 per cent of total annual emissions.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Others have already commented on this in detail. Just to emphasize: the statement is clearly misleading. What matters here is how human emissions drive the net atmospheric CO2 budget (emissions minus uptake) out of balance, which leads to an accumulation of CO2 in the atmosphere.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Human activities contribute significantly to the increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, which is causing global warming. 

MYTH: Global human emissions are only 3 per cent of total annual emissions.

FALLACY: This myth uses a misleading statistic to downplay the significant impact of human activities on climate change. While it is true that natural sources of greenhouse gases, such as volcanic eruptions and wildfires, also contribute to the total annual emissions, human activities are responsible for the majority of the increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. 

FACT2: Let's not be misled by this myth. We need to take responsibility for our actions and work towards reducing our carbon footprint to mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: Could natural factors be the cause of the warming? Nope.”
comment_by_fact-checker: We are sure that natural factors alone could not have caused the observed warming—without the increase of greenhouse gases there would not be so much warming—but they could have contributed. For the period 1951 to 2010 our best estimate is that all of the warming was due to human activities. But natural factors could have warmed or cooled the Earth a bit. In the period around 1900, part of the warming was probably natural due to fewer volcanic eruptions and a stronger Sun. [Also see this related Claim Review. ]
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Human Activity is the Main Cause of Global Warming
FACT1: The overwhelming majority of climate scientists agree that human activity, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, is the main cause of global warming. This is supported by a vast body of scientific evidence, including temperature records, ice core data, and computer models.
MYTH: Natural factors are the main cause of global warming.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of the False Cause fallacy, which assumes that because two things are happening at the same time, one must be causing the other. While natural factors such as solar radiation and volcanic activity can influence the Earth's climate, they cannot account for the rapid warming observed in recent decades.
FACT2: It is important to recognize the role of human activity in causing global warming in order to take action to mitigate its effects. Let's reduce our carbon footprint and support policies that promote renewable energy sources.

fact_checked_segment: “unprecedented droughts nearly everywhere food is today produced”
comment_by_fact-checker: Actually, overall the general projection is for the world to be wetter on average, with increasing drought in some regions but decreases in others, and increased annual rainfall in many places. The projections are extremely uncertain though, so while it is probably possible to cherry-pick model simulations that suggest increased drought in almost any region (and hence argue, probably fairly, that most places do have some increased risk of drought) these would not be expected to happen concurrently everywhere. A scenario with increased drought in one region would generally see a decrease elsewhere.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
FACT1: Droughts are becoming more frequent and severe due to climate change, which is affecting food production in many regions of the world.

MYTH: Droughts are a natural occurrence and have nothing to do with climate change.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of oversimplification and false equivalence. While droughts have occurred naturally in the past, the current frequency and severity of droughts are directly linked to climate change caused by human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation. Ignoring this link oversimplifies the issue and falsely equates current droughts with past ones.

FACT2: We can take action to mitigate the effects of climate change and reduce the frequency and severity of droughts. Let's support policies and practices that reduce greenhouse gas emissions and promote sustainable agriculture.

fact_checked_segment: “The human contribution can be up to 30 percent or so of the total rainfall coming out of the storm”
comment_by_fact-checker: Climate change doesn’t cause events like this, but probably makes them worse by making storms (which are strong to begin with) more intense and enhancing rainfall in that process. I don’t think anyone can say with confidence that climate change has made tropical cyclones worse. There’s too much natural variability (Pacific Decadal Oscillation, Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation, etc.) and the sample size of intense hurricanes is small. It is consistent with what’s predicted for the future, though. However, I’m not exactly sure where the “30 percent” number comes from for the human contribution to rainfall. For every one degree increase in sea surface temperature, the saturation vapor pressure increases by about 7% based on the “Clausius-Clapeyron” equation. There’s also an assumption that hurricanes will likely get stronger because of climate change, so perhaps the stronger winds will also increase evaporation.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Human activities can affect rainfall from storms
FACT1: Human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation can affect the amount of rainfall that comes out of a storm. This is because these activities can alter the temperature and moisture levels in the atmosphere, which can impact the formation and behavior of storms. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: The statement is generally true, but it is important to note that the extent of human influence on rainfall from storms can vary depending on a number of factors, including the location and intensity of the storm, as well as the specific human activities in question. Additionally, while human activities can contribute to changes in rainfall patterns, they are not the only factor at play. 
FACT2: Let's be mindful of the impact our actions have on the environment and take steps to reduce our carbon footprint and protect natural ecosystems.

fact_checked_segment: These facts are completely supported by 4,000 ocean floats
comment_by_fact-checker: The fact that the Earth is warming is completely supported by ocean floats.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Ocean floats provide strong evidence for climate change
FACT1: Ocean floats are devices that measure temperature, salinity, and other properties of the ocean. There are currently over 4,000 ocean floats deployed worldwide, providing a wealth of data on the state of the ocean.
MYTH: There is no evidence for climate change.
FALLACY: This myth is a combination of cherry-picking and ignoring evidence. The overwhelming scientific consensus is that climate change is happening and is primarily caused by human activities. The data from ocean floats is just one piece of evidence that supports this conclusion.
FACT2: Let's not ignore the wealth of evidence that supports the reality of climate change. We should take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: We may not be able to stop it, but we’d better get ready to adapt to it.
comment_by_fact-checker: The magnitude of equilibrium climate sensitivity has nothing to do with whether or not we can stop climate change. Global temperatures will stabilize when the atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gasses stabilize. So regardless of the climate sensitivity value, we can “stop” climate change by stabilizing greenhouse gas concentrations.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change Adaptation is Crucial for Our Future
FACT1: Climate change is already happening and will continue to impact our planet, causing more frequent and severe natural disasters, rising sea levels, and changes in weather patterns. Adapting to these changes is crucial for our survival and well-being.
MYTH: Climate change is not happening, or it is not caused by human activity.
FALLACY: The fallacy underlying this myth is denialism, which is the rejection of scientific evidence and consensus. Denialism is often fueled by misinformation, cherry-picking data, and conspiracy theories. It is important to recognize that the overwhelming majority of climate scientists agree that climate change is happening and is caused by human activity.
FACT2: We need to take action to adapt to the impacts of climate change, such as building infrastructure that can withstand extreme weather events, protecting vulnerable communities, and transitioning to more sustainable and resilient systems. Let's not ignore the reality of climate change and work towards a better future for ourselves and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: The most recent IPCC report lays out a future if we limit global heating to 1.5°C instead of the Paris Agreement’s 2°C.
comment_by_fact-checker: The article doesn’t mention it, but it’s worth pointing out that the underlying report criticizes the IPCC for being too “reticent” and gives an erroneous example: it claims that mean global temperatures will accelerate beyond the IPCC’s projections since human greenhouse gas emissions are themselves accelerating. Emissions ARE accelerating exponentially, leading to exponential CO2 atmospheric fraction increase, but exponential growth in CO2 fraction leads to linearly increasing global mean temperature.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The Benefits of Limiting Global Heating to 1.5°C
FACT1: The most recent IPCC report shows that limiting global heating to 1.5°C instead of 2°C would significantly reduce the risks and impacts of climate change. This includes reducing the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, protecting biodiversity and ecosystems, and improving food security and human health.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's work towards limiting global heating to 1.5°C by reducing greenhouse gas emissions and transitioning to renewable energy sources. This will help protect our planet and ensure a sustainable future for generations to come.

fact_checked_segment: “The U.S. National Climate Assessment found that U.S. heat waves have already “become more frequent and intense,” that the U.S. is shattering high temperature records far more frequently than it is shattering low temperature records (just as you’d expect), and that it is seeing correspondingly fewer cold spells.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is true and is also consistent with findings from other areas of the world. For example, Dr Sophie Lewis led work that showed in Australia there have been 12 times as many hot records compared to cold records since 2000.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Heat waves in the U.S. have become more frequent and intense, and the country is breaking high temperature records more often than low temperature records.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to acknowledge the reality of climate change and its impact on extreme weather events. Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: Actual weather records over the past 100 years show no correlation between rising carbon dioxide levels and local temperatures.
comment_by_fact-checker: Science only claims a relationship between carbon dioxide levels and the global temperature. Still, it would be nice if the authors would provide a source for their claim.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
FACT1: Carbon dioxide levels and local temperatures are not always directly correlated. However, this does not mean that rising carbon dioxide levels do not contribute to global warming, which is a long-term trend in the increase of the Earth's average surface temperature.

MYTH: Rising carbon dioxide levels do not cause global warming because there is no correlation between carbon dioxide levels and local temperatures.

FALLACY: This argument is a false equivalence, as it compares short-term local temperature fluctuations to long-term global temperature trends. It also cherry-picks data by focusing on a narrow time frame and ignoring the overall trend of rising global temperatures.

FACT2: The scientific consensus is that rising carbon dioxide levels are contributing to global warming, which is causing a range of negative impacts such as sea level rise, more frequent and severe heatwaves, and more intense storms. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and instead rely on the overwhelming evidence provided by climate scientists.

fact_checked_segment: “So far this month, there have been nearly 5,000 daily record highs set or tied, compared to just 42 daily record lows.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is very appropriate to look at this ratio of record highs versus record lows, as the climate stations themselves have different periods of records and therefore different expected rates of records (all are “long term” and have at least 30 years of data but some have much longer periods of record). But, one would still expect a one-to-one ratio of record highs to record lows in a stationary climate regime.
label: false analogy
debunk:
FACT1: Daily record high temperatures are being set at a much higher rate than daily record low temperatures. 

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: This statement is not a fallacy, but it is important to note that it is a fact that supports the scientific consensus that the Earth's climate is warming. The increase in daily record high temperatures is consistent with the overall trend of rising global temperatures, which is largely driven by human activities such as burning fossil fuels. 

FACT2: Let's not ignore the overwhelming evidence of climate change and take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions.

fact_checked_segment: “This will achieve almost nothing. My peer-reviewed research, published last November in the journal Global Policy, shows that even if every nation were to fulfill all their carbon-cutting promises by 2030 and stick to them all the way through the century—at a cost of more than $100 trillion in lost GDP—global temperature rise would be reduced by a tiny 0.3°F (0.17°C).”
comment_by_fact-checker: Dr. Lomborg sets out to show that the INDCs [emission reduction pledges] are useless. To do so he grossly misrepresents the pledges. He constructs an incomplete accounting that omits the pledges of many nations, ignores China’s pledge to cap its emissions by 2030, and assumes that the [European Union countries] will abandon their commitment to emissions reductions as soon as their pledges are fulfilled. (find more details in this rebuttal of Lomborg’s paper)
label: strawman
debunk:
FACT1: Even if all nations fulfill their carbon-cutting promises by 2030 and stick to them through the century, global temperature rise would only be reduced by 0.3°F (0.17°C), according to peer-reviewed research published in the journal Global Policy. This would come at a cost of over $100 trillion in lost GDP.

MYTH: The myth is that efforts to reduce carbon emissions will have a significant impact on global temperature rise.

FALLACY: This argument uses the fallacy of impossible expectations, demanding unrealistic standards of certainty before acting on the science. While it is true that reducing carbon emissions alone will not solve the problem of climate change, it is an important step in mitigating its effects. The research cited in the quote sets an unrealistic standard of complete elimination of temperature rise, which is not the goal of carbon reduction efforts.

FACT2: While reducing carbon emissions alone will not solve the problem of climate change, it is an important step in mitigating its effects. Let's continue to work towards reducing our carbon footprint and finding innovative solutions to combat climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “new research in Nature Climate Change not only reinforces the reality of this trend — which is already provoking debate about the overall climate consequences of a warming Arctic — but statistically attributes it to human causes, which largely means greenhouse gas emissions (albeit with a mix of other elements as well).”
comment_by_fact-checker: That’s a good summary of what’s new in this study: Arctic greening had been documented before, its causes had been discussed, but this is the first study to formally attribute this greening trend to human gas emissions. Note that trends in surface temperature and in some aspects of the hydrological cycle (e.g., precipitation, evaporation) have been detected and attributed similarly; this is the first study to do so with vegetation trends (which appear closely related to temperature trends, though).
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Human Activities are the Main Cause of Arctic Warming
FACT1: The Arctic is warming at an alarming rate, and new research published in Nature Climate Change has found that human activities are the main cause of this trend. The study statistically attributes the warming to greenhouse gas emissions and other human activities.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to acknowledge the role of human activities in Arctic warming and take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and other harmful human activities. Let's work towards a sustainable future to protect our planet and its inhabitants.

fact_checked_segment: “Temperatures in the Arctic have soared recently, and scientists are struggling to explain exactly why.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The only quibble I have with this article is this statement. I’d say that we have a fairly good understanding of the causes of this warm episode. As mentioned in the article, a very diminished ice cover this summer allowed additional solar energy to be absorbed by the Arctic Ocean, which is then released back to the atmosphere in fall that in turn retards refreezing. Additional moisture is also evaporated from the open ocean, which not only traps additional heat as a greenhouse gas, but also tends to form more clouds that also trap heat. An unusually wavy jet-stream pattern has also transported extra heat and moisture from lower-latitude regions into the Arctic, adding to the warmth. We know many self-reinforcing mechanisms operate in the Arctic, so when some heat shows up there (think greenhouse gases, moisture, etc.), its effects are amplified. This has been understood for a long time, but perhaps the pace of this warming is somewhat unexpected.
label: hasty generalization
debunk:
TITLE: The Mystery of Arctic Temperature Rise
FACT1: The Arctic is experiencing a significant temperature rise, with temperatures increasing at twice the global average rate. This warming trend is causing the Arctic sea ice to melt, which has serious implications for the environment and global climate patterns.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important for scientists to continue studying the Arctic temperature rise to better understand the causes and potential consequences. Let's support scientific research and efforts to address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: The ­atmospheric residency time of carbon dioxide is five years and it is quickly sequestered into plants, marine life, oceans and sediments.
comment_by_fact-checker: There are many papers that looked at the time it would take for natural negative feedbacks to remove the excess carbon from the atmosphere. It would take millennia*. Eby et al (2008) Lifetime of Anthropogenic Climate Change: Millennial Time Scales of Potential CO2 and Surface Temperature Perturbations, Journal of Climate
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Short Residency Time of Carbon Dioxide in the Atmosphere
FACT1: Carbon dioxide has a short residency time in the atmosphere, lasting only about five years. During this time, it is quickly absorbed by plants, marine life, oceans, and sediments.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Understanding the short residency time of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is important for understanding the carbon cycle and the impact of human activities on the environment. Let's continue to educate ourselves on the science of climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: International Energy Agency, a global analysis organization, “continue to see a role for coal for the foreseeable future.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement deserves more scrutiny because it appears that the IEA outlook and the UN Report are considering different scenarios. In the IEA outlook, it is true that coal remains a large component of the global energy system through 2040 under existing and expected policies (“NPS scenario”), but their projection under the “Sustainable Development Scenario,” which takes international climate objectives into account, has coal accounting for 12% of global energy by 2040.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
FACT1: The International Energy Agency (IEA) acknowledges that coal will continue to play a role in the global energy mix for the foreseeable future.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: This statement is an example of a false dilemma fallacy, which presents only two options when there are actually more. The statement implies that either coal will be completely phased out or it will continue to be used at current levels, when in reality, there are many potential scenarios in between.

FACT2: While coal will continue to play a role in the global energy mix, it is important to transition to cleaner energy sources in order to mitigate the impacts of climate change. Let's work towards a future where renewable energy sources are the primary source of energy.

fact_checked_segment: “‘This El Niño might have contributed about a quarter or a third’ of the record in 2016, said Deke Arndt, chief of the global monitoring branch at NOAA’s National Centers for Environmental Information, on a press call Wednesday.”
comment_by_fact-checker: I find this part confusing. The “percentage of the anomaly” caused by El Niño depends of course on the anomaly, which depends on the baseline. So it’s not really a useful number. El Niño caused a much larger fraction if you only look at a very recent baseline (e.g. just compare to 2014-15). A more straightforward number is the 2016 anomaly relative to what it would have been if ENSO were in a neutral phase. I calculated this to be ~0.13 C (0.23 F).
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: El Niño Contributed to Record Temperatures in 2016
FACT1: El Niño, a natural climate pattern characterized by warmer-than-average ocean temperatures in the Pacific, contributed to a significant portion of the record temperatures in 2016, according to Deke Arndt, chief of the global monitoring branch at NOAA’s National Centers for Environmental Information.
MYTH: The record temperatures in 2016 were solely caused by human activity.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false dichotomy, which presents two options as the only possibilities when other possibilities exist. While human activity has contributed to the overall warming of the planet, natural climate patterns like El Niño can also have a significant impact on global temperatures.
FACT2: It is important to recognize the role that both human activity and natural climate patterns play in global temperature trends. Let's continue to study and understand these factors in order to make informed decisions about how to address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “this event poses severe risks to health — particularly for children and the elderly […] an extreme 2003 heat wave that affected Paris and Europe, and which has indeed been connected to climate change through statistical attribution analysis […] killed hundreds of people in Paris and London, and a recent study attributed at least some of those deaths, themselves, to climate change.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The majority of injuries, illnesses, and deaths during heatwaves are preventable. A robust literature base documents individuals at higher risk during heatwaves, such as adults over the age of 65 years, infants, individuals with certain chronic diseases, and others. Heatwave early warning and response systems save lives; expanding these systems to more cities and increasing awareness of the health risks of high ambient temperatures could increase resilience as heatwaves increase in frequency, intensity, and duration. Another issue is that growing confidence that climate change is increasing the probability of heatwaves means some deaths during heatwaves could be attributed to climate change.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change and Heat Waves: A Deadly Combination
FACT1: Heat waves pose severe risks to health, particularly for children and the elderly. In 2003, an extreme heat wave that affected Paris and Europe killed hundreds of people in Paris and London. A recent study attributed at least some of those deaths to climate change.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to take action to mitigate the effects of climate change and prevent more deadly heat waves in the future. Let's support policies and practices that reduce greenhouse gas emissions and promote sustainable living.

fact_checked_segment: But efforts to determine what causes seas to rise are marred by poor data and disagreements about methodology.
comment_by_fact-checker: I think this is a misinterpretation of what is currently known about sea level rise where we know that roughly 50% comes from glaciers’ mass loss, and the other 50% comes from volume expansion because of heat. There are multiple independent observation systems that confirm the current knowledge.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding the Challenges of Measuring Sea Level Rise
FACT1: Measuring sea level rise is a complex and challenging task that requires accurate data and consistent methodology. It involves measuring the height of the ocean surface relative to the land, which can be affected by factors such as tides, waves, and ocean currents. 
MYTH: There is poor data and disagreements about methodology when it comes to measuring sea level rise. 
FALLACY: The fallacy here is ambiguity, as the statement is vague and lacks specific details about what data is poor and what disagreements exist. This can lead to a misleading conclusion that the science of sea level rise is unreliable or uncertain. In reality, while there are challenges to measuring sea level rise, there is a broad scientific consensus that it is happening and that human activities are contributing to it. 
FACT2: Despite the challenges, scientists have developed sophisticated methods for measuring sea level rise, including satellite altimetry and tide gauges. It is important to rely on accurate data and consistent methodology to better understand and address the impacts of sea level rise. Let's not spread misinformation about the reliability of sea level rise science.

fact_checked_segment: One of the main areas of contention is the existence of two strange climate episodes known as The Medieval Warm Period (MWP) and the Little Ice Age. The MWP lasted from about 950 to 1250AD, and temperature
comment_by_fact-checker: The author uses a common technique of confusing the climate in single region with the global climate. Statments such as this (or “this winter is so cold, we can call climate change off”) are irrelevant because they do not refer to the global climate.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Medieval Warm Period and the Little Ice Age: Separating Fact from Fiction
FACT1: The Medieval Warm Period (MWP) and the Little Ice Age were two climate episodes that occurred in the past, but they were not global phenomena and did not have the same causes as current climate change. The MWP was a period of warmer temperatures that occurred in some regions of the world from about 950 to 1250 AD, while the Little Ice Age was a period of cooler temperatures that occurred from about 1350 to 1850 AD.
MYTH: There is a belief that the MWP and the Little Ice Age were global phenomena that prove that current climate change is natural and not caused by human activities.
FALLACY: This is a case of cherry-picking, where only certain data are selected to support a particular argument while ignoring other data that contradict it. While the MWP and the Little Ice Age were real climate events, they were not global phenomena and did not have the same causes as current climate change. The current warming trend is caused by human activities, primarily the burning of fossil fuels, which has led to an increase in greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere.
FACT2: Let's not use the MWP and the Little Ice Age to deny the reality of current climate change. Instead, let's focus on the overwhelming scientific evidence that shows that human activities are causing the Earth's climate to warm at an unprecedented rate.

fact_checked_segment: More than 100 climate models over the past 30 years did not predict what actually happened because it was assumed carbon dioxide had the pivotal role in driving climate change and that the effects of clouds, back-radiation and the sun were trivial.
comment_by_fact-checker: Climate model projections from decades ago accurately predicted: (1) global warming would happen, (2) it would happen faster at high latitudes, (3) the HQadley Cell circulation would expand poleward, (4) the stratosphere would cool, (5) Arctic sea ice would retreat, (6) convective cloud tops in the tropics would get higher. These changes have all now been measured. For example, a 1988 study1 discussed rising convective cloud tops. And a 2016 study2 showed it was measured with satellites. 1-Wetherald and Manabe (1988) Cloud Feedback Processes in a General Circulation Model, Journal of the Atmospheric Sciences 2-Norris et al (2016) Evidence for climate change in the satellite cloud record, Nature
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The Role of Carbon Dioxide in Climate Change
FACT1: Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas that traps heat in the Earth's atmosphere, contributing to global warming. However, it is not the only factor that affects climate change. Other factors, such as clouds, back-radiation, and the sun, also play a role in driving climate change.
MYTH: A warning that a misunderstanding is coming. "Climate models did not predict what actually happened because carbon dioxide was assumed to be the only factor driving climate change."
FALLACY: This is a false cause fallacy, as it assumes that the failure of climate models to predict climate change is solely due to the assumption that carbon dioxide is the only factor driving climate change. In reality, climate models take into account a wide range of factors that affect climate change, including carbon dioxide, clouds, back-radiation, and the sun. The failure of some climate models to accurately predict climate change is due to the complexity of the Earth's climate system and the limitations of current scientific understanding.
FACT2: Let's not oversimplify the complex factors that contribute to climate change. It is important to continue to improve our understanding of the Earth's climate system and to develop more accurate climate models to inform policy decisions.

fact_checked_segment: Because it’s getting warmer, there’s more CO2 coming out which means it’s going to get warmer which means there’s more CO2 coming out[…] And it will just run away with itself.”
comment_by_fact-checker: (Dr Commane is the first author of the scientific study discussed in the ThinkProgress article) I spoke with Henry Fountain (New York Times), Chris Mooney (Washington Post), Oli Milman (Guardian), and Bob Berwyn (Inside Climate News) about the PNAS paper and I think they all did a great job condensing my attempts at communicating the message of the paper. The radio chat I did with a local NPR station in Juneau, AK (which I think is the source of this article) was probably the least comprehensive attempt—I tried to make things as simple as possible and didn’t realize that the quote would sound so off when taken outside of that context. I think the written articles better conveyed the essence of the paper compared to what I tried to say in the radio piece.
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: The Feedback Loop Fallacy
FACT1: The Feedback Loop Fallacy is the idea that a small change in one direction will lead to an unstoppable chain reaction in the same direction. In reality, most systems have feedback mechanisms that stabilize them and prevent runaway effects.
MYTH: "Because it’s getting warmer, there’s more CO2 coming out which means it’s going to get warmer which means there’s more CO2 coming out[…] And it will just run away with itself."
FALLACY: This statement is an example of the Feedback Loop Fallacy. While it is true that warming temperatures can cause more CO2 to be released from the environment, this does not mean that the process will continue indefinitely. In fact, there are many feedback mechanisms that can help to stabilize the climate, such as increased plant growth and the absorption of CO2 by the oceans.
FACT2: Let's not fall for the Feedback Loop Fallacy. While it is important to recognize the potential for feedback effects in the climate system, we should also remember that there are many factors that can help to stabilize the climate and prevent runaway warming.

fact_checked_segment: “The science is far from settled.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The basic controls on the climate, sunlight and greenhouse gases, have been understood for over a century and are not disputed. The frontiers of climate research are where the debates lie, as with any branch of science.
label: red herring
debunk:
MYTH: The myth is that the science of climate change is not settled.

FALLACY: This is a classic example of the "Moving Goalposts" fallacy, where the goalposts for what constitutes "settled science" are constantly shifted. In reality, the overwhelming majority of climate scientists agree that climate change is happening and is primarily caused by human activities, such as burning fossil fuels. While there is always room for further research and refinement of scientific understanding, the basic facts of climate change are well-established.

FACT: The fact is that the scientific consensus on climate change is clear and strong. Multiple studies have shown that over 97% of climate scientists agree that climate change is happening and is primarily caused by human activities. This consensus is supported by a vast body of scientific evidence, including temperature records, ice core data, and observations of changes in the natural world.

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. It is important to recognize that the science of climate change is settled and to take action to address this urgent global challenge.

fact_checked_segment: “Because the collapse of vulnerable parts of the ice sheet could raise the sea level dramatically, the continued existence of the world’s great coastal cities — Miami, New York, Shanghai and many more — is tied to Antarctica’s fate.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is the prime motive of understanding Antarctic ice sheet dynamics, especially since the far-field location gives Antarctica relatively more weight to sea level rise along many Northern Hemisphere cities than Greenland.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The fate of coastal cities is tied to Antarctica's ice sheet
FACT1: The stability of Antarctica's ice sheet is crucial for the survival of coastal cities such as Miami, New York, and Shanghai. If vulnerable parts of the ice sheet collapse, it could lead to a dramatic rise in sea levels, which would threaten the existence of these cities. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to take action to address climate change and reduce greenhouse gas emissions to prevent the collapse of Antarctica's ice sheet and protect coastal cities from the devastating effects of rising sea levels. Let's work together to protect our planet and ensure a sustainable future for all.

fact_checked_segment: “‘Acid’ was chosen, Moore believes, because it has ‘strong negative connotations for most people’.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The terms acidification was not chosen for its negative connotation but rather because it defines the direction of change. Here is a simple example: when you describe the cooling of your coffee what term do you use? Cooling or un-warming? If the temperature is going down we say it is cooling. If the temperature is going up we say it is warming. The same applies to acidity. When the pH of something goes down we say that it is acidifying. That simple.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Term "Acid" in "Acid Rain" was not Chosen for Scientific Reasons
FACT1: Acid rain is a real phenomenon caused by emissions of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide, which react with the atmosphere to form sulfuric and nitric acid. These acids can fall to the ground as rain, snow, or dry particles. However, the term "acid" in "acid rain" was not chosen for scientific reasons.
MYTH: Acid rain is called "acid" because it is highly acidic.
FALLACY: This statement is a red herring fallacy, as it distracts from the fact that the term "acid" in "acid rain" was not chosen for scientific reasons. The term was actually coined by a scientist named Robert Angus Smith in the 19th century, who used it to describe rain that was unusually acidic due to pollution from human activities. The term "acid" was later popularized by environmental activists in the 1970s and 1980s to draw attention to the harmful effects of acid rain on the environment.
FACT2: Let's continue to use the term "acid rain" to describe this environmental phenomenon, but let's also be aware that the term was not chosen for scientific reasons. Instead, it was chosen for its strong negative connotations to draw attention to the issue.

fact_checked_segment: “this event poses severe risks to health — particularly for children and the elderly […] an extreme 2003 heat wave that affected Paris and Europe, and which has indeed been connected to climate change through statistical attribution analysis […] killed hundreds of people in Paris and London, and a recent study attributed at least some of those deaths, themselves, to climate change.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Only mentioning the deaths in two cities understates the danger of heat waves. The number of people who died in the 2003 heat wave is estimated to be in the tens of thousands. This article estimates it was 70 thousand additional deaths.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change and Heat Waves: A Deadly Combination
FACT1: Heat waves pose severe risks to health, particularly for children and the elderly. In 2003, an extreme heat wave that affected Paris and Europe killed hundreds of people in Paris and London. A recent study attributed at least some of those deaths to climate change.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's take action to mitigate climate change and prevent more deadly heat waves in the future. This includes reducing greenhouse gas emissions, transitioning to renewable energy sources, and implementing policies to adapt to the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The problem with this ploy is that carbon dioxide is not a pollutant and it is dishonest to say it is. CO2 is colorless, odorless and completely non-toxic. Plants depend on it to live and grow, and human beings draw some into their lungs with every breath they take to no ill effect whatsoever. Growers regularly pump CO2 into greenhouses, raising levels to three times that of the natural environment, to produce stronger, greener, healthier plants.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement is absolutely ridiculous. It violates the most basic, fundamental maxim of toxicology, first articulated by the Renaissance physician Paracelsus: “The dose makes the poison.” Or, “All things are poison and nothing is without poison; only the dose makes a thing not a poison.” In other words, just because a substance at one concentration is harmless does not mean it is harmless at another concentration. We don’t normally think of consumption of water as harmful to humans, but at high enough doses it will kill—and has done so. A pollutant is generally defined as a substance—artificial (synthetic) or natural—that occurs in the environment at least in part because of human activity, and that has a deleterious impact on living systems. Given that basic definition, there is no way that CO2 can not be a pollutant. It is produced by a variety of human activities, but principally burning of fossil fuels. Increases in its concentration are clearly linked to global warming, which has already, and increasingly will, negatively affect living systems, including humans.
