MYTH: Climate change predictions have been proven wrong because various calamities that were supposed to have occurred by now have not materialized.
FALLACY: This is a straw man fallacy, as it misrepresents the predictions made by climate scientists. Climate change predictions are not based on specific calamities that are supposed to occur by a certain date, but rather on long-term trends and probabilities. While some predictions may not have come to pass yet, many others have, and the overall trend towards a warmer planet is clear.
FACT2: It is important to continue to take climate change seriously and work towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions in order to mitigate the worst effects of a warming planet. Let's not use the straw man fallacy to dismiss the scientific consensus on climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “This means it is possible that by some yardsticks, 2016 will be declared as hot as 2015 or even slightly hotter – because El Nino did not vanish until the middle of the year.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Even without the big El Niño spike, 2016 will be the hottest year on record, and 2015 the second hottest. Scientists have methods to remove the effect of El Niño on the temperature record. We can also see this in a simple example where we just remove the big El Niño-related temperature spike, but 2016 remains the warmest year in the surface temperature record:
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: El Nino Did Not End Until Mid-2016
FACT1: El Nino is a natural climate pattern that occurs every few years, characterized by warmer than average sea surface temperatures in the Pacific Ocean. It can have significant impacts on weather patterns around the world, including droughts, floods, and heatwaves. 
MYTH: El Nino ended in 2015, and therefore any temperature records set in 2016 cannot be attributed to El Nino.
FALLACY: This statement is a false assumption that El Nino ended in 2015. In reality, El Nino continued to have an impact on global temperatures until mid-2016. Therefore, it is possible that temperature records set in 2016 were influenced by El Nino.
FACT2: Let's not overlook the continued impact of El Nino on global temperatures in 2016. It is important to consider all factors that contribute to climate patterns in order to better understand and address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “People tend to think of an ice-free Arctic in summer in terms of it merely being a symbol of global change.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a good point. Changes in one part of the Earth system due to warming are not in isolation and result in feedbacks in other parts of the Earth system.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Importance of an Ice-Free Arctic in Summer
FACT1: The Arctic sea ice is melting at an alarming rate, with the summer ice cover shrinking by about 13% per decade. An ice-free Arctic in summer would have significant consequences for the climate, ecosystems, and human societies around the world. It would accelerate global warming, disrupt ocean currents, and cause sea levels to rise, among other impacts.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is crucial to recognize the importance of an ice-free Arctic in summer and take action to mitigate the effects of climate change. We can reduce our carbon footprint, support renewable energy, and advocate for policies that prioritize climate action. Let's work together to protect the Arctic and our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “But scientific research indicates the world was last this warm about 115,000 years ago and that the planet has not experienced such high levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere for 4m years.”
comment_by_fact-checker: At the last interglacial period 115,000 years ago, increased solar intensity was responsible for the added warmth, but today’s high CO2 was last seen in the atmosphere 3-5 million years ago. At that time, global mean temperatures were a couple of degrees higher than present, and sea levels were several metres higher than present.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: The Earth is experiencing unprecedented warming and high levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
FACT1: The Earth is currently experiencing warming and high levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which are unprecedented in recent history. Scientific research indicates that the last time the Earth was this warm was about 115,000 years ago, and the planet has not experienced such high levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere for 4 million years.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change. Let's work together to protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “The world’s alpine glaciers recorded a net annual loss of ice for the 36th consecutive year and the Greenland ice sheet … experienced melting over more than 50% of its surface.”
comment_by_fact-checker: That is correct, see figure below: There was an event in the beginning of July when ~50% of the ice sheet experienced melt. This is clearly outside of the expected natural variability, but does not necessarily project the overall Greenland summer (since such melt events are extremely episodic). Overall, Greenland experienced a warm summer, with slightly more surface runoff than average and overall average amounts of snowfall (source)
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Glaciers and Ice Sheets are Melting at an Alarming Rate
FACT1: Glaciers and ice sheets are losing ice at an alarming rate. The world's alpine glaciers have recorded a net annual loss of ice for the 36th consecutive year, and the Greenland ice sheet has experienced melting over more than 50% of its surface. This melting is contributing to sea-level rise, which poses a significant threat to coastal communities around the world.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and support policies that address climate change. We can also support organizations that work to protect glaciers and ice sheets, and educate ourselves and others about the importance of preserving these vital components of our planet's ecosystem.

fact_checked_segment: since 1979 to the most reliable observations — those made by satellites and weather balloons over the vast tropics.
comment_by_fact-checker: This plot hides the large differences between these highly uncertain estimates by only showing the average
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The Most Reliable Observations of Global Temperature Trends
FACT1: Satellites and weather balloons provide the most reliable observations of global temperature trends since 1979. These observations cover the vast tropics and are not subject to the biases and errors that can occur with surface temperature measurements.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's trust the most reliable observations of global temperature trends and use them to inform our understanding of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “there are alarming stories every day, like last month’s satellite data showing the globe warming, since 1998, more than twice as fast as scientists had thought”
comment_by_fact-checker: This sentence is true for RSS data, but it’s somewhat misleading due to lack of context. If you look at the two most recent versions of the RSS data and compute linear trends Jan 1998-Dec 2016, you find that the new version has a trend value for this period of about 2.6 times larger than the previous version. But, it is good to remember that 1998 is a favorite starting point for those that seek to minimize the perceived threat of global warming. This preference is because 1998 is a relative maximum in global temperature (due to a large ENSO event), and thus trends that start in Jan 1998 are smaller than trends that start in other, nearby years. This means that when the change in trends between datasets is reported as a multiplicative effect, the change appears quite large. However, if one calculated the trends for Jan 1999-Dec 2016 instead, the trends increases by a factor of about 1.6, not 2.6, only a 60% increase. Of course this is still a pretty large increase. The sentence also ignores the other sources of lower-tropospheric satellite data. The newer version of the UAH (Version 6.0) data shows less warming than the previous version. Also, the radiosonde datasets show more warming over this period that any of the satellite datasets (except maybe UAH V5.6), and have done so for years.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The rate of global warming is accelerating.
FACT1: The Earth's temperature is increasing at an alarming rate. The rate of global warming has accelerated since the 1970s, and the last decade was the warmest on record. This warming is caused by human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation, which release greenhouse gases into the atmosphere and trap heat.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is crucial to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change. Let's make sustainable choices and support policies that prioritize the health of our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “His Gaia hypothesis, which contends that the earth is a single, self-regulating organism, is now accepted as the founding principle of most climate science […]”
comment_by_fact-checker: Climate science is based on physical, biological, and chemical processes. There are feedbacks between these processes such as biological consumption of atmospheric CO2 by photosynthesis. However, the idea of a self-regulated Earth system due to biological activity is not a common principle of climate science.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Gaia Hypothesis and Climate Science
FACT1: The Gaia hypothesis, proposed by James Lovelock in the 1970s, suggests that the Earth is a self-regulating system in which living organisms interact with their environment to maintain conditions suitable for life. This hypothesis has influenced the development of climate science and the understanding of the Earth's systems.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Understanding the Earth as a self-regulating system has helped scientists to better understand the complex interactions between living organisms and the environment, and how these interactions affect the Earth's climate. Let's continue to explore and learn from the Gaia hypothesis and other scientific theories to deepen our understanding of the world around us.

fact_checked_segment: “The report confidently claims that when temperatures rise, “the reduction in premature deaths from cold are expected to be smaller than the increase in deaths from heat in the United States.” Six footnotes are attached to that statement.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The report says “The decrease in deaths and illness due to reductions in winter cold have not been as well studied as the health impacts of increased heat, but the reduction in premature deaths from cold are expected to be smaller than the increase in deaths from heat in the United States“. This doesn’t sound over-confident to me; and as for the “footnotes”, there are scientific references to back up that claim, not asterisks leading to fine-print caveats…
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change and Health: Separating Fact from Fiction
FACT1: Climate change is expected to increase the number of deaths from heat in the United States, while reducing the number of deaths from cold. This is supported by multiple sources and studies.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: The statement in the report is supported by multiple sources and studies, but the six footnotes attached to it suggest that the authors have done their due diligence in researching and verifying the claim. However, some may still try to dismiss the claim as unfounded or biased.
FACT2: It is important to acknowledge the potential health impacts of climate change and take action to mitigate them. Let's not ignore the evidence and continue to educate ourselves on the issue.

fact_checked_segment: “An “inherent bias” in scientific journals in favour of more calamitous predictions has excluded research showing that marine creatures are not damaged by ocean acidification, which is caused by the sea absorbing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.”
comment_by_fact-checker: A publication bias towards positive results is inherent to all fields of research. But I believe that it is far from being as bad as the article suggests. The most recent and comprehensive meta-analysis of the impact of ocean acidification shows that many processes and taxonomic groups exhibit no statistically significant response (Kroeker et al., 2013). This demonstrates that many non-calamitous papers are published. Kroeker K. et al., 2013. Impacts of ocean acidification on marine organisms: quantifying sensitivities and interaction with warming. Global Change Biology 19:1884-1896.
label: red herring
debunk:
FACT1: Ocean acidification, caused by the absorption of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, is a real and ongoing process that affects marine ecosystems worldwide. 

MYTH: There is an inherent bias in scientific journals that excludes research showing that marine creatures are not damaged by ocean acidification.

FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, where a single study or a few studies are used to support a particular viewpoint while ignoring the larger body of evidence. While it is true that some studies have found that certain marine organisms are less affected by ocean acidification than others, the overwhelming majority of research shows that ocean acidification has negative impacts on marine ecosystems, including reduced growth and survival rates, changes in behavior, and altered food webs.

FACT2: It is important to consider the full body of scientific evidence when evaluating the impacts of ocean acidification on marine ecosystems. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: “In the sugarcane region of El Salvador, as much as one-fifth of the population has chronic kidney disease, including over a quarter of the men, the presumed result of dehydration from working the fields they were able to comfortably harvest as recently as two decades ago.”
comment_by_fact-checker: If this author already writes “presumed result”, I would love to see a reference to the scientific literature. It would be quite surprising if the 1-1.5 °C warming we have seen up now makes such a differences. Source: Berkeley Earth
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Chronic kidney disease in El Salvador's sugarcane region
FACT1: In El Salvador's sugarcane region, up to 20% of the population suffers from chronic kidney disease, with over 25% of men affected. This is believed to be due to dehydration caused by working in the fields, which was not a problem just 20 years ago.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's raise awareness about the health risks faced by sugarcane workers in El Salvador and support efforts to improve working conditions and access to healthcare.

fact_checked_segment: “suggest that residents are fleeing atolls swiftly sinking into the sea. Yet new research shows that this is not the entire—or even an accurate—picture.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Scientists’ comments on this article clearly show that it is also not an “entire” or “accurate” picture. So Mr. Lomborg is using the very flawed reasoning he is condemning others of.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The Reality of Atoll Displacement
FACT1: Atolls are not sinking as quickly as previously thought, and displacement is caused by a combination of factors, including erosion and sea level rise. 
MYTH: Atolls are rapidly sinking into the sea, causing residents to flee. 
FALLACY: The myth is based on a simplistic understanding of the complex processes that cause atoll displacement. It also ignores the fact that displacement is caused by a combination of factors, including erosion and sea level rise. 
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about atoll displacement. Instead, let's work to understand the complex processes that cause it and find solutions to help those affected by it.

fact_checked_segment: We have also been told the problem is DEFINITELY NOT a billions-year-old planet running through cycles where the temperature might fluctuate a bit.
comment_by_fact-checker: We are well aware that there are climatic fluctuations through geological time. Huge numbers of scientists study how the Earth’s climate has fluctuated before, and we know what caused those changes. Current warming is not related to any natural climate cycle, or process, or astronomic phenomenon.
label: red herring
debunk:
MYTH: The Earth's current climate change is just a natural cycle that has occurred throughout the planet's history.

FALLACY: This is a false equivalence fallacy, as it assumes that because the Earth has undergone natural climate changes in the past, the current changes must also be natural. However, the current changes are occurring at an unprecedented rate and are primarily caused by human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation.

FACT: The Earth's current climate change is primarily caused by human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation. This is supported by overwhelming scientific evidence, including the fact that the current rate of warming is much faster than any natural climate change in the past. 

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about the causes of climate change. It is important to recognize the role of human activities in causing climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: “Scientists have published strong evidence that the warming climate is making heat waves more frequent and intense. It is also causing heavier rainstorms”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is hard to attribute each particular event to human-induced climate change. The article correctly frames the influence in terms of increasing frequency and intensity of extremes, and directs the reader to a good reference page with clear explanations for non-experts. Daniel Swain, Researcher, UCLA, and Research Fellow, National Center for Atmospheric Research: Indeed, there is now observational evidence that global warming has already increased the likelihood and magnitude of extreme heat and intense downpours across much of the globe*. Diffenbaugh et al (2017) Quantifying the influence of global warming on unprecedented extreme climate events, PNAS
label: post hoc
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change is Increasing the Frequency and Intensity of Heat Waves and Heavy Rainstorms
FACT1: Climate change is causing more frequent and intense heat waves and heavier rainstorms, according to scientific evidence. This is due to the warming of the planet caused by human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: The myth here is the denial of the scientific evidence that shows that climate change is causing more frequent and intense heat waves and heavier rainstorms. This denial is often based on cherry-picking data or anecdotal evidence, rather than looking at the larger body of scientific research. 
FACT2: Let's not ignore the scientific evidence and instead take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: There’s no trend in global droughts. Cold snaps in the U.S. are down but, unexpectedly, so are heatwaves.
comment_by_fact-checker: The temperature claims are a bit misleading. We experience more and more record breaking warm temperatures over time due to global warming. These changes are damaging for many reasons beyond drought.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: The Complexity of Global Droughts and Heatwaves
FACT1: Droughts and heatwaves are complex phenomena that cannot be reduced to simple trends. While some regions may experience more frequent or severe droughts or heatwaves, others may not. Additionally, the frequency and severity of these events can vary from year to year, making it difficult to identify clear trends.
MYTH: There is no trend in global droughts and heatwaves.
FALLACY: This myth is an oversimplification of the complex nature of droughts and heatwaves. It assumes that these events should follow a clear trend, when in reality, they are influenced by a variety of factors, including regional climate patterns, land use changes, and global climate change. Focusing solely on trends can lead to a misunderstanding of the complexity of these events and their impacts.
FACT2: Instead of looking for simple trends, it is important to understand the complex factors that contribute to droughts and heatwaves. This understanding can help us better prepare for and mitigate the impacts of these events. Let's not oversimplify the complexity of these phenomena and instead focus on understanding and addressing their root causes.

fact_checked_segment: In its 5th assessment report in 2013, the IPCC estimated that human emissions are probably responsible for more than half of the observed increase in global average temperature from 1951 to 2010. But it means a chunk of the rise is coming from elsewhere.
comment_by_fact-checker: In its 2013 fifth assessment report, the IPCC stated in its summary for policymakers that it is “extremely likely that more than half of the observed increase in global average surface temperature” from 1951 to 2010 was caused by human activity. By “extremely likely”, it meant that there was between a 95% and 100% probability that more than half of modern warming was due to humans. This somewhat convoluted statement has been often misinterpreted as implying that the human responsibility for modern warming lies somewhere between 50% and 100%. In fact, as NASA’s Dr. Gavin Schmidt has pointed out, the IPCC’s implied best guess was that humans were responsible for around 110% of observed warming (ranging from 72% to 146%), with natural factors in isolation leading to a slight cooling over the past 50 years. For more details, see my Carbon Brief explainer on why the best-estimate of the human contribution is around 100% of observed warming.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Human activity is the main cause of global warming, but natural factors also play a role.

FACT1: Human activity, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, is the primary cause of global warming. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) estimates that human emissions are responsible for more than half of the observed increase in global average temperature from 1951 to 2010.

MYTH: Some people believe that human activity is not the main cause of global warming, and that natural factors are responsible for most of the observed increase in temperature.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of the false equivalence fallacy, which incorrectly claims that two things are equivalent despite notable differences between them. While natural factors such as solar radiation and volcanic activity can influence the Earth's climate, they cannot account for the rapid warming observed in recent decades. The overwhelming scientific consensus is that human activity is the primary cause of global warming.

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. It is important to understand the overwhelming scientific evidence that human activity is the primary cause of global warming, and to take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions.

fact_checked_segment: “According to a recent National Economic Research Associates Economic Consulting study, the Paris Agreement could obliterate $3 trillion of GDP, 6.5 million industrial sector jobs and $7,000 in per capita household income from the American economy by 2040. Meeting the 2025 emissions reduction target alone could subtract $250 billion from our GDP and eliminate 2.7 million jobs. The cement, iron and steel, and petroleum refining industries could see their production cut by 21% 19%, and 11% respectively.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The National Economic Research Associates study assumes that the United States meets the 2025 target for reducing annual emissions of greenhouse gases, which is set out in its “nationally determined contribution”, and goes on to reduce its annual emissions by 80% by 2050 compared with 1990. The authors of the study admit on pages 10-11 to making the astonishing assumption that every other country in the world ignores the targets in their nationally determined contributions and make no further efforts to reduce emissions, so that much of the calculated costs to the United States economy subsequently arise from high-carbon companies relocate or lose business to competitors in other countries. The model assumes no increase in low-carbon electricity generation over the next four decades compared with the baseline scenario, so no increase in economic growth or jobs in the low-carbon sector and no substitution of low-carbon energy for high-carbon energy—emissions reductions are achieved by imposing very high carbon prices that reduce the consumption of coal and energy. The study makes the unrealistic assumption that there will be no economic benefits to the United States from avoided impacts of climate change or co-benefits from reducing local air pollution from fossil fuels which currently contributes to the premature deaths of 200,000 Americans each year, according to a study by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology*. Overall, this is an inaccurate and misleading assessment of the cost to the United States of participating in the Paris Agreement and honouring the commitments in its nationally determined contribution—indeed, the extreme assumptions mean this a study of the costs of policy-makers attempting to achieve emissions reduction targets in some of the least cost-effective ways available. Caiazzo et al (2013) Air pollution and early deaths in the United States. Part I: Quantifying the impact of major sectors in 2005, Atmospheric Environment
label: false authority
debunk: The Economic Consulting study claims that the Paris Agreement could have a negative impact on the American economy, with a potential loss of GDP, jobs, and household income. However, this argument is based on a flawed understanding of the Paris Agreement and its goals. The Paris Agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5 degrees Celsius. By achieving these goals, the Paris Agreement seeks to prevent the worst impacts of climate change, which would have far-reaching economic and social consequences. In fact, investing in clean energy and transitioning to a low-carbon economy could create new jobs and stimulate economic growth. Let's not be misled by flawed arguments that ignore the long-term benefits of addressing climate change.

fact_checked_segment: Like countless other organ­isms, we move and adapt when the environment changes. Species thrive when it is warm.
comment_by_fact-checker: The rate of change is important. CO2 concentrations and temperatures are changing at an unprecedented rate, which will make it impossible for many organisms to “move and adapt”
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Species Adapt to Environmental Changes
FACT1: Species have the ability to adapt to changes in their environment, including changes in temperature. This adaptation allows them to thrive in different conditions and continue to survive. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Understanding the adaptability of species can help us better understand how they will respond to changes in their environment, including those caused by human activities. Let's continue to study and protect the biodiversity of our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “Sea level rise, which was occurring long before humans could be blamed, has not accelerated and still amounts to only 1 inch every ten years. If a major hurricane is approaching with a predicted storm surge of 10-14 feet, are you really going to worry about a sea level rise of 1 inch per decade?”
comment_by_fact-checker: Proxy analysis has clearly shown an acceleration in rate of sea-level rise. Our research* found that the rate of sea-level rise on the US Atlantic coast is greater now than at any time in the past 2,000 years. The research also shows a consistent link between global mean surface temperature and changes in sea level for the past millennium. The study shows that after relatively subtle changes in temperature and sea-level rise over the last 2,000 years, the rate of sea-level rise increased in the late 19th century. Sea-level rise contributes significantly to the frequency of flooding from hurricanes. The contribution from sea-level rise to flood height works in together with other factors such as timing of the storm relative to high tide, and the strength and direction of individual hurricanes. Sea-level rise between hurricanes raises the “baseline” water level and makes flooding more likely. We published another paper* showing that New York City can expect nine-foot floods, as intense as that produced by 2012’s Superstorm Sandy, at least four times more frequently over the next century. We report that floods as intense as Sandy’s would have occurred about once every 400 years on average under present day sea-level rise conditions, but that over the 21st century are expected to be about four times more probable (once every 100 years) due to an acceleration in the rate of sea-level rise. Kemp et al. (2011) Climate related sea-level variations over the past two millennia, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences Lin et al. (2016) Hurricane Sandy’s flood frequency increasing from year 1800 to 2100, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Sea Level Rise is a Real Threat
FACT1: Sea level rise is a gradual increase in the average level of the ocean, caused by melting glaciers and ice sheets, as well as the thermal expansion of seawater due to global warming. It is a real threat to coastal communities, causing flooding, erosion, and saltwater intrusion into freshwater sources. 
MYTH: Sea level rise is not a significant threat because it has been occurring naturally for a long time and has not accelerated. 
FALLACY: This argument uses the false equivalence fallacy by equating the natural, gradual sea level rise that has occurred over thousands of years with the rapid, human-caused sea level rise that is happening now. It also uses the cherry-picking fallacy by focusing on the rate of sea level rise over a short period of time and ignoring the long-term trend. 
FACT2: Sea level rise is a real and significant threat to coastal communities, and we should take action to mitigate its impacts. Let's not downplay the threat of sea level rise and instead work towards solutions to protect our communities and our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “The oceans, which absorb more than 90% of the extra CO2 pumped into the atmosphere“
comment_by_fact-checker: Here “CO2” should be “heat” … according to the Scripps Institute, the uptake of CO2″ is about 26%.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Oceans' Role in Absorbing CO2
FACT1: The oceans absorb more than 90% of the extra CO2 that is released into the atmosphere. This absorption helps to slow down the rate of global warming caused by human activities.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's continue to reduce our carbon footprint and support policies that prioritize the health of our planet and oceans.

fact_checked_segment: “The thermal expansion of the oceans, compounded by melting glaciers, resulted in the highest global sea level on record in 2015.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement in the AMS report refers to the satellite altimetry record, which reaches back to 1993. It is also important to remember that it refers to the global average sea level. We do have local records of past sea level that extend further back in time, for instance tide gauge records or inferences based upon biological markers. For instance, combined tide gauge records have been used to infer global mean sea level rise (GMSL) over the 20th century and into the 21st century. The obtained estimate of the GMSL rise agrees with the satellite altimetry record in their overlap since 1993 (e.g., Hay et al., 2015: Probabilistic reanalysis of twentieth-century sea-level rise).
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Melting Glaciers and Thermal Expansion are Raising Sea Levels
FACT1: The sea level is rising due to the thermal expansion of the oceans and melting glaciers. Thermal expansion occurs when water heats up and expands, taking up more space. Melting glaciers add more water to the oceans, further increasing sea levels. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and slow down the rate of global warming to prevent further sea level rise.

fact_checked_segment: “climate economists see a positive externality, not a negative one, from the human influence on climate. (In technical lingo, the so-called social cost of carbon would be negative.)”
comment_by_fact-checker: The social cost of carbon would indeed be negative for a low climate sensitivity. This is because the net impacts of climate change only turn negative at more pronounced warming, and this would occur in a more distant future for a low climate sensitivity. At the same time, the positive impacts of carbon dioxide fertilization would be unaffected.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change Can Have Positive Externalities
FACT1: Climate change can have positive externalities, which are benefits that are not reflected in market prices. For example, increased carbon dioxide levels can lead to increased plant growth and crop yields in some regions. This is known as the "fertilization effect" and can have positive impacts on food security and agricultural productivity.

MYTH: Climate change is always negative and has no positive impacts.

FALLACY: The myth is based on a false dichotomy, assuming that climate change can only have negative impacts. This is a form of the false choice fallacy. In reality, climate change can have both positive and negative impacts, and it is important to consider both when evaluating the costs and benefits of climate policies.

FACT2: Recognizing the potential positive externalities of climate change does not mean that we should ignore the negative impacts or stop taking action to mitigate them. Instead, it highlights the need for a comprehensive approach to climate policy that considers all of the costs and benefits, including those that are not reflected in market prices. Let's continue to work towards effective climate policies that take into account all of the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: Protecting and restoring forests would reduce 18% of emissions by 2030
comment_by_fact-checker: The original statement says: could provide 18%[v] of cost-effective mitigation through 2030.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Forests are a key solution to reducing emissions
FACT1: Protecting and restoring forests could reduce 18% of global greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, according to the United Nations. Trees absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and store it in their biomass, making them a natural carbon sink. Deforestation and forest degradation, on the other hand, release carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, contributing to climate change.
MYTH: Forests are just a nice-to-have, not a necessity, for addressing climate change.
FALLACY: The myth that forests are not a key solution to reducing emissions is a false choice fallacy. It presents the idea that there are only two options: either focus on reducing emissions from fossil fuels or focus on protecting forests. In reality, both are necessary to address climate change. Protecting and restoring forests is a cost-effective way to reduce emissions, while also providing additional benefits such as preserving biodiversity and supporting local communities.
FACT2: Protecting and restoring forests is a crucial part of addressing climate change. Let's support efforts to protect and restore forests, and advocate for policies that prioritize this important solution.

fact_checked_segment: “The contrast in precipitation between wet and dry regions and between wet and dry seasons will increase, although there may be regional exceptions.”
comment_by_fact-checker: While this picture might provide a leading order approximation, it is mostly valid over the oceans. Over land, recent research has shown that the “wet get wetter, dry get drier” picture does not really apply and things are a little more complex (e.g., see: Byrne and O’Gorman. “The Response of Precipitation Minus Evapotranspiration to Climate Warming: Why the “Wet-Get-Wetter, Dry-Get-Drier” Scaling Does Not Hold over Land” Journal of Climate (2015).)
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Precipitation Contrasts Will Increase
FACT1: Precipitation contrasts between wet and dry regions and seasons will increase, with some regional exceptions. This means that areas that are already dry will become drier, and areas that are already wet will become wetter. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to recognize that climate change will have different impacts in different regions, and to take action to mitigate and adapt to these changes. Let's work together to address the challenges of a changing climate.

fact_checked_segment: Already, scientists know enough to be concerned. About 120,000 years ago, before the last ice age, the planet went through a natural warm period, with temperatures similar to those expected in coming decades. The sea level was 20 to 30 feet higher than it is today, implying that the ice sheets in both Greenland and Antarctica must have partly disintegrated, a warning of what could occur in the relatively near future if the heating of the planet continues unchecked.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is factually correct. Indeed, past climate states analogous to the state which is expected to manifest in the near future, are characterized by much higher sea levels. This implies that the current Antarctic (and Greenland) ice sheet volumes are not consistent with warmer climate states. Rather, warmer climate states are consistent with smaller ice sheets. “Relatively near future” is probably a misleading statement in the text, because it implies to average people a decadal timeframe—almost certainly unrealistic for 20-30 ft of sea level rise.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: The planet has experienced natural warm periods in the past, with temperatures similar to those expected in the coming decades. About 120,000 years ago, before the last ice age, the sea level was 20 to 30 feet higher than it is today, indicating that the ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica must have partly disintegrated.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: None.

FACT2: It is important to take action to prevent further heating of the planet and the potential disintegration of ice sheets, which could lead to a significant rise in sea levels. Let's take steps to reduce our carbon footprint and support policies that prioritize sustainability and environmental protection.

fact_checked_segment: “Mass coral bleaching is a new phenomenon and was never observed before the 1980s as global warming ramped up.”
comment_by_fact-checker: On the Great Barrier Reef, I believe this is true. Global (especially tropical) temperatures took a jump upwards in the late 1970s, providing the extra warmth that puts corals in danger.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Coral bleaching is a process where corals lose their color and become more vulnerable to disease and death. It occurs when corals are exposed to stressors such as high temperatures, pollution, and ocean acidification. 

MYTH: Mass coral bleaching is a new phenomenon and was never observed before the 1980s as global warming ramped up.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, where only a small part of the available data is used to support a particular argument. While it is true that mass coral bleaching events have become more frequent and severe in recent decades, coral bleaching has been observed for centuries. Historical records and scientific studies show that coral bleaching events have occurred in the past, but they were less frequent and less severe than they are today.

FACT2: Let's not underestimate the impact of climate change on coral reefs. We can take action to reduce our carbon footprint and support conservation efforts to protect these vital ecosystems.

fact_checked_segment: frost fairs were held on the Thames when the river froze
comment_by_fact-checker: The cessation of these frost fairs was linked to changes in river management and not to climate change.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Frost Fairs on the Thames
FACT1: In the past, when the Thames River in London froze over, people would hold fairs on the ice. These fairs included games, food, and even printing presses. The last frost fair was held in 1814.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: While the Thames River rarely freezes over now due to climate change, the tradition of frost fairs on the river is a fascinating part of London's history. Let's appreciate the ingenuity and creativity of those who made the most of the frozen river in the past.

fact_checked_segment: “2017 is so unexpectedly warm it is freaking out climate scientists”
comment_by_fact-checker: 2017 is not “unexpectedly warm” nor is it “freaking out” climate scientists, because they predicted this!
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Unprecedented Warmth of 2017
FACT1: 2017 was one of the warmest years on record, with global temperatures averaging 1.62°F (0.9°C) above the 20th-century average. This warming trend is consistent with the long-term trend of human-caused climate change.
MYTH: A statement claiming that the unexpected warmth of 2017 is causing alarm among climate scientists.
FALLACY: The fallacy in this statement is cherry-picking, which involves selectively choosing data that support a particular argument while ignoring other data that contradict it. While 2017 was an unusually warm year, it is just one year in a long-term trend of warming caused by human activities. Focusing on a single year's temperature data without considering the broader context is misleading and can create a false impression that the warming trend is not significant.
FACT2: Let's not be misled by cherry-picked data. The long-term trend of human-caused climate change is clear and supported by overwhelming scientific evidence. We must take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “What do you say to people who theorize that the Earth as it continues to warm is returning to its normal temperature?”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a fallacy, which has been correctly rebutted by Duffy. What matters is that a large increase in global temperatures is problematic for us humans, who have built a civilisation in a relatively stable climate, and which we are now perturbing far outside this stable range.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The Earth's Temperature is Rising
FACT1: The Earth's temperature is rising due to human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation. This has led to an increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, which trap heat and cause the planet to warm up. 
MYTH: Some people theorize that the Earth is returning to its normal temperature as it continues to warm. 
FALLACY: This is an example of the False Analogy fallacy, as it assumes that the current warming trend is part of a natural cycle, when in fact it is caused by human activities. It also ignores the overwhelming scientific evidence that shows that the Earth is warming at an unprecedented rate. 
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. The Earth's temperature is rising due to human activities, and we need to take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “We almost take forests as a given but we lose forest every year, which means we are diminishing them as a carbon sink.
comment_by_fact-checker: Deforestation does happen every year, but on the whole, the latest research suggests that we are currently (over the last 30 years) slightly gaining forests globally (+7% compared to early 80’s), as forest gains outside of the Tropics, in particular in the Northern Hemisphere, are a bit greater than tropical deforestation*. We could certainly limit deforestation to gain even more forests, though. In addition, from a carbon perspective and local climate regulation, tropical forests are probably more important than mid-/high-latitude forests. Song et al (2018) Global land change from 1982 to 2016 Nature
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Forests as Carbon Sinks
FACT1: Forests play a crucial role in mitigating climate change by absorbing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and storing it in their biomass and soil. They are one of the most effective natural carbon sinks on the planet, absorbing about 2.4 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide each year.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: However, deforestation and forest degradation are major contributors to greenhouse gas emissions, accounting for about 10% of global emissions. It is important to protect and restore forests to maintain their role as carbon sinks and mitigate climate change. Let's support efforts to conserve and restore forests, and reduce our reliance on products that contribute to deforestation.

fact_checked_segment: “cold kills many more people than heat.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Mr. Lomborg is confusing seasonal mortality with temperature-related mortality. It is true that mortality is higher during winter than summer. However, it does not follow that winter mortality is temperature-dependent (which summer mortality is). Dave Mills and I reviewed the evidence and concluded that only a small proportion of winter mortality is likely associated with temperature. A growing numbers of publications are exploring associations between weather and winter mortality, with differences in methods and results. The country with the strongest association between winter mortality and temperature is England, which appears in other publications to be at least partly due to cold housing. Winter mortality is lower in northern European countries.
label: false cause
debunk:
FACT1: Both cold and heat can be dangerous, but cold temperatures are generally more deadly than hot temperatures. Cold weather can lead to hypothermia, frostbite, and other health problems, especially in vulnerable populations such as the elderly and homeless.

MYTH: The myth is that cold temperatures are not as dangerous as hot temperatures and that cold weather is not a significant health risk.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that two things are equivalent when they are not. While both cold and heat can be dangerous, they affect the body in different ways and have different health risks. Cold temperatures can lead to hypothermia, frostbite, and other health problems, while hot temperatures can cause heat stroke, dehydration, and other heat-related illnesses.

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about the dangers of cold weather. It is important to take precautions during cold weather, such as wearing warm clothing and staying indoors when possible, especially for vulnerable populations such as the elderly and homeless.

fact_checked_segment: “In 2004, two NOAA scientists, Richard Feely and Christopher Sabine, produced a chart showing a strong correlation between rising atmospheric CO2 levels and falling oceanic pH levels. But then, just over a year ago, Mike Wallace, a hydrologist with 30 years’ experience, noticed while researching his PhD that they had omitted some key information[…] his results were surprising: there has been no reduction in oceanic pH levels in the last -century.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is plain wrong. Oceanic pH levels decreased by 0.1 units compared to pre-industrial levels. This corresponds to a 30% increase in acidity. For a primer on pH, see this NOAA explainer. Peer-reviewed references: Doney et al (2009) Ocean acidification: the other CO2 problem, Annual Review of Marine Science Raven et al (2005) Ocean acidification due to increasing atmospheric carbon dioxide, The Royal Society
label: no fallacy
debunk: Ocean acidification is a real and ongoing problem caused by the absorption of carbon dioxide by seawater, which leads to a decrease in pH levels. However, a myth has been circulating that ocean acidification is not happening or is not caused by human activities. This myth is often spread by cherry-picking data or misrepresenting scientific studies. In the case of the quote above, the myth is based on a straw man fallacy, where the argument is misrepresenting the scientific consensus on ocean acidification. The study cited in the quote did not claim that there has been no reduction in oceanic pH levels in the last century, but rather that the rate of acidification has not been constant over time. The scientific consensus is that ocean acidification is happening and is caused by human activities, and we should take action to address this issue. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: To revisit the ocean’s paleotemperatures now, we need to carefully quantify this re-equilibration, which has been overlooked for too long. For that, we have to work on other types of marine organisms so that we clearly understand what took place in the sediment over geological time”
comment_by_fact-checker: There are already other methods based both on different organisms and different proxy methods which the authors ignore.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding the Re-equilibration of Ocean Paleotemperatures
FACT1: The re-equilibration of ocean paleotemperatures has been overlooked for too long, and it is important to carefully quantify it in order to accurately understand the history of the Earth's climate. This requires studying other marine organisms to gain a clearer understanding of the sediment over geological time.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's continue to study and learn about the Earth's climate history by carefully quantifying the re-equilibration of ocean paleotemperatures and studying other marine organisms. By doing so, we can gain a better understanding of the Earth's climate and how it has changed over time.

fact_checked_segment: Yet other scientists claim this is a red herring because of the positive feedback loop created by water vapour.
comment_by_fact-checker: This entire article is a mess of false equivalency. It is not a case of “some scientists say this, while others say this”. There is the scientific consensus (the so-called 97%) and then there are a few fringe scientists such as Willie Soon who have been comprehensively proven to produce poor work riddled with errors.1 Benestad et al (2015) Learning from mistakes in climate research, Theoretical and Applied Climatology
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Water vapour feedback loop in climate change
FACT1: Water vapour is the most abundant greenhouse gas in the Earth's atmosphere, and it plays a crucial role in the climate system. As the Earth's temperature increases due to the increase in greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide, the amount of water vapour in the atmosphere also increases, creating a positive feedback loop that amplifies the warming effect.
MYTH: Some scientists claim that the role of water vapour in climate change is a red herring, and that it is not a significant factor in the warming of the Earth's atmosphere.
FALLACY: This argument is a red herring fallacy, as it diverts attention from the main issue of the role of water vapour in climate change. While it is true that water vapour is not the only factor contributing to climate change, it is a crucial component of the Earth's climate system and cannot be ignored.
FACT2: Understanding the role of water vapour in climate change is essential for developing effective strategies to mitigate the impacts of global warming. Let's not overlook the importance of water vapour in the Earth's climate system and work towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions to prevent further warming of the planet.

fact_checked_segment: This scientist proved climate change isn’t causing extreme weather
comment_by_fact-checker: This is misleading. The main argument of Pielke’s presentation at the University of Minnesota, the Hohenkammer Consensus Statement, and the IPCC reports is that the increasing COST due to extreme weather cannot be linked to climate change.
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change and Extreme Weather: Separating Fact from Fiction
FACT1: Climate change is causing more frequent and severe extreme weather events, such as heatwaves, droughts, floods, and hurricanes. These events have devastating impacts on human health, infrastructure, and ecosystems. However, it is not accurate to attribute any single weather event to climate change, as weather is a complex and variable system influenced by many factors. Instead, we can look at the long-term trends and patterns of extreme weather to see the influence of climate change.
MYTH: A scientist has proven that climate change isn't causing extreme weather.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, which is the practice of selecting data that appear to confirm one position while ignoring other data that contradicts that position. While it is true that weather events have multiple causes, including natural variability and human activities, the overwhelming scientific evidence shows that climate change is exacerbating extreme weather events. This evidence comes from multiple lines of research, including observations, modeling, and attribution studies, which compare the likelihood and intensity of extreme events in a world with and without human-caused warming.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's educate ourselves and others about the real impacts of climate change on extreme weather and take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to the changing climate.

fact_checked_segment: In its 5th assessment report in 2013, the IPCC estimated that human emissions are probably responsible for more than half of the observed increase in global average temperature from 1951 to 2010. But it means a chunk of the rise is coming from elsewhere.
comment_by_fact-checker: This is deceptive. Most published work suggests human activities are responsible for all, if not more than 100% of observed warming.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Human activity is the main cause of global warming, but natural factors also play a role.

FACT1: Human activity, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, is the primary cause of global warming. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) estimates that human emissions are responsible for more than half of the observed increase in global average temperature from 1951 to 2010.

MYTH: Some people believe that human activity is not the main cause of global warming, and that natural factors are responsible for most of the observed increase in temperature.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of the false equivalence fallacy, which incorrectly claims that two things are equivalent despite notable differences between them. While natural factors such as solar radiation and volcanic activity can influence the Earth's climate, they cannot account for the rapid warming observed in recent decades. The overwhelming scientific consensus is that human activity is the primary cause of global warming.

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. It is important to understand the overwhelming scientific evidence that human activity is the primary cause of global warming, and to take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions.

fact_checked_segment: “Despite recent attempts to paint the United States as a major global polluter, according to the World Health Organization (WHO), the U.S. is among the cleanest nations on the planet.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This presumes a strong link between the cleanliness of a country’s air and its own emissions. This does not necessarily hold. For example, the tiny papal state of the Vatican City is probably rather polluted (as it’s contained solely within the city of Rome). However, the vast majority of that pollution will have been emitted in Italy.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: The United States is not among the cleanest nations on the planet, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). 

MYTH: The United States is among the cleanest nations on the planet.

FALLACY: This statement uses the fallacy of cherry-picking by selectively choosing one source of information to support a claim while ignoring other sources that contradict it. The WHO has not made any such claim about the United States being among the cleanest nations on the planet. In fact, the United States is one of the largest emitters of greenhouse gases in the world and has a significant impact on global pollution.

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about the United States' environmental impact. It is important to acknowledge the country's role in global pollution and work towards reducing its carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: at the end of recent ice ages, the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere started to rise only after temperatures began to climb.
comment_by_fact-checker: his is misleading. The way it is written incorrectly suggests that warming simply causes an increase in atmospheric CO2. The author has not acknowledged the positive feedback whereby as the Earth warms, the ocean releases more carbon to the atmosphere, reinforcing the warming.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: The Relationship Between Temperature and CO2 Concentration
FACT1: The concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has been shown to increase after temperatures begin to climb, not before.
MYTH: The myth is that the rise in carbon dioxide concentration causes the increase in temperature.
FALLACY: This is an example of a false cause fallacy, where a causal relationship is assumed between two events without sufficient evidence. While it is true that carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas and can contribute to warming, the historical record shows that temperature increases have preceded carbon dioxide increases in the past.
FACT2: Understanding the relationship between temperature and carbon dioxide concentration is important for accurately predicting future climate change. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and instead focus on the scientific evidence.

fact_checked_segment: “a killer analysis conducted by Craig Idso of all the studies which have been done on the effects of reduced pH levels on marine life.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The Idso meta-analysis described by Delingpole was never published. It does not take into account the proper method of proportional scaling analysis. It does not demonstrate how negative effects will impact ecosystem services and food-web processes that can have an effect on economically important fish and shellfish. It does not address the impacts we are already seeing on important fish food, such as pteropods (see Bednarsek et al., 2012, 2014; Feely et al., 2016). There are several highly credible published meta-analysis studies (Kroeker et al. ,2013; Wittman & Pörtner, 2013; and Busch and McElhany, 2016) that have told a much different story than Idso’s unpublished work. Delingpole failed to even mention these other studies, which show very significant impacts on several marine taxa. In summary, Delingpole’s article demonstrates a complete lack of appreciation of scientific literature on this topic and the proper choice of scientific methods for data analysis and synthesis that leads to a more accurate understanding of the present-day and future impacts of ocean acidification. Bednaršek et al (2012) Extensive dissolution of live pteropods in the Southern Ocean, Nature Geoscience Bednaršek et al (2014) Limacina helicina shell dissolution as an indicator of declining habitat, Proc. of the Royal Society B Feely et al (2016) Chemical and biological impacts of ocean acidification along the west coast of North America, Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: The Effects of Ocean Acidification on Marine Life
FACT1: Ocean acidification is the ongoing decrease in the pH of the Earth's oceans, caused by the absorption of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. This decrease in pH can have negative impacts on marine life, including reduced growth and reproduction rates, weakened shells and skeletons, and changes in behavior and habitat.
MYTH: None mentioned.
FALLACY: The statement implies that the analysis conducted by Craig Idso is the only one that has been done on the effects of reduced pH levels on marine life. This is a cherry-picking fallacy, as there have been numerous studies conducted on this topic, many of which have found negative impacts on marine life.
FACT2: Let's not rely on a single analysis to understand the impacts of ocean acidification on marine life. Instead, we should look at the body of scientific research on this topic to fully understand the potential consequences and take action to mitigate them.

fact_checked_segment: “At the end of the current paper, the researchers are blunt about the consequences of a continuing loss of oceanic oxygen. ‘Far-reaching implications for marine ecosystems and fisheries can be expected,’ they write.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It’s true that this is the last sentence of the paper. However, they refer to another study here: Cheung et al (2012) Shrinking of fishes exacerbates impacts of global ocean changes on marine ecosystems. Nature Climate Change.
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: Loss of Oceanic Oxygen Threatens Marine Ecosystems and Fisheries
FACT1: The ocean is losing oxygen at an alarming rate, with some areas experiencing a decline of up to 40% in the past 50 years. This is due to a combination of factors, including climate change and pollution.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is crucial that we take action to address the root causes of this problem, such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions and improving waste management practices. By doing so, we can help protect the health of our oceans and the many species that depend on them. Let's take responsibility for our actions and work towards a sustainable future.

fact_checked_segment: “What we don’t hear from her is that fewer people will die from cold.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Every report I have ever read about the impacts of climate change on temperature-related deaths discuss both the impacts of heat and cold. Such as the new USGCRP Health report: “Based on present-day sensitivity to heat, an increase of thousands to tens of thousands of premature heat-related deaths in the summer [Very Likely, High Confidence] and a decrease of premature cold-related deaths in the winter [Very Likely, Medium Confidence] are projected each year as a result of climate change by the end of the century. Future adaptation will very likely reduce these impacts (see Changing Tolerance to Extreme Heat Finding). The reduction in cold-related deaths is projected to be smaller than the increase in heat-related deaths in most regions [Likely, Medium Confidence].” Climate Feedback: This claim is not supported by available evidence and has been thoroughly discussed in a previous Climate Feedback analysis of an op-ed by Bjorn Lomborg.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The Benefits of Addressing Climate Change
FACT1: Addressing climate change can have numerous benefits, including reducing air pollution, improving public health, and creating new job opportunities in the renewable energy sector.
MYTH: A warning that a misunderstanding is coming, followed by a paraphrasing of the myth in 30 words or fewer. Only the myth. Don't debunk. Don't deny it yet. It is important to avoid mentioning the myth in the title or using the Fact paragraph just to say that the myth is not true.
MYTH: Addressing climate change will only have negative consequences, such as more people dying from cold.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of a false choice fallacy, as it presents two options as the only possibilities when there are other possibilities. It also uses anecdotal evidence to support a claim that is not supported by scientific evidence. While it is true that addressing climate change may lead to changes in temperature patterns, it is not accurate to claim that it will only have negative consequences. In fact, addressing climate change can have numerous benefits, including reducing air pollution, improving public health, and creating new job opportunities in the renewable energy sector.
FACT2: Addressing climate change is important for the health of our planet and future generations. Let's not spread misinformation that undermines the importance of taking action.

fact_checked_segment: spanning five countries
comment_by_fact-checker: Going quickly through the authors I identified 7 countries: Brasil, US, France, Austria, Italy, Canada, United Kingdom (the list might not be complete).
label: no fallacy
debunk:
{
    "TITLE": "The Amazon Rainforest spans five countries",
    "FACT1": "The Amazon Rainforest is the largest rainforest in the world, covering an area of 5.5 million square kilometers. It is home to millions of species of plants and animals, many of which are found nowhere else on Earth.",
    "MYTH": "The Amazon Rainforest is only located in Brazil.",
    "FALLACY": "The myth of the Amazon Rainforest only being located in Brazil is a result of oversimplification. While Brazil does contain the majority of the rainforest, it also spans over four other countries: Peru, Colombia, Ecuador, and Bolivia.",
    "FACT2": "Let's not overlook the importance of the Amazon Rainforest and its impact on the planet. It plays a crucial role in regulating the Earth's climate and is often referred to as the 'lungs of the Earth' due to its ability to absorb carbon dioxide and produce oxygen."
}

fact_checked_segment: “The amount of summer sea ice in the Arctic has steadily declined over the past few decades because of man-made global warming, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.”
comment_by_fact-checker: A recent study* makes this link very tangible by attributing every loss of 3 ± 0.3 m2 of September sea-ice area to 1 metric ton of man-made CO2 emissions. Notz and Stroeve (2016) Observed Arctic sea-ice loss directly follows anthropogenic CO2 emission, Science
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Arctic Sea Ice Decline Linked to Global Warming
FACT1: The amount of summer sea ice in the Arctic has been decreasing over the past few decades, with 2020 marking the second-lowest extent of sea ice on record. This decline is linked to global warming caused by human activities, such as the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation, which release greenhouse gases into the atmosphere and trap heat. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: The myth is not stated, but it is important to note that denying the link between Arctic sea ice decline and global warming is a form of cherry-picking, where one selectively chooses data that support their position while ignoring the larger body of evidence. 
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the scientific consensus that human activities are causing global warming and take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions to mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “ The discrepancy between model-predicted warming and (lower) real-world observations has inspired new respect for natural climate variability relative to greenhouse-gas forcing. ”
comment_by_fact-checker: Robert Bradley Jr. probably makes the typical mistake of equating the spread of individual model simulations within the ensemble spread with the model uncertainty. If climate models are used for decadal climate prediction, like Robert Bradley Jr. does here, the uncertainty is twice as large as the model spread. (more details and explanations) Natural variability has been studied by science since the beginning. That El Niño fluctuations can give the appearance of a “hiatus” is something scientists have warned about since the likes of Robert Bradley Jr. have started their “hiatus” meme, ignoring all those warnings. Without any need for statistical expertise, this can be seen in the plot below from the Texas State Climatologist. Source
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Natural Climate Variability and Greenhouse Gas Forcing
FACT1: Natural climate variability and greenhouse gas forcing are two factors that affect the Earth's climate. Natural climate variability refers to the natural fluctuations in the Earth's climate system, while greenhouse gas forcing refers to the warming effect caused by human activities such as burning fossil fuels. 
MYTH: The discrepancy between model-predicted warming and lower real-world observations has inspired new respect for natural climate variability relative to greenhouse-gas forcing.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, where only one aspect of the climate change debate is highlighted while ignoring other important factors. While natural climate variability is an important factor in the Earth's climate system, it is not the only factor. The overwhelming scientific consensus is that human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, are the primary cause of the observed warming of the Earth's climate. 
FACT2: It is important to consider all factors that affect the Earth's climate, including natural climate variability and greenhouse gas forcing. However, the overwhelming scientific evidence supports the conclusion that human activities are the primary cause of the observed warming of the Earth's climate. Let's not ignore the scientific consensus and continue to take action to address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Sea ice thickness also substantially declined in the latter half of the 20th century, the snow and ice data center said.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Agree—and adding how we don’t know much about Antarctic sea ice thickness would have been helpful.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Decline in Sea Ice Thickness
FACT1: The thickness of sea ice has decreased significantly in the latter half of the 20th century.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the fact that sea ice thickness has been declining and take action to reduce our carbon emissions to slow down the rate of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Hard evidence, including studies that use radioactivity to distinguish industrial emissions from natural emissions, shows that the extra gas is coming from human activity.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Also important is that we have good estimates of how much fossil fuel we have burned, from which one can estimate the CO2 emissions. The increase in CO2 concentration in the atmosphere is about half of those emissions (the rest was taken up by the vegetation and the oceans). It would have been more accurate to say that we can see that the CO2 increase is from burning fossil fuels by measuring isotopes (differences in the number of nuclear particles of atoms). Not all relevant isotopes are radioactive and the ones that are only a little.
label: post hoc
debunk:
TITLE: Human Activity is the Main Cause of Increased Greenhouse Gases
FACT1: Studies using radioactivity to distinguish between natural and industrial emissions have shown that the increase in greenhouse gases is mainly due to human activity. 
MYTH: The increase in greenhouse gases is due to natural causes and not human activity.
FALLACY: The myth is based on the false assumption that the increase in greenhouse gases is due to natural causes, despite the overwhelming scientific evidence that human activity is the main cause. This fallacy is known as "ignoring relevant evidence" or slothful induction, where relevant evidence is ignored when coming to a conclusion. 
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the scientific evidence and take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions to mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: The surprising thing is that the Energy Balance estimates are very low compared to model-based estimates.
comment_by_fact-checker: While on average Energy Balance-based approaches (or “instrumental” approaches) tend to give a lower sensitivity than model or paleoclimate results, not all do. See the figure below from Carbon Brief’s recent climate sensitivity explainer, which looks at 143 studies on equilibrium climate sensitivity between 2000 and present: McKitrick also completely ignores all the climate sensitivity evidence from studies of the Earth’s past climate changes (Paleoclimate), which broadly agrees with the equilibrium climate sensitivity range from climate models.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Energy Balance Estimates vs Model-Based Estimates of Climate Change

FACT1: Climate scientists use different methods to estimate the amount of energy that is being absorbed by the Earth's atmosphere and surface. One method is called Energy Balance, which estimates the amount of energy based on measurements of incoming and outgoing radiation. Another method is based on computer models that simulate the Earth's climate system. These models take into account a wide range of factors that affect the Earth's energy balance, such as greenhouse gas concentrations, solar radiation, and cloud cover.

MYTH: Energy Balance estimates of climate change are more accurate than model-based estimates.

FALLACY: The fallacy underlying this myth is a false dichotomy, which presents two options as the only possibilities when other possibilities exist. In reality, both Energy Balance and model-based estimates have their strengths and weaknesses, and scientists use both methods to gain a more complete understanding of climate change. Energy Balance estimates are based on direct measurements, but they are limited by the availability and quality of data. Model-based estimates are based on complex simulations, but they are limited by the accuracy of the models and the assumptions that are built into them.

FACT2: Both Energy Balance and model-based estimates are important tools for understanding climate change. By using multiple methods and comparing results, scientists can gain a more accurate and comprehensive understanding of the Earth's energy balance and how it is changing over time. Let's continue to support scientific research and use evidence-based information to inform our decisions about climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The growth is largely attributable to just two huge glaciers — Pine Island and Thwaites. The latter is increasingly being viewed as posing a potential planetary emergency, because of its enormous size and its role as a gateway that could allow the ocean to someday access the entirety of West Antarctica, turning the marine-based ice sheet into a new sea.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is known as the Marine Ice Sheet Instability hypothesis (MISI), see Box 13.2 in the latest IPCC report (Working Group 1). Figure – Schematic of the processes leading to the potentially unstable retreat of a grounding line showing (a) geometry and ice fluxes of a marine icesheet, (b) the grounding line in steady state, (c) climate change triggering mass outflow from the ice sheet and the start of grounding line retreat and (d) self-sustainedretreat of the grounding line. Source: IPCC
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Pine Island and Thwaites Glaciers are Rapidly Melting in Antarctica
FACT1: Pine Island and Thwaites glaciers are the main contributors to the melting of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet. Thwaites Glacier is of particular concern because of its size and role as a gateway that could allow the ocean to access the entirety of West Antarctica, leading to a rise in sea levels.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is crucial to address the melting of these glaciers to prevent a rise in sea levels and potential planetary emergency. Let's support efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and protect our planet.

fact_checked_segment: ” ‘You’ve only got to look at Singapore. It’s two-and-a-half times higher than the worst-case scenario for climate change, and it’s one of the most desirable cities in the world to live in.’ ”
comment_by_fact-checker: I am not sure I understand Lovelock’s point about Singapore. Singapore is a relatively wealthy, urbanized country, with an economy that is not highly weather dependent. One would expect Singapore to be able to adapt to temperature changes with far greater ease than would a poor agrarian economy. Also, several studies have projected massive increases in sea-level as a consequence of climate change. Most of Singapore is within 15 meters of sea-level. Thus, if CO2 emissions continue, we can expect most of Singapore to be underwater within a few centuries.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Singapore's High Sea Levels
FACT1: Singapore is a city-state located on an island with an average elevation of 15 meters above sea level. Due to its low-lying geography, Singapore is vulnerable to rising sea levels caused by climate change. 
MYTH: Singapore's high sea levels are not a problem because the city is desirable to live in.
FALLACY: This argument is a false equivalence fallacy, as it equates the desirability of a city with its vulnerability to climate change. Just because Singapore is a desirable city to live in does not mean that its high sea levels are not a problem. 
FACT2: Rising sea levels pose a significant threat to Singapore's infrastructure, economy, and population. It is important to acknowledge and address this issue to ensure the long-term sustainability and livability of the city. Let's prioritize taking action to mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: there has been no systematic increase in the frequency of extreme weather events,
comment_by_fact-checker: This is not true. We have good evidence that heat waves are occurring more frequently and that rainfall is falling in more intense events1. These are both things were predicted long ago to occur with global warming. 1- State of the Climate in 2018, Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Extreme Weather Events: Separating Fact from Fiction
FACT1: Extreme weather events have always occurred, but there is no evidence to suggest that their frequency has systematically increased over time.
MYTH: Climate change is causing an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events.
FALLACY: This myth is based on the fallacy of cherry-picking, which involves selectively choosing data that support a particular argument while ignoring data that contradict it. While it is true that individual extreme weather events, such as hurricanes or heatwaves, have become more intense in some regions, there is no evidence to suggest that their frequency has systematically increased over time. In fact, some studies suggest that the frequency of extreme weather events may have decreased in recent decades.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. While it is important to take action to address climate change, we should not exaggerate the frequency or severity of extreme weather events in order to make our case. Instead, we should focus on the scientific evidence and work together to find solutions that are based on sound science and good policy.

fact_checked_segment: “Not only do polls suggest the public is unmoved at home and in abroad…”
comment_by_fact-checker: This claim is incorrect.
