The source given to support “the public is unmoved at home” is an article titled “Poll: 91% Of Americans Aren’t Worried About Global Warming.” However, this article reports that “only 9.2 percent of Americans rank global warming as their biggest concern.” Not ranking global warming as your biggest concern is not the same thing as not being concerned at all. According to a 2016 Gallup survey, 64% of Americans are “worried a ‘great deal’ or ‘fair amount'” about global warming:
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Public Opinion on Climate Change
FACT1: A majority of people around the world believe that climate change is a serious problem that requires immediate action. In the United States, a majority of Americans also believe that climate change is happening and that it is caused by human activities.
MYTH: The public is not concerned about climate change.
FALLACY: The statement is a hasty generalization, as it is not supported by evidence. Polls show that a majority of people around the world believe that climate change is a serious problem that requires immediate action. The statement also ignores the fact that public opinion can be influenced by media coverage and political messaging.
FACT2: Let's not underestimate the importance of public opinion on climate change. It is crucial for policymakers to take into account the concerns and beliefs of the public when making decisions about climate policy. We can all play a role in raising awareness and advocating for action on climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “finding out how fast these glaciers will collapse is one of the most important scientific questions in the world today”
comment_by_fact-checker: There are many important science questions, but it is true that understanding the rate of ice loss at Pine Island and Thwaites Glaciers is very important for understanding how quickly future sea level rise will happen. Understanding Thwaites is arguably more important than Pine Island, though they are part of a connect region of ice. A recent peer-reviewed science article that takes a closer look at the question and explains the importance of understanding changes is Scambos et al, 2017*. Scambos et al (2017) How much, how fast?: A science review and outlook for research on the instability of Antarctica’s Thwaites Glacier in the 21st century, Global and Planetary Change
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The urgency of understanding glacier collapse
FACT1: Glaciers are melting at an alarming rate due to climate change, and understanding how fast they will collapse is crucial for predicting sea level rise and its impacts on coastal communities.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's support scientific research and efforts to mitigate climate change to prevent further glacier melting and sea level rise.

fact_checked_segment: “It seems self-evident that rising sea levels will reduce land area. However, there is a process of accretion, where coral broken up by the waves washes up on these low-lying islands as sand, counteracting the reduction in land mass. Research shows that this process is overpowering the erosion from sea-level rise, leading to net land-area gain.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It’s just plain wrong to assume that all atolls are washing away. It’s also wrong to sugar-coat the sobering facts that rising sea levels will ultimately seal the fate of low-lying islands and their limited soils and groundwater. The confusion isn’t surprising. It’s just more complicated than many expect.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Coral Accretion Counters Sea-Level Rise on Low-Lying Islands
FACT1: Coral broken up by waves washes up on low-lying islands as sand, counteracting the reduction in land mass caused by rising sea levels. Research shows that this process of accretion is overpowering the erosion from sea-level rise, leading to net land-area gain.
MYTH: Rising sea levels will inevitably reduce land area on low-lying islands.
FALLACY: This myth is an oversimplification that ignores the process of accretion, where coral broken up by waves washes up on low-lying islands as sand, counteracting the reduction in land mass caused by rising sea levels. This process has been shown to overpower the erosion from sea-level rise, leading to net land-area gain.
FACT2: Coral accretion is an important process that can help low-lying islands adapt to rising sea levels. Let's not overlook the potential of this process and continue to study and understand its effects.

fact_checked_segment: [subsidies for wind and solar] add to emissions because coal-fired elec­tricity needs to be on standby for when there is no wind or sunshine.
comment_by_fact-checker: Baseless and, in regions where this has been studied, false. For example, in Illinois1. And this ignores more efficient ways of reducing backup emissions, such as energy storage like batteries. 1- Valentino et al (2012) System-Wide Emissions Implications of Increased Wind Power Penetration, Environmental Science & Technology
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk: Wind and solar subsidies do not add to emissions because coal-fired electricity needs to be on standby for when there is no wind or sunshine. This is a common myth that is not supported by evidence. In fact, studies have shown that renewable energy sources like wind and solar can reduce emissions and improve air quality. While it is true that backup power sources are needed for times when wind and solar are not available, this does not negate the benefits of renewable energy. In fact, many countries are successfully integrating renewable energy into their grids and reducing their reliance on fossil fuels. Let's support the transition to clean energy and reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: The first adjustment changed how the temperature of the ocean surface is calculated, by replacing satellite data with drifting buoys and temperatures in ships’ water intake.
comment_by_fact-checker: This isn’t what happened. Satellite data was not replaced, it was never there in the first place. Independent satellite data confirmed that the new corrections are solid.1 1- Hausfather et al (2017) Assessing recent warming using instrumentally homogeneous sea surface temperature records, Science Advances
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: New method for measuring ocean surface temperature
FACT1: Scientists have replaced satellite data with drifting buoys and temperatures in ships’ water intake to measure the temperature of the ocean surface. This new method is more accurate and reliable than the previous one.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's trust the scientific community and their rigorous methods for measuring and analyzing data.

fact_checked_segment: Sadly, these supposed experts use mathematical equations that do not jibe with reality over the past 140 years.
comment_by_fact-checker: I would like to see the authors to provide the “mathematical equations” to which they refer.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The Reality of Mathematical Equations in Climate Science
FACT1: Climate scientists use mathematical models to understand and predict the Earth's climate. These models are based on physical laws and observations of the climate system, and are constantly being refined and improved.
MYTH: Mathematical equations used in climate science do not match up with reality over the past 140 years.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, as it focuses on a specific time period and ignores the overall accuracy of climate models. Climate models have been shown to accurately simulate past climate conditions and make accurate predictions about future climate change.
FACT2: Let's not dismiss the hard work and dedication of climate scientists who use mathematical models to better understand our planet's climate. These models are an important tool in predicting and mitigating the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Venus, which was once a very Earth-like planet with plenty of life-supporting water before runaway climate change rapidly transformed it into an arid and uninhabitable sphere enveloped in an unbreathable gas”
comment_by_fact-checker: My expertise is not in exoplanetary climate, but it is not a definitively accepted “fact” that Venus was once habitable. There is still considerable debate regarding the past habitability of Venus (see links below). Therefore, this statement (which appears to imply that Venus’s climate trajectory is foreshadowing for Earth’s) comes off way too strong. Way et al (2016) Was Venus the first habitable world of our solar system?, Geophysical Research Letters Chassefière et al (2012) The evolution of Venus: Present state of knowledge and future exploration, Planetary and Space Science
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Venus: A Planet Transformed by Runaway Climate Change
FACT1: Venus was once a planet with a similar environment to Earth, with water and a habitable climate. However, due to a runaway greenhouse effect, the planet's climate rapidly changed, causing the water to evaporate and the atmosphere to become thick with carbon dioxide, making it uninhabitable.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: This statement is not a fallacy, but rather a fact-based explanation of the transformation of Venus due to climate change. However, it is important to note that this example is not directly related to the current climate change on Earth, as the causes and effects are different.

FACT2: Understanding the transformation of Venus due to climate change can help us better understand the potential consequences of unchecked greenhouse gas emissions on Earth. Let's continue to study and address the causes of climate change to prevent a similar fate for our planet.

fact_checked_segment: One of the main areas of contention is the existence of two strange climate episodes known as The Medieval Warm Period (MWP) and the Little Ice Age. The MWP lasted from about 950 to 1250AD, and temperature records appear to show it was even hotter than today
comment_by_fact-checker: These periods are now well understood to be, at best, regional phenomena rather than global-scale changes. Indeed, it is the broad global nature of the recently observed changes that make them unusual. The realisation of these being largely regional phenomena centred on the N. Atlantic region has led to a growing deprecation of these terms.
label: red herring
debunk:
MYTH: The Medieval Warm Period (MWP) was hotter than today, and this proves that current global warming is natural and not caused by human activities.

FALLACY: This is a false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that because two things are alike in some ways, they are alike in some other respect. The MWP was a regional phenomenon that occurred mainly in the North Atlantic region, while current global warming is a global phenomenon caused by human activities. The MWP was also not as warm as today, as current global temperatures are the warmest they have been in at least 2,000 years.

FACT: The Medieval Warm Period (MWP) was a regional climate anomaly that occurred mainly in the North Atlantic region from about 950 to 1250AD. While temperatures were warmer than the preceding and following centuries, they were not as warm as today. Current global temperatures are the warmest they have been in at least 2,000 years, and this warming is caused by human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation.

Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: “For example, the Arctic heatwaves are made tens of times more likely and the soaring temperatures seen in Australia in February were made twice as likely.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement is referring to rapid attribution analyses that were conducted by the World Weather Attribution group. We found that the Arctic heat of late 2016 was made much more likely by human-induced climate change (although it remains a very unusual event in the current climate). In another analysis, we found the February heatwave in New South Wales was at least twice as likely to occur because of climate change.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change is Increasing the Likelihood of Extreme Weather Events
FACT1: Climate change is causing extreme weather events to become more frequent and severe. This includes heatwaves, droughts, floods, hurricanes, and wildfires. These events can have devastating impacts on human health, infrastructure, and the economy.
MYTH: Climate change is not causing extreme weather events.
FALLACY: The myth is based on a false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that because extreme weather events have occurred in the past, they must be natural and not caused by human activities. However, scientific evidence shows that climate change is increasing the likelihood and severity of these events.
FACT2: It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change. This includes transitioning to renewable energy, improving energy efficiency, and implementing policies to reduce emissions from transportation, industry, and agriculture. Let's take action to protect our planet and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: Their analysis calculates the existential climate-related security risk to Earth through a scenario set 30 years into the future.
comment_by_fact-checker: No, the report’s authors have merely read (or possibly seen without actually reading) a few of the scariest papers they could find, misunderstood (or not read properly) at least one of them, and presented unjustified statements.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change Poses an Existential Security Risk to Earth, Study Finds
FACT1: A recent study has found that climate change poses an existential security risk to Earth. The study uses a scenario set 30 years into the future to calculate the potential impact of climate change on the planet. The study argues that climate change could lead to a collapse of civilization and the end of human life as we know it.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to take action to address climate change and reduce its impact on the planet. This includes reducing greenhouse gas emissions, transitioning to renewable energy sources, and implementing policies to mitigate the effects of climate change. Let's work together to create a sustainable future for ourselves and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “The news comes amid mounting evidence that the recent run of world record high temperatures is about to end.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The modest decline in temperatures in the past few months is a normal reversion after the end of the El Niño event. It has relatively little impact on the longer-term warming trend, which is the most scientifically relevant metric of climate change.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: World Record High Temperatures About to End
FACT1: The Earth's climate is constantly changing, and temperature records are regularly broken. However, the recent run of world record high temperatures is not expected to continue indefinitely.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to continue monitoring and addressing the causes of climate change to mitigate its impacts and prevent further temperature increases. Let's work together to reduce our carbon footprint and protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “Sea level rise, which was occurring long before humans could be blamed, has not accelerated and still amounts to only 1 inch every ten years. If a major hurricane is approaching with a predicted storm surge of 10-14 feet, are you really going to worry about a sea level rise of 1 inch per decade?”
comment_by_fact-checker: Sea level rise is indeed accelerating and is currently tracking predictions that are consistent with a roughly 1 meter (3 foot) rise by the end of the century. We are already seeing bad effects in places like Miami Beach. And 1 meter makes a large difference, so if one is concerned about one’s descendants, then yes, it is something to worry about.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Insignificance of Sea Level Rise in the Face of Natural Disasters
FACT1: Sea level rise is a gradual increase in the average height of the ocean's surface, caused by the melting of glaciers and ice sheets and the thermal expansion of seawater due to global warming. It is currently occurring at a rate of about 1 inch every 10 years.
MYTH: Sea level rise is insignificant and not worth worrying about, especially in the face of natural disasters like hurricanes.
FALLACY: This argument uses the false equivalence fallacy by comparing the gradual and long-term process of sea level rise to the immediate and short-term threat of a hurricane. It also uses the cherry-picking fallacy by focusing on a single aspect of sea level rise (the rate of increase) while ignoring the potential long-term consequences, such as flooding and displacement of coastal communities.
FACT2: While it is true that sea level rise may not be an immediate threat in the face of a natural disaster like a hurricane, it is still a significant long-term issue that requires attention and action. Rising sea levels can lead to increased flooding, erosion, and loss of habitat for marine life, as well as displacement of coastal communities. It is important to address this issue through mitigation and adaptation measures to protect both people and the environment. Let's not dismiss the significance of sea level rise and take action to address it.

fact_checked_segment: Computer models of the climate are at the heart of calls to ban the cheap, reliable energy that powers our thriving economy and promotes healthier, longer lives.
comment_by_fact-checker: Assessments of climate change include many lines of evidence. In addition to computer models, observations of many aspects of the climate (e.g. changes in land and sea ice, sea level rise, temperature, humidity, etc.) and paleoclimate evidence is considered.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The Importance of Climate Models in Understanding Climate Change
FACT1: Climate models are essential tools used by scientists to understand how the Earth's climate system works and how it may change in the future. These models are based on fundamental principles of physics, chemistry, and biology, and are tested against observations of past and present climate conditions. They help us to understand the complex interactions between the atmosphere, oceans, land surface, and ice, and to make predictions about future climate scenarios.
MYTH: Climate models are unreliable and should not be used to inform policy decisions.
FALLACY: This statement is a form of the false equivalence fallacy, which incorrectly claims that two things are equivalent, despite notable differences between them. While it is true that climate models are not perfect and have uncertainties, they are still the best tools we have for understanding the Earth's climate system and making predictions about future climate scenarios. The scientific community has extensively tested and validated climate models, and they are continually being improved as new data and understanding become available. Ignoring the insights provided by climate models would be akin to ignoring the advice of a doctor who has diagnosed a serious illness.
FACT2: Let's not dismiss the importance of climate models in understanding climate change. By continuing to improve and refine these models, we can better understand the impacts of climate change and make informed decisions to mitigate its effects.

fact_checked_segment: “But the air is already so full of greenhouse gases that most land ice on the planet has started to melt.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Not sure how I would parse “most of the land ice has started to melt”.  It is true that there is net mass loss from most mountain glaciers, the Greenland Ice Sheet, and the West Antarctic ice sheet, which numerically makes most of the land ice. But, much of the ice remains too cold to melt, the big central region of East Antarctica is not melting, and much of the sea-level rise from the Antarctic is from faster flow into the ocean (after which the ice does melt…) rather than from melting in place.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Land ice is melting due to greenhouse gases
FACT1: Greenhouse gases are causing land ice to melt at an alarming rate. As the Earth's temperature rises, glaciers and ice sheets are melting, leading to rising sea levels and other environmental impacts. This is due to the fact that greenhouse gases trap heat in the atmosphere, leading to a warming planet. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: This statement is based on scientific evidence and is not a fallacy.
FACT2: It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in order to slow down the melting of land ice and mitigate the impacts of climate change. Let's work together to reduce our carbon footprint and protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “This chart gives you a good idea of the direction of the adjustments.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This chart does not show the adjustments. It shows an unsourced graph with the difference between two datasets. This is also due to increases in the amount of data used and thus also increases in coverage. In as far as the reason are adjustments, a likely reason would be the adjustments of the sea surface temperature that make global warming smaller. Older bucket measurements are cooler than modern buoy measurements because the water cools by evaporation between taking the bucket out of the water and reading the thermometer. In the past these adjustments were thought to be larger than modern estimates. So the “scandal” here would be that scientists were conservative in their early estimate of global warming.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding Data Adjustments in Climate Science
FACT1: Climate scientists often adjust raw data to correct for errors and biases, such as changes in measurement methods or urbanization effects. These adjustments are necessary to ensure accurate and consistent data over time.
MYTH: Data adjustments in climate science are made to manipulate the data and support a predetermined conclusion.
FALLACY: The fallacy underlying this myth is the false assumption that data adjustments are made to manipulate the data. In reality, adjustments are made to correct for known errors and biases in the raw data, and are subject to rigorous scientific scrutiny and peer review.
FACT2: Understanding the reasons for data adjustments in climate science can help us appreciate the importance of accurate and consistent data in understanding the impacts of climate change. Let's trust the scientific process and the experts who are working to ensure the accuracy of climate data.

fact_checked_segment: “‘The Arctic may be remote, but changes that occur there directly affect us. The melting of the Greenland ice sheet is already contributing significantly to sea level rise, and new research is highlighting that the melting of Arctic sea ice can alter weather conditions across Europe, Asia and North America.’”
comment_by_fact-checker: There is indeed observational evidence that melting of the Greenland ice sheet, which contributes to global sea level rise, has accelerated in recent years. While scientists are still intensively investigating the details, it is also true that recent research* suggests that the loss of Arctic sea ice will mostly likely influence weather patterns in mid-latitude regions (including much of Europe, Asia, and North America). Screen (2017) Far-flung effects of Arctic warming, Nature Geoscience
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The Arctic's Melting Ice Has Global Consequences
FACT1: The Arctic's melting ice has far-reaching consequences beyond the region. The melting of the Greenland ice sheet is already contributing significantly to sea level rise, and new research shows that the melting of Arctic sea ice can alter weather conditions across Europe, Asia, and North America. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It's important to recognize that the Arctic's melting ice has global consequences and take action to address the root causes of climate change. Let's work together to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: I chose to assess the sea-level trend from 1915-45
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a blatant case of cherry picking to confirm a Singer’s position while ignoring all other instrumental sea level data that may contradict that position. This fallacy is a major problem in public debate.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding the Sea-Level Trend from 1915-45
FACT1: The sea level trend from 1915-45 was relatively stable, with an average rise of 1.5 mm per year. This is in contrast to the more rapid rise in sea level observed in recent decades.
MYTH: Some people argue that the sea level trend from 1915-45 is evidence that current sea level rise is natural and not caused by human activities.
FALLACY: This argument is an example of the logical fallacy of cherry-picking. By focusing on a relatively stable period of sea level rise, this argument ignores the larger trend of accelerating sea level rise observed in recent decades. It also ignores the overwhelming scientific evidence that human activities, such as the burning of fossil fuels, are the primary cause of current sea level rise.
FACT2: It is important to consider the full context of sea level rise, including the larger trend of accelerating sea level rise and the overwhelming scientific evidence of human-caused climate change. Let's not use cherry-picked data to dismiss the urgent need for action to address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “More than half of the 44 studies selected for publication found that raised levels of CO2 had little or no impact on marine life, including crabs, limpets, sea urchins and sponges”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is crucial to understand exactly which species are and aren’t affected by Ocean Acidification, as that will determine how ecosystems will change through time. I will also point out that if this figure is correct, and 50% of organisms are unaffected by Ocean Acidification, 50% of organisms are affected by Ocean Acidification, which is a HUGE amount of marine life. It also neglects the fact that reefs themselves are most definitely affected, which creates and maintains the habitat for many of these other organisms in the first place.
label: strawman
debunk:
FACT1: CO2 levels have little or no impact on marine life, according to more than half of the 44 studies selected for publication. 

MYTH: None stated.

FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, where only a select few studies are used to support a particular claim while ignoring the larger body of evidence. While some studies may have found little impact of CO2 on marine life, many others have found significant negative impacts, such as ocean acidification, which can harm the growth and survival of many marine organisms.

FACT2: It is important to consider the full body of evidence when evaluating the impact of CO2 on marine life. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: “Federal scientists have documented a sharp jump in this nuisance flooding — often called ‘sunny-day flooding’ — along both the East Coast and the Gulf Coast in recent years. The sea is now so near the brim in many places that they believe the problem is likely to worsen quickly.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is accurate. Global sea levels have risen by about 20 cm due to human induced global warming in the last 100 years. Both US coasts have experienced this. It is true that subsidence on the east coast has exacerbated this and the last 20 years of natural variations on the west coast may have given folks a false sense of security because it has opposed or hidden the global rise experienced almost everywhere else.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Nuisance Flooding on the Rise
FACT1: Nuisance flooding, also known as "sunny-day flooding," has increased significantly along the East Coast and Gulf Coast in recent years. This type of flooding occurs during high tides and causes minor damage to infrastructure and property. The problem is expected to worsen as sea levels continue to rise.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's take action to address climate change and reduce greenhouse gas emissions to slow down sea level rise and mitigate the impacts of nuisance flooding.

fact_checked_segment: “Houlton has been exploring this possibility for years. Back in 2011, he reported that forest trees can tap into nitrogen found in rock. At the time, he said ‘the stunning finding that forests can also feed on nitrogen in rocks has the potential to change all projections related to climate change,’ because it meant there could be more carbon storage on land and less in the atmosphere than climate models say.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It should be noted that much of the Net Primary Productivity arises from grasses and other non-boreal sources. If only trees that are deep rooted enough to reach bedrock can tap this source then the potential is very much geographically limited.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Forests can obtain nitrogen from rocks, which can impact climate change projections.
FACT1: Forests can obtain nitrogen from rocks, which can impact climate change projections. This means that forests have the potential to store more carbon on land and less in the atmosphere than previously thought.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's continue to explore and research the ways in which forests can impact climate change and carbon storage. By understanding the complex interactions between forests and the environment, we can better address the challenges of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “about 56 million years ago … The planet proceeded to warm rapidly, at least in geologic terms, and major die-offs of some marine organisms followed due to strong acidification of the oceans.”
comment_by_fact-checker: There are several potential causes for the benthic extinctions that are seen in sediment cores. In addition to acidification, abrupt warming of bottom waters, decrease in dissolved oxygen and a potential decrease in food availability (raining down from surface layers) have been put forward in the past (e.g. Thomas [2003] Extinction and food at the seafloor…; Thomas [2007] Cenozoic mass extinctions in the deep sea…; Sluijs et al. [2007] The Palaeocene–Eocene Thermal Maximum super greenhouse…; McInerney and Wing [2011] The Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum: A Perturbation of Carbon Cycle, Climate, and Biosphere with Implications for the Future).
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Ocean Acidification and Extinctions
FACT1: About 56 million years ago, the Earth experienced a rapid warming event that led to major die-offs of some marine organisms due to strong acidification of the oceans. 
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Today, human activities are causing the oceans to acidify at a rate that is much faster than the natural processes that caused the acidification 56 million years ago. This is putting many marine organisms at risk of extinction. We can take action to reduce our carbon emissions and protect the health of our oceans.

fact_checked_segment: Did the Earth experience its highest temperature ever this year? The answer is no.
comment_by_fact-checker: Does this have any significant bearing on the steadily increasing ocean heat content and annual mean global surface temperature? The answer is no.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Earth's Highest Temperature Ever
FACT1: The Earth did not experience its highest temperature ever this year. In fact, the highest temperature ever recorded on Earth was 134 degrees Fahrenheit (56.7 degrees Celsius) in Furnace Creek Ranch, California, in 1913.
MYTH: The myth is that the Earth experienced its highest temperature ever this year.
FALLACY: The fallacy here is a misunderstanding of the difference between weather and climate. Weather refers to short-term atmospheric conditions, while climate refers to long-term patterns of temperature, precipitation, and other factors. While individual weather events can be extreme, they do not necessarily reflect long-term climate trends. Therefore, a single high temperature in one location does not indicate a global trend of increasing temperatures.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about the Earth experiencing its highest temperature ever this year. It's important to understand the difference between weather and climate and to rely on long-term data to understand global temperature trends.

fact_checked_segment: “Climate change? Global warming? What do we call it? […]You can think of global warming as one type of climate change. The broader term covers changes beyond warmer temperatures, such as shifting rainfall patterns.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a good way to describe the difference in language. It would also be reasonable to say that global warming (the increase in Earth’s average temperature) causes climate change (shifts in the location/frequency/intensity of weather patterns). In practice, the two terms are often used somewhat imprecisely and interchangeably (even in the scientific literature).
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change vs Global Warming: What's the Difference?
FACT1: Climate change and global warming are not interchangeable terms. Global warming refers specifically to the increase in Earth's average surface temperature, while climate change encompasses a broader range of changes in the Earth's climate system, including changes in precipitation patterns, sea level rise, and more frequent extreme weather events.
MYTH: Climate change and global warming are the same thing.
FALLACY: Ambiguity. Using ambiguous language in order to lead to a misleading conclusion. The myth is based on a misunderstanding of the difference between the two terms, which can lead to confusion and miscommunication about the nature and scope of the changes occurring in the Earth's climate system.
FACT2: Let's use these terms accurately to better understand and communicate the changes happening in our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “cold kills many more people than heat.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is cherry picking – even if it were true. Climate change is much more than just temperature. It also affects precipitation and the lack thereof – with consequences such as floods, mud slides, droughts, and wildfires. Furthermore, the cold is fairly limited to the high northern latitudes, … and not so many live there, but many more in the warm tropics… These rich countries also have the means to collect statistics. The poor developing countries often lack credible statistics, and I do not believe for a second that we have an estimate of all people who die from heat stress in Asia, Africa, and Latin America.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
FACT1: Both cold and heat can be dangerous, but cold temperatures are generally more deadly than hot temperatures. Cold weather can lead to hypothermia, frostbite, and other health problems, especially in vulnerable populations such as the elderly and homeless.

MYTH: The myth is that cold temperatures are not as dangerous as hot temperatures and that cold weather is not a significant health risk.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that two things are equivalent when they are not. While both cold and heat can be dangerous, they affect the body in different ways and have different health risks. Cold temperatures can lead to hypothermia, frostbite, and other health problems, while hot temperatures can cause heat stroke, dehydration, and other heat-related illnesses.

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about the dangers of cold weather. It is important to take precautions during cold weather, such as wearing warm clothing and staying indoors when possible, especially for vulnerable populations such as the elderly and homeless.

fact_checked_segment: as continents rise after the overlying ice has melted
comment_by_fact-checker: Glacial Isostatic Adjustment (GIA) also causes subsidence of the solid Earth surface in the regions located outside the margins of the former ice sheets (for instance, along the U.S. East coast, where GIA-related subsidence is exacerbating the effects of global mean sea level rise).
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Post-glacial rebound: Why continents are rising after the ice melts
FACT1: Post-glacial rebound is the process by which land masses rise after the weight of ice sheets has been removed. This is due to the fact that the Earth's mantle is viscous and responds to changes in surface loads. As the ice melts, the weight is removed, and the mantle slowly flows back into the space previously occupied by the ice, causing the land to rise.
MYTH: The rising of continents after the ice melts is not well understood and may be due to other factors.
FALLACY: The myth is based on a lack of understanding of the process of post-glacial rebound. While there are other factors that can affect land elevation, such as tectonic activity and erosion, post-glacial rebound is a well-established process that has been observed in many parts of the world. The myth may also be perpetuated by those who deny the existence of climate change and its effects on the Earth's systems.
FACT2: Understanding the process of post-glacial rebound is important for predicting future changes in land elevation and for understanding the effects of climate change on the Earth's systems. Let's continue to learn and educate others about this natural process.

fact_checked_segment: These examples all illustrate that cherry picking record high temperatures in isolated locations tells absolutely nothing about the Earth’s climate.
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a bizarre ending of this part of the article were the authors admit that their really bad method to study whether the weather becomes more extreme is a really bad method to study whether the weather becomes more extreme. Fortunately, scientist put in more effort to produce reliable knowledge. A good way to access what science knows about changes in extreme weather is the IPCC Special Report on Managing the Risks of Extreme Events and Disasters to Advance Climate Change Adaptation. The authors of this article would have saved the time of many readers had they read up on the state of the science.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Cherry Picking Record High Temperatures

FACT1: Cherry picking record high temperatures in isolated locations is not a reliable way to understand the Earth's climate. 

MYTH: Using isolated record high temperatures to argue against global warming.

FALLACY: Cherry picking fallacy. This fallacy involves selecting only the data that supports a particular argument while ignoring other data that contradicts it. In this case, cherry picking record high temperatures in isolated locations to argue against global warming ignores the overwhelming evidence of global warming from multiple sources and locations. 

FACT2: Instead of relying on isolated record high temperatures, we should look at the larger picture of global temperature trends and the overwhelming scientific consensus on the reality of human-caused climate change. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: “[…]an explanation of the fluctuations of the earth’s temperatures that global warming alarmists are going to make sure to bury: The cycle of changes in the climate over the millennia is a result of changes in the amount of solar radiation, in part caused by small changes in the orbits of Earth and Mars.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is the accepted explanation for periodic past changes in Earth’s climate. We spend multiple classes explaining this to our students. We certainly do not bury it.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Earth's Temperature Fluctuations are not Solely Caused by Changes in Solar Radiation
FACT1: The Earth's temperature is influenced by a variety of factors, including solar radiation, greenhouse gases, and natural climate cycles. While changes in solar radiation can contribute to temperature fluctuations, they are not the sole cause of climate change.
MYTH: Changes in the Earth's temperature are solely caused by changes in solar radiation due to changes in the Earth's orbit.
FALLACY: This statement is an oversimplification of the complex factors that contribute to climate change. While changes in solar radiation can contribute to temperature fluctuations, they are not the sole cause of climate change. The Earth's temperature is also influenced by greenhouse gases, natural climate cycles, and other factors.
FACT2: Climate change is a complex issue that requires a comprehensive understanding of the various factors that contribute to it. Let's not oversimplify the issue and instead seek to understand the full picture.

fact_checked_segment: “The WMO’s assessment of the climate in 2016, published on Tuesday, reports unprecedented heat across the globe, exceptionally low ice at both poles and surging sea-level rise.”
comment_by_fact-checker: “Surging” suggests that the faster sea level rise in 2016 has continued, whereas the surge was between Nov 2014 and Feb 2016, as indicated in WMO’s statement and in the data.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Unprecedented Climate Events in 2016
FACT1: In 2016, the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) reported unprecedented climate events, including record-breaking heat, low ice levels at both poles, and rising sea levels.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to recognize the severity of these events and take action to address climate change. Let's work towards reducing our carbon footprint and promoting sustainable practices to mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The warming will slow to a potentially manageable pace only when human emissions are reduced to zero.”
comment_by_fact-checker: he current understanding of interactions between the global carbon cycle and the climate system is that when global CO2 emissions are reduced to zero, the warming will remain approximately constant. This is very often confused by estimates of committed “warming in the pipeline” which instead of assuming that global emissions are reduced to zero, assume that concentrations (and therewith to a large degree forcing) are kept constant. Keeping CO2 concentrations constant would require continuous emissions of CO2 that perfectly counter the uptake by natural sinks. If CO2 emissions are reduced to zero, atmospheric CO2 concentrations will gradually decline. For heat-trapping emissions other than CO2, the requirement to reduce them to zero to stabilize warming depends on their residence time in the atmosphere. For gases and particles that only stay in the atmosphere for shorter time periods (days to a decade) achieving constant emissions would also achieve approximately stabilized warming.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Warming Will Continue Even with Reduced Emissions
FACT1: Climate change is caused by the accumulation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, primarily carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels. Even if we reduce emissions, the warming will continue for decades due to the long lifespan of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
MYTH: The warming will slow to a potentially manageable pace only when human emissions are reduced to zero.
FALLACY: This myth is based on a false dichotomy, presenting only two options when there are actually multiple possibilities. While reducing emissions is crucial to mitigating the worst impacts of climate change, it is not the only solution. We can also adapt to the changes that are already happening and invest in technologies to remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
FACT2: We need to take action to reduce emissions and adapt to the changes that are already happening. Let's work towards a sustainable future for ourselves and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “the researchers calculated that the impact of greenhouse gas emissions from wet soils, or wetlands, will be higher than from drier soils[…] This finding, if further confirmed, could reorient calculations of the overall potential of permafrost to worsen global warming over the coming century.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The statement is true and properly cautious about the results of the Knoblauch et al paper. The article could have included that the present estimate* for additional warming from the permafrost carbon feedback is on the order of 0.13–0.27 °C to give a more quantitative sense of the strength of the feedback. Shuur et al (2015) Climate change and the permafrost carbon feedback, Nature
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Wet soils may have a greater impact on greenhouse gas emissions than dry soils

FACT1: Wet soils, such as wetlands, may have a greater impact on greenhouse gas emissions than dry soils. This is because wet soils release more methane, a potent greenhouse gas, than dry soils. Methane is estimated to have a warming effect 28 times greater than carbon dioxide over a 100-year timescale.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: None.

FACT2: It is important to further confirm this finding in order to accurately calculate the overall potential of permafrost to worsen global warming over the coming century. Let's continue to study and understand the impact of wet soils on greenhouse gas emissions to inform effective climate action.

fact_checked_segment: “Climate change might be worse than thought after scientists find major mistake in water temperature readings The sea was much colder than previously thought, the study suggests, indicating that climate change is advancing at an unprecedented rate”
comment_by_fact-checker: Even if it were correct, there is no direct link between our understanding based on the method discussed in the paper and our understanding of the severity of future and present climate change. The paper does not find a “major mistake” but suggests there may be complications with ONE method used to reconstruct past ocean temperatures.
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: Study finds major mistake in water temperature readings
FACT1: A recent study has found that there was a major mistake in water temperature readings, indicating that the sea was much colder than previously thought. This mistake has led to an underestimation of the rate at which climate change is advancing.
MYTH: Climate change might be worse than thought due to a major mistake in water temperature readings.
FALLACY: The article uses the fallacy of cherry-picking by focusing on one study that found a mistake in water temperature readings and presenting it as evidence that climate change is worse than previously thought. This ignores the overwhelming evidence from multiple studies and sources that show the significant impact of climate change on our planet.
FACT2: Let's not be misled by cherry-picked studies and instead look at the overwhelming evidence from multiple sources that show the significant impact of climate change on our planet. It is important to take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “[Sea ice] also helps regulate the planet’s temperature by influencing the circulation of the atmosphere and ocean. It can affect weather in the U.S.”
comment_by_fact-checker: There is currently no consensus in the scientific community about the magnitude of Arctic-lower-latitudes teleconnections compared to other teleconnections (e.g. from the tropics). This statement has to be taken with caution.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: The Importance of Sea Ice in Regulating the Planet's Temperature
FACT1: Sea ice plays a crucial role in regulating the planet's temperature by influencing the circulation of the atmosphere and ocean. It helps to cool the planet by reflecting sunlight back into space, and it also helps to regulate ocean currents and weather patterns.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's recognize the importance of sea ice in regulating the planet's temperature and take action to protect it. We can reduce our carbon footprint, support policies that promote renewable energy, and advocate for stronger protections for our oceans and the Arctic.

fact_checked_segment: “Global human emissions are only 3 per cent of total annual emissions.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is purposely misleading. Others have commented appropriately. The global carbon budget provides an overview of sources and sinks of CO2 since 1880. Source: Global Carbon Project
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Human activities contribute significantly to the increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, which is causing global warming. 

MYTH: Global human emissions are only 3 per cent of total annual emissions.

FALLACY: This myth uses a misleading statistic to downplay the significant impact of human activities on climate change. While it is true that natural sources of greenhouse gases, such as volcanic eruptions and wildfires, also contribute to the total annual emissions, human activities are responsible for the majority of the increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. 

FACT2: Let's not be misled by this myth. We need to take responsibility for our actions and work towards reducing our carbon footprint to mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The research challenges the ways that researchers have worked out sea temperatures until now, meaning that they may be increasing quicker than previously suggested.”
comment_by_fact-checker: I don’t think there’s a link between alteration of deeply buried sediments in this study (i.e., oxygen isotope measurements from millions of years ago) and current rates of temperature increase (directly measured from satellites and weather stations). It may challenge the way we work out sea temperatures (although as I will note later the paper seriously overstates its case), but this doesn’t change the observed rates of change in the post-industrial era. This is inaccurately presented.
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: New Research Suggests Sea Temperatures May Be Increasing Faster Than Previously Thought
FACT1: Sea temperatures are rising at a faster rate than previously thought due to new research that challenges the methods used to measure them. This means that the impact of climate change on the oceans may be more severe than previously estimated.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to continue researching and monitoring the oceans to better understand the impact of climate change and take action to mitigate its effects. Let's support efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and protect our oceans.

fact_checked_segment: The knock-on consequences affect national security, as the scale of the challenges involved, such as pandemic disease outbreaks, are overwhelming. Armed conflicts over resources may become a reality, and have the potential to escalate into nuclear war. In the worst case scenario, a scale of destruction the authors say is beyond their capacity to model, there is a ‘high likelihood of human civilization coming to an end’.
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a highly questionable conclusion. The reference provided in the report is for the “Global Catastrophic Risks 2018” report from the “Global Challenges Foundation” and not peer-reviewed literature. (It is worth noting that this latter report also provides no peer-reviewed evidence to support this claim). Furthermore, if it is apparently beyond our capability to model these impacts, how can they assign a ‘high likelihood’ to this outcome? While it is true that warming of this magnitude would be catastrophic, making claims such as this without evidence serves only to undermine the trust the public will have in the science. Daniel Swain, Researcher, UCLA, and Research Fellow, National Center for Atmospheric Research: It seems that the eye-catching headline-level claims in the report stem almost entirely from these knock-on effects, which the authors themselves admit are “beyond their capacity to model.” Thus, from a scientific perspective, the purported “high likelihood of civilization coming to an end by 2050” is essentially personal speculation on the part of the report’s authors, rather than a clear conclusion drawn from rigorous assessment of the
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change Poses a Threat to National Security and Human Civilization
FACT1: Climate change is not just an environmental issue, but also a national security issue. The consequences of climate change, such as pandemics and armed conflicts over resources, can have devastating effects on human civilization. 
MYTH: Climate change is just an environmental issue and does not pose a threat to national security or human civilization. 
FALLACY: The myth is based on a false dichotomy that separates environmental issues from national security and human civilization. Climate change is a complex issue that affects multiple aspects of society, including the economy, public health, and international relations. Ignoring the security implications of climate change can lead to catastrophic consequences. 
FACT2: It is important to recognize the security implications of climate change and take action to mitigate its effects. Let's prioritize policies and actions that address the root causes of climate change and protect human civilization.

fact_checked_segment: “‘The interaction between Arctic ocean temperatures and the loss of ice formation leading to continuing record minimums is clearly a climate change signal,’ said Thomas Mote, a geography research professor at the University of Georgia.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Yes. The “ice-albedo feedback” has been evident in the Arctic for some years, contributing to “polar amplification”—the effect where polar latitudes warm at around twice the rate of the globe as a whole.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Arctic Ocean Temperatures and Ice Loss are Signals of Climate Change
FACT1: The Arctic Ocean is experiencing record minimum ice formation due to rising temperatures, which is a clear signal of climate change. This is according to Thomas Mote, a geography research professor at the University of Georgia.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to recognize the impact of rising temperatures on the Arctic Ocean and take action to address climate change. Let's support efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “To revisit the ocean’s paleotemperatures now, we need to carefully quantify this re-equilibration, which has been overlooked for too long. For that, we have to work on other types of marine organisms so that we clearly understand what took place in the sediment over geological time”
comment_by_fact-checker: Or use other temperature proxies to compare with the oxygen isotope data to see if they are consistent—which is what has been done for years.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Re-evaluating paleotemperatures in the ocean requires careful consideration of re-equilibration
FACT1: Re-evaluating paleotemperatures in the ocean requires careful consideration of re-equilibration, which has been overlooked for too long. This process needs to be quantified accurately to understand what took place in the sediment over geological time.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's not overlook the importance of re-equilibration in understanding paleotemperatures in the ocean. Accurately quantifying this process will help us gain a better understanding of the changes that have occurred over geological time.

fact_checked_segment: “It’s safe to say [the hot Arctic] is going to have a big impact, but it’s hard to say exactly how big right now.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement is unclear. Arctic warming will clearly have a strong impact on the midlatitudes in the future (certainly by the end of the century). Whether it has had a noticeable effect so far is a lot less clear.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Impact of a Hot Arctic
FACT1: The Arctic is experiencing unprecedented warming, with temperatures rising at twice the rate of the rest of the world. This warming is causing the ice to melt, sea levels to rise, and weather patterns to change. The full extent of the impact is not yet known, but it is clear that it will be significant.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to continue studying the effects of a hot Arctic and take action to mitigate its impact. Let's support efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and protect vulnerable Arctic ecosystems.

fact_checked_segment: “with some of the world’s most arable land turning quickly to desert”
comment_by_fact-checker: What regions? Is this a statement about the present, or the future? If about the present, I am unaware of major arable land regions currently facing desertification. Current drought trends—whether droughts, on the global scale, are increasing in extent and/or severity—and their future under global warming, is still somewhat uncertain and a topic of ongoing research.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Land degradation is a growing problem worldwide
FACT1: Land degradation is the decline in the quality of land, affecting its productivity and ability to support life. It is a growing problem worldwide, with an estimated 25% of the Earth's land surface affected by degradation. This can lead to desertification, soil erosion, and loss of biodiversity, among other issues. 
MYTH: None stated.
FALLACY: None stated.
FACT2: It is important to take action to prevent and reverse land degradation, such as implementing sustainable land management practices, reducing deforestation, and promoting reforestation and afforestation. Let's work towards protecting our land for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “many scientists were surprised when other researchers subsequently found that ringed and bearded seals (the primary prey of polar bears) north of the Bering Strait especially thrived with a longer open-water season, which is particularly conducive to fishing”
comment_by_fact-checker: The Chukchi sea is essentially all continental shelf and is probably the most productive of the Arctic Seas. This is in contrast to the Beaufort Sea which, beyond the very narrow continental shelf, is very unproductive. Recent research has shown that this tremendous productivity and the fact that, although ice has significantly retreated, bears there still have fewer ice free days over the shelf than in the Beaufort, can explain why Chukchi Sea polar bears have not yet declined like those in the Beaufort.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Longer Open-Water Season Benefits Ringed and Bearded Seals, the Primary Prey of Polar Bears
FACT1: Ringed and bearded seals, which are the primary prey of polar bears, thrive with a longer open-water season. This is because a longer open-water season is particularly conducive to fishing, which benefits these seals.
MYTH: The myth is not explicitly stated in this quote, but it may be that a longer open-water season is harmful to the Arctic ecosystem and its inhabitants, including polar bears.
FALLACY: The myth may be based on the false assumption that a longer open-water season is uniformly harmful to the Arctic ecosystem and its inhabitants. However, as this quote suggests, a longer open-water season can benefit certain species, such as ringed and bearded seals, which in turn can benefit other species, such as polar bears. This is an example of the false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that two things are equivalent despite notable differences between them.
FACT2: A longer open-water season can benefit certain species in the Arctic ecosystem, such as ringed and bearded seals, which can in turn benefit other species, such as polar bears. Let's not assume that a longer open-water season is uniformly harmful to the Arctic ecosystem and its inhabitants.

fact_checked_segment: “Peter Wadhams, professor of ocean physics at the University of Cambridge, predicted ‘global disaster’ from the demise of Arctic sea ice—in four years. He too, is eating crow.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Indeed. Wadham’s claims have been roundly refuted by the climate science community. They are certainly an example of exaggeration, but to suggest that they somehow represent the scientific mainstream is a great distortion. [See Climate Feedback review of the latest prediction by P. Wadhams]
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Arctic sea ice decline is not a myth
FACT1: Arctic sea ice is declining at an alarming rate, with the extent of sea ice in September 2020 being the second-lowest on record. This decline is due to human-caused climate change, which is causing the Arctic to warm at a rate twice as fast as the rest of the world. The loss of Arctic sea ice has significant consequences for the climate, wildlife, and people who live in the Arctic region.
MYTH: The myth is that the decline of Arctic sea ice is a myth, and that predictions of global disaster resulting from this decline have been proven wrong.
FALLACY: The myth is based on the logical fallacy of cherry-picking, which involves selectively choosing data that support a particular argument while ignoring other data that contradict it. While some specific predictions about the timing and extent of Arctic sea ice decline may have been inaccurate, the overall trend of Arctic sea ice decline is well-established and supported by scientific evidence. Focusing on individual predictions that may have been incorrect ignores the larger body of evidence that supports the reality of Arctic sea ice decline and its consequences.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about the decline of Arctic sea ice. The loss of Arctic sea ice is a real and pressing issue that requires urgent action to address the root cause of the problem: human-caused climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Underneath the permafrost there are sediments full of methane hydrates. When the permafrost goes, you release the pressure on top of these hydrates and the methane comes out of solution”
comment_by_fact-checker: It’s unclear what is meant by ‘permafrost goes’. Nothing particularly ‘goes’ anywhere, it just melts (and has been naturally melting due to post-Last Glacial Maximum sea level rise and the resulting thermal flux due to shelf inundation). Consequentially, I would not expect the pressure seen by the underlying hydrates to decrease if the overlying permafrost degrades. In fact in the real world it will probably increase due to anthropogenic sea level rise. So it will necessarily be an anthropogenic temperature pulse, not a pressure pulse that will destabilize methane hydrates under relic permafrost. Finally, methane molecules in hydrates is not ‘in solution’ but rather in the hydrate crystalline lattice.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Methane hydrates in permafrost
FACT1: Methane hydrates are a type of frozen gas that are found in permafrost and under the ocean floor. They are formed when methane gas is trapped in ice crystals. Methane is a potent greenhouse gas that is 28 times more effective at trapping heat than carbon dioxide over a 100-year timescale.
MYTH: Methane hydrates in permafrost are harmless.
FALLACY: The myth is based on a misunderstanding of the potential impact of methane hydrates in permafrost. When permafrost thaws, it can release methane into the atmosphere, which can contribute to global warming. Methane hydrates are a significant source of methane, and their release could accelerate climate change. However, it is important to note that the extent of this impact is still being studied and is not yet fully understood.
FACT2: Let's not underestimate the potential impact of methane hydrates in permafrost. It is important to continue researching and monitoring this issue to better understand and mitigate its effects on the environment.

fact_checked_segment: ” ‘You’ve only got to look at Singapore. It’s two-and-a-half times higher than the worst-case scenario for climate change, and it’s one of the most desirable cities in the world to live in.’ ”
comment_by_fact-checker: There is a study by Cannaby and colleagues from the UK Met Office on sea-level rise around Singapore*. They talk about vulnerable regions within 2 m of the sea level, and find a ‘worst-case’ sea-level rise of 0.74 ± 0.29 m by 2100, so I’d say this statement is not correct. Cannaby et al (2016) Projected sea level rise and changes in extreme storm surge and wave events during the 21st century in the region of Singapore, Ocean Science
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Singapore's High Sea Levels
FACT1: Singapore is a city-state located on an island with an average elevation of 15 meters above sea level. Due to its low-lying geography, Singapore is vulnerable to rising sea levels caused by climate change. 
MYTH: Singapore's high sea levels are not a problem because the city is desirable to live in.
FALLACY: This argument is a false equivalence fallacy, as it equates the desirability of a city with its vulnerability to climate change. Just because Singapore is a desirable city to live in does not mean that its high sea levels are not a problem. 
FACT2: Rising sea levels pose a significant threat to Singapore's infrastructure, economy, and population. It is important to acknowledge and address this issue to ensure the long-term sustainability and livability of the city. Let's prioritize taking action to mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Arctic sea ice is thicker than ever”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is wrong. Arctic sea-ice thickness in 2017 is actually at its lowest values compared to earlier years for which we have sufficient data coverage, see:
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Arctic sea ice thickness is not increasing
FACT1: Arctic sea ice thickness has been decreasing over the past few decades due to global warming. The Arctic sea ice is melting at an alarming rate, and the thickness of the ice has decreased by 40% since the 1980s. 
MYTH: Arctic sea ice is thicker than ever.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, where a small amount of data is selected to support a particular argument while ignoring the larger trend. While there may be some areas where the ice is thicker than in previous years, the overall trend is a significant decrease in ice thickness. 
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about the state of Arctic sea ice. The melting of Arctic sea ice has serious consequences for the planet, including rising sea levels and changes in weather patterns. It is important to acknowledge the reality of the situation and take action to address the root cause of the problem, which is global warming.

fact_checked_segment: “‘That isn’t going to sound horribly unmanageable. But remember for the northern hemisphere, for North America, the fact that the location in West Antarctica is where the action is amplifies that rate of sea level rise by up to an about additional 25 percent in a city like Boston or New York.’ That’s because as Antarctica’s mass shrinks, the ice sheet’s gravitational pull on the ocean relaxes somewhat, and the seas travel back across the globe to pile up far away — with U.S. coasts being one prime destination.”
comment_by_fact-checker: What Rob DeConto and Chris Mooney explain here are the “far-field” sea level rise effects of losing so much concentrated ice mass in West Antarctica. This loss of mass reduces the gravitational pull that Antarctica otherwise has on the ocean, causing more water to slosh away from the far South. This just so happens to have a maximum impact on both coasts of North America, as illustrated in the Climate Science Special Report released in 2017 as part of the 4th National Climate Assessment undertaken by US federal agencies and universities. Figure 12.1 in the Sea Level Rise chapter shows that an extra 1.4 feet per century of relative sea level rise can be expected for North America (data originally from Kopp et al*), coming largely from the two largest West Antarctic glaciers—Pine Island and Thwaites Glaciers. Figure – Regional sea level rise patterns for ice loss from Greenland Ice Sheet (GIS), West Antarctica Ice Sheet (WAIS), East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS), and movement of continental crust (GIA).(Source: US NCA) Kopp et al (2014) Probabilistic 21st and 22nd century sea‐level projections at a global network of tide‐gauge sites, Earth’s Future
label: false cause
debunk: Antarctica's melting ice sheet is causing sea levels to rise, and this rise is amplified in North America due to the location of West Antarctica. As the ice sheet loses mass, its gravitational pull on the ocean weakens, causing the seas to pile up in other parts of the world, including the coasts of the United States. This can result in an additional 25% increase in the rate of sea level rise in cities like Boston or New York. This is not a myth, but a fact supported by scientific evidence.

fact_checked_segment: “Because the collapse of vulnerable parts of the ice sheet could raise the sea level dramatically, the continued existence of the world’s great coastal cities — Miami, New York, Shanghai and many more — is tied to Antarctica’s fate.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The vulnerable parts of the ice sheet are those that resting on beds that are below sea level; therefore, the ice itself is in contact with a warming ocean. The majority of the West Antarctic and ~30% of the East Antarctic sectors of the ice sheet are grounded below sea level.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The fate of coastal cities is tied to Antarctica's ice sheet
FACT1: The stability of Antarctica's ice sheet is crucial for the survival of coastal cities such as Miami, New York, and Shanghai. If vulnerable parts of the ice sheet collapse, it could lead to a dramatic rise in sea levels, which would threaten the existence of these cities. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to take action to address climate change and reduce greenhouse gas emissions to prevent the collapse of the Antarctic ice sheet and protect coastal cities. Let's work together to protect our planet and ensure a sustainable future for all.

fact_checked_segment: Yes, you read that correctly, three million — million — years ago CO2 levels on Earth were the same as they are today, but there is one major difference between three million years ago and today…
comment_by_fact-checker: The author writes this as if this is something that is a surprise. We all know that the Earth’s CO2 levels were higher at various times in the past. In the Eocene, 50 million years ago, they may have even been four times as high. This is not an issue. In the past, rates of volcanic CO2 emissions globally were higher as continental spreading rates changed, for example. Saying that CO2 isn’t rising now due to humans just because it used to be high in the past is like saying “I didn’t chop the cherry tree down because 40 years ago there was never a cherry tree there”. It is totally unrelated.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: CO2 levels on Earth were the same three million years ago, but there is a major difference today
FACT1: CO2 levels on Earth were the same three million years ago as they are today, but the Earth was a very different place. The average global temperature was 3-4°C warmer, sea levels were 10-20 meters higher, and there were no ice sheets in the northern hemisphere.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: This argument commits the fallacy of false equivalence. It assumes that because CO2 levels were the same three million years ago as they are today, the Earth's climate must be the same. However, this ignores the fact that the Earth's climate is a complex system that is influenced by many factors, including the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, the position of the continents, and the amount of solar radiation the Earth receives.
FACT2: Let's not oversimplify the Earth's climate system. While CO2 levels were the same three million years ago as they are today, the Earth was a very different place. We need to consider all the factors that influence the Earth's climate in order to understand how it will respond to increasing levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.

fact_checked_segment: “The Greenland ice cap last winter increased in volume faster than at any time for years.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is not per se completely incorrect, but the author does not tell us the whole story. The author refers to the growing of the ice sheet volume through snowfall throughout winter. The snow accumulated on Greenland in past winter (September-April) has indeed been remarkably high: However, this does not imply that the volume of the ice sheet is increasing, because (1) the ice sheet also loses ice through discharging icebergs; it is the difference between snowfall-driven growth and solid ice discharge that determines if the ice sheet gains or loses volume, and (2) the snow that accumulated during the winter will (at least partly) melt over the summer. That’s why we analyse changes to the ice sheet volume/mass on (at least) annual time scales. Only after the summer we will know how much of the accumulated snow has (not) been melted. uring the past years, the amount of melting has been record-high, and much of snow that accumulated over the winter melted and ran off into the ocean. Concurrently, ice discharge continued, so the Greenland ice sheet LOST considerable volume. We will know in September how much the ice sheet has changed volume this year. Two additional remarks: (a) The word “faster” should not have been used here. We are not talking about the rate of speed, but rather about the total change in volume. Also, it is easier to talk about “mass changes” than “volume changes” since the former is not sensitive to the density of the medium we are talking about (snow has a lower density than ice!). (b) The enhanced snowfall, ironically, is most probably also a signal of the strongly warming Arctic: as the atmosphere warms, it contains more moisture, and generates more precipitation. Also, record-low fall and winter sea ice extent led to large streaks of open water that might have contributed to additional moisture loading of the air.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Greenland's Ice Cap is Melting Despite Winter Gains
FACT1: Greenland's ice sheet is melting at an alarming rate, contributing to rising sea levels. While it is true that the ice cap increased in volume last winter, this is a temporary and insignificant gain compared to the overall trend of melting.
MYTH: The Greenland ice cap is not melting because it gained volume last winter.
FALLACY: This statement uses the cherry-picking fallacy by focusing on a single event (the winter gain) while ignoring the larger trend of melting. It also uses the ambiguity fallacy by not providing context for the winter gain, which was caused by increased snowfall rather than a decrease in melting.
FACT2: Let's not be misled by temporary gains in the ice cap. The overall trend is clear: Greenland's ice sheet is melting at an alarming rate, and we need to take action to address the causes of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “But other scientific authors have expressed considerable skepticism of these kinds of ideas in the past. A recent study in Nature Geoscience, for instance, called into question whether the Arctic’s melting, and in particular its sea ice loss, has been causing winter cooling over Eurasia, another idea that has been swept up in the debate over the jet stream and weather extremes.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Again, the debate has been about Arctic amplification and winter storm behavior, so this is somewhat misleading. It gives the impression that the new study tacitly pushes the debate about the winter storms toward the Francis/Vavrus side.
label: strawman
debunk:
Misrepresentation: The quote suggests that there is significant scientific disagreement about whether Arctic melting and sea ice loss are causing winter cooling over Eurasia. However, the study cited in Nature Geoscience does not dispute the fact that Arctic melting is causing global warming and climate change. Instead, it questions the specific mechanism by which Arctic melting affects winter weather patterns over Eurasia. This is a nuanced scientific debate that does not undermine the overwhelming evidence for human-caused climate change. 

FACT: The study cited in Nature Geoscience questions the specific mechanism by which Arctic melting affects winter weather patterns over Eurasia, but does not dispute the fact that Arctic melting is causing global warming and climate change. 

MYTH: There is significant scientific disagreement about whether Arctic melting and sea ice loss are causing winter cooling over Eurasia. 

FALLACY: Misrepresentation - the quote misrepresents the scientific debate by suggesting that there is significant disagreement about the basic fact of Arctic melting causing global warming and climate change. 

FACT: Let's not be misled by misrepresentations of scientific debates. The overwhelming evidence shows that Arctic melting is causing global warming and climate change, and we need to take action to address this urgent issue.

fact_checked_segment: when 3 per cent of total annual global emissions of carbon dioxide are from humans and Australia prod­uces 1.3 per cent of this 3 per cent, then no amount of emissions reductio­n here will have any effect on global climate.
comment_by_fact-checker: This is enormously misleading; humans are entirely responsible for the rapid increase in the greenhouse gas concentrations within the atmosphere over the last 150 years, primarily through the burning of fossil fuels.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Australia's contribution to global carbon dioxide emissions is small, but still significant. In 2019, Australia was responsible for 1.2% of global carbon dioxide emissions, which is the 16th highest in the world. While this may seem small, it is still a significant amount for a country with a relatively small population.

MYTH: Australia's carbon dioxide emissions are too small to have any impact on global climate, so reducing emissions in Australia is pointless.

FALLACY: This argument is a form of the "False Choice" fallacy, which presents two options as the only possibilities when other possibilities exist. While it is true that Australia's emissions are a small percentage of global emissions, it is still a significant amount that contributes to the overall problem of climate change. Every country has a responsibility to reduce their emissions, regardless of their size or contribution to the global total.

FACT2: Let's not use this argument as an excuse to avoid taking action on climate change. Every country, including Australia, has a responsibility to reduce their carbon dioxide emissions and take action to address the global problem of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “On the Pacific Coast, a climate pattern that had pushed billions of gallons of water toward Asia is now ending, so that in coming decades the sea is likely to rise quickly off states like Oregon and California.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement is likely to be accurate. Several papers already demonstrated the influence of decadal ENSO (El Niño) variations (or the Pacific Decadal Oscillation; PDO) onto the large-scale decadal sea-level variations in the Pacific Ocean (e.g. Zhang and Church 2012). Bromirski et al. (2011) specifically addressed the influence of decadal PDO/ENSO onto the west coast of America and demonstrated an influence of the PDO there, with a suppression of sea-level rise from the 80’s until 2005.
