As the decadal ENSO/PDO phase is reversing, there is over the past five years an accelerated sea-level rise over the west coast of America (Hamlington et al. 2016) that should continue in the next decade. Zhang and Church (2012) Sea level trends, interannual and decadal variability in the Pacific Ocean. Geophys Res Lett Bromirski et al. (2011) Multidecadal regional sea level shifts in the Pacific over 1958-2008. J Geophys Res. Hamlington et al. (2016) An ongoing shift in Pacific Ocean sea level. Journal of Geophysical Research: Oceans
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Sea levels are rising quickly off the Pacific Coast
FACT1: Sea levels off the Pacific Coast are projected to rise quickly in the coming decades due to the end of a climate pattern that had pushed water towards Asia. This rise in sea levels will have significant impacts on coastal communities, including increased flooding and erosion.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to take action to mitigate the impacts of rising sea levels, including reducing greenhouse gas emissions and implementing adaptation measures such as building sea walls and relocating infrastructure away from the coast. Let's work together to protect our coastal communities.

fact_checked_segment: “The ongoing global bleaching event is the longest-lasting one ever observed, and only the third ever seen. It has occurred during the warmest year on record, which occurred in 2015, and the two most unusually mild months on Earth, which took place in January and February, respectively.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It should be emphasized to the readers that mass coral bleaching first turns up in scientific records in the early 1980s – with no reports prior to that. Over time, mass coral bleaching and mortality has expanded in frequency and severity, with three truly global events being recorded so far – 1998, 2010, and 2016. The apparent shortening of the interval between global events is of great concern and suggests that anything we can do now to avoid further increases in carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere will save very substantial amounts in lost income and livelihoods from subsistence as well as industries such as fishing and tourism. This is an issue of food security – the effects of which are already occurring and which are growing more serious by the day.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Global Bleaching Event: A Threat to Coral Reefs
FACT1: Coral reefs are facing a global bleaching event, which is the longest and third-ever observed. This event is happening during the warmest year on record, 2015, and the two most unusually mild months on Earth, January and February.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: The global bleaching event is a result of the unusually warm ocean temperatures caused by climate change. When corals are exposed to high temperatures, they expel the algae living in their tissues, causing them to turn white or "bleach." This process weakens the corals and makes them more susceptible to disease and death. The fallacy is that the bleaching event is a natural occurrence and not caused by human activities.

FACT2: Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and protect coral reefs. We can reduce our carbon emissions by using public transportation, walking, or biking instead of driving, and by using energy-efficient appliances and light bulbs. We can also support organizations that work to protect coral reefs and their ecosystems.

fact_checked_segment: But-but-but-but Alexandria Ocasio-Crazy told me we only have 12 years!
comment_by_fact-checker: This confuses the time left to start seriously cutting emissions, with the long tail of impacts that those emissions have. As noted above in this article, there are lags in the climate system that mean CO2 emissions now will continue to warm the planet for a long time, and some long-acting positive feedbacks (like ice melting) take time.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The urgency of addressing climate change
FACT1: Climate change is a pressing issue that requires immediate action to mitigate its impacts. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has warned that we need to limit global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels to avoid the worst impacts of climate change, and that we have a limited window of time to achieve this goal.
MYTH: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez claimed that we only have 12 years to address climate change.
FALLACY: This myth is a misinterpretation of a statement made by Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who was referring to the urgent need to take action on climate change. The IPCC report states that we need to make significant changes to our energy systems and reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 45% by 2030 to limit global warming to 1.5°C. This means that we have a limited window of time to take action, and that urgent action is needed to avoid the worst impacts of climate change.
FACT2: It is important to recognize the urgency of addressing climate change and take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, transition to renewable energy sources, and implement policies to mitigate the impacts of climate change. Let's work together to create a sustainable future for ourselves and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “The ocean has accelerated and is now rising at a rate of about a foot per century[…] The risk is that the rate will increase still more. Scientists who study the Earth’s history say waters could rise by a foot per decade in a worst-case scenario, though that looks unlikely. Many experts believe that even if emissions stopped tomorrow, 15 or 20 feet of sea level rise is already inevitable, enough to flood many cities unless trillions of dollars are spent protecting them. How long it will take is unclear. But if emissions continue apace, the ultimate rise could be 80 or 100 feet.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is accurate to say sea-level rise is approximately one foot per century. Present-day sea-level rise is a major indicator of climate change. Since the early 1990s, sea level rose at a mean rate of ~3.1 mm/yr (~1 foot over 100 years). It is virtually certain that global mean sea level rise will continue for many centuries beyond 2100, with the amount of rise dependent on future emissions. The latest IPCC report estimates 1 to more than 3 m (up to ~10 feet) for high emission scenarios by 2300. But, those projections of sea-level rise may be limited by uncertainties surrounding the response of the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets. For example, the report projected a likely contribution of the Antarctic ice sheet (AIS) of -8 to +15 cm under the high emissions scenario by 2100, but a recent coupled ice sheet and climate dynamics model suggests that the AIS could contribute more than 1 m by 2100, and more than 10 m by 2300, under that high emissions scenario.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Rising Sea Levels: A Fact-Based Overview
FACT1: Sea levels are rising at an accelerating rate, with a current rate of about a foot per century. Even if emissions stopped tomorrow, 15 or 20 feet of sea level rise is already inevitable, which could flood many cities unless trillions of dollars are spent protecting them. 
MYTH: There is no significant rise in sea levels, and even if there is, it is not caused by human activities.
FALLACY: The myth is based on a false analogy, assuming that because sea levels have changed naturally in the past, the current rise must also be natural. However, scientific evidence shows that the current rise is primarily caused by human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation, which release greenhouse gases and warm the planet. 
FACT2: Let's not ignore the fact that sea levels are rising at an alarming rate, and it is primarily caused by human activities. We need to take action to reduce our carbon footprint and protect our cities from the inevitable rise in sea levels.

fact_checked_segment: “But observations, such as those on our CO2 Coalition website, show that increased CO2 levels over the next century will cause modest and beneficial warming—perhaps as much as one degree Celsius (1.8 degrees Fahrenheit)”
comment_by_fact-checker: That [1 °C warming] is an absolute best-case scenario, if significant mitigation action is taken urgently. Increased CO2 leads to warming, which leads to increased atmospheric water vapor, less ice, and other feedbacks. A doubling of CO2 concentrations would lead to about 3 °C warming. Timothy Osborn, Professor, University of East Anglia, and Director of Research, Climatic Research Unit: Projections of future warming can’t be made from observations alone: we need understanding of the mechanisms and physical processes. Neither of these are provided by the quoted website, which instead contains inaccurate articles about supposed adjustments to temperature data and claiming a new ‘little ice age’ is already here—both of which have been shown to be incorrect by scientific research. (For example, section 1.3.2 of the Fourth Assessment Working Group I IPCC report compared global temperature records from various vintages and found broad consistency.)
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Increased CO2 levels will cause modest and beneficial warming
FACT1: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is a greenhouse gas that traps heat in the atmosphere, leading to global warming. Increased levels of CO2 in the atmosphere will cause warming, but the extent of the warming depends on the amount of CO2 emitted and other factors. 
MYTH: Increased CO2 levels will cause only modest and beneficial warming.
FALLACY: This statement is an oversimplification of the complex relationship between CO2 and global warming. While it is true that some warming may be beneficial in certain regions, the overall impact of global warming is negative and far-reaching, including rising sea levels, more frequent and severe weather events, and damage to ecosystems and human health. Additionally, the statement ignores the fact that the rate of warming is accelerating and that the impacts of global warming will be felt for centuries to come.
FACT2: Let's not downplay the serious consequences of global warming. We should take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The chain of events that links the melting Arctic with weather to the south begins with rising global temperatures causing more sea ice to melt. Unlike on the Antarctic continent, melting ice here exposes dark ocean beneath, which absorbs more sunlight than ice and warms further. This feedback loop is why the Arctic is heating up much faster than the rest of the planet.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement correctly identifies how the sea ice-albedo feedback contributes to Arctic temperature amplification, but incorrectly implies that it is the only process responsible for the enhanced warming. While some studies have concluded that the sea ice-albedo feedback is the primary driver of Arctic amplification [1-2]​​, other feedbacks [3-4]​​, internal atmospheric variability, and decadal variations in sea surface temperature and ocean circulation [​5]​​, may have contributed as much, if not more, to the Arctic tropospheric temperature increase. 1. Screen and Simmonds (2010) The central role of diminishing sea ice in recent Arctic temperature amplification, Nature 2. Taylor et al. (2014) A Decomposition of Feedback Contributions to Polar Warming Amplification, Journal of Climate 3. Pithan and Mauritsen (2014) Arctic amplification dominated by temperature feedbacks in contemporary climate models, Nature Geoscience 4. Winton (2006) Amplified Arctic climate change: What does surface albedo feedback have to do with it?, Geophysical Research Letters 5. Perlwitz et al. (2015) Arctic Tropospheric Warming: Causes and Linkages to Lower Latitudes,
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: The Arctic is heating up faster than the rest of the planet due to a feedback loop caused by melting sea ice.
FACT1: The Arctic is experiencing more rapid warming than any other region on Earth due to a feedback loop caused by melting sea ice. As global temperatures rise, more sea ice melts, exposing dark ocean beneath. This dark ocean absorbs more sunlight than ice, causing further warming and melting in a self-reinforcing cycle.
MYTH: The Arctic is not warming faster than the rest of the planet.
FALLACY: The myth is a case of cherry-picking data, as it focuses on global temperature averages rather than regional differences. While global temperatures have risen by about 1 degree Celsius since pre-industrial times, the Arctic has warmed by more than twice that amount. This is due to the feedback loop caused by melting sea ice, which amplifies warming in the region.
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the reality of the Arctic's rapid warming and take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and slow the pace of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: the data does not support the claim that the United States is hotter than ever as a result of rising Carbon dioxide levels
comment_by_fact-checker: This would be claim about the average temperature of America and would normally refer to the annual average temperature—that does not follow from summer maximum temperature records.
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: Is the United States hotter than ever due to rising CO2 levels?

FACT1: The United States has experienced an increase in average temperatures over the past century, with the warmest years occurring in the last few decades. However, this increase cannot be solely attributed to rising CO2 levels.

MYTH: The myth is that the United States is hotter than ever due to rising CO2 levels.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, as it focuses on a single aspect of climate change (temperature) while ignoring other important factors such as sea level rise, ocean acidification, and extreme weather events. It also ignores the fact that temperature increases are caused by a complex set of factors, including natural variability and human activities other than CO2 emissions.

FACT2: While rising CO2 levels are contributing to global warming, it is important to consider the full range of evidence when evaluating claims about climate change. Let's not oversimplify the issue and instead rely on scientific evidence to inform our understanding of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Already, scientists know enough to be concerned. About 120,000 years ago, before the last ice age, the planet went through a natural warm period, with temperatures similar to those expected in coming decades. The sea level was 20 to 30 feet higher than it is today, implying that the ice sheets in both Greenland and Antarctica must have partly disintegrated, a warning of what could occur in the relatively near future if the heating of the planet continues unchecked.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Although factually correct, the information provided is not sufficient to convey the relevance of sea level during this previous warm period (the previous interglacial) to the current global warming situation. It is not directly analogous because of differences in the Earth’s orbit and the long timescale during which the ice sheet melt was exposed to the warmer temperatures. IPCC AR5 WGI Summary for Policy Makers section B4 notes these two relevant issues: “This change in sea level occurred in the context of different orbital forcing and with high-latitude surface temperature, averaged over several thousand years, at least 2°C warmer than present”. IPCC (2013) Climate Change 2013: The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of Working Group I to the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Rising Sea Levels and Past Climate Change
FACT1: The Earth has experienced natural warm periods in the past, such as 120,000 years ago, before the last ice age. During this time, temperatures were similar to those expected in the coming decades, and the sea level was 20 to 30 feet higher than it is today. This suggests that the ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica must have partially disintegrated, which could happen again if the planet continues to heat up unchecked.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to take action to address climate change and prevent further warming of the planet to avoid the potential consequences of rising sea levels. Let's work together to reduce our carbon footprint and protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “But scientific research indicates the world was last this warm about 115,000 years ago and that the planet has not experienced such high levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere for 4m years.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement is overly confident and not based on a broad consensus in the literature. Even the cited study states “we cannot be certain that the current year is warmer than any single year earlier in the Holocene due to centennial smoothing of the Holocene stack and original resolution of the underlying proxy records”. The most recent IPCC assessment indicates only moderate confidence that 1983-2012 was the warmest 30-year period in the last 1,400 years and limited this to the Northern Hemisphere rather than the global average.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The Earth is experiencing unprecedented warming and high levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
FACT1: The Earth is currently experiencing warming and high levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which are unprecedented in recent history. Scientific research indicates that the last time the Earth was this warm was about 115,000 years ago, and the planet has not experienced such high levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere for 4 million years.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change. Let's work together to protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “‘If you remove the ice shelf, there’s a potential that not just ice-cliff instabilities will start occurring, but a process called marine ice-sheet instabilities,’ says Matthew Wise, a polar scientist at the University of Cambridge. This signals the possible rapid destabilization of the entire West Antarctic ice sheet in this century.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Multiple studies have indicated that the marine ice sheet instability is likely already underway in the Pine Island region1,2. There has been no evidence to suggest that the loss of ice from this region will stop. However, that the loss of ice from marine ice sheet instability is underway does NOT mean that the entire West Antarctic Ice Sheet will destabilize this century. There is no evidence for the ice loss to occur that quickly. 1- Joughin et al (2014) Marine Ice Sheet Collapse Potentially Under Way for the Thwaites Glacier Basin, West Antarctica, Science 2- Rignot et al (2014) Widespread, rapid grounding line retreat of Pine Island, Thwaites, Smith, and Kohler glaciers, West Antarctica, from 1992 to 2011, Geophysical Research Letters
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The potential destabilization of the West Antarctic ice sheet
FACT1: The West Antarctic ice sheet is at risk of destabilization due to the potential removal of the ice shelf, which could trigger a process called marine ice-sheet instabilities. This could lead to rapid destabilization of the entire ice sheet in this century.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to take action to mitigate climate change and reduce greenhouse gas emissions to prevent further melting of the West Antarctic ice sheet. Let's work towards a sustainable future for our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “This means the global temperature trend has now shown no further warming for 19 years”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement is false. Global temperatures continue their long-term warming trend.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Global Temperature Trend Has Not Shown No Further Warming for 19 Years
FACT1: The global temperature trend has continued to rise over the past 19 years, despite claims to the contrary. In fact, 2016 was the hottest year on record, and the five hottest years on record have all occurred since 2010.
MYTH: A warning that a misunderstanding is coming. "This means the global temperature trend has now shown no further warming for 19 years."
FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, where a small amount of data is selected to support a particular argument while ignoring the larger trend. By focusing on a specific 19-year period, this statement ignores the overall trend of rising temperatures over the past century.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's focus on the overwhelming evidence that shows the Earth is warming and take action to address the causes and impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Global human emissions are only 3 per cent of total annual emissions.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Global human emissions are indeed only a small percentage of what ecosystems cycle, but the reasoning is completely flawed. Regarding the impact on climate, it is the net emissions that matter, not the amount of carbon that is being cycled over and over. Terrestrial ecosystems take up and re-emit about 12 times more CO2 than humans emit, and oceans cycle about 9 times more CO2 than we emit. BUT! This carbon uptake and release is more or less balanced at the annual scale, and net ecosystem emissions are even negative. Without these ecosystems, atmospheric CO2 concentration would have risen even more as a consequence of fossil fuel burning; the CO2 concentration in the air would already be around 550 ppm (instead of the current ~400 ppm). Hence, it is absolutely misleading to compare amounts of CO2 cycling through the ecosystems with human CO2 emissions in this context. If anything, the CO2 cycling through the ecosystems should be taken as a reason to safeguard them: if we lose these carbon sinks, CO2 in the air will increase no matter what we do.
label: red herring
debunk:
FACT1: Human activities contribute significantly to the increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, which is causing global warming. 

MYTH: Global human emissions are only 3 per cent of total annual emissions.

FALLACY: This myth uses a misleading statistic to downplay the significant impact of human activities on climate change. While it is true that natural sources of greenhouse gases, such as volcanic eruptions and wildfires, also contribute to the total annual emissions, human activities are responsible for the majority of the increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. 

FACT2: Let's not underestimate the impact of human activities on climate change. We can take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the effects of global warming.

fact_checked_segment: “[…]looking to the future, mass coral bleaching on the Great Barrier Reef will likely be an annual phenomenon within a decade, Torda said.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This may turn out to be true but most studies place annual bleaching, especially on the Great Barrier Reef, a bit further out—perhaps 2050. van Hooidonk et al (2013) Temporary refugia for coral reefs in a warming world, Nature Climate Change
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Mass coral bleaching on the Great Barrier Reef is becoming an annual phenomenon.
FACT1: Coral bleaching is a phenomenon that occurs when corals expel the algae that live in their tissues, causing the coral to turn white and making it more susceptible to disease and death. Mass coral bleaching events have become more frequent and severe due to climate change and warming ocean temperatures.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and protect the Great Barrier Reef from further damage. Let's support policies and practices that promote sustainability and protect our oceans.

fact_checked_segment: “the climate models have overestimated the amount of global warming and failed to predict what climatologists call the warming ‘hiatus’”
comment_by_fact-checker: Recent media headlines have again discussed the issue of whether climate models are overly sensitive to greenhouse gases. These headlines have misinterpreted a study by Millar et al. which was discussing carbon budgets to limit global temperature rise to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. A recent study by Medhaug et al. analysed the issue of how the models have performed against recent observations at length and largely reconciled the issue. An overly simplistic comparison of simulated global temperatures and observations might suggest that the models were warming too much, but this would be wrong for a number of reasons. In the Medhaug et al. paper they show the range of models (blue shading in figure with median in light blue), compared with the HadCRUT4 observations and their estimated uncertainty (orange shading with light orange line). There are a number of well understood reasons why the light orange line might not follow the light blue line, namely: radiative forcings, variability, observational biases and choice of reference period. [Read more…] Figure 5 from Medhaug et al. showing CMIP5 simulations and observations (HadCRUT4) of global temperature. Medhaug et al (2017) Reconciling controversies about the ‘global warming hiatus’, Nature
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Warming Hiatus is a Misunderstanding
FACT1: The Earth's climate has continued to warm over the past few decades, despite a temporary slowdown in the rate of warming from the late 1990s to the early 2010s. This slowdown, often referred to as the "warming hiatus," was caused by natural climate variability, such as changes in ocean circulation patterns and volcanic eruptions, and does not contradict the long-term trend of global warming.
MYTH: Warning that a misunderstanding is coming. "The climate models have overestimated the amount of global warming and failed to predict what climatologists call the warming 'hiatus.'"
FALLACY: The myth is based on cherry-picking a short-term trend and ignoring the long-term trend of global warming. The warming hiatus was a temporary slowdown in the rate of warming caused by natural climate variability, not a long-term cooling trend. Climate models have accurately predicted the long-term trend of global warming, and continue to do so.
FACT2: Let's not be misled by the warming hiatus myth. The long-term trend of global warming is clear and supported by scientific evidence.

fact_checked_segment: “Scientists used to think that ice sheets could take millennia to respond to changing climates”
comment_by_fact-checker: This was a common perspective before the era of satellite data that showed rapid changes on ice sheets.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Ice sheets can respond quickly to changing climates
FACT1: Ice sheets can respond to changing climates much faster than previously thought. Research has shown that ice sheets can respond within decades, rather than millennia, to changes in temperature and other environmental factors. This means that the effects of climate change on ice sheets can be seen much sooner than previously anticipated.
MYTH: Scientists used to think that ice sheets could take millennia to respond to changing climates.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false belief based on outdated information. It is a form of slothful induction, where relevant evidence is ignored when coming to a conclusion. The myth ignores recent research that has shown that ice sheets can respond much more quickly to changing climates than previously thought.
FACT2: Let's not underestimate the speed at which ice sheets can respond to changing climates. It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and slow the pace of climate change to prevent further damage to our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “That is especially bad because the Amazon alone provides 20 percent of our oxygen.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This sentence somehow implies that deforesting the Amazon would reduce atmospheric oxygen by 20%. This is not true. To quote Wally Broecker, who is cited later in the article: “Simply put, our atmosphere is endowed with such an enormous reserve of this gas that even if we were to burn all our fossil fuel reserves, all our trees, and all the organic matter stored in soils, we would use up only a few percent of the available O2. No matter how foolishly we treat our environmental heritage, we simply don’t have the capacity to put more than a small dent in our O2 supply. Furthermore, the Earth’s forests do not play a dominant role in maintaining O2 reserves, because they consume just as much of this gas as they produce. In the tropics, ants, termites, bacteria, and fungi eat nearly the entire photosynthetic O2 product. Only a tiny fraction of the organic matter they produce accumulates in swamps and soils or is carried down the rivers for burial on the sea floor.”
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Amazon Rainforest and Oxygen Production
FACT1: The Amazon Rainforest is a vital ecosystem that produces a significant amount of the world's oxygen. 
MYTH: A common myth is that the Amazon Rainforest provides 20% of the world's oxygen. 
FALLACY: This myth is an example of an appeal to emotion fallacy, as it plays on people's fears of losing a vital resource. While the Amazon Rainforest is important for oxygen production, it is not the only source of oxygen, and the 20% figure is an exaggeration. 
FACT2: While the exact amount of oxygen produced by the Amazon Rainforest is difficult to measure, it is estimated to be around 6% of the world's oxygen. It is important to protect the Amazon Rainforest and other ecosystems for their ecological value, but we should not rely on exaggerated claims to make the case for conservation.

fact_checked_segment: Globally averaged thermometers show two periods of warming since 1900: a half-degree from natural causes in the first half of the 20th century, before there was an increase in industrial carbon dioxide that was enough to produce it, and another half-degree in the last quarter of the century.
comment_by_fact-checker: The earlier warming (~0.3-0.4 °C) is about a third to a half of the warming since the 1970s (0.8-0.9 °C). They are not comparable, and selecting “the last quarter” of the 20th century to ignore the warming since 2000 misleads readers. Secondly, human activity was sufficient to cause warming in the first half of the 20th century.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: The Two Periods of Warming in the 20th Century
FACT1: The Earth's temperature has risen by half a degree Celsius in two periods of warming since 1900. The first period occurred in the first half of the 20th century due to natural causes, while the second period occurred in the last quarter of the century due to an increase in industrial carbon dioxide.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Understanding the two periods of warming in the 20th century is crucial to understanding the role of natural and human-caused factors in climate change. Let's continue to educate ourselves on the science of climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: More than 100 climate models over the past 30 years did not predict what actually happened because it was assumed carbon dioxide had the pivotal role in driving climate change and that the effects of clouds, back-radiation and the sun were trivial.
comment_by_fact-checker: Rather than take Plimer’s word for this, a quick google of climate model predictions (and some evaluation of the quality of sources) will lead you to actual comparison of early climate model projections versus observations. Plimer’s statement is simply not true, climate model projections have been surprisingly accurate despite the simplicity of early computer models. As for the relative contribution of various factors to this warming, carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases are indeed much more important than other factors like clouds and the sun. See excellent visuals of this here.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Role of Carbon Dioxide in Climate Change
FACT1: Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas that traps heat in the Earth's atmosphere, contributing to global warming. However, it is not the only factor that affects climate change. Other factors, such as clouds, back-radiation, and the sun, also play a role in driving climate change.
MYTH: A warning that a misunderstanding is coming. "Climate models did not predict what actually happened because carbon dioxide was assumed to be the only factor driving climate change."
FALLACY: This is a false cause fallacy, as it assumes that the failure of climate models to predict climate change is solely due to the assumption that carbon dioxide is the only factor driving climate change. In reality, climate models take into account a wide range of factors that affect climate change, including carbon dioxide, clouds, back-radiation, and the sun. The failure of some climate models to accurately predict climate change is due to the complexity of the Earth's climate system and the limitations of current modeling techniques.
FACT2: Let's not oversimplify the complex factors that contribute to climate change. It is important to continue to improve our understanding of the Earth's climate system and to develop more accurate climate models to inform policy decisions.

fact_checked_segment: Temperatures in the Southwest increased by nearly two degrees Fahrenheit (one degree Celsius) from 1901 to 2010, and some climate models forecast a total rise of six degrees or more by the end of this century.
comment_by_fact-checker: I checked various sources and these numbers are about right, an increase of almost 2 °F, or +0.17/decade1. Annual temperatures in New Mexico are projected to rise another 3.5 to 8.5°F by 21002. 1-Tebaldi et al (2012) The heat is on: U.S. temperature trends, Climate Central 2-NOAA Technical Report NESDIS 142-5 (2013) Regional Climate Trends and Scenarios for the U.S. National Climate Assessment. Part 5. Climate of the Southwest U.S.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Rising Temperatures in the Southwest
FACT1: Temperatures in the Southwest have increased by nearly two degrees Fahrenheit (one degree Celsius) from 1901 to 2010. Climate models predict a total rise of six degrees or more by the end of this century.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: Currently, sea-level rise does not seem to depend on ocean temperature, and certainly not on CO2.
comment_by_fact-checker: There is a clear relationship between the accelerating rate of sea-level rise and the increasing global temperature, which is shown in this post (e.g. in Figure 3).
label: post hoc
debunk:
TITLE: Sea-level rise is not caused by ocean temperature or CO2
FACT1: Sea-level rise is primarily caused by the melting of glaciers and ice sheets, which is in turn caused by global warming. This warming is caused by the increase in greenhouse gases, including CO2, in the atmosphere. Ocean temperature does play a role in sea-level rise, but it is not the primary cause.
MYTH: Sea-level rise is not caused by ocean temperature or CO2.
FALLACY: This statement is a false dichotomy, presenting only two options when there are actually multiple factors that contribute to sea-level rise. It also ignores the overwhelming scientific consensus that global warming, caused by the increase in greenhouse gases, is the primary cause of sea-level rise.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about the causes of sea-level rise. It is important to understand the complex factors that contribute to this issue in order to address it effectively.

fact_checked_segment: “Moreover, its warming impact decreases sharply after the first 20 or 30 ppm. Adding more CO2 molecules to the atmosphere is like painting over a red wall with white paint — the first coat does most of the work of concealing the red. A second coat of paint has much less of an effect, while adding a third or fourth coat has almost no impact at all.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is flawed reasoning as it is not a sensible analogy for how the greenhouse effect works. The science is more complex: Namely, radiation from the surface at a warmer temperature is absorbed in the layers above which are at a colder temperature; the colder layers emit less radiation so that there is a net loss of radiative energy escaping to space from the atmosphere-surface system as a whole, but coming about due to the “exchange” as formulated. This is true in absorption bands that are transparent and not opaque—i.e., in bands that are not saturated. In bands that are opaque, the radiation emanating from the layer to space represents a “cooling-to-space” and this too represents a “trapping”. In this regard, the lapse-rate and decrease of temperature with height (in the troposphere) are important. The more CO2 that is added to the atmosphere, the more heat that is “trapped” in the climate system, although it is not 1:1 and is instead a logarithmic relationship. However, regardless of the rate, we still have more warming with more CO2—that is unequivocally true.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Diminishing Returns of CO2
FACT1: CO2 has a diminishing warming effect as its concentration increases in the atmosphere. The first 20-30 ppm of CO2 has the most significant impact on warming, while additional CO2 has a decreasing effect. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: This statement is an accurate representation of the scientific understanding of the warming effect of CO2. However, it is important to note that while the warming effect of CO2 may diminish with increasing concentrations, it does not mean that adding more CO2 to the atmosphere will not have any impact on global temperatures. In fact, even small increases in CO2 concentrations can have significant impacts on the climate. 
FACT2: It is important to continue to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to limit the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere and mitigate the impacts of climate change. Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and transition to cleaner energy sources.

fact_checked_segment: “At the bottom of the world, sea ice is also at all-time record low levels around Antarctica, the data center said. The lack of ice in the Antarctic, where it is currently summer, is most pronounced in the Amundsen Sea, where only a few scattered patches of ice remain.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This short example reveals why sea ice extent is a useful, but not sufficient diagnostic to characterize the recent sea ice variability.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Antarctic Sea Ice Reaches Record Low
FACT1: The sea ice around Antarctica has reached an all-time record low level, particularly in the Amundsen Sea, where only a few scattered patches of ice remain. This is due to a combination of natural variability and human-caused climate change, which has led to warmer ocean temperatures and reduced ice formation. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to recognize the impact of human-caused climate change on the Antarctic sea ice and take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Let's work towards a sustainable future to protect our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “‘Continued investment in climate research and observations is vital if our scientific knowledge is to keep pace with the rapid rate of climate change.’”
comment_by_fact-checker: Correct. We are learning as we go, observing how the climate is changing, but more effort is required to keep up with changes and to understand the physical processes at play.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Climate research and observations are crucial to keep up with the fast pace of climate change. 

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: None.

FACT2: Let's support continued investment in climate research and observations to better understand and address the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: since 1979 to the most reliable observations — those made by satellites and weather balloons over the vast tropics.
comment_by_fact-checker: These are not the “most reliable” observations. They have the largest issues with lack of independent data to check against, and different groups come up with temperature trends that are far more different than the surface temperature records.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: The Most Reliable Observations of Global Temperature Trends
FACT1: Satellites and weather balloons provide the most reliable observations of global temperature trends since 1979. These observations cover the vast tropics and are not subject to the biases and errors that can occur with surface temperature measurements.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's trust the most reliable observations of global temperature trends and use them to inform our understanding of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “In a new study out last month in the journal Nature, a team of scientists from Cambridge and Sweden point to evidence from thousands of scratches left by ancient icebergs on the ocean floor, indicating that Pine Island’s glaciers shattered in a relatively short amount of time at the end of the last ice age.”
comment_by_fact-checker: As noted earlier, I think there is still some disagreement on whether these are conclusive results.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Pine Island Glacier Melted Rapidly at the End of the Last Ice Age
FACT1: Pine Island Glacier, located in Antarctica, melted rapidly at the end of the last ice age. This is supported by evidence from thousands of scratches left by ancient icebergs on the ocean floor, according to a study published in the journal Nature.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's continue to study and understand the effects of climate change on our planet, including the melting of glaciers, in order to take action to mitigate its impact.

fact_checked_segment: They failed to predict a decadelong [sic] pause in global temperatures.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Individual runs of individual models did capture such behaviour as has been shown by a wealth of literature on the topic. On a decadal scale, natural variability plays an important role, as can short-lived forcing effects. The scientific community has a substantial understanding of the “pause” and its causes. This understanding builds rather than diminishes confidence in the climate models.
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: The Misleading Claim of a "Pause" in Global Temperatures
FACT1: Global temperatures have been steadily increasing over the past century, with the last decade being the warmest on record. While there have been short-term fluctuations, there has been no long-term "pause" in global warming.
MYTH: The claim that there has been a "pause" in global temperatures, implying that global warming has stopped or slowed down.
FALLACY: This claim is an example of cherry-picking, where short-term fluctuations are used to misrepresent the long-term trend. The fact is that global temperatures have been steadily increasing over the past century, with the last decade being the warmest on record. The "pause" claim also ignores the fact that the oceans have continued to warm during this period, and that other indicators of climate change, such as melting glaciers and sea ice, have continued to show a clear trend towards warming.
FACT2: Let's not be misled by claims of a "pause" in global temperatures. The scientific consensus is clear: global warming is happening and is primarily caused by human activities. It is important that we take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Ice-free means the central basin of the Arctic will be ice-free and I think that that is going to happen in summer 2017 or 2018.”
comment_by_fact-checker: There is no reason to believe that the sea ice cover will disappear this quickly. Our best estimate for this comes from climate models projections, which show that the Arctic could become ice free (less than a million square km) by mid-century — at the earliest — under business-as-usual emissions. Observations show that sea ice is declining somewhat faster than models predict, but even accounting for this suggests that an ice-free Arctic is decades away.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Arctic Sea Ice Melting
FACT1: Arctic sea ice is melting at an alarming rate due to global warming caused by human activities. The Arctic sea ice has been declining at a rate of 12.8% per decade since 1979, and the minimum extent of sea ice in the Arctic has decreased by 13.3% per decade.
MYTH: The central basin of the Arctic will be ice-free in summer 2017 or 2018.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of the slippery slope fallacy, which suggests that taking a minor action will inevitably lead to major consequences. The prediction of an ice-free Arctic in 2017 or 2018 is not supported by scientific evidence and is based on a single observation of a low ice extent in 2012. It is important to note that the Arctic sea ice extent varies from year to year due to natural variability and weather patterns.
FACT2: The Arctic sea ice is melting at an alarming rate due to human activities, and this has serious consequences for the global climate system. We need to take immediate action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and slow down the rate of Arctic sea ice melting. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and family, and instead, educate them about the importance of taking action to address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “while it’s true that studies in some regions show polar bears are lighter in weight than they were in the 1980s, there is no evidence that more individuals are starving to death or becoming too thin to reproduce because of less summer ice.”
comment_by_fact-checker: There is evidence. Bromaghin et al 20151 and Hunter et al 20102 examine this issue. Bromaghin et al state, “Low survival from 2004 through 2006 led to a 25–50% decline in abundance. We hypothesize that low survival during this period resulted from (1) unfavorable ice conditions that limited access to prey during multiple seasons; and possibly, (2) low prey abundance. For reasons that are not clear, survival of adults and cubs began to improve in 2007 and abundance was comparatively stable from 2008 to 2010, with ~900 bears in 2010 (90% CI 606–1212). However, survival of subadult bears declined throughout the entire period. Reduced spatial and temporal availability of sea ice is expected to increasingly force population dynamics of polar bears as the climate continues to warm. However, in the short term, our findings suggest that factors other than sea ice can influence survival.” Hunter et al stated, “Deterministic models projected population growth in years with more extensive ice coverage (2001-2003) and population decline in years with less ice coverage (2004-2005). LTRE (life table response experiment) analysis showed that the reduction in lambda in years with low sea ice was due primarily to reduced adult female survival, and secondarily to reduced breeding. A stochastic model with two environmental states, good and poor sea ice conditions, projected a declining stochastic growth rate, log lambda(s), as the frequency of poor ice years increased. The observed frequency of poor ice years since 1979 would imply log lambda(s) approximate to -0.01, which agrees with available (albeit crude) observations of population size. The stochastic model was linked to a set of 10 GCMs compiled by the IPCC; the models were chosen for their ability to reproduce historical observations of sea ice and were forced with “business as usual” (A1B) greenhouse gas emissions. The resulting stochastic population projections showed drastic declines in the polar bear population by the end of the 21st century. These projections were instrumental in the decision to list the polar bear as a threatened species under the U. S. Endangered Species Act.” 1- Bromaghin et al (2015) Polar bear population dynamics in the southern Beaufort Sea during a period of sea ice decline, Ecological Applications 2- Hunter et al (2010) Climate change threatens polar bear populations: a stochastic
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Polar bears are lighter in weight than they were in the 1980s in some regions.
MYTH: The decline in summer ice is not affecting polar bears.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, as it focuses on one aspect of the impact of declining summer ice on polar bears while ignoring other evidence. While it is true that there is no evidence that more polar bears are starving to death or becoming too thin to reproduce, there is evidence that declining summer ice is affecting polar bears in other ways, such as reducing their access to prey and increasing their energy expenditure. 
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the full impact of declining summer ice on polar bears and work towards solutions to mitigate its effects.

fact_checked_segment: “The end of food”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is hyperbole. Yes there are threats to crop production and other aspects of food security, but the scientific analyses do not suggest an actual “end of food”—it is more a case of regional winners and losers. Not all current food-producing regions are projected to lose their productivity. A redistribution of production would still still be a major issue that society will need to deal with, and may well require growing crops in new places, but this is not the same as suggesting that food supplies will completely come to an end.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: The Future of Food
FACT1: The world's population is expected to reach 9.7 billion by 2050, and current food production methods are unsustainable. Climate change, soil degradation, and water scarcity are all major challenges facing the food industry. 
MYTH: "We are running out of food and will soon face the end of food."
FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false dilemma, presenting only two extreme options: either we have an abundance of food or we have none at all. In reality, the issue is much more complex and nuanced. While there are certainly challenges facing the food industry, there are also many innovative solutions being developed to address these challenges. 
FACT2: By investing in sustainable agriculture, reducing food waste, and developing new technologies, we can ensure that there is enough food to feed the world's growing population. Let's work towards a more sustainable and equitable food system.

fact_checked_segment: This is a critical error. Getting the tropical climate right is essential to understanding climate worldwide.
comment_by_fact-checker: This is only a critical error because they’re desperate to discredit the models. If the disagreement were in the polar regions, they’d be talking about how important it is to get the polar regions right. Obviously, you want to get everything right, but we live on the surface, so getting that right is the most important—and the models do that.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding Tropical Climate is Essential for Understanding Climate Worldwide
FACT1: The tropics play a crucial role in regulating the Earth's climate, as they receive the most solar radiation and are responsible for a significant portion of the planet's heat and moisture transport. Understanding the dynamics of tropical climate is therefore essential for understanding climate worldwide.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's make sure we prioritize research and education on tropical climate to better understand and address global climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Unlike genuine pollutants, carbon dioxide (CO2) is an odorless, colorless gas. Every human being exhales about two pounds of CO2 a day, along with a similar amount of water vapor. CO2 is nontoxic to people and animals”
comment_by_fact-checker: Timothy Osborn, Professor, University of East Anglia, and Director of Research, Climatic Research Unit: This is a diversionary tactic: the concern about CO2 is not about its smell, its colour or its direct toxicity; instead it is about its effect on the Earth’s climate. So it is a strawman statement that may be easily demolished but not relevant to the concern about CO2 and climate change.
label: strawman
debunk:
FACT1: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is a colorless and odorless gas that is naturally present in the Earth's atmosphere. It is produced by natural processes such as respiration and volcanic activity, as well as human activities such as burning fossil fuels. While CO2 is not toxic to humans or animals in small concentrations, it is a greenhouse gas that contributes to global warming and climate change.

MYTH: CO2 is harmless because it is a natural component of the atmosphere and is not toxic to humans or animals.

FALLACY: This argument uses the fallacy of false equivalence by equating the natural presence of CO2 in the atmosphere with the increased levels of CO2 resulting from human activities. It also uses the fallacy of ambiguity by implying that because CO2 is not toxic in small concentrations, it cannot have negative effects on the environment.

FACT2: While CO2 is not toxic to humans or animals in small concentrations, the increased levels of CO2 resulting from human activities are contributing to global warming and climate change. It is important to reduce our carbon footprint by using renewable energy sources and reducing our reliance on fossil fuels. Let's take action to reduce our impact on the environment and protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “The heat extremes were especially pervasive in the Arctic, with temperatures in the fall running 20 to 30 degrees Fahrenheit above normal across large stretches of the Arctic Ocean.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Where the Arctic ocean freezes the air can get very cold because the ice blocks the heat transport from the relatively warm ocean water. The temperature variability is naturally larger in the Arctic than in the mid-latitudes (USA, Europe). Thus it was very warm in the Arctic. As NASA’s Gavin Schmidt said: “What’s going on in the Arctic is really very impressive; this year was ridiculously off the chart” But 20 to 30 degrees Fahrenheit may not be as exceptional as it sounds to our ears.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Unprecedented Arctic Heat
FACT1: The Arctic is experiencing unprecedented heat, with temperatures in the fall running 20 to 30 degrees Fahrenheit above normal across large stretches of the Arctic Ocean.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the reality of climate change and take action to reduce our carbon emissions to prevent further warming of the Arctic and other regions of the world.

fact_checked_segment: I chose to assess the sea-level trend from 1915-45
comment_by_fact-checker: It is rather ironic that the author first complains about “poor data” and then goes on to cherry-pick a time of particularly poor data that includes the World War 2 period. Even the temperature data from this period are questionable; the sea surface temperature data show a strong warm peak at the end of WW2 (the basis of his claim of 0.5 °C warming) which is probably a data collection artefact, given that no such warming is seen in the data collected at the global network of weather stations on land. Also, in the peer-reviewed literature it has been shown that minor inaccuracies in sea-level data by just a few millimeters can lead to spurious fluctuations of sea level trends when too-short time intervals are considered*. Rahmstorf et al (2011) Testing the robustness of semi-empirical sea level projections, Climate Dynamics
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding the Sea-Level Trend from 1915-45
FACT1: The sea level trend from 1915-45 was relatively stable, with an average rise of 1.5 mm per year. This is in contrast to the more rapid rise in sea level observed in recent decades.
MYTH: Some people argue that the sea level trend from 1915-45 is evidence that current sea level rise is natural and not caused by human activities.
FALLACY: This argument is an example of the false choice fallacy, which presents two options as the only possibilities when other possibilities exist. Just because sea level rise was relatively stable during a certain period in the past does not mean that current sea level rise is not caused by human activities. In fact, there is overwhelming scientific evidence that human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation, are causing the current sea level rise.
FACT2: It is important to understand the sea level trend from 1915-45 in order to put current sea level rise into context. However, it is not a valid argument to suggest that current sea level rise is natural based on this period alone. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and instead focus on the overwhelming scientific evidence that human activities are causing the current sea level rise.

fact_checked_segment: “as surface temperatures of the oceans warm up, the immediate response is more water vapor in the atmosphere. We’re in a system inherently capable of producing more floods.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Exactly. Every degree C of warming equates to around 7% more water vapor in the air. Not only does this lead to heavier rain, it adds to the warming as water vapor is a potent greenhouse gas.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Warmer Oceans Lead to More Water Vapor in the Atmosphere
FACT1: Warmer oceans lead to more water vapor in the atmosphere, which can result in more frequent and intense precipitation events such as floods. This is due to the fact that warm air can hold more moisture than cold air, and as the oceans warm up, more water evaporates into the atmosphere. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the link between warmer oceans and increased water vapor in the atmosphere, and take steps to mitigate the effects of climate change to prevent more frequent and intense floods.

fact_checked_segment: “Russian scientists who have investigated waters off their coast have detected more and more plumes of methane bubbling up from the seabed.”
comment_by_fact-checker: However, there is evidence from a dedicated field campaign that the methane in ocean plumes does not affect the atmosphere: Extensive release of methane from Arctic seabed west of Svalbard during summer 2014 does not influence the atmosphere
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Methane Plumes Detected in Russian Waters
FACT1: Methane plumes have been detected in waters off the coast of Russia. Methane is a potent greenhouse gas that can contribute to global warming and climate change. These plumes are likely caused by the melting of permafrost on the ocean floor, which releases trapped methane gas.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to continue monitoring and studying these methane plumes to better understand their impact on the environment and to develop strategies to mitigate their effects. Let's support scientific research and efforts to address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “[…]and increase monthly utility costs for hardworking families”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is unlikely. Other modeled analyses, such as those for the Clean Power Plan, have shown that monthly utility costs would decline under action due to increased energy efficiency investments. See EPA’s regulatory impact analysis.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Cost of Renewable Energy
FACT1: Renewable energy can be expensive to implement, but it can also save money in the long run. The cost of renewable energy has been decreasing rapidly in recent years, making it more affordable than ever before. Additionally, renewable energy can reduce the overall cost of energy by decreasing the need for expensive fossil fuels and reducing the impact of climate change on infrastructure.
MYTH: Renewable energy is too expensive and will increase monthly utility costs for families.
FALLACY: This is a false dilemma fallacy, which presents only two options when there are actually more. It assumes that the only options are to use expensive renewable energy or to continue using cheap fossil fuels. In reality, renewable energy can be cost-effective and save money in the long run. Additionally, it ignores the long-term costs of using fossil fuels, such as the cost of climate change on infrastructure and the health costs associated with air pollution.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about renewable energy. While it can be expensive to implement, it can also save money in the long run and reduce the overall cost of energy.

fact_checked_segment: Now the states rely on the weather and compete to reach the bottom. South Australia is winning: it has the most unreliable grid in the world outside Africa and the most expensive electricity. When South Australians buy electricity at $14,200/MWh, they are paying the equivalent of $400 a litre for petrol.
comment_by_fact-checker: Mark Diesendorf, Associate Professor, UNSW Sydney The comments about South Australia are misleading. SA has the same reliability as the rest of the Australian National Electricity Market. On average, SA has always had the highest electricity prices of the Australian states, long before wind power made a significant contribution, because of SA’s high dependence on high-priced natural gas. The growth of wind power has actually reduced the wholesale price of electricity in SA compared with what it would have been in the absence of wind. This is a consequence of the Merit Order Effect: wind and solar can bid into the grid at zero, or close to zero, price, because they have no fuel cost. The figure $14,200/MWh is grossly misleading. It’s the price during a rare peak in demand when supply was low. Similar high peak prices have occurred occasionally in the other states. It’s not typical of SA.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The High Cost of Electricity in South Australia
FACT1: South Australia has the most expensive electricity in the world, with prices reaching up to $14,200/MWh. This is due to a reliance on weather-dependent energy sources and a lack of investment in reliable infrastructure.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: The argument presented in the statement is an example of cherry-picking, as it focuses on the highest electricity prices in South Australia without providing context or comparison to other regions. It also presents a false equivalence by comparing the cost of electricity to the cost of petrol, which are two different commodities with different pricing structures.
FACT2: Investing in reliable infrastructure and diversifying energy sources can help reduce the cost of electricity in South Australia. Let's support policies that promote sustainable and affordable energy for all.

fact_checked_segment: “record temperatures brought in 2016 by an exceptionally strong El Niño”
comment_by_fact-checker: Last year the annual global temperature was about 1.1 °C above a late-19th century baseline but only about 0.1°C of this was due to the El Niño—the other 1 °C is due to human influences. So while the record occurred in 2016 due to El Niño, most of the anomaly was due to climate change
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding the Role of El Niño in Record Temperatures
FACT1: El Niño is a natural climate pattern that occurs when sea surface temperatures in the Pacific Ocean become unusually warm, leading to changes in weather patterns around the world. During an El Niño event, temperatures can rise globally, leading to record-breaking temperatures in some regions. 
MYTH: The record temperatures in 2016 were solely caused by global warming.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of oversimplification, as it ignores the role of natural climate patterns like El Niño in driving temperature changes. While global warming is a significant factor in rising temperatures, it is not the only one. 
FACT2: Understanding the role of El Niño in driving temperature changes is important for accurately assessing the impact of global warming on our climate. Let's not oversimplify the complex factors that contribute to temperature changes and instead continue to study and understand the role of natural climate patterns like El Niño.

fact_checked_segment: “the rapid ice loss recorded by satellite measurements over the last 20 years is not likely to be a blip, but part of a long-term trend being exacerbated by climate change. Global warming is driving major melting on the surface of Greenland’s glaciers and is speeding up their travel into the sea.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Yes, there are two processes going on here: 1) changes still happening in the solid Earth from the last ice age and 2) current changes to the Greenland ice sheet. The former is impacting our ability to measure the latter.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Greenland's glaciers are melting due to climate change
FACT1: Satellite measurements over the last 20 years show that Greenland's glaciers are rapidly losing ice, and this is part of a long-term trend that is being exacerbated by climate change. Global warming is causing major melting on the surface of the glaciers and is speeding up their travel into the sea.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and slow down the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Australia’s Great Barrier Reef is one of the world’s greatest reservoirs of biodiversity.  A World Heritage site, it is currently under assault from unusually hot ocean temperatures,”
comment_by_fact-checker: Note that there is also a possibility that ocean acidification is contributing stress to coral reef systems, making them more susceptible to bleaching from high seawater temperatures.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Great Barrier Reef is a World Heritage site under threat from rising ocean temperatures.
FACT1: The Great Barrier Reef is a vast ecosystem that is home to thousands of species of marine life, making it one of the most biodiverse places on Earth. It is also a World Heritage site, recognized for its unique beauty and ecological importance.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: The Great Barrier Reef is under threat from rising ocean temperatures caused by climate change. When ocean temperatures rise, it causes coral bleaching, which can lead to the death of coral reefs. Coral reefs are important because they provide habitat for many species of marine life, and they also protect coastlines from storms and erosion. The fallacy is that climate change is not real or not caused by human activity, which is not supported by scientific evidence.
FACT2: Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and protect the Great Barrier Reef for future generations to enjoy.

fact_checked_segment: “The Arctic also stores terrifying bugs from more recent times. In Alaska, already, researchers have discovered remnants of the 1918 flu that infected as many as 500 million and killed as many as 100 million”
comment_by_fact-checker: A series of cholera pandemics and 1918 Spanish influenza were global pandemics causing high mortality long before anthropogenic climate change began influencing the geographic range of climate-sensitive health outcomes.  The World Health Organization and national health systems are preparing for changes in the intensity of transmission, geographic range, and seasonality of climate-sensitive infectious diseases.  Certainly much more needs to be done, but the article implies national and International public health organizations and institutions will not take action when diseases emerge or re-emerge.  This is not consistent with the responses to Ebola, Zika, and other recent events.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Arctic as a reservoir of ancient viruses
FACT1: The Arctic permafrost contains ancient viruses that have been frozen for thousands of years. These viruses are not harmful to humans as they have been dormant for so long, but they could potentially be reactivated due to climate change.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: As the permafrost thaws due to rising temperatures, these ancient viruses could be released into the environment, posing a potential threat to human health. It is important to continue monitoring and studying these viruses to better understand their potential impact and develop strategies to prevent their reemergence.

fact_checked_segment: “Warm weather worsened the most recent five-year drought, which included the driest four-year period on record in terms of statewide precipitation. California’s first-, second- and third-hottest years on record, in terms of statewide average temperatures, were 2014, 2015 and 2016.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This claim is supported by a wide range of scientific research*. Record warmth during the recent drought has also been directly implicated in some of the most iconic drought impacts, such as extreme lack of Sierra Nevada snowpack* and a large increase in wildfire intensity*. Diffenbaugh et al (2015) Anthropogenic warming has increased drought risk in California, PNAS Williams et al (2015) Contribution of anthropogenic warming to California drought during 2012–2014, Geophysical Research Letters Belmecheri et al (2016) Multi-century evaluation of Sierra Nevada snowpack, Nature Climate Change Yoon et al (2015) Increasing water cycle extremes in California and in relation to ENSO cycle under global warming, Nature Communications
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: California's Drought and Hot Weather
FACT1: California's most recent five-year drought was worsened by warm weather, which included the driest four-year period on record in terms of statewide precipitation. The state's first-, second-, and third-hottest years on record, in terms of statewide average temperatures, were 2014, 2015, and 2016.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the impact of warm weather on California's drought and take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Coral bleaching has devastated 93% of the Great Barrier Reef”
comment_by_fact-checker: This headline stating that “bleaching has devastated 93% of the GBR” is misleading as I explained in a recent article in The Conversation: “It is important to recognise that if bleaching was observed on a reef, this does not mean a particular reef has entirely bleached. […] Perhaps the more accurate way to frame the results (and indeed the wording used in the media release) is to say that only 7% of the coral reefs across the Great Barrier Reef have completely avoided bleaching.”
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Great Barrier Reef is facing a serious threat
FACT1: The Great Barrier Reef, located off the coast of Australia, is the world's largest coral reef system, home to thousands of species of marine life. The reef is facing a serious threat due to coral bleaching, which occurs when coral becomes stressed and expels the algae that live inside it, causing it to turn white and potentially die.

MYTH: A warning that a misunderstanding is coming, followed by a paraphrasing of the myth in 30 words or fewer. Only the myth. Don't debunk. Don't deny it yet. It is important to avoid mentioning the myth in the title or using the Fact paragraph just to say that the myth is not true.
It is often claimed that 93% of the Great Barrier Reef has been devastated by coral bleaching.

FALLACY: The claim that 93% of the Great Barrier Reef has been devastated by coral bleaching is an example of cherry-picking. While it is true that some areas of the reef have been severely affected by coral bleaching, the 93% figure refers specifically to the northern section of the reef, which is only a small portion of the entire reef system. This figure does not accurately represent the overall health of the Great Barrier Reef.

FACT2: The Great Barrier Reef is still facing a serious threat from coral bleaching, but it is important to accurately represent the extent of the damage. Efforts are being made to protect and restore the reef, including reducing greenhouse gas emissions and improving water quality. Let's continue to support these efforts and raise awareness about the importance of protecting our oceans.

fact_checked_segment: “In those years, the jet stream deviated deeply southwards over those regions, pulling down savagely cold air. Prof Adam Scaife, a climate modelling expert at the UK’s Met Office, said the evidence for a link to shrinking Arctic ice was now good: ‘The consensus points towards that being a real effect.’”
comment_by_fact-checker: This refers to a southward shifted jet in response to sea ice loss (a negative North Atlantic Oscillation pattern). It’s not clear at all that this is the same kind of behaviour as suggested by the quoted scientists.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Shrinking Arctic Ice Linked to Extreme Cold Weather
FACT1: Shrinking Arctic ice is linked to extreme cold weather in some regions. The jet stream, which is a band of strong winds that circles the Earth, can deviate southwards over certain regions, pulling down cold air and causing extreme cold weather. Climate modelling experts have found evidence linking this phenomenon to shrinking Arctic ice.
MYTH: Shrinking Arctic ice has no impact on extreme cold weather.
FALLACY: The myth is based on a false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that because some regions may experience warmer temperatures due to climate change, extreme cold weather cannot occur in other regions. This oversimplifies the complex and interconnected nature of the Earth's climate system, which can lead to both warming and cooling effects in different regions.
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the complexity of the Earth's climate system and the potential impacts of shrinking Arctic ice on extreme weather events. By understanding these connections, we can better prepare for and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: How is this possible 2,999,971 years before Arnold Schwarzenegger bought his Hummer?
comment_by_fact-checker: Because the amount of CO2 naturally present in the atmosphere depends on how much is being released or taken up by the oceans, land ecosystems, and chemical reactions involved in rock weathering. These change naturally, but gradually, over thousands or millions of years. Human emissions of CO2 are merely adding an extra factor to the equation, but it is one which has a big effect over much short timescales (the last few decades).
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Age of the Earth
FACT1: The Earth is estimated to be around 4.54 billion years old, based on radiometric dating of rocks and meteorites.
MYTH: None stated.
FALLACY: None stated.
FACT2: Let's appreciate the vastness of time and the incredible history of our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “The last time the planet was even four degrees warmer, Peter Brannen points out in The Ends of the World, his new history of the planet’s major extinction events, the oceans were hundreds of feet higher.”
comment_by_fact-checker: I don’t know what time period the author is referring to here, but closer to us, during the last interglacial (roughly 120,000 years ago), Earth was ~2 °C warmer than temperatures in the 19th century, and sea levels were about 5-6 meters higher. This suggests that even “good-case, 2 °C” long-term warming in our future could also raise oceans by that much eventually, even if the pace of that rise (and thus the amount of rise by 2100) is uncertain.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: The Consequences of a 4-Degree Warmer Planet
FACT1: A 4-degree increase in global temperature would cause a significant rise in sea levels, according to Peter Brannen's book, The Ends of the World. 
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is crucial to take action to prevent further global warming and its catastrophic consequences, such as rising sea levels, which would have devastating effects on coastal communities and ecosystems. Let's take steps to reduce our carbon footprint and support policies that prioritize sustainability.

fact_checked_segment: “ever since December temperatures in the Arctic have consistently been lower than minus 20 C”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is indeed true that the Arctic is cold in winter—it’s hard to argue with that. But this statement belies the fact that winter 2017 was actually extraordinarily warm by historical standards, and second only to the record-shattering warmth observed just last year (in 2016). The attached plot, created by Zachary Labe and available at http://sites.uci.edu/zlabe/arctic-temperatures, shows that the -20 °C temperatures this winter are nearly 10 °C degrees above the long-term average of -30 °C! Therefore, the fact that temperatures were -20 °C this winter in the Arctic is actually a testament to just how much the Arctic has warmed in recent years.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Arctic Temperatures in Winter
FACT1: The Arctic is one of the coldest regions on Earth, with temperatures often dropping below minus 20 C in the winter months. This is due to the region's high latitude and lack of sunlight during the winter season.
MYTH: None stated.
FALLACY: Ambiguity. The statement is true, but it is misleading because it implies that this is evidence against global warming, when in fact it is consistent with the overall trend of warming in the Arctic. While winter temperatures in the Arctic can still be very cold, the overall trend is towards warmer temperatures, with the Arctic warming at a rate twice as fast as the rest of the world.
FACT2: Let's not use isolated examples to draw conclusions about global climate trends. Instead, let's look at the overall data and scientific consensus to better understand the complex and ongoing changes in our climate.

fact_checked_segment: La Niñas, on the other hand, feature cooler than average waters in the Pacific
comment_by_fact-checker: This should be “in the eastern equatorial Pacific”.
label: vagueness
debunk:
{
    "TITLE": "La Niña brings cooler waters to the Pacific",
    "FACT1": "La Niña is a weather pattern that occurs when cooler than average waters appear in the Pacific Ocean, leading to changes in global weather patterns.",
    "MYTH": "",
    "FALLACY": "",
    "FACT2": "Let's learn more about La Niña and its effects on the climate."
}

fact_checked_segment: “collaborating on studies which all corroborate, independently and rigorously, the increasingly respectable view that ‘man-made global warming’ just isn’t a thing.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This false statement is based on a list of figures taken completely out of context. For instance, No Tricks Zone [the blog Breitbart is using as a source] takes a figure from Markle et al., (2017)1 and assumes the x-axis refers to years before present. With this incorrect interpretation, it seems as though ocean temperature anomalies are very low at year 0. However, these plots show the result of simulations of idealized Dansgaard-Oeschger or Antarctic Isotope Maximum events in a general circulation model. Year 0 is simply the beginning of the simulated event and is not displaying actual modern sea surface temperature data (i.e. year 0 is not today, 0 years before present). Not only is this a red herring, it is a completely misinterpreted red herring. They also repeat the favorite Antarctic cooling cherry, taking (and altering) a figure from Mayewski et al., (2017)2 which shows Antarctic-wide climate reanalysis temperature data. As a continent (larger than the US lower-48), Antarctica is not warming. This is because much of high, dry East Antarctica is not warming.
