However, important areas of Antarctica, including West Antarctica which likely would show about a 0.2ºC per decade warming trend over the reanalysis period (from 1979 to present, since satellites have given good data coverage). Climate is incredibly variable around Antarctica, and also through time (large interannual variability). This is well studied, but if you only look at one graph rather than reading the research papers you will not be aware of this. See: Nicolas and Bromwich (2014) New Reconstruction of Antarctic Near-Surface Temperatures: Multidecadal Trends and Reliability of Global Reanalyses. Journal of Climate Bromwich et al (2012) Central West Antarctica among the most rapidly warming regions on Earth. Nature Geoscience 1- Markle et al., (2017) Global atmospheric teleconnections during Dansgaard–Oeschger events. Nature Geoscience 2- Mayewski et al., (2017) Ice core and climate reanalysis analogs to predict Antarctic and Southern Hemisphere climate changes. Quaternary Science Reviews
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The Consensus on Man-Made Global Warming
FACT1: The overwhelming majority of climate scientists agree that man-made global warming is real and a significant threat to our planet. This consensus is based on decades of rigorous research and analysis of data from around the world.
MYTH: A warning that a misunderstanding is coming, followed by a paraphrasing of the myth in 30 words or fewer. Only the myth. Don't debunk. Don't deny it yet. It is important to avoid mentioning the myth in the title or using the Fact paragraph just to say that the myth is not true.
FALLACY: The statement is a classic example of cherry-picking, where a small number of studies are selected to support a particular viewpoint while ignoring the vast majority of research that contradicts it. This fallacy is misleading because it presents a distorted view of the scientific consensus on man-made global warming.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's rely on the overwhelming scientific consensus and take action to address the urgent threat of man-made global warming.

fact_checked_segment: “Stress from unusually warm ocean water heated by man-made climate change and the natural El Niño climate pattern caused the die-off.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Yes, human-caused warming boosts the background temperature, so that warming associated with El Niño can now reach levels intolerable by corals.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Unusually warm ocean water and El Niño caused marine die-off
FACT1: A marine die-off occurred due to unusually warm ocean water and the El Niño climate pattern. This die-off was caused by a combination of natural and human-induced factors.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's continue to monitor and address the impacts of climate change on our oceans to prevent further harm to marine life.

fact_checked_segment: Yet, some scientists argue that the gas is not capable of producing the extreme temperature rises seen in recent decades.
comment_by_fact-checker: In the same way some “scientists” claim quantum mechanics is wrong. Single scientists are not a source of reliable scientific information, especially after searching them out for holding views that reject the scientific understanding of the world. Normally the reporting in the science section of a reputable newspaper would be based on the overwhelming evidence presented in high quality peer reviewed scientific journals.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: CO2 Alone Cannot Explain Recent Temperature Rises
FACT1: While carbon dioxide is a potent greenhouse gas, it is not the only factor contributing to recent temperature rises. Other factors, such as changes in solar radiation, volcanic activity, and human land use, also play a role in the Earth's climate system.
MYTH: Some scientists argue that CO2 is not capable of producing the extreme temperature rises seen in recent decades.
FALLACY: This myth is an oversimplification of the complex factors that contribute to the Earth's climate system. While CO2 is a potent greenhouse gas, it is not the only factor contributing to recent temperature rises. Other factors, such as changes in solar radiation, volcanic activity, and human land use, also play a role in the Earth's climate system. By focusing solely on CO2, this myth ignores the complexity of the Earth's climate system and misleads people into thinking that CO2 is not a significant contributor to climate change.
FACT2: It is important to recognize that while CO2 is not the only factor contributing to recent temperature rises, it is a significant contributor. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and instead educate ourselves on the complex factors that contribute to climate change.

fact_checked_segment: One of the main areas of contention is the existence of two strange climate episodes known as The Medieval Warm Period (MWP) and the Little Ice Age. The MWP lasted from about 950 to 1250AD, and temperature
comment_by_fact-checker: There is little evidence in the academic literature that the Medieval Warm Period was warmer than today in terms of global average temperatures. The PAGES 2k Consortium—a group of dozens of paleoclimate researchers from around the world—found1: “There were no globally synchronous multi-decadal warm or cold intervals that define a worldwide Medieval Warm Period or Little Ice Age, but all reconstructions show generally cold conditions between AD 1580 and 1880, punctuated in some regions by warm decades during the eighteenth century. The transition to these colder conditions occurred earlier in the Arctic, Europe and Asia than in North America or the Southern Hemisphere regions. Recent warming reversed the long-term cooling; during the period AD 1971–2000, the area-weighted average reconstructed temperature was higher than any other time in nearly 1,400 years.” 1- Pages 2k Consortium (2013) Continental-scale temperature variability during the past two millennia, Nature Geoscience
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The Medieval Warm Period and the Little Ice Age: Separating Fact from Fiction
FACT1: The Medieval Warm Period (MWP) and the Little Ice Age were two climate episodes that occurred in the past, but they were not global phenomena and did not have the same causes as current climate change. The MWP was a period of warmer temperatures that occurred in some regions of the world from about 950 to 1250 AD, while the Little Ice Age was a period of cooler temperatures that occurred from about 1350 to 1850 AD.
MYTH: There is a belief that the MWP and the Little Ice Age were global phenomena that prove that current climate change is natural and not caused by human activities.
FALLACY: The fallacy here is cherry-picking, which involves selectively choosing data that support a particular argument while ignoring other data that contradict it. While the MWP and the Little Ice Age were real climate episodes, they were not global phenomena and did not have the same causes as current climate change. The evidence shows that current climate change is primarily caused by human activities, such as the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation, which release greenhouse gases into the atmosphere and trap heat.
FACT2: Let's not use the MWP and the Little Ice Age as evidence against current climate change. Instead, let's focus on the overwhelming scientific evidence that shows that human activities are causing the Earth's climate to warm at an unprecedented rate. It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: I note particularly that sea-level rise is not affected by the warming; it continues at the same rate, 1.8 millimeters a year, according to a 1990 review by Andrew S. Trupin and John Wahr.
comment_by_fact-checker: This claim is against the basic laws of physics—warming causes thermal expansion of sea water and thereby sea-level rise, full stop. This is true regardless of whether this effect can be detected in a cherry-picked short time interval with poor data quality.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
FACT1: Sea levels are rising at a rate of 1.8 millimeters per year, according to a 1990 review by Andrew S. Trupin and John Wahr.
MYTH: Sea-level rise is affected by warming.
FALLACY: This statement uses ambiguity to mislead readers. While it is true that sea levels continue to rise at a steady rate, it is also true that warming is causing the rate of sea-level rise to accelerate. As the Earth's temperature increases, glaciers and ice sheets melt, causing more water to enter the oceans and leading to a faster rate of sea-level rise. By focusing on the steady rate of sea-level rise, this statement ignores the accelerating effect of warming on sea-level rise.
FACT2: Let's not be misled by statements that use ambiguity to downplay the impact of warming on sea-level rise. The scientific consensus is clear: warming is causing sea levels to rise at an accelerating rate, and we must take action to address this issue.

fact_checked_segment: “Sea level rise, which was occurring long before humans could be blamed, has not accelerated and still amounts to only 1 inch every ten years. If a major hurricane is approaching with a predicted storm surge of 10-14 feet, are you really going to worry about a sea level rise of 1 inch per decade?”
comment_by_fact-checker: A major storm that has a sea-level higher than it would otherwise have been without climate change will simply be more damaging. It doesn’t matter that current sea-level rise changes are slow. Sandy’s storm surge hit at high tide—a tide that was higher than it would otherwise have been because of human-caused climate change. Some estimates are that damages were many billions of dollars higher as a result.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The Insignificance of Sea Level Rise in the Face of Natural Disasters
FACT1: Sea level rise is a gradual increase in the average height of the ocean's surface, caused by the melting of glaciers and ice sheets and the thermal expansion of seawater due to global warming. It is currently occurring at a rate of about 1 inch every 10 years.
MYTH: Sea level rise is insignificant and not worth worrying about, especially in the face of natural disasters like hurricanes.
FALLACY: This argument uses the false equivalence fallacy by comparing the gradual and long-term process of sea level rise to the immediate and short-term threat of a hurricane. It also uses the cherry-picking fallacy by focusing on a single aspect of sea level rise (the rate of increase) while ignoring the potential long-term consequences, such as flooding and displacement of coastal communities.
FACT2: While it is true that sea level rise may not be an immediate threat in the face of a natural disaster like a hurricane, it is still a significant long-term issue that requires attention and action. Rising sea levels can lead to increased flooding, erosion, and loss of habitat for marine life, as well as displacement of coastal communities. It is important to address this issue through mitigation and adaptation measures to protect both people and the environment. Let's not dismiss the significance of sea level rise and take action to address it.

fact_checked_segment: “At the bottom of the world, sea ice is also at all-time record low levels around Antarctica, the data center said. The lack of ice in the Antarctic, where it is currently summer, is most pronounced in the Amundsen Sea, where only a few scattered patches of ice remain.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Looking at recent time-evolution of Antarctic sea ice anomalies since November 2016 is insightful to appreciate the complexity of Antarctic sea ice dynamics. In early austral spring (below) the total Antarctic sea ice extent was already anomalously low because of strong ice retreat in the Indian Sector.
label: post hoc
debunk:
TITLE: Antarctic Sea Ice Reaches Record Low Levels
FACT1: The amount of sea ice around Antarctica has reached record low levels, particularly in the Amundsen Sea, where only a few scattered patches of ice remain. This is happening during the summer season in Antarctica.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to acknowledge the reality of the situation and take action to address the underlying causes of this phenomenon, such as climate change. Let's work towards reducing our carbon emissions and protecting our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “Global sea level rise surged between November 2014 and February 2016, with the El Niño event helping the oceans rise by 15mm.”
comment_by_fact-checker: A large part of this rise is related to the transition from La Niña to El Niño. The background rate of global sea level rise is still between 3-4mm per year.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: El Niño event caused a surge in global sea level rise between 2014 and 2016
FACT1: Global sea level rise surged by 15mm between November 2014 and February 2016, due in part to the El Niño event.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to understand the factors that contribute to sea level rise, including natural events like El Niño, in order to better predict and prepare for future changes. Let's continue to monitor and study sea level rise to better understand its impacts on our planet.

fact_checked_segment: Most of the atmospheric moisture originates in the tropical ocean, and the difference between surface and upper atmospheric temperature determines how much of the moisture rises into the atmosphere.
comment_by_fact-checker: Satellite-observed increases in atmospheric moisture content agree with satellite datasets that show more warming.1 1- Mears et al (2015) Intercomparison of total precipitable water measurements made by satellite-borne microwave radiometers and ground-based GPS instruments, Journal of Geophysical Research
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Moisture in the Atmosphere
FACT1: The majority of atmospheric moisture comes from the tropical ocean, and the amount that rises into the atmosphere is determined by the temperature difference between the surface and upper atmosphere.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Understanding the source and behavior of atmospheric moisture is important for predicting weather patterns and climate change. Let's continue to study and learn about the Earth's atmosphere.

fact_checked_segment: “global warming causes about as much damage as benefits.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The studies of the aggregate economic impacts from global warming synthesized in the last IPCC (Intergovermental Panel on Climate Change) do not support the claim that benefits from climate change counterbalance the costs. All but one study find net costs, and the study finding aggregate benefits at the global level is focusing on a very low warming (+1°C). Since the IPCC assessment report, new studies have evaluated economic costs and benefits from climate change. Notably, Burke et al 2015 (Global non-linear effect of temperature on economic production) do find some net benefits for a limited number of countries, but at the global level the net economic effect corresponds to costs.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The Benefits and Drawbacks of Global Warming
FACT1: Global warming has both positive and negative effects on the environment and human society. For example, it can lead to longer growing seasons and increased agricultural productivity in some regions, but it can also cause more frequent and severe weather events, sea level rise, and harm to ecosystems and human health.
MYTH: A common myth is that global warming causes about as much damage as benefits.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that two things are equivalent when they are not. While global warming may have some benefits, such as increased agricultural productivity in some regions, the negative impacts far outweigh the positive ones. The scientific consensus is that global warming is causing significant harm to the environment and human society, including more frequent and severe weather events, sea level rise, and harm to ecosystems and human health.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. It is important to understand the full picture of the impacts of global warming and take action to mitigate its negative effects.

fact_checked_segment: “ NASA concurred with NOAA, also declaring 2016 the warmest year on record in its own data set that tracks the temperatures at the surface of the planet’s land and oceans, and expressing ‘greater than 95 percent certainty’ in that conclusion. (In contrast, NOAA gave a 62 percent confidence in the broken record.) ”
comment_by_fact-checker: The difference between NOAA and NASA-GISS is because of the way the Arctic—where much of the warming was in 2016, but where we do not have many measurements—is treated. NOAA excludes much of the Arctic, which gives it a cool bias in 2016, which is accounted for by a larger uncertainty. NOAA. The gray areas are where NOAA’s methods do not have enough observations to compute the temperature. Not computing a temperature is similar to assuming these regions warm like the global average, but the Arctic warmed more. GISTEMP of NASA-GISS uses other mathematical methods and does compute temperatures for the Arctic, which results in a more accurate global average.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: NASA and NOAA agree: 2016 was the warmest year on record
FACT1: In 2016, NASA and NOAA independently declared that it was the warmest year on record. NASA tracks the temperatures at the surface of the planet's land and oceans, and expressed "greater than 95 percent certainty" in their conclusion. 
MYTH: There is no evidence that 2016 was the warmest year on record.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of slothful induction, as it ignores relevant evidence when coming to a conclusion. The fact that both NASA and NOAA independently declared 2016 as the warmest year on record, with NASA expressing "greater than 95 percent certainty," provides strong evidence that this claim is true. 
FACT2: Let's trust the scientific consensus and accept that 2016 was the warmest year on record. We should continue to support efforts to address climate change and reduce our impact on the planet.

fact_checked_segment: “And since the biggest risk to humanity is poverty, if we allow policymakers to have their way, the resulting energy poverty will indeed cause the deaths of some of our children and grandchildren.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Poverty and energy poverty are indeed a risk for humanity; but current understanding shows that unmitigated climate change would hinder the efforts of poverty alleviation, because climate change impacts bear on most vulnerable countries and people.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Energy Poverty and Poverty are not the same thing
FACT1: Energy poverty is a lack of access to modern energy services, while poverty is a lack of access to basic human needs such as food, shelter, and healthcare. Energy poverty disproportionately affects people in developing countries, while poverty affects people in both developed and developing countries.
MYTH: Energy poverty is the same as poverty.
FALLACY: This argument uses a false equivalence fallacy by equating energy poverty with poverty. While energy poverty can contribute to poverty, it is not the same thing. The argument also uses a slippery slope fallacy by suggesting that policies to address climate change will inevitably lead to energy poverty and the deaths of children and grandchildren. In reality, there are many ways to address climate change while also ensuring access to modern energy services for all.
FACT2: Let's not conflate energy poverty with poverty and instead work towards solutions that address both issues. We can support policies that promote clean energy and energy access for all, while also addressing poverty through measures such as social safety nets and economic development programs.

fact_checked_segment: “The coal industry alone supplies almost one-third of America’s electric power — with an increasing amount of clean coal-burning technology becoming available.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is misleading. While coal burning has become cleaner due to regulations on the air pollutants it emits, it still emits copious amounts of carbon dioxide, which is a greenhouse gas. Carbon capture and sequestration technologies have proven to be expensive and troubled (For example, see this story in The New York Times).
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The Reality of Coal's Contribution to America's Electric Power
FACT1: Coal is a significant source of America's electric power, but its contribution has been declining in recent years. In 2020, coal accounted for 19.3% of the country's electricity generation, down from 50% in 2005. 
MYTH: A misleading statement that suggests coal is still a major source of America's electric power and that clean coal-burning technology is increasingly available.
FALLACY: The statement uses the fallacy of cherry-picking by focusing on the coal industry's contribution to America's electric power without acknowledging the declining trend. It also uses the fallacy of ambiguity by suggesting that clean coal-burning technology is increasingly available without providing evidence to support this claim.
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the reality that coal's contribution to America's electric power has been declining in recent years, and we should continue to invest in cleaner and more sustainable sources of energy.

fact_checked_segment: “In recent decades this warming has been accompanied by a constant rise in the sea level and, it would appear, by an increase of extreme weather events, even if a scientifically determinable cause cannot be assigned to each particular phenomenon.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It depends on the type of event. heatwaves and extreme heat events have increased since at least the 1950s1. Though tropical cyclones and drought are a bit harder to analyse since natural climate variability also plays a large role. This means there may be a signal of change due to human activity, but is more difficult to measure, due to the noise of the natural variability of the climate. Also, “attribution” can be done for specific events. this basically compares how often an extreme event of a particular magnitude and duration occurs in climate model simulations both with and without human emissions of greenhouse gases. This was first done on the 2003 European heatwave2. So it can be done, but is heavily dependent to the event you analyse, the spacial scale on which it occurs, and even the climate model/s and experimental set up you use3 1- Perkins (2012) Increasing frequency, intensity and duration of observed global heatwaves and warm spells. Geophysical Research Letters 2- Stott (2004) Human contribution to the European heatwave of 2003. Nature 3- Angelil (2014) Attribution of extreme weather to anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions:
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change and Extreme Weather Events
FACT1: Climate change is associated with a rise in sea levels and an increase in extreme weather events, such as hurricanes, floods, and droughts. While it is difficult to attribute a single event to climate change, the overall trend is clear.
MYTH: There is no evidence linking climate change to extreme weather events.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, as it focuses on individual events rather than the overall trend. It also ignores the fact that climate change is a complex phenomenon that can contribute to a variety of extreme weather events in different ways.
FACT2: Let's not ignore the overwhelming evidence linking climate change to extreme weather events. We need to take action to mitigate the effects of climate change and prevent further damage to our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “…scientist James Hansen unequivocally stated: ‘We have at most ten years—not ten years to decide upon action, but ten years to alter fundamentally the trajectory of global greenhouse emissions.'”
comment_by_fact-checker: The classic because-x-did-not-happen-yet-thus-x-will-not-happen fallacy. A fallacy that is especially ignorant in the case of a problem like climate change which responds slowly, like an oil tanker…
label: post hoc
debunk:
TITLE: Urgency of Climate Action
FACT1: Climate change is a pressing issue that requires immediate action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The window of opportunity to prevent the worst impacts of climate change is rapidly closing, and we must act quickly to avoid irreversible damage to our planet.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's take action now to reduce our carbon footprint and transition to a more sustainable future. We can make a difference by reducing our energy consumption, supporting renewable energy, and advocating for policies that address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “While scientists are loathe to attribute any single event to changes in the climate, they state that warming temperatures are helping tip the scales towards altered precipitation. Some, however, bristle at the belief that because floods and storms have always occurred, they should not be linked to climate change”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is true that floods and storms always have occurred, but they have always ocurred for a physical reason. This may be evidence suggesting that these phenomena are rather sensitive to a climate change, if modest natural changes in physical conditions already give rise to variations in the floods and storm activity. We now know that the earth’s atmosphere is changing (increased CO2 and a global warming). It would be naive to think that floods and storms do not change when important factors change while they have always changed in the past. It is also important to think about these concepts in a risk-analysis frame, and it is important to plan for various plausible scenarios.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change and Extreme Weather Events
FACT1: Climate change is causing more extreme weather events, such as floods and storms, due to altered precipitation patterns resulting from warming temperatures.
MYTH: Some people believe that floods and storms have always occurred, so they should not be linked to climate change.
FALLACY: This is a false equivalence fallacy, as it assumes that just because floods and storms have occurred in the past, they cannot be linked to climate change. The reality is that climate change is exacerbating the frequency and severity of extreme weather events, making them more frequent and intense than they would be otherwise.
FACT2: It is important to recognize the link between climate change and extreme weather events in order to take action to mitigate the effects of climate change. Let's not ignore the evidence and take steps to reduce our carbon footprint and transition to renewable energy sources.

fact_checked_segment: the first scientists to show that the thick icecap that once covered the Arctic ocean was beginning to thin and shrink.
comment_by_fact-checker: Arctic sea ice is typically less than 4 m thick. The use of ‘ice cap’ traditionally implies a body of ice on land that covers less area than an ice sheet; however, the article discusses sea ice, not an ice cap, which is floating ice that forms due to freezing of surface water.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Arctic Icecap is Shrinking
FACT1: The Arctic icecap, which once covered the Arctic ocean, is beginning to thin and shrink. This is due to rising temperatures caused by human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and slow down the rate of Arctic ice melting.

fact_checked_segment: “Stress from unusually warm ocean water heated by man-made climate change and the natural El Niño climate pattern caused the die-off.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Roughly speaking, the El Niño may have added a quarter of a degree C to the global average in 2015/16, while the greenhouse-gas-related warming trend has added twice that much to the average values since the 1980s. It’s also important to note that this is only one part of a global coral bleaching event that has been occurring since mid-2014. NOAA declares third ever global coral bleaching event
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Unusually warm ocean water and El Niño caused marine die-off
FACT1: A marine die-off occurred due to unusually warm ocean water and the El Niño climate pattern. This die-off was caused by a combination of natural and human-induced factors.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's continue to monitor and address the impacts of climate change on our oceans to prevent further harm to marine life.

fact_checked_segment: Sadly, these supposed experts use mathematical equations that do not jibe with reality over the past 140 years.
comment_by_fact-checker: Experts tend to use mathematical equations. If the authors would like to claim an equation is wrong, they should state which one and provide a source. Otherwise it is just hot air.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The Reality of Mathematical Equations and Climate Change
FACT1: Mathematical equations are used to model and predict climate change. These models are based on scientific data and observations from the past 140 years, including temperature records, ice core samples, and satellite data. 
MYTH: Warning, a misunderstanding is coming. The myth is that mathematical equations used to model climate change do not align with reality over the past 140 years.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, where only a small portion of the data is used to support a particular argument while ignoring the larger body of evidence. Climate models are based on a wide range of data and observations, and while they are not perfect, they have been shown to accurately predict past and present climate trends. 
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Climate change is a complex issue, and it is important to rely on accurate and comprehensive information when discussing it.

fact_checked_segment: “Climate Models Have Overestimated Global Warming”
comment_by_fact-checker: The title does not truly reflect the article in Nature Geoscience. The issue is not that the models are too warm by 2015. CMIP5 models are on the warm end, yes, but that’s not the main issue here. The article explains that problem comes when looking at both cumulative CO2 emissions and associated warming. The cumulative CO2 emissions simulated by the models only reach 545 GtC (the present-day value) after 2020, by which time the CMIP5 ensemble-mean human- induced warming is over 0.3 ºC warmer than the central estimate for human-induced warming to 2015.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The Accuracy of Climate Models in Predicting Global Warming
FACT1: Climate models are computer simulations that use physics, chemistry, and biology to predict how the Earth's climate will change in response to various factors, such as greenhouse gas emissions. These models have been developed and refined over decades by thousands of scientists around the world.
MYTH: Climate models have overestimated global warming.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, where a few studies that suggest overestimation are highlighted while ignoring the majority of studies that show good agreement between models and observations. Climate models are not perfect, but they are the best tools we have for predicting future climate change.
FACT2: Let's trust the scientific consensus that climate models are accurate in predicting global warming. We should continue to use these models to inform policy decisions and take action to mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “the rapid ice loss recorded by satellite measurements over the last 20 years is not likely to be a blip, but part of a long-term trend being exacerbated by climate change. Global warming is driving major melting on the surface of Greenland’s glaciers and is speeding up their travel into the sea.”
comment_by_fact-checker: While this paragraph is not imprecise, there is a slight wiggle room for the wrong interpretation that the acceleration of ice loss seen in the past decades is just a “blip” on top of a much larger rate of mass loss since the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM). This new work finds the contribution to sea level rise from the Greenland Ice Sheet since the LGM to be 4.6 ± 0.7 m – an average ice loss rate of roughly 75-80 Gt/yr, which is almost identical to the rate of ice loss in the 20th century (75 Gt/yr) suggested by Kjeldsen et al. (2015). The rate of ice loss has accelerated in the past decades so that we today see rates that are more than the triple of those earlier rates. However, I do not think this is a major issue, as the paragraph is sandwiched in between precise explanations and context provided by scientists.
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: Melting glaciers in Greenland are part of a long-term trend
FACT1: Satellite measurements over the last 20 years show that the ice loss in Greenland is not a temporary event, but part of a long-term trend. Climate change is exacerbating this trend, causing major melting on the surface of Greenland's glaciers and accelerating their travel into the sea.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the reality of climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint. We can make a difference by making small changes in our daily lives, such as using public transportation, reducing meat consumption, and supporting renewable energy sources.

fact_checked_segment: the ongoing rise in sea level that began with the end of the ice age continues with no great increase in magnitude.
comment_by_fact-checker: misleads readers not to mention the research suggesting accelerated global sea level rise1. While the authors may think a 50-100% acceleration of sea level rise is “no great increase”, readers may misunderstand this. 1- Dangendorf et al (2019) Persistent acceleration in global sea-level rise since the 1960s, Nature Climate Change
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Sea level rise is ongoing and not slowing down
FACT1: Sea level has been rising since the end of the last ice age, and it continues to rise today. The rate of sea level rise has increased in recent decades, and it is projected to continue to accelerate in the future.
MYTH: Sea level rise is not a significant problem because it has been ongoing since the end of the last ice age and is not increasing in magnitude.
FALLACY: This argument is an example of the "moving goalposts" fallacy, where the standard of evidence is constantly raised to avoid accepting the conclusion. The fact that sea level has been rising for thousands of years does not mean that the current rate of sea level rise is not a problem. The current rate of sea level rise is much faster than the natural rate, and it is causing significant impacts on coastal communities and ecosystems.
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the reality of ongoing sea level rise and take action to mitigate its impacts. This includes reducing greenhouse gas emissions, protecting coastal communities, and investing in adaptation measures.

fact_checked_segment: “Or the news from Antarctica this past May, when a crack in an ice shelf grew 11 miles in six days, then kept going; the break now has just three miles to go — by the time you read this, it may already have met the open water, where it will drop into the sea one of the biggest icebergs ever, a process known poetically as ‘calving.’”
comment_by_fact-checker: Although a particularly dramatic and well-observed example of how floating ice shelves calve icebergs into the ocean, there is little evidence that the crack in the Larsen C ice shelf is directly related to climate change. At best this is subject to considerable debate, as it is difficult to directly connect particular atmospheric and oceanic mechanisms to the cracking of this single, albeit large, proto-iceberg. For a very measured treatment of this topic, see the Guardian article by Professor Helen Fricker of Scripps Institute of Oceanography. Having now just calved an iceberg as of July 12, it is good to hear from the most experience experts how concerning this event is. A really great simple summary is provided by David Vaughan, Director of Science for the British Antarctic Survey, who has worked on the Antarctic Peninsula and studied regional ice shelves for decades.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The Antarctic ice shelf is breaking apart
FACT1: A massive crack in an Antarctic ice shelf grew 11 miles in six days in May 2017, and is now just three miles from meeting open water. This could result in one of the biggest icebergs ever recorded, a process known as "calving."
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to pay attention to the effects of climate change on our planet, including the melting of ice shelves in Antarctica. Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: I note particularly that sea-level rise is not affected by the warming; it continues at the same rate, 1.8 millimeters a year, according to a 1990 review by Andrew S. Trupin and John Wahr.
comment_by_fact-checker: This is very misleading. Why is the author using a review dating from 1990, when there have been many publications over the past 28 years that show a much higher rate of Global Mean Sea Level (GMSL) rise over the last few decades? For instance, Hay et al* have looked at tide gauge records since the beginning of the 20th century and found that the rate of GMSL rise was 1.2 +/- 0.2 mm/yr over the 1901-1990 period, but 3.0 +/- 0.7 mm/yr over the 1993-2010 period (this period corresponds to the time for which we also have satellite altimetry measurements, which are consistent with this rate). The author also talks about an “accelerating rate” of sea-level rise later in his article, which contradicts his own statement. Hay et al (2015) Probabilistic reanalysis of twentieth-century sea-level rise, Nature
label: red herring
debunk:
FACT1: Sea levels are rising at a rate of 1.8 millimeters per year, according to a 1990 review by Andrew S. Trupin and John Wahr.
MYTH: Sea-level rise is affected by warming.
FALLACY: This statement uses ambiguity to mislead readers. While it is true that sea levels continue to rise at a steady rate, it is also true that warming is causing the rate of sea-level rise to accelerate. As the Earth's temperature increases, glaciers and ice sheets melt, causing more water to enter the oceans and leading to a faster rate of sea-level rise. By focusing on the steady rate of sea-level rise, this statement ignores the fact that warming is causing the rate to increase.
FACT2: Let's not be misled by statements that use ambiguity to downplay the impact of warming on sea-level rise. The scientific consensus is clear: warming is causing sea levels to rise at an accelerating rate, which poses a significant threat to coastal communities around the world.

fact_checked_segment: “Most people expect this year will see a record low in the Arctic’s summer sea-ice cover.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is incorrect. The SIPN team (Sea Ice Prediction Network) have collected forecasts from 40 international groups and none are predicting a record low in 2016.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Arctic's Summer Sea-Ice Cover
FACT1: The Arctic's summer sea-ice cover has been decreasing at an alarming rate due to global warming. In the past 40 years, the Arctic has lost 95% of its oldest and thickest ice. This loss of ice has significant impacts on the Arctic ecosystem, as well as global weather patterns and sea levels. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the reality of the situation and take action to reduce our carbon emissions to slow down the rate of Arctic sea-ice loss.

fact_checked_segment: “The ‘ancient carbon’ of Alaska’s tundras is being released, starting a vicious warming cycle ‘This is ancient carbon, thousands and millions of years old.’ It’s being released ‘much earlier than we thought.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Most of the carbon in the permafrost pool is thousands to tens of thousands year old at the oldest, rather than millions.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Ancient Carbon in Alaska's Tundras is Being Released, Contributing to Warming
FACT1: The thawing of Alaska's tundras is releasing ancient carbon that has been stored for thousands and millions of years. This carbon is being released much earlier than previously thought, contributing to a vicious warming cycle that exacerbates climate change. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: This statement is not a fallacy, but rather a fact-based explanation of how the thawing of Alaska's tundras is contributing to climate change. The release of ancient carbon is a well-documented phenomenon that has been observed in other parts of the world as well. The release of this carbon contributes to the greenhouse effect, trapping more heat in the atmosphere and exacerbating climate change. 
FACT2: Let's work towards reducing our carbon emissions and transitioning to renewable energy sources to mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The list of variables that shape climate […] would run to hundreds, if not thousands, of elements, none of which scientists would claim to understand with absolute precision.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The basic argument in the remainder of the article is one of “complexity” and the notion that climatologists cannot perfectly understand thousands of variables, and hence the behavior of the system under investigation. Jacoby is not completely wrong—climate is extremely complex, and poses no shortage of interesting research questions. However, it is sometimes difficult for non-specialists to appreciate the emergent simplicity that can arise in an incredibly complex system. After all, how do we know summer will be warmer than winter, that the top of Mt. Everest is colder than the base, or that Arizona is expected to be on average drier than Florida, or that the equator ought to be hotter than New York, or that the climate will cool following a large volcanic eruption? These statements are not just based on prior observations, but in fact can be predicted by applying fundamental equations to a rotating planet. Part of the beauty in studying atmospheric science is in gaining an appreciation for where complexity is counterbalanced by an almost eerie predictability, much like how the outcome of a single spin in roulette is hopelessly unpredictable (and certainly influenced by every slight detail at the time the dealer releases the ball), but casinos have no problem with such complexity because the statistical behavior of the roulette wheel is well-posed. Similarly, the statistical behavior of the atmosphere, while unsolved, is not actually that complex. The appeal to complexity is a compelling one. Nonetheless, progress has been made in many complex sciences (astrophysics, geology) in which the system under investigation cannot be experimentally isolated, and yet where so much is known. However, it turns out to be incredibly simple to rule out El Niño, volcanic eruptions, soil quality, sunspot cycles, plate tectonics, etc. to the trend in global temperatures since 1950. Just as geologists can inform you of the glacial history of a region, sometimes with little more than a trained eye, CO2 leaves behind “fingerprints” in the atmospheric warming that other “forcing agents” do not. Another perhaps surprising component is that this result is not extremely sensitive to unknown variables. Suppose, for example, that the Andes Mountains were abruptly flattened. This would almost certainly affect important aspects of the global and regional climate, but many of the critical phenomena of the climate system (e.g. that the equator is wet where air rises, that storm tracks develop in the mid-latitudes, the presence of a jet stream, etc.) would still remain. Furthermore, adding CO2 to a “flat-Andes hypothetical Earth” would still result in warming. It’s physics, and it’s unavoidable. It is true that the exact magnitude of future warming, even if we knew future carbon emissions perfectly, is still not known to within even 10%. However, that uncertainty range does not overlap with “very little warming” or “make the planet uninhabitable warming.” In any case, if one’s argument is based on how complex the system is, surely perturbing that complex system is not something they ought to advocate for!
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Climate is complex, but scientists have a good understanding of its variables
FACT1: Climate is a complex system that is influenced by many variables, including greenhouse gases, solar radiation, ocean currents, and land use changes. Scientists have a good understanding of these variables and their interactions, but there is always room for improvement and refinement in their understanding.
MYTH: Climate is too complex to understand, and scientists don't have a good grasp of its variables.
FALLACY: This statement uses ambiguity to create a misleading conclusion. While it is true that climate is a complex system with many variables, scientists have made significant progress in understanding these variables and their interactions. This statement implies that because scientists don't understand every single variable with absolute precision, they don't have a good understanding of climate as a whole, which is not true.
FACT2: Let's not underestimate the progress that scientists have made in understanding climate. We should continue to support their research and use their findings to inform policy decisions.

fact_checked_segment: Scientists such as Dr Willie Soon, a solar astrophysicist at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, have shown that as water vapour rises, so does temperature. It is why cloudless nights are so chilly.
comment_by_fact-checker: The water vapor feedback is one of the main positive feedbacks in the climate system. It has been well understood for much of the century that increased temperatures will increase the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere, trapping additional heat. This is by no means a controversial topic in the scientific community, fringe views by Willie Soon notwithstanding. Water vapor cannot be a forcing because of its extremely short atmospheric lifetime in the troposphere. Adding a bunch of additional water vapor won’t cause long-term changes, at it will quickly precipitate out. However, the absolute amount of water vapor in the atmosphere is strongly determined by the temperature; warm the planet (e.g. by increasing CO2 concentrations) and you will end up with more water vapor in the air. This is why water vapor is a feedback rather than a forcing. This RealClimate post provides some good background on the role of water vapor as a climate feedback.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
MYTH: Water vapor is the main driver of global warming, not carbon dioxide.

FALLACY: This is a false equivalence fallacy, as it assumes that because water vapor and carbon dioxide are both greenhouse gases, they must have equal contributions to global warming. In reality, water vapor is a feedback mechanism that amplifies the warming caused by other greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide. Additionally, carbon dioxide is a much more potent greenhouse gas than water vapor, and its concentration in the atmosphere has increased significantly due to human activities such as burning fossil fuels.

FACT: While water vapor does play a role in the Earth's climate system, it is not the main driver of global warming. The overwhelming scientific consensus is that human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, are the primary cause of the current warming trend. It is important to understand the difference between feedback mechanisms and primary drivers of climate change.

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about the main drivers of global warming. The scientific evidence overwhelmingly supports the conclusion that human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, are the primary cause of the current warming trend.

fact_checked_segment: “the basic rule for staple cereal crops grown at optimal temperature is that for every degree of warming, yields decline by 10 percent. Some estimates run as high as 15 or even 17 percent. Which means that if the planet is five degrees warmer at the end of the century, we may have as many as 50 percent more people to feed and 50 percent less grain to give them.”
comment_by_fact-checker: These numbers stem from the results of controlled field sites (in, for example, the Philippines, India and Mexico) and refer to the impact of local temperature changes on yield, all else being equal. (Also, note that the major grain producing regions are in the midlatitudes, where the projected temperature increases are substantially greater than the projected global average temperature increase.) The projected changes in precipitation are sufficiently uncertain that it is not possible to quantitatively account for the impact of their changes, although the IPCC 2013 WG1 Report concludes: “In many mid-latitude and subtropical dry regions, mean precipitation will likely decrease, while in many mid-latitude wet regions, mean precipitation will likely increase under the RCP8.5 scenario.” (In IPCC lingo, “likely” is greater than 2/3 chance.) Finally, there is also a fertilization effect associated with increasing CO2, although studies have shown that the deleterious impact of increasing temperature far outweigh the impact of increased CO2.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Warming temperatures can significantly reduce crop yields
FACT1: For every degree of warming, yields of staple cereal crops grown at optimal temperature can decline by 10-17 percent. This means that if the planet warms by five degrees by the end of the century, we may have 50 percent less grain to feed a growing population.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: The myth here is the assumption that global warming will not have a significant impact on crop yields. This assumption is flawed because scientific evidence shows that warming temperatures can significantly reduce crop yields, which can have serious consequences for food security.
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the impact of warming temperatures on crop yields and work towards sustainable solutions to mitigate the effects of climate change on agriculture.

fact_checked_segment: “Huge sections of the Great Barrier Reef, stretching across hundreds of miles of its most pristine northern sector, were recently found to be dead, killed last year by overheated seawater.”
comment_by_fact-checker: For validation, see our previous analysis of an article in USA Today titled “Australia’s Great Barrier Reef has worst coral die-off ever”.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Great Barrier Reef Suffers Extensive Damage Due to Overheated Seawater
FACT1: The Great Barrier Reef, one of the world's most iconic natural wonders, has suffered extensive damage due to overheated seawater. Huge sections of the reef, stretching across hundreds of miles of its most pristine northern sector, were recently found to be dead. This damage was caused by a combination of climate change-induced warming of the oceans and a severe El Niño event in 2016. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to take action to reduce our carbon emissions and limit the effects of climate change on our planet. Let's work together to protect our natural wonders like the Great Barrier Reef for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: Computer models of the climate are at the heart of calls to ban the cheap, reliable energy that powers our thriving economy and promotes healthier, longer lives.
comment_by_fact-checker: Also, without numerical computer models we have many lines of evidence that climate change is a problem (basic physics, observed changes, climatic changes in the deep past). The uncertainties and thus the risks would be higher. There would thus be a greater urgency to reduce risks without climate models.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Importance of Climate Models in Understanding Climate Change
FACT1: Climate models are essential tools used by scientists to understand how the Earth's climate system works and how it may change in the future. These models are based on fundamental principles of physics, chemistry, and biology, and are tested against observations of past and present climate conditions. They help us to understand the complex interactions between the atmosphere, oceans, land surface, and ice, and to make predictions about future climate scenarios.
MYTH: Climate models are unreliable and should not be used to inform policy decisions.
FALLACY: This statement is a form of the false equivalence fallacy, which incorrectly claims that two things are equivalent, despite notable differences between them. While it is true that climate models are not perfect and have uncertainties, they are still the best tools we have for understanding the Earth's climate system and making predictions about future climate scenarios. The scientific community has extensively tested and validated climate models, and they are continually being improved as new data and understanding become available. Ignoring the insights provided by climate models would be akin to ignoring the advice of a doctor who has diagnosed a serious illness.
FACT2: Climate models are an essential tool for understanding climate change and making informed policy decisions. Let's trust the scientific community and continue to use these models to guide our actions towards a sustainable future.

fact_checked_segment: Climate projections also assume […] that a temporary terrestrial vertebrate on an evolving planet can change major planetary and extraterrestrial systems.
comment_by_fact-checker: This is the “argument from incredulity” logical fallacy. Ian Plimer is so bemused by the physics of climate change science, he refuses to accept its conclusions.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Projections and Terrestrial Vertebrates
FACT1: Climate projections are based on scientific models that take into account various factors such as greenhouse gas emissions, solar radiation, and ocean currents. These models are constantly being refined and updated as new data becomes available. However, climate projections do not assume that a temporary terrestrial vertebrate can change major planetary and extraterrestrial systems.
MYTH: A warning that a misunderstanding is coming. Climate projections assume that a temporary terrestrial vertebrate on an evolving planet can change major planetary and extraterrestrial systems.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of a Straw Man fallacy, as it misrepresents the scientific understanding of climate projections. Climate projections are based on scientific models that take into account various factors, and do not assume that a single species can change major planetary and extraterrestrial systems.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about climate projections and their assumptions. It is important to understand the scientific basis of climate projections and the factors that contribute to climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Using satellite data rather than tide-gauge data that is normally used to measure sea levels allows for more precise estimates of global sea level, since it provides measurements of the open ocean.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Global geological sea-level data from the Common Era (last 2000 years), global sea-level data from tide gauge records since 1880 and now satellite sea-level data from 1993 all show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating. These accelerations in sea level is a cause for great concern. As the satellite altimetry record length grows so does the satellite derived time series of (near) global mean sea surface height. Putting recent estimates of GMSL, 2.6-3.2 mm/yr, into historical context is an important and daunting task, and is necessary in order to quantify sea-level accelerations, both regionally and globally. This CNN article highlights the importance of Nerem’s excellent paper.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Satellite data provides more precise estimates of global sea level
FACT1: Satellite data is more accurate than tide-gauge data for measuring global sea level because it provides measurements of the open ocean, allowing for more precise estimates.
MYTH: Tide-gauge data is the most accurate way to measure global sea level.
FALLACY: The myth relies on the false assumption that tide-gauge data is the only way to measure sea level. This is a false equivalence fallacy, as it assumes that two methods of measurement are equivalent when they are not. Tide-gauge data is limited to coastal areas and cannot provide measurements of the open ocean, while satellite data can provide a more comprehensive view of sea level changes.
FACT2: Let's use the most accurate and comprehensive data available to measure global sea level and better understand the impacts of climate change on our planet.

fact_checked_segment: Dr Willie Soon’s comparison of temperature data and water vapour [Figure]
comment_by_fact-checker: This follows the physical expectation that water vapour scales with temperature. The temperature change is driving the changes in water vapour (maintaining quasi-constant relative humidity) and not vice-versa. So they are correlated but for precisely the opposite reason than is being reported here.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding the Relationship Between Temperature and Water Vapor
FACT1: Water vapor is the most abundant greenhouse gas in the Earth's atmosphere, and it plays a crucial role in regulating the Earth's temperature. As temperatures rise, the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere also increases, which can lead to a positive feedback loop that amplifies warming.
MYTH: Dr. Willie Soon's comparison of temperature data and water vapor suggests that water vapor is the primary driver of climate change, rather than human activities like burning fossil fuels.
FALLACY: This argument is an example of cherry-picking, as it focuses on one aspect of the climate system while ignoring other factors that contribute to climate change. While water vapor is an important greenhouse gas, it is not the primary driver of climate change. Human activities like burning fossil fuels have led to a significant increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide, which is the primary driver of current warming trends.
FACT2: Understanding the role of water vapor in the Earth's climate is important, but it is also crucial to recognize the significant impact of human activities on the climate. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: “that is a sign the underlying global warming trend is stronger than ever.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The rate of warming has been about the same since 1980. The warming is only exceptionally strong if you were deceived by people claiming that global warming had/has stopped.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Extreme weather events are a sign of global warming
FACT1: Extreme weather events such as heatwaves, droughts, floods, and hurricanes are becoming more frequent and intense due to global warming. This is because the warming of the planet is causing changes in the atmosphere and oceans, leading to more extreme weather conditions.
MYTH: Extreme weather events are just natural occurrences and not related to global warming.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of the false equivalence fallacy, which incorrectly claims that two things are equivalent despite notable differences between them. Extreme weather events are becoming more frequent and intense due to global warming, which is caused by human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation. While natural weather patterns have always existed, the current trend of extreme weather events is not natural and is a result of human-induced climate change.
FACT2: Let's not ignore the evidence and take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the effects of global warming. We can make a difference by reducing our energy consumption, using renewable energy sources, and supporting policies that address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “This is happening even as the overall warming of the planet may, by lengthening growing seasons and moistening the atmosphere, further stoke plant growth.”
comment_by_fact-checker: … note that relative humidity over land, near the surface, is projected to decrease with global warming (i.e., humidity increases more slowly than temperature over land). This has been observed in the past 10-15 years (although the role of variability is still unclear). So “moistening of the atmosphere”, as far as vegetation is concerned, is not accurate (at least globally). See: https://www.climate.gov/news-features/understanding-climate/2013-state-climate-humidity
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change and Plant Growth
FACT1: Climate change is affecting plant growth by lengthening growing seasons and increasing atmospheric moisture, which can lead to increased plant growth in some areas.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: While climate change may have some positive effects on plant growth in certain areas, it is important to remember that it also has negative effects such as droughts, heatwaves, and extreme weather events that can harm plant growth and agriculture. It is crucial to address climate change to ensure the long-term health and productivity of our planet's ecosystems. Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and support sustainable practices.

fact_checked_segment: natural warm times, like now, bring great prosperity, increased longevity and less disease, whereas Jack Frost brings death, depopulation and economic stresses.
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a common misconception. We are not talking about minor climate fluctuations, we are experiencing a major, abrupt climate change. Because current climate change is so fast, ecosystems are at risk, infrastructure is at risk, and the result will certainly not bring great prosperity. Climate change related health impacts are also on the rise, so there will certainly not be “less disease”
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Benefits and Drawbacks of Natural Warm Times
FACT1: Natural warm times can bring benefits such as increased agricultural productivity, longer growing seasons, and reduced energy consumption for heating. However, they can also lead to negative consequences such as droughts, heatwaves, and increased risk of wildfires.
MYTH: Natural warm times always bring prosperity and health benefits, while cold times bring death and economic stress.
FALLACY: This argument is a false dichotomy, presenting only two extreme options and ignoring the complexity of the issue. It also uses anecdotal evidence and oversimplification to support its claims, ignoring the potential negative consequences of natural warm times.
FACT2: It is important to consider the full range of potential consequences of natural warm times, both positive and negative, in order to make informed decisions about how to address climate change. Let's not oversimplify the issue and instead seek to understand the full picture.

fact_checked_segment: ” ‘and it’s only got to take one sizable volcano to erupt and all the models, everything else, is right off the board’ ”
comment_by_fact-checker: Volcanoes have a sizable impact on the climate, but a relatively short-lived one. The impact of a large volcano like the Pinatubo eruption in 1991 will cool the climate for a few years, but after five years or so the system would revert to nearly the same state it would have been without the eruption*. It would take a supervolcano or a large period of extended volcanism to seriously disrupt our modeled scenarios, and these sort of events are relatively rare (the odds of them happening in the next 100 years are very small). Some climate models do actually have volcanoes of various sizes stuck in randomly in the future (since we can’t really predict future volcanism apart from assuming it occurs at roughly the same rate as we’ve experienced in the past), but the inclusion of these don’t really change the expected warming or other climate impacts in the next century. Hansen et al (1996) A Pinatubo Climate Modeling Investigation
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Volcanoes can't explain global warming
FACT1: While volcanic eruptions can release large amounts of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, they are not responsible for the current trend of global warming. 
MYTH: Volcanic eruptions can explain the current trend of global warming.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false cause fallacy, which assumes that because two events occur together, one must have caused the other. While volcanic eruptions can contribute to short-term fluctuations in temperature, they do not explain the long-term trend of global warming that has been observed over the past century. 
FACT2: Let's not use volcanic eruptions as an excuse to ignore the overwhelming evidence that human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, are the primary cause of global warming.

fact_checked_segment: Skeptics claim such anomalies prove that Earth can quickly warm and cool even in the absence of carbon dioxide, and any warming today may be caused by similar natural events.
comment_by_fact-checker: And climate scientists would agree—a large volcanic eruption will quickly (albeit temporarily) cool the Earth. Critically, there is zero evidence that present day warming is caused by anything other than human activity.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Natural Anomalies Can't Explain Current Warming
FACT1: Natural anomalies, such as volcanic eruptions and changes in solar radiation, have caused short-term climate fluctuations in the past. However, they cannot explain the current warming trend, which is occurring at an unprecedented rate and is directly linked to human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation.
MYTH: Skeptics claim that natural anomalies can explain the current warming trend and that human activities are not responsible for it.
FALLACY: This argument relies on the false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that because natural anomalies have caused climate fluctuations in the past, they must be the cause of the current warming trend. This ignores the overwhelming scientific evidence that human activities are the primary cause of the current warming trend.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's educate ourselves and others about the overwhelming scientific evidence that human activities are causing the current warming trend and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: “When someone says, ‘climate science is settled,’ remind them to check the facts.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement highlights the major problem with this article. The authors do not support their claims with scientific references and data. Their logic is flawed and does not take into account basic scientific theories that explain, for example, the role of certain gases in causing a greenhouse effect and the negative impacts of high levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. […] So based on this statement and the lack of scientific references in this article, readers should be prompted to disregard the majority of claims it presents.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The Fallacy of "Climate Science is Not Settled"
FACT1: Climate science is a complex and evolving field that involves the study of the Earth's climate system, including the atmosphere, oceans, land, and ice. Scientists use a variety of methods, including observations, computer models, and experiments, to understand how the climate is changing and what the impacts of those changes will be.
MYTH: "Climate science is settled" is a myth that suggests that there is no room for further scientific inquiry or debate on the topic of climate change.
FALLACY: The fallacy of "climate science is not settled" is a false dichotomy that presents a misleading choice between two extremes: either the science is completely settled and there is no room for further inquiry, or the science is completely uncertain and there is no basis for action. In reality, science is never completely settled, but that does not mean that there is no basis for action. The overwhelming consensus among climate scientists is that human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, are causing the Earth's climate to change at an unprecedented rate, and that urgent action is needed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change.
FACT2: Let's not use the fallacy of "climate science is not settled" to delay action on climate change. Instead, let's continue to support scientific inquiry and use the best available evidence to inform policy decisions.

fact_checked_segment: “a warming planet causes our weather to become more stuck in place”
comment_by_fact-checker: This claim is somewhat overly confident given the available evidence. Observational studies (e.g. Francis and Vavrus 2015*) do indeed suggest that the “waviness” of the jet stream and subsequently the propensity for weather patterns to become more persistent has increased in certain regions and during certain seasons, although this is not universally true. There is also emerging evidence that the rapid warming of the Arctic may be playing a role in creating the conditions favorable for weather patterns to become “stuck in place”—a hypothesis that the new Mann et al. 2017* paper discussed in the article supports. The connections between amplified Arctic warming and mid-latitude weather extremes remains a very active area of scientific research (Overland et al. 2016*), however, and considerable uncertainty regarding the magnitude and mechanisms of this effect remain. Francis and Vavrus (2015) Evidence for a wavier jet stream in response to rapid Arctic warming, Environmental Research Letters Mann et al (2017) Influence of Anthropogenic Climate Change on Planetary Wave Resonance and Extreme Weather Events, Scientific Reports Overland et al (2016) Nonlinear response of mid-latitude weather to the changing Arctic, Nature Climate Change
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change and Weather Patterns
FACT1: Climate change can cause weather patterns to become more persistent and extreme, leading to more frequent and severe heatwaves, droughts, and floods.
MYTH: A warming planet causes our weather to become more stuck in place.
FALLACY: This myth is an oversimplification of the complex relationship between climate change and weather patterns. While it is true that a warming planet can cause weather patterns to become more persistent, this is just one aspect of the overall impact of climate change on weather. Climate change can also lead to more extreme weather events, such as hurricanes, tornadoes, and wildfires, as well as changes in precipitation patterns and sea level rise.
FACT2: It is important to recognize the complex and varied impacts of climate change on weather patterns, and to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change. Let's work together to protect our planet and our communities from the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Fires have not only been increasing in size due to climate change. In the early 20th century, state and federal governments began aggressively fighting wildfires and trying to keep them as small as possible. This has caused denser and more fire-prone forests than the long-term average for the West, which has led to more massive and uncontrollable fires.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement should have included a citation and also noted that the influence of fire suppression on subsequent fire activity varies with the frequency of historical fires. The century of fire suppression has potentially increased fuel accumulation in dry forests that historically experienced very frequent fires (e.g. every 5-20 years). On the other hand, fire suppression has likely had far less of an impact on wetter forests, such as those in coastal Oregon and Washington, that historically went centuries without fire.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
FACT1: Aggressive wildfire suppression in the early 20th century has led to denser and more fire-prone forests in the Western US, contributing to the increase in massive and uncontrollable fires. 

MYTH: The increase in the size of wildfires is solely due to climate change. 

FALLACY: This myth is an example of oversimplification, assuming that there is only one cause for the increase in wildfire size. While climate change has contributed to the problem, aggressive wildfire suppression has also played a significant role. By preventing smaller fires from burning through forests, fuel builds up over time, creating denser forests that are more prone to large fires. 

FACT2: Understanding the multiple factors that contribute to the increase in wildfire size is crucial in developing effective strategies to prevent and manage them. Let's not oversimplify the issue and instead consider all the contributing factors.

fact_checked_segment: “Two degrees is more significant than it sounds. […]The number may sound low, but as an average over the surface of an entire planet, it is actually high”
comment_by_fact-checker: Note that the warming over land is about twice as large as the warming over the ocean. Over the ocean, more of the additional heat goes into evaporation of water rather than warming of the air. It furthermore takes time to heat up the oceans, just like a water kettle takes time to boil. Because there is more land in the Northern Hemisphere, it will warm more than the Southern Hemisphere. One way to see how much of a difference two degrees makes is to look at a region closer to the equator that is two degrees warmer. Nature will look very different.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Significance of Two Degrees Celsius
FACT1: Two degrees Celsius is a significant increase in global temperature. It may sound low, but as an average over the surface of an entire planet, it is actually high. This increase can have severe consequences for the planet and its inhabitants.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: The fallacy of equivocation, which involves using a term with multiple meanings in an ambiguous way. In this case, the term "two degrees" is being equivocated, as it can refer to a small number in absolute terms, but a significant increase in global temperature.
FACT2: Let's not underestimate the significance of a two-degree increase in global temperature. We must take action to mitigate the effects of climate change and work towards a sustainable future.

fact_checked_segment: “The peer-reviewed study by two scientists and a veteran statistician looked at the global average temperature datasets[…]”
comment_by_fact-checker: In addition to not being peer reviewed, the study also doesn’t appear to cite ANY peer-reviewed literature to support its conclusions, nor does the report provide any additional references. Furthermore, the report appears to have a clear dismissive tone towards peer-reviewed research and uses dubious language such as “Climate Alarmist”, further straining the credibility of the report this article is based solely on.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Peer-Reviewed Study Finds Global Warming is Real
FACT1: A recent peer-reviewed study conducted by two scientists and a veteran statistician analyzed global average temperature datasets and found that global warming is real and that the warming trend is accelerating.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's trust the scientific consensus on climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: The effect of long-term warming is to make it harder to count on snowmelt runoff in wet times
comment_by_fact-checker: This is true even if there is no large-scale change in overall precipitation in the watershed. Warmer temperatures will both increase local evaporation rates and cause an earlier and reduced snowmelt season. Both of these mechanisms reduce the availability of snowmelt runoff through the summer.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Snowmelt Runoff and Long-Term Warming
FACT1: Snowmelt runoff is an important source of water for many regions, especially during wet times. However, long-term warming can make it harder to rely on snowmelt runoff as a consistent source of water. Warmer temperatures can cause snow to melt earlier in the season, leading to less water availability during dry times. 
MYTH: Snowmelt runoff is a reliable source of water that can always be counted on, regardless of long-term warming trends.
FALLACY: The myth relies on a false equivalence between past and future conditions. Just because snowmelt runoff has been reliable in the past does not mean it will continue to be so in the future, especially as long-term warming trends continue. Additionally, the myth ignores the fact that warmer temperatures can cause snow to melt earlier in the season, leading to less water availability during dry times.
FACT2: It is important to consider the potential impacts of long-term warming on snowmelt runoff and water availability in order to better prepare for future water management. Let's not assume that snowmelt runoff will always be a reliable source of water and instead work towards sustainable water management practices.

fact_checked_segment: But each serial adjustment has tended to make the early years colder, which increases the warming trend.
comment_by_fact-checker: While this says that adjustments increase the total warming, they actually decrease it since the 1800s.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Serial adjustments in temperature data
FACT1: Temperature data is often adjusted to account for changes in measurement methods, station locations, and other factors that can affect the accuracy of the data. These adjustments are made to ensure that the data is as accurate and reliable as possible.
MYTH: Temperature adjustments are made to increase the warming trend.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, where only a small part of the data is selected to support a particular argument. While it is true that some adjustments may make earlier years colder, other adjustments may make them warmer. The overall effect of adjustments is to improve the accuracy of the data, not to increase the warming trend.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about temperature adjustments. These adjustments are made to ensure that the data is as accurate and reliable as possible.

fact_checked_segment: as time progresses and fossil fuel emissions increase, the number of record highs should increase and record lows should decrease.
comment_by_fact-checker: In fact, globally, record daily high temperatures are outpacing record daily lows. This is even also the case over the relatively small region of the globe we call the US. See, for example, this Climate Central article.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Climate change is causing an increase in the frequency and intensity of heatwaves, which leads to more record high temperatures and fewer record low temperatures.

MYTH: The number of record highs should increase and record lows should decrease as time progresses and fossil fuel emissions increase.
