FALLACY: This is an example of oversimplification, as it assumes that the relationship between fossil fuel emissions and temperature records is straightforward. In reality, there are many factors that can influence temperature records, including natural variability and regional differences.

FACT2: It is important to understand the complex factors that influence temperature records and to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in order to mitigate the impacts of climate change. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and instead work towards a sustainable future.

fact_checked_segment: “about 56 million years ago … The planet proceeded to warm rapidly, at least in geologic terms, and major die-offs of some marine organisms followed due to strong acidification of the oceans.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The event was a “strong acidification” event relative to changes that ordinarily occur over geologic time but it was a weak event compared to what our modern industrial society is threatening to produce. If anything, Chris Mooney is erring on the side of downplaying risks from ocean acidification by saying that “major die-offs” were associated with a “strong acidification” event, when in fact they have been associated with events that are far weaker than we will produce with continued burning of coal, oil, and gas.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Acidification of the oceans caused major die-offs of marine organisms 56 million years ago
FACT1: Acidification of the oceans can cause major die-offs of marine organisms. This occurs when carbon dioxide dissolves in seawater, forming carbonic acid and lowering the pH of the water. This can make it difficult for marine organisms to build shells and skeletons, and can also harm other aspects of their physiology.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Today, human activities are causing the oceans to acidify at a rate faster than any time in the past 300 million years. This is due to the large amounts of carbon dioxide we are emitting into the atmosphere, which is being absorbed by the oceans. It is important to reduce our carbon emissions to slow down this process and protect marine ecosystems. Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and protect our oceans.

fact_checked_segment: “The problem with this ploy is that carbon dioxide is not a pollutant and it is dishonest to say it is. CO2 is colorless, odorless and completely non-toxic. Plants depend on it to live and grow, and human beings draw some into their lungs with every breath they take to no ill effect whatsoever. Growers regularly pump CO2 into greenhouses, raising levels to three times that of the natural environment, to produce stronger, greener, healthier plants.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Again, the point is not “is CO2 a pollutant or not”. (I believe the Supreme Court said it is.) The point is: CO2 emissions in the atmosphere lead to climate change as CO2 is a greenhouse gas. Climate change has and will have negative impact on ecosystems (land and ocean). The author deliberately ignores this.
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: CO2 is not a pollutant
FACT1: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is a naturally occurring gas that is colorless, odorless, and non-toxic. It is a vital component of the Earth's atmosphere and is necessary for plant growth and human respiration. 
MYTH: CO2 is a pollutant.
FALLACY: The argument uses a straw man fallacy by misrepresenting the definition of a pollutant. A pollutant is any substance that causes harm to the environment or living organisms. While CO2 is not toxic, it is a greenhouse gas that contributes to climate change and can have harmful effects on the environment and human health in high concentrations. 
FACT2: While CO2 is not toxic, it is still considered a pollutant because of its contribution to climate change. Let's not spread misinformation about the definition of pollutants and their effects on the environment.

fact_checked_segment: “Healthy societies do not fall apart over slow, widely predicted, relatively small economic adjustments of the sort painted by climate analysis. Societies do fall apart from war, disease or chaos. Climate policy must compete with other long-term threats for always-scarce resources.”
comment_by_fact-checker: To suggest that climate change does not bear (or has little bearing) upon war, disease, and chaos represents either an exceedingly narrow and optimistic view of available peer reviewed research on the influence of climate change on these outcomes or ignorance. The extraordinary threat that climate change already poses to national security was outlined by the U.S. Defense Department in 2015. Research on climate change and infectious disease risks suggests that it either directly (through changes in mosquito population distributions) or indirectly (through forcing mass migrations) will augment risks of pandemics.
label: false analogy
debunk:
FACT1: Climate change is a long-term threat that requires action to prevent catastrophic consequences. It is not just a small economic adjustment, but a global issue that affects the environment, economy, and society as a whole. 

MYTH: Climate policy is not a priority because it competes with other long-term threats for resources. 

FALLACY: This argument is a false dichotomy, suggesting that we must choose between addressing climate change and other long-term threats. In reality, we can and must address multiple threats simultaneously. Additionally, climate change is not just a long-term threat, but also a current and urgent one that requires immediate action. 

FACT2: We must prioritize action on climate change as a critical threat to our society and the planet. We can and must allocate resources to address multiple threats simultaneously. Let's not delay action on climate change and work towards a sustainable future for all.

fact_checked_segment: “When someone says, ‘climate science is settled,’ remind them to check the facts.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The basic radiation physics has been well known for 150 years. The details will always be under discussion, but we are already seeing very clearly the expected patterns of climate change.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Fallacy of Settled Science
FACT1: Science is a process of continuous inquiry and refinement, and no scientific theory is ever truly "settled." However, the overwhelming majority of climate scientists agree that human activities are causing global warming and climate change.
MYTH: The myth is that climate science is "settled" and there is no room for further inquiry or debate.
FALLACY: This is a false dichotomy fallacy, which presents only two options when there are actually more. The idea that climate science is either "settled" or completely uncertain is a false choice. In reality, there is a high degree of scientific consensus on the issue of human-caused climate change, but there is still ongoing research and debate about the details and potential solutions.
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the scientific consensus on climate change and continue to support research and innovation to better understand and address this global challenge.

fact_checked_segment: “The problem with this ploy is that carbon dioxide is not a pollutant and it is dishonest to say it is. CO2 is colorless, odorless and completely non-toxic. Plants depend on it to live and grow, and human beings draw some into their lungs with every breath they take to no ill effect whatsoever. Growers regularly pump CO2 into greenhouses, raising levels to three times that of the natural environment, to produce stronger, greener, healthier plants.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This depends on the definition of “pollutant”. To the extent that CO2-induced global warming endangers human welfare and health, CO2 fits the Clean Air Act’s broad definition of “air pollutants”—that’s the reasoning behind the Supreme Court’s decision to let the EPA regulate CO2 emissions. Not that this is relevant to the definition of CO2 as a pollutant (which relies on it causing climate change), but the alleged total non-toxicity is not entirely true: there is some research* showing impairments in cognitive function test scores in people exposed to CO2 concentrations in the 950-1,000 ppm range, and even significantly worse performance when CO2 rose to 1500 and 2,500 ppm. Current atmospheric CO2 is around 400 ppm—possibly going up at least a few more hundred ppm this century without emission cuts—but concentrations greater than ~1000 ppm are often found in poorly ventilated rooms and buildings. Allen et al (2016) Associations of cognitive function scores with carbon dioxide, ventilation, and volatile organic compound exposures in office workers: a controlled exposure study of green and conventional office environments, Environmental Health
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Truth About Carbon Dioxide
FACT1: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is a naturally occurring gas that is essential for life on Earth. It is colorless, odorless, and non-toxic. Plants use CO2 to produce oxygen through photosynthesis, and humans exhale CO2 with every breath they take. However, the increase in CO2 levels due to human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, is causing significant changes in the Earth's climate.
MYTH: CO2 is not a pollutant and is beneficial for the environment.
FALLACY: The argument is based on a false premise that CO2 is not a pollutant and ignores the fact that the increase in CO2 levels due to human activities is causing significant changes in the Earth's climate. The argument also uses the "straw man" fallacy by misrepresenting the argument that CO2 is a pollutant by claiming that it is being called toxic or harmful to human health, which is not the case.
FACT2: Let's not ignore the scientific evidence that shows the increase in CO2 levels due to human activities is causing significant changes in the Earth's climate. We need to take action to reduce our carbon footprint and transition to cleaner sources of energy to mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The list of variables that shape climate […] would run to hundreds, if not thousands, of elements, none of which scientists would claim to understand with absolute precision.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Jacoby is making a laundry list, not trying to understand the issues. He is also confusing the issue by trying to claim that since scientists cannot predict climate change at a given small location at a fixed point in future time that they do not have the ability to generally predict the the future trend. Climate scientists are after the trend. Most of the variables he mentions cause the local climate to deviate to a small extent from the trend. Some, like volcanic activity or El Niño, affect the climate for a small number of years, and then their effect disappears.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Climate is complex and has many variables
FACT1: Climate is a complex system that is influenced by many variables, including solar radiation, greenhouse gases, ocean currents, and land use changes. Scientists do not claim to understand all of these variables with absolute precision, but they use models and data to make predictions about future climate trends.
MYTH: Climate science is not reliable because scientists do not understand all the variables that shape climate.
FALLACY: This is an example of the ambiguity fallacy, which uses vague language to lead to a misleading conclusion. While it is true that climate is complex and has many variables, scientists have made significant progress in understanding and modeling these variables. The fact that there is uncertainty in some aspects of climate science does not mean that the entire field is unreliable.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about climate science. While there is still much to learn about the complexities of climate, scientists have made significant progress in understanding and modeling the many variables that shape our climate.

fact_checked_segment: “Then it will destroy all the species that depend on it — causing an almighty mass extinction which will wipe out the fishing industry and turn our oceans into a barren zone of death.”
comment_by_fact-checker: That is not a truthful summary of the scientific literature. Check, for example, the meta-analysis of Kroeker et al. (2013) who describe processes and organisms that do not seem to be affected by ocean acidification. Kroeker et al. (2013) Impacts of ocean acidification on marine organisms: quantifying sensitivities and interaction with warming. Global Change Biology.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The impact of overfishing on marine ecosystems
FACT1: Overfishing can have devastating effects on marine ecosystems, leading to the depletion of fish populations and the disruption of entire food webs. This can have serious consequences for the health of our oceans and the species that depend on them.
MYTH: None stated.
FALLACY: This statement uses hyperbolic language to exaggerate the potential consequences of overfishing. While overfishing can have serious consequences, it is unlikely to result in a complete "barren zone of death." This type of language is an example of the slippery slope fallacy, which suggests that taking a minor action will inevitably lead to major consequences.
FACT2: It is important to manage fish populations sustainably to ensure the long-term health of our oceans and the species that depend on them. Let's support sustainable fishing practices and work to protect our marine ecosystems.

fact_checked_segment: “Sea level rise of 65 centimeters, or roughly 2 feet would cause significant problems for coastal cities around the world.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It should be mentioned that this is a global average. The increase will not be uniform—exacerbating the consequences described below
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Impact of Sea Level Rise on Coastal Cities
FACT1: Sea level rise of 65 centimeters (roughly 2 feet) would have significant consequences for coastal cities worldwide. This rise would lead to more frequent and severe flooding, erosion of beaches and shorelines, and damage to infrastructure such as roads, buildings, and sewage systems. It would also increase the risk of storm surges and saltwater intrusion into freshwater sources.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: The myth here is that sea level rise is not a significant problem for coastal cities. This fallacy is based on a lack of understanding of the potential consequences of sea level rise and the impact it can have on coastal communities. It is important to recognize that sea level rise is a real and pressing issue that requires immediate action to mitigate its effects.

FACT2: Let's not ignore the potential consequences of sea level rise on coastal cities. We must take action to reduce our carbon emissions and invest in infrastructure to protect our communities from the impacts of sea level rise. By working together, we can ensure a safer and more sustainable future for ourselves and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “To make matters worse, the water temperatures in the Arctic Ocean are several degrees above average, which is an expected result of having less sea ice.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Generally, the absorbed solar radiation leads to enhanced ocean temperatures in the mixed layer, so with summers of less ice the ocean mixed layer temperatures are usually warmer than average. Though even that is more driven by the timing of when the sea ice retreats. If it retreats early in the melt season when the sun is still high in the sky then you get more ocean warming, but if like in 2012 the ice retreats rapidly in August, it doesn’t have the same impact on ocean temperatures because the sun is already starting to set. But while this may be part of the explanation for warmer ocean temperatures at the moment, in the Barents Sea it is actually a result of warm Atlantic waters entering the Arctic. I have spoken with oceanographers about this and the sea surface temperature anomalies are a result of stronger inflow to the Barents Sea and along the west coast of Svalbard. The strong northwards flow of Atlantic water is also consistent with the more southerly winds this November that have helped to bring in warm air temperatures.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Arctic Ocean Water Temperatures are Above Average
FACT1: The water temperatures in the Arctic Ocean are several degrees above average.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: The warming of the Arctic Ocean is a clear sign of the impact of climate change. As the sea ice melts, the ocean absorbs more heat from the sun, which leads to further warming and melting. This vicious cycle is a major concern for the Arctic ecosystem and has global implications for sea level rise and weather patterns. Let's take action to reduce our carbon emissions and protect the Arctic.

fact_checked_segment: “Lake-bottom sediments in Florida tell us that recent major hurricane activity in the Gulf of Mexico has been less frequent than in centuries past.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The lake-bottom sediment study, in which I participated, catalogued hurricanes at a particular location over several thousand years. There are indeed centennial-scale variations at particular locations that are not strongly correlated across different locations, so the authors interpreted these fluctuations in terms of changing [hurricane] tracks. The technique cannot distinguish between a weak event nearby and a strong one at a distance, so there is little data pertaining to storm intensity.
label: red herring
debunk:
FACT1: Hurricane activity in the Gulf of Mexico has varied over centuries, with some periods having more frequent major hurricanes than others. This is based on analysis of lake-bottom sediments in Florida. 

MYTH: There is a belief that recent hurricane activity in the Gulf of Mexico has been more frequent than in centuries past.

FALLACY: This myth is based on a misunderstanding of historical hurricane activity in the Gulf of Mexico. While there have been some recent high-impact hurricanes, the overall frequency of major hurricanes in the Gulf has varied over centuries. The analysis of lake-bottom sediments in Florida provides evidence of this variability. 

FACT2: Understanding the historical variability of hurricane activity in the Gulf of Mexico can help us better prepare for future hurricane seasons. Let's not spread misinformation about hurricane activity and instead focus on taking necessary precautions to protect ourselves and our communities.

fact_checked_segment: paints a far more dire picture of the immediate consequences of climate change than previously thought
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement and similar statements would benefit from specific examples from the report or more context. Although I agree the problem is dire, I’m not sure which aspect of the problem is worse than previously thought. For example, the carbon budget (i.e., how much humans can emit and still warm less than 1.5 degrees C) has expanded from previous estimates. It may be that some impacts will be felt earlier or will be worse than previously estimated—this just wasn’t clearly articulated. Other statements that I thought could have used greater context or examples from the report include the quote by Bill Hare (below), or the statement that “the new report, however, shows that many of those effects will come much sooner, at the 2.7-degree mark.”
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
{
    "TITLE": "Climate change has immediate and severe consequences",
    "FACT1": "Climate change is causing more frequent and severe weather events, such as heatwaves, droughts, floods, and hurricanes, which have devastating impacts on human health, infrastructure, and economies.",
    "MYTH": "Climate change is not an urgent problem and its consequences are not severe.",
    "FALLACY": "This myth is based on the fallacy of downplaying the severity of the problem and ignoring the overwhelming scientific evidence that shows the immediate and severe consequences of climate change.",
    "FACT2": "Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and support policies that address climate change, such as renewable energy and carbon pricing, to mitigate its impacts and protect our planet for future generations."
}

fact_checked_segment: “The Arctic’s carbon bomb might be even more potent than we thought […] methane, a shorter-lived but far harder-hitting gas that could cause faster bursts of warming”
comment_by_fact-checker: This wording suggests that permafrost melt in the Arctic is an abrupt event. Even the new research referred to here doesn’t put earlier work* fundamentally into question that argued for “a gradual and prolonged release of greenhouse gas emissions in a warming climate”. Shuur et al (2015) Climate change and the permafrost carbon feedback, Nature
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Methane in the Arctic is a potent greenhouse gas
FACT1: Methane is a greenhouse gas that is more potent than carbon dioxide, and it is released in large quantities from the Arctic permafrost. Methane has a shorter lifespan in the atmosphere than carbon dioxide, but it is far more effective at trapping heat, making it a potent contributor to global warming. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, including methane, to mitigate the effects of climate change. Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and support policies that prioritize renewable energy and sustainable practices.

fact_checked_segment: “Last year’s warmth was manifested across the planet, from the warm tropical ocean waters off the coast of northeastern Australia, where the Great Barrier Reef experienced its worst coral bleaching event on record and large scale coral death, to the Arctic, where sea ice hit regular monthly record lows and overall temperatures were also the warmest on record, at least from January through September 2016.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The article overlooks the fact that not only was the bleaching on the northern Great Barrier Reef the worst on record, so was the bleaching in many areas around the world. In fact, the global coral bleaching event that is still underway is the longest, most widespread, and perhaps most damaging event on record.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Record-breaking warmth in 2016
FACT1: 2016 was a year of record-breaking warmth across the globe. The Great Barrier Reef experienced its worst coral bleaching event on record due to warm tropical ocean waters off the coast of northeastern Australia. The Arctic also experienced record warmth, with sea ice hitting regular monthly record lows.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the reality of climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: “An additional kick was supplied by an El Niño weather pattern that peaked in 2016 and temporarily warmed much of the surface of the planet, causing the hottest year in a historical record dating to 1880.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a very common misconception even among scientists. The warming, bleaching, and coral loss is 100% due to greenhouse gas emissions, not the ENSO cycle and the fact that we were in a peak of the El Niño phase in early 2016. The Great Barrier Reef has experienced El Niño events for thousands of years, yet bleaching wasn’t observed there until 1998 when ocean warming pushed ocean temperatures just above the bleaching threshold.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: El Niño and 2016: The Hottest Year on Record
FACT1: The year 2016 was the hottest year on record since 1880, with global temperatures reaching unprecedented levels. This was partly due to the El Niño weather pattern, which temporarily warmed much of the planet's surface.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to recognize the role of natural phenomena such as El Niño in contributing to global temperature increases, but it is also crucial to acknowledge the overwhelming scientific consensus that human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, are the primary cause of climate change. Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “In 2013, scientists reached a consensus that three feet was the highest plausible rise by the year 2100. But now some of them are starting to say that six or seven feet may be possible.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Yes, I couldn’t agree more. I actually wrote a paper regarding a survey of sea-level scientists. The concluding statement was that most experts estimate a larger sea-level rise by AD 2100 than the IPCC’s Fifth Assessment Report AR5 projects: Horton, Rahmstorf, Engelhart, and Kemp (2014) Expert assessment of sea-level rise by AD 2100 and AD 2300. Quaternary Science Reviews
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Possibility of Higher Sea Level Rise
FACT1: Sea level rise is a major consequence of climate change, caused by the melting of glaciers and ice sheets and the thermal expansion of seawater. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has projected a global sea level rise of 0.3 to 1.1 meters (1 to 3.6 feet) by 2100, depending on future greenhouse gas emissions.
MYTH: Scientists initially agreed that the highest plausible sea level rise by 2100 was three feet, but now some are saying it could be as high as six or seven feet.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, as it focuses on a few scientists who have suggested higher sea level rise scenarios while ignoring the consensus projections of the IPCC and other scientific bodies. It also implies that scientists were wrong or misled in their initial projections, when in fact they have always acknowledged the uncertainty and potential for higher sea level rise.
FACT2: While some scientists have suggested higher sea level rise scenarios based on new research and observations, the consensus projections of the IPCC and other scientific bodies remain the most reliable and widely accepted estimates. It is important to continue monitoring and studying sea level rise to better understand and prepare for its impacts. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and instead rely on the consensus projections of the scientific community.

fact_checked_segment: Because it’s getting warmer, there’s more CO2 coming out which means it’s going to get warmer which means there’s more CO2 coming out[…] And it will just run away with itself.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a simplistic description of a positive feedback. Yes, warming would lead to release of carbon from soils and permafrost, and this would lead to more warming, hence more carbon loss. But in no way would this lead to a runaway feedback. Say a warming of 1°C led to a release of carbon from soils that induces an additional warming of 0.1°C (that’s quite a large positive feedback: 10% of the initial perturbation). This additional 0.1°C would lead to an additional release of carbon, inducing an additional warming of 0.01°C, which will lead to more carbon released and an additional 0.001°C warming, etc… Ultimately, warming will be 1.111…°C—larger than the initial warming of 1°C but quite far from a runaway scenario.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: The Feedback Loop Fallacy
FACT1: The Feedback Loop Fallacy is the idea that a small change in one direction will lead to an unstoppable chain reaction in the same direction. This fallacy is often used to argue that climate change will spiral out of control and that there is nothing we can do to stop it.
MYTH: "Because it’s getting warmer, there’s more CO2 coming out which means it’s going to get warmer which means there’s more CO2 coming out[…] And it will just run away with itself."
FALLACY: This argument is based on the Feedback Loop Fallacy. While it is true that warming temperatures can cause more CO2 to be released from the oceans and other sources, this does not mean that the process will continue indefinitely. In reality, there are many factors that can limit the amount of CO2 that is released, such as the ability of plants to absorb CO2 through photosynthesis. Additionally, human actions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions can help to slow or even reverse the warming trend.
FACT2: Let's not fall for the Feedback Loop Fallacy. While climate change is a serious issue, it is not an unstoppable force. By taking action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions, we can help to mitigate the worst effects of climate change and create a more sustainable future.

fact_checked_segment: We are expected to believe that emission of traces of a trace gas into the atmosphere is a major planetary driving force.
comment_by_fact-checker: I assume then that Ian also denies the existence of the ozone hole due to emissions of trace gases such as CFCs and HFCs?
label: no fallacy
debunk:
MYTH: The myth is that the emission of a trace gas, such as carbon dioxide, into the atmosphere cannot be a major driving force behind climate change.

FALLACY: This myth is an oversimplification fallacy. While carbon dioxide is a trace gas, it is also a greenhouse gas that traps heat in the atmosphere. The increase in carbon dioxide emissions from human activities has led to a significant increase in atmospheric concentrations of this gas, which has caused the Earth's temperature to rise. This warming effect has been observed and measured by scientists around the world.

FACT1: Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas that traps heat in the atmosphere, and its increase in concentration has led to a significant increase in the Earth's temperature.

FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's educate ourselves on the science behind climate change and the role that carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases play in it. By understanding the facts, we can take action to reduce our carbon footprint and help mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “‘If we are right, our study challenges decades of paleoclimate research,” said Anders Meibom, the head of EPFL’s Laboratory for Biological Geochemistry and a professor at the University of Lausanne.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It only potentially challenges ONE method used to reconstruct past temperatures. Other methods and observations based on biomarkers, pollen, large fossils support a much warmer ocean at this time.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: New study challenges previous paleoclimate research
FACT1: A recent study conducted by EPFL's Laboratory for Biological Geochemistry challenges previous paleoclimate research. The study suggests that the Earth's climate may have been more sensitive to CO2 in the past than previously thought. The researchers used coral samples to reconstruct past ocean temperatures and found that the Earth's climate may have been more sensitive to CO2 during warm periods than during cold periods.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to continue conducting research and analyzing data to gain a better understanding of the Earth's climate and how it has changed over time. Let's support scientific research and use evidence-based information to inform our understanding of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: Globally averaged thermometers show two periods of warming since 1900: a half-degree from natural causes in the first half of the 20th century, before there was an increase in industrial carbon dioxide that was enough to produce it, and another half-degree in the last quarter of the century.
comment_by_fact-checker: To be clear, that is half a degree Celsius, a full degree Fahrenheit.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Two Periods of Warming in the 20th Century
FACT1: The Earth's temperature has risen by half a degree Celsius in two periods of warming since 1900. The first period occurred in the first half of the 20th century due to natural causes, while the second period occurred in the last quarter of the century due to an increase in industrial carbon dioxide.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's continue to monitor and address the causes of global warming to prevent further temperature increases and their negative impacts on our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “Burning gas instead of coal in power plants reduces emissions in the short run, though gas is still a fossil fuel and will have to be phased out in the long run.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is arguable whether natural gas is a reasonable solution even in the short run. I argued in favor of this 20 years ago, but nowadays we have to cut emissions more drastically than would be possible by switching to another fossil fuel. The CO2 coefficient of natural gas is still about 2/3 of that of coal. Efficiency factors of power plants are also somewhat better for natural gas than for coal. Overall, we might save a bit more than half of the emissions by switching to natural gas while renewables can save much more. Furthermore, given the long technical lifetime of power stations, the “short run” could easily extend to 2060 or more.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Gas is a fossil fuel that produces less emissions than coal when burned in power plants, but it still contributes to climate change and needs to be phased out in the long run.

MYTH: Burning gas is a long-term solution to reduce emissions.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of oversimplification. While burning gas instead of coal does reduce emissions in the short run, it is not a long-term solution to address climate change. Gas is still a fossil fuel that contributes to greenhouse gas emissions and needs to be phased out in the long run to achieve a sustainable future.

FACT2: Let's not rely on gas as a long-term solution to reduce emissions. Instead, we should invest in renewable energy sources like wind and solar power to transition to a sustainable future.

fact_checked_segment: the first scientists to show that the thick icecap that once covered the Arctic ocean was beginning to thin and shrink.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a misleading term. Ice caps are technically large land-based glaciers, whereas I think ‘Arctic icecaps’ here mean Arctic sea ice.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Arctic Ice Melting: A Fact-Based Overview
FACT1: The Arctic ice cap is melting at an alarming rate, with the ice cover shrinking by an average of 12.8% per decade since 1979. This has significant implications for global sea levels, weather patterns, and the survival of Arctic wildlife.
MYTH: The melting of Arctic ice is a natural phenomenon that has nothing to do with human activity.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of the False Cause fallacy, which assumes that because two things happen at the same time, one must cause the other. While natural factors such as solar radiation and volcanic activity can influence Arctic ice cover, the overwhelming scientific consensus is that human-caused greenhouse gas emissions are the primary driver of Arctic ice loss.
FACT2: It is crucial to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and slow the rate of Arctic ice loss. Let's work together to protect this vital ecosystem and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “While the notion that the impact on earth’s orbital cycle on solar radiation levels is the most significant factor determining global temperatures is anything but new, the team of scientists seem to have tied the phenomenon to planetary orbits in a more concrete manner than previous studies.”
comment_by_fact-checker: I can’t help but think this sentence really refers to a research article called “A simple rule to determine which insolation cycles lead to interglacials” by Tzedakis and colleagues, rather than “Theory of chaotic orbital variations confirmed by Cretaceous geological evidence” by Ma, Meyers & Sageman.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Planetary Orbits and Global Temperatures
FACT1: The earth's orbital cycle and solar radiation levels have an impact on global temperatures, but this is not the only factor. Other factors, such as greenhouse gas emissions, also play a significant role in determining global temperatures. 
MYTH: The impact of the earth's orbital cycle on solar radiation levels is the most significant factor determining global temperatures. 
FALLACY: This statement is an oversimplification of the complex factors that contribute to global temperatures. While the earth's orbital cycle does have an impact on solar radiation levels, it is not the only factor that determines global temperatures. Other factors, such as greenhouse gas emissions, also play a significant role. 
FACT2: It is important to consider all the factors that contribute to global temperatures, including greenhouse gas emissions, when discussing climate change. Let's not oversimplify the issue and instead focus on taking action to reduce our impact on the environment.

fact_checked_segment: “The jet stream forms a boundary between the cold north and the warmer south, but the lower temperature difference means the winds are now weaker. This means the jet stream meanders more, with big loops bringing warm air to the frozen north and cold air into warmer southern climes.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Daniel Swain, Researcher, UCLA, and Research Fellow, National Center for Atmospheric Research: The statement regarding what the jet stream is (a “boundary between cold north and warmer south”) is essentially correct, and there is indeed evidence that the north-south temperature difference has decreased in some regions.[1] But there remains considerable scientific uncertainty regarding whether the jet stream is actually “meandering more” in a general sense, and whether these large jet stream meanders are actually caused by sea ice loss.[2-3] 1. Francis and Skific (2015) Evidence for a wavier jet stream in response to rapid Arctic warming, Environmental Research Letters 2. Barnes and Screen (2015) The impact of Arctic warming on the midlatitude jet‐stream: Can it? Has it? Will it?, Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Climate Change 3. Screen and Simmonds (2013) Exploring links between Arctic amplification and mid-latitude weather, Geophysical Research Letters
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Jet Stream and Climate Change
FACT1: The jet stream is a high-altitude, fast-moving air current that plays a crucial role in weather patterns. It forms a boundary between cold and warm air masses and helps to steer storms and weather systems around the globe.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Climate change is causing the jet stream to weaken and meander more, leading to more extreme weather events such as heatwaves, droughts, and floods. This is because the warming of the Arctic is reducing the temperature difference between the poles and the equator, which is what drives the jet stream. To mitigate the impacts of climate change, we need to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and transition to a cleaner, more sustainable energy system.

fact_checked_segment: “For what appears to be the first time since scientists began keeping track, sea ice in the Arctic and the Antarctic are at record lows this time of year.”
comment_by_fact-checker: While we have a very clear picture of the sea ice concentration only over the satellite era (1979-present) there are other measurements available that are more or less direct, ranging from whaling and shipping log books (showing higher sea ice extent over the past 100 years) to paleo-climate reconstruction (proxies) over thousands to million of years. [more about ‘polar amplification’ in past climate]
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Record Low Sea Ice in Arctic and Antarctic
FACT1: Sea ice in both the Arctic and Antarctic is at record lows this time of year, according to scientists.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: The loss of sea ice in both the Arctic and Antarctic is a clear indication of the impact of climate change on our planet. Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “Dr Browman, a marine scientist for 35 years, said he was not saying that ocean acidification posed no threat, but that he believed that “a higher level of academic scepticism” should be applied to the topic.
comment_by_fact-checker: By making such broad statements, Dr Browman is undermining the hard work of many people who have spent a huge amount of effort to document the effects of ocean acidification on many marine species. If Dr Browman wants to attack particular studies, he should cite particular statements from particular papers that he thinks are false. It is inappropriate to make vague accusations denigrating an entire field of inquiry.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Importance of Academic Scepticism in Ocean Acidification Research
FACT1: Ocean acidification is a process that occurs when carbon dioxide is absorbed by seawater, leading to a decrease in pH levels. This can have negative impacts on marine life, including the ability of organisms to build shells and skeletons.
MYTH: A marine scientist has suggested that a higher level of academic scepticism should be applied to the topic of ocean acidification.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of the Bulk Fake Experts fallacy, which involves citing large numbers of seeming experts to argue that there is no scientific consensus on a topic. In this case, the scientist's opinion is being presented as if it represents a significant challenge to the scientific consensus on ocean acidification, when in fact the vast majority of scientific research supports the idea that it poses a significant threat to marine ecosystems.
FACT2: It is important to approach scientific research with a healthy level of scepticism, but this should not be used as an excuse to dismiss well-established scientific facts. Let's continue to support rigorous scientific research on ocean acidification and work towards finding solutions to mitigate its impacts.

fact_checked_segment: Our evolving dynamic planet has survived sea level changes of hundreds of metres
comment_by_fact-checker: That is really nice for that rock revolving around the Sun. I personally also care about the people and communities living in coastal cities and towns and their cultural heritage. Ian Plimer can naturally have another opinion on their value.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Our Dynamic Planet Has Survived Sea Level Changes
FACT1: Our planet has experienced significant sea level changes throughout its history, with fluctuations of hundreds of meters over millions of years. These changes are due to natural processes such as plate tectonics, volcanic activity, and changes in the Earth's orbit and axial tilt. 
MYTH: Sea level rise is a new phenomenon caused solely by human activity. 
FALLACY: The fallacy underlying this myth is oversimplification. While it is true that human activity has contributed to the current rate of sea level rise, it is not a new phenomenon. Sea levels have been rising and falling for millions of years due to natural processes. 
FACT2: Understanding the natural processes that have caused sea level changes in the past can help us better understand and prepare for the current and future changes. Let's continue to study and monitor sea level changes to better protect our planet and its inhabitants.

fact_checked_segment: “This past winter, a string of days 60 and 70 degrees warmer than normal baked the North Pole”
comment_by_fact-checker: Regions with open water will stay relatively warm due to the relatively warm water. As soon as ice limits heat flows from the ocean to the atmosphere it can get very cold. Also, in general variability is much stronger in the Arctic—what sounds like a really big warm anomaly to an innocent reader in the USA is thus exceptional, but less so than the numbers suggest. That is context a reader would need to know. Steffensen et al (2008) High-Resolution Greenland Ice Core Data Show Abrupt Climate Change Happens in Few Years, Science
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The North Pole experienced an unusual heatwave last winter
FACT1: The North Pole experienced a heatwave last winter, with temperatures 60-70 degrees warmer than normal.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the reality of climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: “At a cost of between $1 trillion and $2 trillion annually, the Paris climate agreement, recently ratified by China, is likely to be history’s most expensive treaty. It will slow the world’s economic growth to force a shift to inefficient green energy sources.”
comment_by_fact-checker: There are hundreds of corporations who have signed on to reducing emissions in their own best interest (e.g. Walmart, DuPont, Chevron, Johnson and Johnson, Mercedes Benz, Dow… consult the White House website for an expanded list), reducing emissions and helping their customers do the same, for the benefit of their bottom line and their employees and their shareholders. These companies know that they will make money working to reduce their carbon emissions (being first to get there). Their gains are not recognized by Bjorn’s cost estimates. This is not to say that it is free. It is to say that Bjorn’s Holy Grail of cost-benefit analysis should include the enormous deductions to costs from the market.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The Paris Climate Agreement and its Economic Impact
FACT1: The Paris Climate Agreement is a global treaty aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions and limiting global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. It was signed by 196 countries in 2015, including China and the United States.

MYTH: The Paris Climate Agreement is the most expensive treaty in history and will slow down economic growth to force a shift to inefficient green energy sources.

FALLACY: This statement uses the Slippery Slope fallacy by suggesting that implementing the Paris Climate Agreement will inevitably lead to economic slowdown and a shift to inefficient green energy sources. It also uses the False Dilemma fallacy by presenting the false choice between economic growth and environmental protection.

FACT2: The Paris Climate Agreement is not a treaty that will cost $1-2 trillion annually. Instead, it is a framework for countries to set their own targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and transitioning to renewable energy sources. The agreement recognizes the importance of balancing economic growth with environmental protection and encourages countries to work together to achieve these goals. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: European average ​temperatures were more than 2C above normal
comment_by_fact-checker: European temperature this year in June were 2°C above the average over the period 1981 to 2010 (which was already warm due to man-made global warming). Climatologists call such averages over 30 year periods climate normals, a tradition that started before we knew about climate change. This technical term is probably best not used when writing for a general audience. The article understates how special the weather was by not mentioning that this average is 1°C above the previous record in 1999. And that it is about 1°C above the long-term warming trend, which is a rare outlier.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Europe experienced a significant temperature increase in recent years.

FACT1: Europe has experienced a temperature increase of more than 2C above normal in recent years. This increase is a result of climate change, which is caused by human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: None.

FACT2: Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the effects of climate change. We can do this by reducing our energy consumption, using renewable energy sources, and supporting policies that promote sustainability.

fact_checked_segment: “According to a recent National Economic Research Associates Economic Consulting study, the Paris Agreement could obliterate $3 trillion of GDP, 6.5 million industrial sector jobs and $7,000 in per capita household income from the American economy by 2040. Meeting the 2025 emissions reduction target alone could subtract $250 billion from our GDP and eliminate 2.7 million jobs. The cement, iron and steel, and petroleum refining industries could see their production cut by 21% 19%, and 11% respectively.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is true that this is what the NERA study says, with many caveats. However, this statement is misleading and taken out of context. There are three reasons for this. First, and most importantly, the NERA study looked at the costs of a hypothetical set of policy actions. These may not be the actions that will be taken to comply with the Paris Agreement. One could easily model other actions with much lower costs. Second, it is only the costs that are modeled. The benefits from avoiding climate change (sea level rise, greater storm surges, greater spread of diseases, etc.) are entirely ignored. The net costs from the policies would be entirely different and likely even positive. Third, there is some cherry-picking going on here. The NERA model is known to be inflexible in how it allows for innovation to influence economic activity, and thus it tends to provide much higher cost estimates than other well-known models such as the U.S. Department of Energy’s NEMS or ICF Consulting’s IPM. The NERA model provides useful information, but it is important for it to be taken in context of model results from other models and not cherry-picked as was done here.
label: cherry picking
debunk: The Economic Consulting study claiming that the Paris Agreement could obliterate $3 trillion of GDP, 6.5 million industrial sector jobs, and $7,000 in per capita household income from the American economy by 2040 is based on flawed reasoning. This study assumes that the only way to reduce emissions is to reduce economic activity, which is not true. In fact, many studies have shown that transitioning to a low-carbon economy can create jobs and boost economic growth. Additionally, the study ignores the potential benefits of reducing the impacts of climate change, such as avoiding the costs of extreme weather events and health impacts. Let's not spread misinformation about the potential economic impacts of climate action and instead focus on the opportunities for a sustainable and prosperous future.

fact_checked_segment: “This will achieve almost nothing. My peer-reviewed research, published last November in the journal Global Policy, shows that even if every nation were to fulfill all their carbon-cutting promises by 2030 and stick to them all the way through the century—at a cost of more than $100 trillion in lost GDP—global temperature rise would be reduced by a tiny 0.3°F (0.17°C).”
comment_by_fact-checker: The last IPCC report makes it very clear that following a path of strong emissions reductions can indeed cap warming at 2C or less, while business as usual would see 4-5C of warming this century. It is also now clear that meeting the Paris targets will likely save the West Antarctic ice sheet from melting, while other scenarios would see many metres of sea level rise, effectively destroying many of the major cities of the world. The costs of such inaction are almost incalculable.
label: no fallacy
debunk: Carbon-cutting efforts will have little impact on global temperature rise. A peer-reviewed study published in the journal Global Policy found that even if every nation fulfills their carbon-cutting promises by 2030 and sticks to them through the century, global temperature rise would only be reduced by 0.3°F (0.17°C). This means that the cost of more than $100 trillion in lost GDP would not be worth the minimal impact on global temperature rise. However, this does not mean that carbon-cutting efforts are useless. They can still have significant benefits for public health, air quality, and energy security. Let's continue to work towards reducing our carbon footprint and finding sustainable solutions.

fact_checked_segment: “[Pruitt’s statement] was an accurate and judicious answer”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is objectively not an accurate answer and is misleading at best. [Pruitt’s statement has been reviewed by scientists with Climate Feedback and found to be incorrect.] While it is certainly challenging to determine human influence on the climate, decades of research by tens of thousands of scientists from different institutions all over the world have yielded a nearly unanimous consensus with extreme confidence that humans are the dominant cause of climate change. In fact, scientists have been questioning and researching human influence on the climate for nearly 200 years. Further, we can use techniques similar to the smoking-cancer causality research to prove that humans are mainly responsible and to show that carbon dioxide is the primary control knob for today’s climate change. There is no “tremendous disagreement” or “debate” about this.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Judicious Answer or Misleading Statement?
FACT1: A statement can be accurate but still misleading if it omits important information.
MYTH: The statement made by Pruitt was accurate and judicious.
FALLACY: The fallacy here is the omission of important information. Pruitt's statement may have been technically accurate, but it was misleading because it failed to acknowledge the overwhelming scientific consensus that human activity is the primary cause of climate change.
FACT2: Let's not be misled by statements that omit important information. It's important to consider the full context and scientific consensus when evaluating claims about climate change.

fact_checked_segment: Even the BBC has admitted to Ofcom that the corporation is now biased on the matter because it no longer thinks there is a counter-argument.
comment_by_fact-checker: The more pernicious issue that pervades media reporting of not just climate change but also many other fields of science and other issues is the false-balance paradigm that this article itself falls foul of repeatedly.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: BBC Admits Bias on Climate Change Reporting

FACT1: The BBC has acknowledged to Ofcom that it has been biased in its reporting on climate change. The corporation has stated that it no longer considers there to be a counter-argument to the scientific consensus on climate change, and as a result, has not given equal weight to opposing views.

MYTH: The BBC is biased against climate change skeptics.

FALLACY: The fallacy at play here is the "False Balance" fallacy, which suggests that opposing views should be given equal weight, even if they lack scientific evidence or consensus. By giving equal weight to opposing views, the media can create a false sense of balance and legitimacy, even when one side is not supported by the evidence.

FACT2: It is important for the media to report on climate change accurately and without bias. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and family by perpetuating false balance and giving equal weight to unsupported views.

fact_checked_segment: Concurrently a compilation of all days since 1915 when temperatures exceeded 90F shows them decreasing with time rather than increasing in Figure 2.
comment_by_fact-checker: The figure again has no source, no way to check how it was computed. Days over 90F focuses on maximum temperature and summer days, the data most affected by the Dust Bowl.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Misleading use of cherry-picked data to deny global warming
FACT1: Cherry-picking data is a common tactic used to mislead people about global warming. By selecting only certain data points, people can create the illusion that temperatures are not increasing when, in fact, they are. 
MYTH: Temperatures exceeding 90F are decreasing over time, not increasing.
FALLACY: This is an example of cherry-picking data. By only looking at days since 1915 when temperatures exceeded 90F, the person is ignoring the overall trend of increasing global temperatures. This is a common tactic used to deny global warming, but it is misleading because it ignores the larger picture. 
FACT2: Let's not be fooled by cherry-picked data. Instead, let's look at the overall trend of increasing global temperatures and take action to address the issue of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “[…]even if the countries of the world agree to do what they promised on climate change, […]the promised actions will have no measurable effect on future global temperatures.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The current promises of governments around the world (INDCs) are not enough to stay below a warming of 2 °C, but they do make a difference. In an article in Nature this June, Joeri Rogelj and colleagues: “The INDCs collectively lower greenhouse gas emissions compared to where current policies stand, but still imply a median warming of 2.6–3.1 degrees Celsius by 2100.”
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change Promises Won't Make a Difference

FACT1: Climate change is a complex issue that requires global cooperation to address. However, some people argue that even if countries follow through on their promises to reduce emissions, it won't make a significant difference in global temperatures.

MYTH: Climate change promises won't make a difference in global temperatures.

FALLACY: This argument is an example of a false equivalence fallacy. It assumes that because individual actions may not have a significant impact, collective actions won't either. However, the reality is that every action counts, and collective efforts can have a significant impact on reducing greenhouse gas emissions and mitigating the effects of climate change.

FACT2: Every individual and collective action counts in the fight against climate change. Let's continue to hold our leaders accountable for their promises and take action in our own lives to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: “Dr. Serreze said that such a situation, which would leave nothing but open ocean in summer until fall freeze-up begins, could occur by 2030, although many scientists say it may not happen for a decade or two after that.”
comment_by_fact-checker: 2030 is on the early side of ice-free predictions but definitely not out of the realm of possibility.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Arctic sea ice could disappear in summer by 2030, says scientist
FACT1: Arctic sea ice is melting at an alarming rate, and scientists predict that it could disappear in summer by 2030. This would leave nothing but open ocean until fall freeze-up begins. The melting of Arctic sea ice is a result of global warming caused by human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and slow down the melting of Arctic sea ice. Let's make changes in our daily lives to reduce our carbon footprint and support policies that prioritize the environment.

fact_checked_segment: “Until now, scientists have calculated the temperature of the ancient seas by looking at foraminifera, the fossils of tiny marine organisms found in the sediment on the ocean floor.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is only one way that scientists have calculated the temperature of the ocean, and they will continue to do so.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Scientists use foraminifera fossils to calculate ancient sea temperatures
FACT1: Foraminifera are tiny marine organisms that have hard shells made of calcium carbonate. When they die, their shells accumulate on the ocean floor and become part of the sediment. Scientists can use the oxygen isotopes in the shells to estimate the temperature of the water in which the foraminifera lived.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Foraminifera fossils are a valuable tool for scientists to understand past climate conditions and how they have changed over time. By studying these fossils, scientists can gain insights into how the Earth's climate has changed in the past and how it may change in the future. Let's continue to support scientific research that helps us better understand our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “[The West Antarctic Ice Sheet] is known to be losing ice rapidly because it is being melted from below by warm ocean waters, a process that is rendering its largest glaciers unstable.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is accurate but doesn’t fully explain that the warm ocean water is not a result of human-caused climate change and it is not a linear warming of Southern Ocean waters that causes melt beneath West Antarctic ice shelves. Rather, it is variability in the delivery of this relatively warm water (called Circumpolar Deep Water) that can directly affect how much melt is happening. Delivery of this water is altered by the direction and strength of winds over the Amundsen Sea, a subset of the Pacific sector of the Southern Ocean. If winds blow from west to east across the Amundsen Sea, they promote upwelling of this deep water under ice shelves, promoting melt and hence increasing ice loss*. Steig et al (2012) Tropical forcing of Circumpolar Deep Water Inflow and outlet glacier thinning in the Amundsen Sea Embayment, West Antarctica, Annals of Glaciology
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Melting from below is causing rapid ice loss in the West Antarctic Ice Sheet
FACT1: Warm ocean waters are melting the West Antarctic Ice Sheet from below, causing rapid ice loss and making its largest glaciers unstable. This process is contributing to sea level rise and could have significant impacts on coastal communities around the world.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: None.

FACT2: It is important to continue monitoring and studying the West Antarctic Ice Sheet to better understand the impacts of its melting on global sea levels and to develop strategies to mitigate these impacts. Let's support scientific research and efforts to address climate change to help protect our planet and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “Ice core drilling shows that 800 years after natural warming, the atmosphere increases in carbon dioxide”
comment_by_fact-checker: Recent work* shows that the temperature and CO2 rise were synchronous within uncertainties: if there was a lag it was less than 400 years, not 800 years as previously thought. Additionally, the temperature increase over the deglaciation cannot be explained solely by orbitally driven insolation changes (modifications of solar energy received by the Earth due to its position). The radiative effect of the CO2 rise amplifies the warming and explains part of the total deglacial warming. Parrenin et al (2013) Synchronous Change of Atmospheric CO2 and Antarctic Temperature During the Last Deglacial Warming, Science
label: post hoc
debunk:
TITLE: The Natural Cycle of Carbon Dioxide and Temperature
FACT1: Carbon dioxide and temperature have a natural cycle that is linked. When the Earth warms, carbon dioxide is released from the oceans and other sources, which in turn amplifies the warming effect. When the Earth cools, carbon dioxide is absorbed by the oceans and other carbon sinks, which helps to cool the planet. 
MYTH: Ice core drilling shows that 800 years after natural warming, the atmosphere increases in carbon dioxide.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false choice fallacy, which presents two options as the only possibilities when other possibilities exist. It suggests that the increase in carbon dioxide is solely due to natural warming, ignoring the fact that human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, have significantly contributed to the increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide over the past century.
FACT2: Understanding the natural cycle of carbon dioxide and temperature is important, but it is also crucial to recognize the impact of human activities on the Earth's climate. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and instead educate ourselves on the science of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Greenland ice sheet … would balloon sea levels by around 7m should it disintegrate”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a reasonable number for the total mean sea level rise if all of the Greenland Ice Sheet melted. Total melt of the Greenland Ice Sheet, however, is essentially impossible over the next several hundred years. Nevertheless, the Greenland Ice Sheet has been losing large amounts of ice and the rate of loss has increased over the recent decade or so (references include this paper and this one). The amount of ice Greenland has lost to date has already raised global sea levels and projections indicate the possibility of 0.5 m more sea level rise from Greenland alone over the coming several centuries.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The potential impact of Greenland's ice sheet on sea levels
FACT1: Greenland's ice sheet is the second-largest ice sheet in the world, covering an area of approximately 1.7 million square kilometers. If it were to completely melt, it would raise global sea levels by about 7 meters.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: The melting of Greenland's ice sheet is a significant concern for scientists studying climate change. It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and slow the rate of global warming to prevent the catastrophic consequences of sea level rise. Let's work together to protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “Instead of negotiating over climate change policies and trying to make them more market-oriented, some political conservatives have taken the approach of blocking them by trying to undermine the science.”
comment_by_fact-checker: On the scientific community side, the consensus is broad. It’s worth revisiting Cook et al. 2015*. In their review they find a 97% consensus about human-induced global warming in published climate studies. Cook et al (2016) Consensus on consensus: a synthesis of consensus estimates on human-caused global warming, Environmental Research Letters
label: cherry picking
debunk:
FACT1: Some political conservatives have tried to undermine the science behind climate change policies instead of negotiating over them.
 
MYTH: None.

FALLACY: This statement highlights the ad hominem fallacy, which attacks the character of political conservatives instead of addressing their arguments. It also highlights the straw man fallacy, which misrepresents the position of political conservatives by suggesting that they are against market-oriented climate change policies.

FACT2: Let's focus on the science behind climate change policies and have constructive discussions on how to make them more effective.

fact_checked_segment: “More acidic oceans ‘will affect all sea life’”
comment_by_fact-checker: “More acidic” is not entirely correct as the ocean is strictly speaking still alkaline (pH>7) and will remain so in the future. It is nevertheless true that the pH will most likely decrease (and has already done so in the past). A small change in the pH leads to large shifts in seawater carbonate chemistry (as the author correctly mentions later in the main text). The pH change will affect many species. I am not sure if the statement “all sea life” is justified at this stage. Indirect effects will likely play a major role here (as mentioned later in the text) but this still lacks evidence. This is more like “work in progress” I would say.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Impact of Acidic Oceans on Sea Life
FACT1: The acidity of the ocean is increasing due to the absorption of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. This increase in acidity can have a significant impact on sea life, including the ability of organisms to build and maintain their shells and skeletons, as well as their overall survival and reproduction rates.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: The fallacy here is that the impact of ocean acidification is often overlooked or dismissed as a minor issue. However, the reality is that the increasing acidity of the ocean can have far-reaching and devastating consequences for marine ecosystems and the people who depend on them. This fallacy is often perpetuated by those who prioritize short-term economic gain over long-term environmental sustainability.
FACT2: Let's not ignore the impact of ocean acidification on sea life. We can take action to reduce our carbon footprint and support policies that prioritize the health of our oceans and the life they support.

fact_checked_segment: “I would certainly not call such [superstorm] scenarios ridiculous,” said Coumou. “But it is speculative – we don’t have the hard evidence.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The superstorm scenario rests on a number of assumptions, especially that the rate of ice melt from Greenland (and Antarctica) will accelerate very rapidly. Definitely still in the realm of speculation.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Superstorms are not ridiculous, but speculative
FACT1: The possibility of superstorms is not ridiculous, but it is speculative and lacks hard evidence. 
MYTH: There is a myth that superstorms are impossible or ridiculous. 
FALLACY: The myth is based on a false dichotomy, assuming that extreme weather events are either impossible or certain to happen. In reality, the likelihood of superstorms is uncertain and requires further research. 
FACT2: Let's not dismiss the possibility of superstorms, but also not jump to conclusions without sufficient evidence. It is important to continue researching and monitoring extreme weather events to better understand their potential impacts.

fact_checked_segment: “Consider where they move. Migration patterns show people heading for warm states like Texas and Florida, not snowy Minnesota and Michigan.”
comment_by_fact-checker: People don’t like the cold, they like sunshine and warmth, and (supposedly as a result, according to Lomborg), they move to the South: does Lomborg really want us to deduce from that that global warming will thus be good for us – even simply in terms of temperature-related deaths? That’s not reasonable. First, while people have indeed generally been moving from the North(-East) to the South over the last decades, it’s not only because of “better climate”: quoting this article by the Washington Post, “Several long-term trends dating as far back as the 1960s are behind this larger pattern. The rise of air conditioning and interstate highways have made once-sleepy (and sweltering) Southern cities more appealing. And, over the same time, the decline of industrial jobs in the Midwest and Northeast have pushed people out. Cheap housing during the boom years also drove growth in states such as Arizona and Nevada“. I think that is already much more reasonable than saying that people move South only because they know they are less likely to die from cold exposure there. Second, people may be moving there right now partly because of climate, and that may indeed be a “smart” move because, TODAY, indeed, current cold-related deaths outnumber heat-related deaths. However, even supposing that this is a significant factor in their decision process, it’s not clear that they are also thinking about future warming. So the fact that people are moving there NOW does not even logically imply, as Lomborg would have it, that FUTURE warming will be beneficial – which is the point of interest here.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Migration patterns do not disprove global warming
FACT1: Migration patterns are influenced by many factors, including job opportunities, cost of living, and family ties. People move to warmer states for many reasons, not just because of climate change.
MYTH: Migration patterns disprove global warming because people are moving to warmer states like Texas and Florida, not snowy Minnesota and Michigan.
FALLACY: This is a false equivalence fallacy, as it assumes that migration patterns are solely determined by climate change. In reality, people move for a variety of reasons, and migration patterns cannot be used as evidence to disprove global warming.
FACT2: Let's not use migration patterns as evidence to disprove global warming. Instead, let's look at the overwhelming scientific evidence that supports the reality of global warming and take action to address this urgent issue.

fact_checked_segment: “Entire states and nations have to decide to clean up their energy systems, using every tool available and moving as quickly as they can.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is not universally agreed upon by experts. The key issue is that it is imprecisely written. I would not be surprised if the intent is correct. But taking it as it is written, it is not clear what “every tool available” includes. Technically, this should include truly everything, including simply shutting down all manufacturing that uses fossil fuels at all. Banning the driving of any vehicle except electric vehicles run on renewables. Banning flying. I doubt that was the intent of the sentence. The same issue holds for “moving as quickly as they can.” What are the limits to”as quickly as they can”? Does it including shutting down the economy? Or is the intended sentence “moving as quickly as they cost-effectively can”? Thus, in short, while the idea is correct, this is imprecisely worded and can easily be critiqued.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Urgency for Clean Energy Transition
FACT1: Transitioning to clean energy is an urgent matter that requires immediate action from states and nations. The use of fossil fuels is contributing to climate change, which has severe consequences for the planet and its inhabitants. Clean energy sources, such as wind and solar power, are readily available and can help reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

MYTH: Transitioning to clean energy is not urgent and can be delayed.

FALLACY: This myth is based on the false assumption that the consequences of climate change are not severe or that they will not affect us in the near future. It also ignores the fact that transitioning to clean energy is a complex process that requires significant planning and investment. Delaying action will only make the transition more difficult and costly in the long run.

FACT2: Let's not delay the transition to clean energy any longer. We need to take action now to reduce our reliance on fossil fuels and transition to cleaner sources of energy. This will not only help mitigate the effects of climate change but also create new jobs and stimulate economic growth.

fact_checked_segment: The data showed European average ​temperatures were more than 2C above normal and temperatures were 6-10C above normal over most of France, Germany and northern Spain during the final days of the month, according to C3S.
comment_by_fact-checker: It is not a good idea to combine numbers for the full month and all of Europe with numbers for a few days and a part of Europe. That double difference makes it hard to understand and easy to miss one of the differences when casually reading it. 6-10 degrees Celsius for the entire month would have been special, but for a few days it is not.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Europe experiences record-breaking heat in July 2021
FACT1: In July 2021, Europe experienced record-breaking heat with temperatures more than 2C above normal. Most of France, Germany, and northern Spain saw temperatures 6-10C above normal during the final days of the month.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the reality of climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint. We can make small changes in our daily lives, such as reducing energy consumption and using public transportation, to help mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Within a decade, certain kinds of branching and plate coral could be extinct, reef scientists say, along with a variety of small fish that rely on them for protection from predators.”
comment_by_fact-checker: I think it is very unlikely any corals would be extinct in a decade. The problem isn’t threat of extinction, its loss of habitat for other critters when corals bleach and die. The corals become less dense, but there will still be many millions of colonies for most species.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Coral and Fish Species at Risk of Extinction
FACT1: Certain types of branching and plate coral, as well as small fish that depend on them for protection, are at risk of extinction within a decade, according to reef scientists.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to take action to protect coral reefs and the species that depend on them. Let's support conservation efforts and reduce our carbon footprint to help preserve these vital ecosystems.

fact_checked_segment: “Representatives from the Marshall Islands have been vocal about the need for strong global action on climate. President Hilda Heine has told reporters that longtime residents are leaving the Marshall Islands because climate change is threatening the nation’s existence.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is an interesting rhetorical trick by Bjorn Lomborg. So far he has only supported the point that ‘as of today, the area of many Pacific islands have not decreased’. But this doesn’t mean that ‘the islands existence is not threatened’, notably in the future as sea level rise becomes more severe. So here, he is swapping a weak claim that he has supported for a much stronger one that he has not, a version of the red herring fallacy.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change Threatens the Existence of the Marshall Islands
FACT1: The Marshall Islands, a low-lying island nation in the Pacific Ocean, is facing an existential threat due to climate change. Rising sea levels, more frequent and severe storms, and ocean acidification are causing damage to the islands' infrastructure, freshwater resources, and food security. The situation is so dire that many residents are already leaving the islands.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is crucial to take immediate and strong global action to mitigate the effects of climate change and prevent further damage to vulnerable nations like the Marshall Islands. Let's support policies and initiatives that reduce greenhouse gas emissions and promote sustainable development.

fact_checked_segment: “’Extremely remarkable’ 2017 heads toward record for hottest year without an El Niño episode.”
comment_by_fact-checker: At the moment, it is more likely than not that 2017 will become the second warmest year of the instrumental period. The warmest was 2016 with El Niño. So this claim is correct.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: 2017 is on track to be one of the hottest years on record
FACT1: 2017 is heading towards being one of the hottest years on record, even without the warming effect of an El Niño event. The first nine months of 2017 were the second warmest on record, and the year is likely to be one of the top three hottest years ever recorded.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Climate change is real and is causing the Earth's temperature to rise. It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change. Let's work together to protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: The strongest heat wave ever recorded [in the US] occurred in July 1936
comment_by_fact-checker: People may know this period as the Dust Bowl, where bad land management practices produced bare soil, dust storms, crop failure, and heat waves. This affected especially the maximum temperature, the summer temperature and stations in the Dust Bowl region. Global warming is about global warming.
