There are other reasons why the temperature changes, but over the last century the main reason is the burning of fossil fuels. Locally, these other reasons can be significant—like the US Dust Bowl.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: The US heat wave of July 1936
FACT1: The summer of 1936 was one of the hottest and driest on record in the United States, with temperatures soaring to unprecedented levels in many parts of the country. The heat wave was particularly severe in the Midwest and Great Plains, where temperatures reached as high as 121°F (49.4°C) in some areas. The extreme heat caused widespread crop failures, leading to a devastating drought that lasted for several years.
MYTH: The strongest heat wave ever recorded occurred in July 1936 in the US.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, where a single event is used to support a broader claim. While the summer of 1936 was indeed exceptionally hot, it is not accurate to claim that it was the strongest heat wave ever recorded in the US. In fact, there have been many other heat waves in the US that have been just as severe, if not more so, than the one in 1936.
FACT2: Let's not downplay the severity of the 1936 heat wave, but it's important to recognize that extreme heat events have occurred throughout history and are becoming more frequent and intense due to climate change. It's crucial that we take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The review found that many studies had used flawed methods, subjecting marine creatures to sudden increases in carbon dioxide that would never be experienced in real life. In some cases it was levels far beyond what would ever be reached even if we burnt every molecule of carbon on the planet”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is an incorrect statement which has already been debunked before, including by two of the authors of the paper this manuscript referee to. Hurd C. L., Cornwall C. E., Dupont S., Gattuso J.-P., Hoegh-Guldberg O., Gao K. & Lagos N. A., 2015. Ocean acidification: Laboratory seawater studies are justified. Nature 525:187. Extreme values are useful for physiologists to elucidate the cellular and molecular pathways confering susceptibility or resistance to elevated CO2. Yang et al. (2016; fig. 8d) showed that most of the data on the biological response to ocean acidification archived in a World Data Centre were collected at pCO2 values below 1000 uatm, in agreement with the business-as-usual CO2 emission scenario. Yang Y.et al., 2016. Data compilation on the biological response to ocean acidification: an update. Earth System Science Data 8:79-87.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Flawed methods used in some studies on the effects of carbon dioxide on marine creatures
FACT1: Some studies on the effects of carbon dioxide on marine creatures have used flawed methods, subjecting them to sudden increases in CO2 that would never be experienced in real life. 
MYTH: None mentioned.
FALLACY: The studies mentioned in the article have used flawed methods, subjecting marine creatures to sudden increases in carbon dioxide that would never be experienced in real life. This is a form of cherry-picking, where the studies have selectively chosen to expose marine creatures to high levels of CO2 that are not representative of real-life conditions. This can lead to misleading conclusions about the effects of CO2 on marine creatures.
FACT2: Let's ensure that studies on the effects of carbon dioxide on marine creatures use methods that are representative of real-life conditions. This will help us to better understand the effects of CO2 on marine creatures and make informed decisions about how to protect them.

fact_checked_segment: “The blue bars show where the raw temperature data has been adjusted downwards to make it cooler; the red bars show where the raw temperature data has been adjusted upwards to make it warmer.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Adjustments are made for good reasons. One of the most common ones is to account for a station located in a growing city, where the urban heat island effect would add spurious warming. In most cases the adjustments reduce, not increase, the warming in the record.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Temperature Adjustments Explained
FACT1: Temperature data is often adjusted to account for changes in measurement methods, station locations, and other factors that can affect the accuracy of the data. These adjustments are made to ensure that the data is as accurate and reliable as possible.
MYTH: Temperature data is manipulated to make it appear warmer than it actually is.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, as it focuses on only one aspect of temperature adjustments and presents it in a misleading way. Temperature adjustments are made to correct for known biases in the data, such as changes in measurement methods or station locations, and are subject to rigorous scientific scrutiny and peer review. The adjustments are made to improve the accuracy and reliability of the data, not to manipulate it.
FACT2: Temperature adjustments are a necessary part of ensuring that temperature data is accurate and reliable. Let's not spread misinformation about temperature adjustments and instead trust the rigorous scientific process that goes into ensuring the accuracy of the data.

fact_checked_segment: “Over the coming 25 or 30 years, scientists say, the climate is likely to gradually warm
comment_by_fact-checker: While the exact details and timing of warming are subject to unpredictable decadal (semi-decadal) climate variability (e.g. El Niño Southern Oscillation, Pacific Decadal Oscillation, Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation), this statement is largely true.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Gradual Warming of Climate Over Next Few Decades
FACT1: Climate scientists predict that the Earth's climate will gradually warm over the next 25-30 years. This warming is expected to be caused by human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, which release greenhouse gases into the atmosphere and trap heat. This warming trend is expected to continue unless significant action is taken to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and slow down the rate of climate change. We can do this by reducing our carbon footprint, using renewable energy sources, and supporting policies that promote sustainability.

fact_checked_segment: “First, marine species that calcify have survived through millions of years when CO2 was at much higher levels; second, they are more than capable of adapting — even in the short term — to environmental change”
comment_by_fact-checker: Many marine organisms respond to changes in calcium carbonate mineral saturation states. These depend not only on pH, but also on factors including amounts of carbon and calcium in the ocean. One of the most important factors is ocean alkalinity, which varies on time scale of many thousands of years. In the geologic past, when atmospheric CO2 was high, ocean alkalinity was also high, and so carbonate mineral saturation states could remain high. Unfortunately, on the timescale of centuries or decades, changes come too fast for the ocean’s natural processes to buffer ocean carbonate mineral saturation states. Directly comparing effects of high CO2 levels that developed in the geologic past over many millions of years with high CO2 levels developing today over decades and centuries shows a fundamental lack of understanding of well-established global geochemical cycles. This open access article explains some of the relevant chemistry: Cao et al (2016) Simulated effect of deep-sea sedimentation and terrestrial weathering on projections of ocean acidification, Journal of Geophysical Research Oceans
label: false cause
debunk:
FACT1: Marine species that calcify have survived through millions of years when CO2 was at much higher levels, and they are capable of adapting to environmental change.

MYTH: Marine species that calcify are unable to survive in the current high CO2 levels and cannot adapt to environmental change.

FALLACY: This argument is a combination of cherry-picking and oversimplification. While it is true that marine species that calcify have survived through millions of years when CO2 was at much higher levels, it is also true that the current rate of CO2 increase is much faster than any previous natural increase. This rapid increase in CO2 levels is causing ocean acidification, which is making it difficult for marine species to adapt quickly enough to survive.

FACT2: It is important to recognize that while marine species that calcify have survived through millions of years, the current rate of CO2 increase is unprecedented and is causing significant harm to marine ecosystems. We should take action to reduce our carbon emissions and protect our oceans. Let's work towards sustainable practices to ensure the survival of marine species and the health of our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “Entire states and nations have to decide to clean up their energy systems”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is correct. It cannot be done by only a few nations—it requires collective action to make a substantial difference.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Transitioning to clean energy is a necessary step to mitigate the impacts of climate change. 

MYTH: Transitioning to clean energy is too difficult and requires too much effort from entire states and nations. 

FALLACY: This statement is an example of a false dilemma fallacy, which presents only two options when there are actually more. It suggests that transitioning to clean energy is an all-or-nothing proposition, when in reality, there are many steps that can be taken at the individual, community, and national levels to reduce our reliance on fossil fuels. 

FACT2: Every individual can make a difference by making small changes in their daily lives, such as using energy-efficient appliances, reducing meat consumption, and using public transportation or carpooling. Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and transition to a cleaner, more sustainable future.

fact_checked_segment: Since then, the planet has been cooling on a millennial scale
comment_by_fact-checker: Here the author is muddling the issue of climate change by introducing time periods that are unrelated. Human-caused climate change via significant greenhouse gas emissions as discussed today only refers to the last roughly 100 years. This human activity has completely altered the Earth’s climate from any natural trend that may occur over 1,000s of years. The “millenial” scale is not relevant to the discussion of current human-caused climate change.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The Misleading Claim of Cooling on a Millennial Scale
FACT1: The Earth's climate has undergone natural cycles of warming and cooling over millions of years. However, the current warming trend is happening at an unprecedented rate and is primarily caused by human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation. 
MYTH: Warning about climate change is unnecessary because the planet has been cooling on a millennial scale.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of the "logical fallacy of cherry-picking" by selectively choosing data that support a particular viewpoint while ignoring other relevant data. While it is true that the Earth's climate has undergone natural cycles of warming and cooling over millions of years, the current warming trend is happening at an unprecedented rate and is primarily caused by human activities. 
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's educate ourselves and others about the reality of climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: “The most famous of these studies, published in 2010 by Paul Kench and Arthur Webb of the South Pacific Applied Geoscience Commission in Fiji, showed that of 27 Pacific islands, 14% lost area. Yet 43% gained area, with the rest remaining stable.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This comment does provide a reasonable assessment of the message of our article: that the majority of islands have become larger or remained stable and that islands are locationally dynamic on their reef platforms. We think these dynamic features do pose management challenges for island communities. However, all reports fail to reflect the nuances of our work.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Pacific Islands are both sinking and growing
FACT1: Some Pacific Islands are sinking, while others are growing, and some remain stable. This is due to a combination of natural processes, such as erosion and sedimentation, and human activities, such as land reclamation and construction.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: False Dichotomy. The myth assumes that Pacific Islands are either sinking or growing, when in fact both processes are occurring simultaneously. This oversimplification can lead to a misunderstanding of the complex processes that shape the islands.
FACT2: Understanding the complex processes that shape Pacific Islands is crucial for developing effective strategies to address the challenges they face, such as sea-level rise and natural disasters. Let's not oversimplify the issue and instead seek to understand the nuances of island dynamics.

fact_checked_segment: A new report has warned there’s an existential risk to humanity from the climate crisis within the coming decades, and a ‘high likelihood of human civilization coming to an end’ over the next three decades unless urgent action is taken.
comment_by_fact-checker: The “report” is not a peer-reviewed scientific paper. It’s from some sort of “think tank” who can basically write what they like. The report itself misunderstands / misrepresents science, and does not provide traceable links to the science it is based on so it cannot easily be checked (although someone familiar with the literature can work it out, and hence see where the report’s conclusions are ramped-up from the original research).
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Crisis Poses Existential Risk to Humanity
FACT1: Urgent action is needed to address the climate crisis, as there is a high likelihood of human civilization coming to an end within the next three decades if no action is taken. This is according to a new report that warns of an existential risk to humanity from the climate crisis.
MYTH: There is no need to take urgent action to address the climate crisis, as it is not a significant threat to humanity.
FALLACY: The myth is based on a false equivalence fallacy, as it assumes that the climate crisis is not a significant threat to humanity despite overwhelming evidence to the contrary. It also relies on cherry-picking data and ignoring the consensus of the scientific community.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's take urgent action to address the climate crisis and work towards a sustainable future for all.

fact_checked_segment: “Drought in the western U.S. pales in comparison to the mega-droughts tree rings tell us existed in centuries past.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Note the comparing reconstructions of past droughts with climate model projections suggests that “future drought risk will likely exceed even the driest centuries of the Medieval Climate Anomaly (1100–1300 CE) in both moderate (RCP 4.5) and high (RCP 8.5) future emissions scenarios, leading to unprecedented drought conditions during the last millennium”. See Cook et al. (2015) Unprecedented 21st century drought risk in the American Southwest and Central Plains, Sciences Advances.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Droughts in the Western U.S. are not less severe than in the past
FACT1: The Western U.S. is currently experiencing a severe drought, with record low levels of water in reservoirs and rivers. However, this is not the first time the region has experienced droughts of this magnitude. Tree ring data shows that the Western U.S. has experienced mega-droughts lasting decades or even centuries in the past.
MYTH: Droughts in the Western U.S. are less severe than in the past.
FALLACY: This statement uses the fallacy of relative privation, which suggests that because something is not as bad as it has been in the past, it is not a problem. While it is true that the Western U.S. has experienced more severe droughts in the past, this does not diminish the severity of the current drought and its impacts on the region's ecosystems, agriculture, and communities.
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the severity of the current drought in the Western U.S. and work towards sustainable solutions to mitigate its impacts on the environment and communities.

fact_checked_segment: But-but-but-but Alexandria Ocasio-Crazy told me we only have 12 years!
comment_by_fact-checker: The 12-year figure quoted comes from the 2018 UN “Special Report on Global warming of 1.5ºC,” released last October. In this report, the year 2030—12 years from now—is given as the “point of no return”, if we keep releasing CO2 at our current rate. What this means is that after this point, it is almost impossible to imagine how CO2 in the atmosphere could ever be brought back down to levels needed to keep global temperatures less than 1.5 ˚C warmer. This figure comes from the IPCC report scientists—hundreds of scientists from different fields working all around the world. The article has taken this figure out of context, and is comparing it to something very different. What ThinkProgress says is related to the timescales it takes for the maximum effects of the CO2 released now to take hold. This is not in conflict with the IPCC figure of 12 years cited by AOC—this report talks about the year we must stop releasing CO2 by in order for the long term knock on effects of this CO2 release to not be so detrimental to humankind.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The urgency of addressing climate change
FACT1: Climate change is a pressing issue that requires immediate action. The scientific consensus is that human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, are causing the Earth's temperature to rise at an unprecedented rate, leading to more frequent and severe weather events, rising sea levels, and other negative impacts on the environment and human health.
MYTH: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez claimed that we only have 12 years to address climate change.
FALLACY: This myth is a misrepresentation of a statement made by Ocasio-Cortez, who was referring to the need to take significant action to address climate change within the next 12 years in order to avoid the worst impacts of global warming. The 12-year timeline is based on a report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), which states that global emissions must be reduced by 45% by 2030 in order to limit global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels.
FACT2: It is important to recognize the urgency of addressing climate change and take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, transition to renewable energy sources, and implement other solutions to mitigate the impacts of global warming. Let's work together to create a sustainable future for ourselves and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “How did a wet Western winter lead to a sky-choking summer? The answer lies in the summer’s record-breaking heat, say wildfire experts. Days of near-100-degree-Fahrenheit temperatures cooked the Mountain West in early July, and a scorching heat wave lingered over the Pacific Northwest in early August.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Exceptionally high summer air temperatures undoubtedly contributed to the extensive forest fire activity that occurred during the summer of 2017 in the western United States. Forest flammability is affected by both winter snowfall and seasonal rain, as well as by spring and summer air temperatures that regulate the timing of snowmelt and how much water the atmosphere will suck out of the forest.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Record-breaking heat, not wet winter, led to sky-choking summer wildfires
FACT1: The summer wildfires were not caused by the wet winter, but rather by the record-breaking heat that occurred in early July and August. The high temperatures dried out the vegetation, making it more susceptible to catching fire and spreading quickly.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: The article correctly identifies the cause of the wildfires, so there is no fallacy to debunk.

FACT2: It is important to understand the role that high temperatures play in increasing the risk of wildfires. As climate change continues to cause more extreme weather events, it is crucial that we take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of global warming. Let's work towards a sustainable future to protect our planet and prevent more devastating wildfires.

fact_checked_segment: “What are the odds that a climate model built on a system that simple would be reliable? Less than 50/50. (Multiplying .95 by itself 15 times yields 46.3 percent.)”
comment_by_fact-checker: Again, this assumes that all variables are independent and everything is happening randomly. This is just not the case. Winds, temperatures, pressures, cloud formation, and so on are all bound together in coherent ways by the laws of physics.
label: false cause
debunk: Climate models are not built on a simple system, but rather on complex mathematical models that take into account a wide range of factors, including atmospheric and oceanic circulation, solar radiation, and greenhouse gas concentrations. This statement is an example of the fallacy of oversimplification, which distorts understanding and leads to erroneous conclusions. The reliability of climate models is supported by a vast body of scientific evidence and has been validated through numerous studies and observations. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: “How did a wet Western winter lead to a sky-choking summer? The answer lies in the summer’s record-breaking heat, say wildfire experts. Days of near-100-degree-Fahrenheit temperatures cooked the Mountain West in early July, and a scorching heat wave lingered over the Pacific Northwest in early August.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Exceptionally high summer air temperatures undoubtedly contributed to the extensive forest fire activity that occurred during the summer of 2017 in the western United States. Forest flammability is affected by both winter snowfall and seasonal rain, as well as by spring and summer air temperatures that regulate the timing of snowmelt and how much water the atmosphere will suck out of the forest.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Record-breaking heat, not wet winter, led to sky-choking summer wildfires
FACT1: The summer's sky-choking wildfires were not caused by the wet Western winter, but rather by the record-breaking heat that occurred in early July and early August. The near-100-degree-Fahrenheit temperatures that cooked the Mountain West and the scorching heat wave that lingered over the Pacific Northwest were the main culprits behind the wildfires.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: The article debunks the idea that the wet Western winter caused the summer's wildfires, which is a false cause fallacy. Just because there was a wet winter does not mean that there cannot be wildfires in the summer due to other factors, such as record-breaking heat.
FACT2: Let's not jump to conclusions and assume that a wet winter will always prevent wildfires. It is important to consider other factors, such as temperature and weather patterns, when predicting the risk of wildfires.

fact_checked_segment: “It has never been shown that human emissions of carbon dioxide drive global warming.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Virtually all statements in this article have been proven wrong so many times by scientific experts that it is unreasonable to once again show that they are wrong. But I want to focus on the statement “it has never been shown” only. How can one claim that the impact of anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions has “never been shown that…”? Clearly, for this author, science per se either does not exist or else has no credibility whatsoever. Surely then, scientific research itself cannot exist, there is no geology to find coal resources, no studies “of natural processes such as ocean degassing”, etc. From this, one can only conclude that we actually cannot know anything—not even the things that this author believes to be true.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: The Role of Human Emissions in Global Warming
FACT1: Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas that traps heat in the Earth's atmosphere, contributing to global warming. Human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, deforestation, and land-use changes, have significantly increased the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
MYTH: "It has never been shown that human emissions of carbon dioxide drive global warming."
FALLACY: This statement is a form of cherry-picking, as it ignores the overwhelming evidence that human emissions of carbon dioxide are the primary cause of global warming. Multiple lines of evidence, including temperature records, ice core data, and computer models, all point to the conclusion that human activities are responsible for the observed warming.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. The scientific consensus is clear: human emissions of carbon dioxide are driving global warming, and we need to take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “…climate change will also reduce the number of cold days and cold spells. That will cut the total number of cold-related deaths.”
comment_by_fact-checker: There is very limited scientific support for the claim that reducing the number of cold days (by which he apparently means winter) will reduce the number of cold-related deaths. Again, this is assuming winter mortality is temperature-dependent; an assumption not verified by research in the US and elsewhere.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change and Cold-Related Deaths
FACT1: Climate change will lead to a reduction in the number of cold days and cold spells, which will ultimately decrease the total number of cold-related deaths. 
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to acknowledge that climate change will have a range of impacts on human health, including an increase in heat-related deaths and other health risks. However, it is also important to recognize that climate change will have some positive impacts, such as reducing the number of cold-related deaths. Let's continue to educate ourselves on the complex impacts of climate change on human health.

fact_checked_segment: “Moreover, its warming impact decreases sharply after the first 20 or 30 ppm. Adding more CO2 molecules to the atmosphere is like painting over a red wall with white paint — the first coat does most of the work of concealing the red. A second coat of paint has much less of an effect, while adding a third or fourth coat has almost no impact at all.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Jacoby emphasizes the logarithmic nature of how CO2 affects the energy balance of Earth, and hence surface temperature (i.e., going from 10 ppm of CO2 to 11 ppm would have a much larger impact than going from 300 to 301 ppm). This is correct, but has been known for well over half a century now, and is fully accounted for in even simple estimates of future warming. This is therefore a distraction.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Diminishing Returns of CO2
FACT1: CO2 has a diminishing warming effect as its concentration increases in the atmosphere. The first 20-30 ppm of CO2 has the most significant impact on warming, while additional CO2 has a decreasing effect. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: This statement is an accurate representation of the scientific understanding of the warming effect of CO2. However, it is important to note that while the warming effect of CO2 may diminish with increasing concentrations, it does not disappear entirely. Even small increases in CO2 concentrations can have significant impacts on the climate. 
FACT2: It is crucial to continue reducing greenhouse gas emissions to limit the warming of the planet and avoid the worst impacts of climate change. Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and transition to cleaner energy sources.

fact_checked_segment: “Antarctica, the planet’s largest ice sheet, lost 219 billion tons of ice annually from 2012 through 2017 — approximately triple the 73 billion ton melt rate of a decade ago, the scientists concluded. From 1992 through 1997, Antarctica lost 49 billion tons of ice annually.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This translates to about 0.6 mm/yr in 2012-2017, while the 1992-1997 rates were 0.14 mm/yr. This may not sound like much, but the current total rate of sea-level rise is around 3.2 mm/yr, so Antarctica is responsible for an increasingly large portion of the observed sea-level rise.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Antarctica is losing ice at an alarming rate
FACT1: Antarctica lost 219 billion tons of ice annually from 2012 through 2017, which is triple the melt rate of a decade ago.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and slow down the rate of ice loss in Antarctica.

fact_checked_segment: “Sea level rise, which was occurring long before humans could be blamed, has not accelerated and still amounts to only 1 inch every ten years. If a major hurricane is approaching with a predicted storm surge of 10-14 feet, are you really going to worry about a sea level rise of 1 inch per decade?”
comment_by_fact-checker: Sea level rise and its impacts vary considerably by region. To state a global mean number is misleading and irrelevant to those regions that are most vulnerable. With or without hurricanes added to the mix, the impacts on humans from sea level rise can be seen now. The author’s comparison of hurricane storm surge to sea level rise is very misleading and blurs the relevance of sea level rise to humans. Sea level rise is creating nuisance flooding in a number of places. The fact that hurricane storm surge is bigger is irrelevant and does not change the fact that people are being impacted.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The Insignificance of Sea Level Rise in the Face of Natural Disasters
FACT1: Sea level rise is a gradual increase in the average height of the ocean's surface, caused by the melting of glaciers and ice sheets and the thermal expansion of seawater due to global warming. It is currently occurring at a rate of about 1 inch every 10 years.
MYTH: Sea level rise is insignificant and not worth worrying about, especially in the face of natural disasters like hurricanes.
FALLACY: This argument uses the false equivalence fallacy by comparing the gradual and long-term effects of sea level rise to the immediate and short-term effects of a natural disaster. It also uses the cherry-picking fallacy by focusing on a single aspect of sea level rise (the rate of rise) while ignoring the potential long-term consequences, such as flooding and displacement of coastal communities.
FACT2: While it is true that sea level rise may not be immediately noticeable in the face of a natural disaster, it is still a significant and ongoing issue that will have long-term consequences for coastal communities and ecosystems. It is important to address and mitigate the causes of sea level rise to prevent further harm. Let's not dismiss the importance of addressing sea level rise in the face of natural disasters.

fact_checked_segment: there has been no systematic increase in the frequency of extreme weather events,
comment_by_fact-checker: It’s not clear how you judge “systematic increase in the frequency of extreme weather”. Since the 2013 UN IPCC report, we have new data and analysis showing increases in extreme heat and precipitation in many areas due to human-caused global warming. It is misleading not to mention this.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Extreme Weather Events: Separating Fact from Fiction
FACT1: Extreme weather events have always occurred, but there is no evidence to suggest that their frequency has systematically increased over time.
MYTH: Climate change is causing an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events.
FALLACY: This myth is based on the fallacy of cherry-picking, which involves selectively choosing data that support a particular argument while ignoring data that contradict it. While it is true that individual extreme weather events, such as hurricanes or heatwaves, have become more intense in some regions, there is no evidence to suggest that their frequency has systematically increased over time. In fact, some studies suggest that the frequency of extreme weather events may have decreased in recent decades.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. While it is important to take action to address climate change, we should not exaggerate the frequency or severity of extreme weather events in order to make our case. Instead, we should focus on the scientific evidence and work together to find solutions that are based on sound science and good policy.

fact_checked_segment: “An “inherent bias” in scientific journals in favour of more calamitous predictions has excluded research showing that marine creatures are not damaged by ocean acidification, which is caused by the sea absorbing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.”
comment_by_fact-checker: In all fields of research, it is much easier to publish a paper saying ‘We were able to develop convincing evidence that X affects Y’ than to publish a paper saying that ‘We were not able to develop convincing evidence that X affects Y’. That is a bias that is inherent in all of modern science and is not specific to ocean acidification research.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Ocean acidification, caused by the absorption of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, is a real and ongoing process that affects marine ecosystems worldwide. 

MYTH: There is an inherent bias in scientific journals that excludes research showing that marine creatures are not damaged by ocean acidification.

FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, where a single study or a few studies are used to support a particular viewpoint while ignoring the larger body of evidence. While it is true that some studies have found that certain marine organisms are less affected by ocean acidification than others, the overwhelming majority of research shows that ocean acidification has negative impacts on marine ecosystems, including reduced growth and survival rates, changes in behavior, and altered food webs.

FACT2: It is important to consider the full body of scientific evidence when evaluating the impacts of ocean acidification on marine ecosystems. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: […] the Roman Warming, the Dark Ages, the Medieval Warming and the Little Ice Age. These took place before industrialisation and were all driven by changes in the sun.
comment_by_fact-checker: These climate fluctuations were small, regional and at a much smaller scale than what the planet experiences today. None of them were globally as warm as today. They were also driven by other forcings than greenhouse gases. The author is confused between small-scale natural variability and long-term irreversible large-scale change.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change Before Industrialisation

FACT1: Climate change has occurred throughout Earth's history, long before the industrial revolution. Natural factors such as changes in the sun's intensity, volcanic activity, and variations in Earth's orbit have all contributed to past climate changes.

MYTH: Climate change is a recent phenomenon caused solely by human activity.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of a false cause fallacy, which assumes that because climate change has occurred naturally in the past, it cannot be caused by human activity. While natural factors have contributed to past climate changes, the overwhelming scientific evidence shows that human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation, are the primary cause of the current warming trend.

FACT2: Understanding the natural factors that have contributed to past climate changes is important, but it does not negate the overwhelming evidence that human activity is causing the current warming trend. Let's not use past climate changes as an excuse to ignore the urgent need to address human-caused climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “an individual heatwave triggering coral bleaching cannot be linked to global warming as the process triggering an individual heatwave is fundamentally different from that triggering global warming”
comment_by_fact-checker: Unfortunately, even under the Paris Agreement, 2016-like heat will be more common*. King et al (2017) Australian climate extremes at 1.5 °C and 2 °C of global warming, Nature Climate Change
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Heatwaves and Global Warming: Understanding the Link
FACT1: Heatwaves are extreme weather events characterized by high temperatures and prolonged periods of heat. Global warming, on the other hand, refers to the long-term increase in the Earth's average surface temperature due to human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation.
MYTH: "An individual heatwave triggering coral bleaching cannot be linked to global warming as the process triggering an individual heatwave is fundamentally different from that triggering global warming."
FALLACY: This argument is a false dichotomy, presenting a false choice between individual heatwaves and global warming. While the processes that trigger individual heatwaves and global warming may be different, they are not mutually exclusive. Global warming increases the likelihood and severity of heatwaves, making them more frequent and intense.
FACT2: Understanding the link between heatwaves and global warming is crucial in addressing the impacts of climate change. Let's not downplay the role of global warming in extreme weather events and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: “His Gaia hypothesis, which contends that the earth is a single, self-regulating organism, is now accepted as the founding principle of most climate science […]”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is going a bit far. The Gaia gave many scientists food for thought, and a new way of thinking about the climate system in a holistic way, but it is hardly the “founding principle” of most climate science. That remains the physics of fluid flow and heat transport, plus chemistry and biology, etc.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: The Gaia Hypothesis and Climate Science
FACT1: The Gaia hypothesis, proposed by James Lovelock in the 1970s, suggests that the Earth is a self-regulating system that maintains conditions necessary for life. This hypothesis has influenced the study of Earth's climate and ecosystems, but it is not the founding principle of most climate science.
MYTH: The Gaia hypothesis is the founding principle of most climate science.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of the appeal to authority fallacy, as it suggests that the Gaia hypothesis is widely accepted in climate science because of James Lovelock's authority as a scientist. However, scientific ideas are not accepted based on the authority of their proponents, but on the evidence and data that support them.
FACT2: While the Gaia hypothesis has influenced the study of Earth's climate and ecosystems, it is not the founding principle of most climate science. Climate science is based on a wide range of evidence and data from multiple fields of study, including physics, chemistry, biology, and geology. Let's not oversimplify the complex and interdisciplinary nature of climate science.

fact_checked_segment: “And this winter’s near disaster at the overflowing Lake Oroville was in part caused by warm storms too.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The skewed rain-snow ratio this season certainly contributed to some of the precipitation-related impacts this winter. While winter 2016-2017 was not exceptionally warm in the Sierra Nevada, especially relative to recent record-warm years, it was still warmer than average. In middle elevation zones of the Sierra Nevada, precipitation fell as rain rather than snow more often that would have historically been the case—leading to a snowpack that significantly lagged overall liquid precipitation (although both were well above average). (See this article in Eos.)
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: Warm storms can contribute to the overflow of Lake Oroville.
MYTH: Warm storms are not a significant factor in the overflow of Lake Oroville.
FALLACY: The myth is an example of cherry-picking, as it focuses on one aspect of the situation while ignoring other factors that contribute to the overflow of Lake Oroville, such as heavy rainfall and inadequate infrastructure.
FACT2: The overflow of Lake Oroville is a complex issue that requires a comprehensive approach to address, including improving infrastructure and managing water resources more effectively. Let's not oversimplify the situation and instead work towards finding sustainable solutions.

fact_checked_segment: “Construction and maintenance of wind and solar facilities ­release far more carbon dioxide than they are meant to save over their working lives and they need to be sup­ported 24/7 by coal-fired generators.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is completely incorrect. There are numerous studies contradicting this. For example, see a series of studies by Sally Benson at Stanford University. Frankly, both parts of this claim are absurd. Coal-fired generators are particularly poorly-suited to act as a backup for solar because they generally are very expensive to ramp up and down, so they are used almost everywhere around the world as baseload generators. Natural gas or hydro are much better suited as backup. This sentence belies a lack of understanding of energy technologies and markets.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
Renewable energy sources like wind and solar power are often criticized for not being as environmentally friendly as they claim to be. However, the fact is that wind and solar facilities do not release more carbon dioxide than they save over their working lives. This statement is a MYTH. 

The FALLACY underlying this myth is Cherry Picking. This myth selectively focuses on the carbon footprint of constructing and maintaining wind and solar facilities while ignoring the carbon savings they provide over their lifetime. It also ignores the fact that renewable energy sources can be paired with energy storage systems to provide power 24/7 without relying on coal-fired generators. 

The FACT is that renewable energy sources like wind and solar power are crucial in reducing carbon emissions and mitigating the effects of climate change. They are becoming increasingly cost-effective and efficient, and with the right policies and investments, they can provide a significant portion of our energy needs. 

Let's not spread misinformation to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: “This means the global temperature trend has now shown no further warming for 19 years”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is blatantly false. Examine the trend here: Furthermore, a short time period of a few months in 2017 cannot say anything whatsoever about the long-term change in climate.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Global Temperature Trend Has Not Shown No Further Warming for 19 Years
FACT1: The global temperature trend has continued to rise over the past 19 years, despite claims to the contrary. In fact, 2016 was the hottest year on record, and the five hottest years on record have all occurred since 2010.
MYTH: This means the global temperature trend has now shown no further warming for 19 years.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, where a small amount of data is selected to support a particular argument while ignoring the larger trend. By focusing on a specific 19-year period, this statement ignores the overall trend of rising temperatures over the past century.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's focus on the overwhelming evidence that shows the Earth is warming and take action to address this critical issue.

fact_checked_segment: “Back in the late 1980s, the UN claimed that if global warming were not checked by 2000, rising sea levels would wash entire counties away.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Rising seas are, in fact, forcing many Pacific island nations and coastal communities in the United States to plan for permanent evacuation. Although low-lying areas will not “disappear” into the ocean anytime soon, nuisance flooding, erosion, and storm surges are making maintaining these communities economically untenable.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: UN's 1980s prediction on global warming and sea levels
FACT1: The UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) was established in 1988 to assess the science related to climate change. In its first report in 1990, the IPCC predicted that global temperatures would rise by 0.3°C per decade and that sea levels would rise by 15-95 cm by 2100 due to human activities such as burning fossil fuels. 
MYTH: The UN claimed in the late 1980s that if global warming were not checked by 2000, rising sea levels would wash entire counties away.
FALLACY: This myth is a misrepresentation of the IPCC's predictions. The IPCC did not make any specific predictions about entire counties being washed away by rising sea levels. Instead, it predicted a range of sea level rise scenarios based on different greenhouse gas emissions scenarios.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about the UN's predictions on global warming and sea levels. The IPCC's predictions were based on scientific evidence and continue to be updated as new research emerges. It is important to take action to mitigate the impacts of climate change and protect vulnerable communities from the effects of rising sea levels.

fact_checked_segment: “And some plants – like algae which use carbon for photosynthesis – may even benefit.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The use of “carbon” here is confusing. However the statement is not totally wrong. It is fine in my opinion to say “some plants maybe benefit” because experiments have only been run on some types of plants and algae.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Carbon Dioxide is not always beneficial for plants
FACT1: While plants need carbon dioxide for photosynthesis, too much of it can be harmful. High levels of carbon dioxide can lead to reduced plant growth, decreased nutrient content, and increased susceptibility to pests and diseases.
MYTH: Carbon dioxide is always beneficial for plants.
FALLACY: The myth is based on the false assumption that more of a good thing is always better. While plants need carbon dioxide for photosynthesis, too much of it can be harmful. High levels of carbon dioxide can lead to reduced plant growth, decreased nutrient content, and increased susceptibility to pests and diseases. This fallacy is known as the "fallacy of moderation," which assumes that the optimal amount of something is always in the middle of two extremes.
FACT2: It is important to maintain a balance of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere to ensure the health of both plants and animals. Let's not spread misinformation about the benefits of excessive carbon dioxide to our friends.

fact_checked_segment: Renew­ables such as wind turbines are environmentally disastrous because they pollute a huge land area, slice and dice birds and bats, kill insects that are bird food, create health problems for humans who live within kilometres of them, leave toxins around the turbine site and despoil the landscape.
comment_by_fact-checker: There is no comparison here with the alternatives. For example, the claimed wind turbine health damages, for which the author shows evidence of zero deaths, should be compared with the millions of deaths that the World Health Organisation links to pollution every year, much of which is from fossil fuels.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: The Environmental Impact of Wind Turbines
FACT1: Wind turbines have a significant environmental impact, but it is not as disastrous as claimed. They do take up land and can cause harm to wildlife, but they also have many benefits, such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions and providing clean energy.
MYTH: Wind turbines are environmentally disastrous because they pollute a huge land area, slice and dice birds and bats, kill insects that are bird food, create health problems for humans who live within kilometres of them, leave toxins around the turbine site and despoil the landscape.
FALLACY: This argument uses several fallacies, including cherry-picking, false equivalence, and anecdotal evidence. While it is true that wind turbines can have negative impacts on the environment, this argument exaggerates and misrepresents the extent of these impacts. It also ignores the many benefits of wind energy and the fact that other forms of energy production, such as fossil fuels, have much greater negative impacts on the environment.
FACT2: Wind turbines have some negative environmental impacts, but they also have many benefits, such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions and providing clean energy. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and instead focus on finding ways to mitigate the negative impacts of wind energy while maximizing its benefits.

fact_checked_segment: Furthermore, whereas in 2008 most of the ice was extremely thin, this year most has been at least two metres thick.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Arctic sea ice volume has actually exhibited record thinness so far during 2017—beating the previous record years of 2012/2016 by a wide margin. Another nice visualization by Zachary Labe illustrates this quite clearly:
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Arctic sea ice is not recovering, despite occasional increases in ice extent.
FACT1: Arctic sea ice is declining at an alarming rate, with the minimum extent in September 2020 being the second-lowest on record. The ice is also becoming thinner, younger, and more vulnerable to melting. 
MYTH: Arctic sea ice is recovering because there has been an increase in ice extent in some years.
FALLACY: This is an example of cherry-picking, where a single piece of data is used to support a particular argument while ignoring other relevant data. While there have been occasional increases in ice extent, the long-term trend is still one of decline. Moreover, the ice that is present is thinner and more vulnerable to melting, making it less resilient to future warming.
FACT2: Let's not be misled by occasional increases in ice extent. The long-term trend is still one of decline, and we need to take urgent action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and limit the extent of future warming.

fact_checked_segment: “The UN has already said that 2016 is highly likely to break the annual record again, after 14 straight months of extreme heat aided by a hefty El Niño climatic event, a weather event that typically raises temperatures around the world.“
comment_by_fact-checker: I would say that it increases ‘global mean temperature’. An El Niño does not necessarily imply warming everywhere on Earth. Also, especially pronounced are the warm conditions in the Arctic, which are not explicitly mentioned here, but do not relate to the strong El Niño.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: 2016 is on track to be the hottest year on record
FACT1: 2016 is likely to break the annual record for the hottest year on record, with 14 consecutive months of extreme heat. This is due in part to the El Niño climatic event, which typically raises temperatures around the world.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important to take action to address climate change and reduce greenhouse gas emissions in order to prevent further warming of the planet. Let's work together to protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “But as long as there are still unburned fossil fuels in the ground, it is not too late to act.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement is imprecise, and depends on value judgments of what “too late” means. Even emitting only a fraction of the available unburned fossil fuels would eliminate important ecosystems like coral reef habitats. For these ecosystems it will thus be too late. Because part of the CO2 that is emitted will remain in the atmosphere for many centuries, climate change constitutes a cumulative problem. Halting CO2 emissions before the last fossil fuel has been burned thus indeed commits the world to less impacts than the theoretically maximum. However, whether this is not “too late” depends on whether no irreversible or societally unacceptable impacts were reached before that point. The latter requires societal value judgments informed by scientific assessments, but is ultimately not a scientific question.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Acting on Climate Change is Still Possible
FACT1: Climate change is a global problem caused by human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, deforestation, and industrial processes. The Earth's temperature is rising, causing more frequent and severe weather events, rising sea levels, and other negative impacts on the environment and human health. However, it is not too late to act to mitigate the worst effects of climate change.
MYTH: It is too late to act on climate change because too much damage has already been done.
FALLACY: This myth is based on the false assumption that climate change is an all-or-nothing problem. In reality, every action taken to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change can make a difference. While some damage has already been done, it is still possible to prevent the worst-case scenarios by reducing emissions and transitioning to renewable energy sources.
FACT2: We can all take action to reduce our carbon footprint, such as using public transportation, eating a plant-based diet, and reducing energy consumption. Governments and businesses can also take action by implementing policies and practices that reduce emissions and promote sustainability. Let's not give up on the fight against climate change and work together to create a more sustainable future.

fact_checked_segment: “Fires have not only been increasing in size due to climate change. In the early 20th century, state and federal governments began aggressively fighting wildfires and trying to keep them as small as possible. This has caused denser and more fire-prone forests than the long-term average for the West, which has led to more massive and uncontrollable fires.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement should have included a citation and also noted that the influence of fire suppression on subsequent fire activity varies with the frequency of historical fires. The century of fire suppression has potentially increased fuel accumulation in dry forests that historically experienced very frequent fires (e.g. every 5-20 years). On the other hand, fire suppression has likely had far less of an impact on wetter forests, such as those in coastal Oregon and Washington, that historically went centuries without fire.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
FACT1: Aggressive wildfire suppression in the early 20th century has led to denser and more fire-prone forests in the Western US, contributing to the increase in massive and uncontrollable fires. 

MYTH: The increase in the size of wildfires is solely due to climate change. 

FALLACY: This myth is an example of oversimplification, assuming that there is only one cause for the increase in wildfire size. While climate change has contributed to the problem, aggressive wildfire suppression has also played a significant role. By preventing smaller fires from burning through forests, fuel builds up over time, creating denser forests that are more prone to large fires. 

FACT2: Understanding the multiple factors that contribute to the increase in wildfire size is crucial in developing effective strategies to prevent and manage them. Let's not oversimplify the issue and instead consider all the contributing factors.

fact_checked_segment: This requires us to work towards avoiding catastrophic possibilities rather than looking at probabilities, as learning from mistakes is not an option when it comes to existential risks.
comment_by_fact-checker: The report focuses on possible scenarios very much on the extreme end of what could happen but then claims there’s a “high likelihood” of human civilisation ending. These two statements don’t fit together.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The Importance of Addressing Existential Risks
FACT1: Existential risks are threats that could potentially cause the extinction of humanity or the collapse of civilization. These risks are not just theoretical, but have the potential to cause catastrophic harm. It is important to take these risks seriously and work towards preventing them, rather than simply relying on probabilities and learning from mistakes.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: This statement highlights the importance of addressing existential risks and the need to take them seriously. It emphasizes that we cannot simply rely on probabilities and learning from mistakes, as the consequences of these risks are too catastrophic to allow for trial and error. By focusing on the importance of prevention rather than reaction, we can work towards mitigating these risks and ensuring the survival of humanity and civilization.
FACT2: Let's prioritize addressing existential risks and work towards preventing them, rather than simply relying on probabilities and learning from mistakes. By taking these risks seriously, we can ensure the survival of humanity and civilization.

fact_checked_segment: “We have known for decades that increasing CO₂ and precipitation from global warming will make the world much greener – by the end of the century, it is likely that global biomass will have increased by forty percent.”
comment_by_fact-checker: In short, the negative effect of climate change is expected to largely offset the positive effect of increasing CO2. [read more]   2.2. It is estimated climate change would double the economic damages caused by hurricanes
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change and Greenery
FACT1: Climate change is expected to increase global biomass by 40% by the end of the century due to increased CO2 and precipitation, leading to a greener world.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the positive effects of climate change on greenery, but we must also recognize the negative impacts on ecosystems, biodiversity, and human societies. We need to take action to mitigate the negative effects of climate change while also promoting sustainable development.

fact_checked_segment: “Instead of a three-foot increase in ocean levels by the end of the century, six feet was more likely, according to DeConto and Pollard’s findings. But if carbon emissions continue to track on something resembling a worst-case scenario, the full 11 feet of ice locked in West Antarctica might be freed up, their study showed.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The study referenced1 finds that, assuming some different possible scenarios for the speed of ice sheet processes and the IPCC’s highest emissions scenario (RCP 8.5), Antarctica alone can contribute anywhere from 0.5 to 4.5 feet (Figure 5b and d, below) of sea level rise. The DeConto & Pollard study1 does not include the potential for sea level rise from thermal expansion of sea water, melting of mountain glaciers or the Greenland Ice Sheet in it’s projections, but if these are included, the total sea level rise projected for 2100 may be something like 6 feet. If this is the calculation implicit in this statement that “…six feet was more likely, according to DeConto and Pollard’s findings”, than it is perhaps a bit misleading, since DeConto & Pollard is only focused on the contribution from the Antarctic Ice Sheet. As DeConto & Pollard say in their study: “…the rates of ice loss simulated here should not be viewed as actual predictions, but rather as possible envelopes of behaviour”. Determining the “likely” amount of sea level rise in the future is a prediction that is strongly dependent on the assumptions about how ice sheet behave and on what time scales. Based on just DeConto & Pollard’s studies, and the assumptions inherent in their model, one can conclude that it is likely that sea level will rise by more than 11 feet, just from Antarctic melting, over the next several centuries, if humans do not significantly reduce emissions of greenhouse gases (see Figure 5 and S7 of DeConto & Pollard 2016). What the glaciological community as a whole considers “likely” depends on which processes we think are likely to be important contributors of ice sheet collapse, which is a matter that is actively under debate. Since the DeConto & Pollard study is relatively new, there is still an ongoing discussion about how likely it is that the Marine Ice Cliff Instability will actually occur and at what rate will it causes ice to be lost from individual glaciers. Though the article as a whole covers some parts of this debate, these individual statements about likelihood do not necessarily reflect a community consensus. DeConto and Pollard (2016) Contribution of Antarctica to past and future sea-level rise, Nature
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Melting Antarctic Ice Could Lead to 11 Feet of Sea Level Rise
FACT1: The melting of ice in West Antarctica could lead to a sea level rise of up to 11 feet, according to a study by DeConto and Pollard. Even if carbon emissions follow a more moderate trajectory, a sea level rise of at least 3 feet is likely by the end of the century.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to take action to reduce carbon emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change to prevent catastrophic sea level rise. Let's work towards a sustainable future for our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “Research shows that this process is overpowering the erosion from sea-level rise, leading to net land-area gain. This is not only true for the Marshall Islands. […]several studies have documented noteworthy shoreline progradation [growth] and positional changes of islands since the mid-20th century, resulting in a net increase in island area.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The dynamics of sand accretion and loss across the tropical Pacific is indeed complicated, and many atolls are at the moment growing. However, as sea levels rise in this area of the globe, water tables also rise and become salinated, reducing the availability of fresh water for drinking or agriculture. Focusing on the tropical Pacific takes attention away from regions where the signal is much clearer, e.g. the east coast of the USA. The occurrence of “nuisance flooding” and coastal inundation has risen dramatically in recent decades. Another 50-100 centimeters of sea level rise globally threatens vast swaths of built infrastructure and hundreds of millions of lives. Whether or not Pacific atolls accrete or shrink is not the most central issue.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
Island Nations are not sinking due to sea-level rise.
MYTH: Island nations are sinking due to sea-level rise.
FALLACY: This myth is based on the false assumption that all islands are static landforms that will be completely submerged as sea levels rise. In reality, many islands are dynamic and can change shape and size over time due to natural processes such as sedimentation and erosion. This means that while some low-lying areas may be lost to the sea, other areas may actually gain land as sediment is deposited. Additionally, human interventions such as building seawalls and planting vegetation can also help to mitigate the effects of sea-level rise.
FACT: Research has shown that many islands in the Pacific, including the Marshall Islands, have actually increased in land area over the past few decades due to natural processes such as sedimentation. While sea-level rise is a concern for these islands, it is not the only factor affecting their long-term viability.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about the fate of island nations due to sea-level rise. While it is a concern, it is important to understand the complex and dynamic nature of these landforms and the various factors that can affect their size and shape over time.

fact_checked_segment: “record temperatures brought in 2016 by an exceptionally strong El Niño”
comment_by_fact-checker: Last year the annual global temperature was about 1.1 °C above a late-19th century baseline but only about 0.1°C of this was due to the El Niño—the other 1 °C is due to human influences. So while the record occurred in 2016 due to El Niño, most of the anomaly was due to climate change.
label: post hoc
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding the Role of El Niño in Record Temperatures
FACT1: El Niño is a natural climate pattern that occurs when sea surface temperatures in the Pacific Ocean become unusually warm, leading to changes in weather patterns around the world. During an El Niño event, temperatures can rise globally, leading to record-breaking temperatures in some regions. 
MYTH: The record temperatures in 2016 were solely caused by global warming.
FALLACY: This myth commits the fallacy of oversimplification by ignoring the role of natural climate patterns, such as El Niño, in contributing to global temperatures. While global warming is a significant factor in rising temperatures, it is not the only factor. 
FACT2: Understanding the role of natural climate patterns, such as El Niño, is important in accurately assessing the causes of record-breaking temperatures. Let's not oversimplify the complex factors that contribute to global temperatures.

fact_checked_segment: “The blue bars show where the raw temperature data has been adjusted downwards to make it cooler; the red bars show where the raw temperature data has been adjusted upwards to make it warmer.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It does no such thing as both the series are adjusted. Hence it is impossible from the graph as constructed to make such an inference. To do so would require taking the adjusted data away from the raw data which is not what is being done here.
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: Temperature Adjustments Explained
FACT1: Temperature data is often adjusted to account for changes in measurement methods, station locations, and other factors that can affect the accuracy of the data. These adjustments are made to ensure that the data is as accurate and reliable as possible.
MYTH: Temperature data is manipulated to make it appear warmer than it actually is.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, as it focuses on only one aspect of temperature adjustments and presents it in a misleading way. Temperature adjustments are made to correct for known biases in the data, such as changes in measurement methods or station locations, and are subject to rigorous scientific scrutiny and peer review. The adjustments are made to improve the accuracy and reliability of the data, not to manipulate it.
FACT2: Temperature adjustments are a necessary part of ensuring that temperature data is accurate and reliable. Let's not spread misinformation about temperature adjustments and instead trust the rigorous scientific process that goes into ensuring the accuracy of the data.

fact_checked_segment: People who study the impacts of global warming have found that if ECS is low — say, less than two — then the impacts of global warming on the economy will be mostly small and, in many places, mildly beneficial. If it is very low, for instance around one, it means greenhouse gas emissions are simply not worth doing anything about.
comment_by_fact-checker: This passage is misleading. It seems to imply that society has already decided to exactly double CO2 concentrations and has committed to emitting no further greenhouse gasses after that. If that were the case, then we could in fact assess climate change impacts in the manner done here. However, society is far from committing to stabilizing CO2 concentrations at “only” twice their preindustrial levels. We may go well beyond that. In that case, lower equilibrium climate sensitivity just means that it takes longer to reach a given level of warming. So even if climate sensitivity turns out to be very low, all the worst impacts could still be realized—they would just be delayed.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
FACT1: The impacts of global warming on the economy depend on the value of ECS (Equilibrium Climate Sensitivity), which measures how much the Earth's temperature will increase in response to a doubling of atmospheric CO2. If ECS is low, the impacts of global warming will be mostly small and, in some places, mildly beneficial.

MYTH: The impacts of global warming on the economy are always negative, regardless of the value of ECS.

FALLACY: This myth is based on a false dichotomy, which presents only two options (either the impacts are always negative or always positive) when in reality, the impacts depend on the value of ECS. It also ignores the fact that even if ECS is low, there will still be negative impacts in some regions, such as increased frequency of extreme weather events.

FACT2: Understanding the value of ECS is crucial for making informed decisions about how to address global warming. Let's not oversimplify the issue and instead focus on finding effective solutions based on scientific evidence.

fact_checked_segment: “climate economists see a positive externality, not a negative one, from the human influence on climate. (In technical lingo, the so-called social cost of carbon would be negative.)”
comment_by_fact-checker: At a minimum, the author should be honest and say that “some climate economists” conclude that the net externalities of climate change may be positive, as the article he links to discusses only the economic views of its author and anecdotes from two climate scientists. Further, the article the author links to discusses only the net economic impacts on “the US and most of the developed countries”, while climate change will impact economies around the globe. This is not a meaningful argument anyway, as the exact value of the climate sensitivity does not inherently determine whether climate impacts will be economically net positive or negative.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change Can Have Positive Externalities
FACT1: Climate change can have positive externalities, which are benefits that are not reflected in market prices. For example, a warmer climate may increase agricultural productivity in some regions, leading to lower food prices and increased food security. Additionally, some economists argue that the social cost of carbon, which measures the economic damage caused by carbon emissions, could be negative, meaning that the benefits of carbon emissions may outweigh the costs in some cases.

MYTH: Climate Change Only Has Negative Consequences
FALLACY: The myth that climate change only has negative consequences is an oversimplification that ignores the complexity of the issue. While climate change is undoubtedly causing significant harm to ecosystems and human societies, it is also true that some regions and industries may benefit from a warmer climate. However, it is important to note that these benefits are likely to be outweighed by the negative impacts of climate change, such as sea level rise, more frequent and severe heatwaves, and increased frequency of extreme weather events.

FACT2: It is important to recognize that climate change is a complex issue with both positive and negative externalities. However, the negative impacts of climate change are likely to outweigh any potential benefits, and urgent action is needed to mitigate the worst effects of climate change. Let's work together to reduce our carbon emissions and protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: In its 5th assessment report in 2013, the IPCC estimated that human emissions are probably responsible for more than half of the observed increase in global average temperature from 1951 to 2010. But it means a chunk of the rise is coming from elsewhere.
comment_by_fact-checker: The relevant finding is: “It is extremely likely that more than half of the observed increase in global average surface temperature from 1951 to 2010 was caused by the anthropogenic increase in greenhouse gas concentrations and other anthropogenic forcings together. The best estimate of the human-induced contribution to warming is similar to the observed warming over this period.” (My italicisation.) The reporter has picked up a commonly used trick to quote just the first sentence of the key finding. The full finding clearly falsifies the assertion here. The best estimate remains that all the warming seen since the mid-20th Century is down to us.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Human activity is the main cause of global warming, but natural factors also play a role.

FACT1: Human activity, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, is the primary cause of global warming. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) estimates that human emissions are responsible for more than half of the observed increase in global average temperature from 1951 to 2010.

MYTH: The rise in global temperature is solely caused by human activity.

FALLACY: This myth is an oversimplification of the complex factors that contribute to global warming. While human activity is the primary cause, natural factors such as volcanic activity and solar radiation also play a role in the Earth's temperature. However, the impact of these natural factors is much smaller than that of human activity.

FACT2: It is important to recognize the significant impact of human activity on global warming and take action to reduce our carbon emissions. Let's work towards a sustainable future by making conscious choices in our daily lives and supporting policies that prioritize the health of our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “For example, Canadian polar bear biologist Ian Stirling learned in the 1970s that spring sea ice in the southern Beaufort Sea periodically gets so thick that seals depart, depriving local polar bears of their prey and causing their numbers to plummet. But that fact, documented in more than a dozen scientific papers, is not discussed today as part of polar bear ecology.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Sea ice conditions are well document to be in steep decline in the southern Beaufort Sea. This polar bear population has declined 25-50% and the loss is related to sea ice loss. There are many papers that address this issue extensively. Heavy sea ice conditions are largely a past issue for ringed seals. It is loss of sea ice habitat as a whole that is negatively affecting ringed seals and thus polar bears. Polar bears have a Goldilocks relationship with sea ice: not too much, not too little, it has to be just right. Dr. Crockford is playing the “too much” sea ice issue to its extreme and ignores the too little aspect altogether. These two papers1,2 are core but there are many more addressing sea ice loss in the Beaufort and the effects on polar bears. 1- Bromaghin et al (2015) Polar bear population dynamics in the southern Beaufort Sea during a period of sea ice decline, Ecological Applications 2- Hunter et al (2010) Climate change threatens polar bear populations: a stochastic demographic analysis, Ecology
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Thick Spring Sea Ice Affects Polar Bear Prey and Population
FACT1: Thick spring sea ice in the southern Beaufort Sea can cause seals to depart, depriving polar bears of their prey and causing their numbers to plummet. This has been documented in more than a dozen scientific papers.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Understanding the impact of thick spring sea ice on polar bear prey and population is important for conservation efforts. Let's continue to support scientific research and use evidence-based information to inform policy decisions.

fact_checked_segment: “We simply cannot afford an agreement that puts thousands of Americans out of work[…]”
comment_by_fact-checker: See above for why it is misleading to say that Americans would be put out of work. Some Americans would be put out of work, while new jobs would open up for others. On net, most evidence suggests that there would be job growth, rather than a decline in jobs.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Economic Impact of Climate Agreements
FACT1: Climate agreements can have both positive and negative economic impacts. While some industries may experience job losses, others may see job gains as the economy shifts towards cleaner energy sources. Additionally, the costs of inaction on climate change can be much greater than the costs of taking action.
MYTH: Climate agreements will put thousands of Americans out of work.
FALLACY: This statement uses a false dilemma fallacy, presenting only two options (climate agreements or job losses) when in reality there are other possibilities, such as job gains in clean energy industries. It also ignores the potential economic benefits of addressing climate change, such as increased innovation and cost savings in the long term.
FACT2: Let's not overlook the potential economic benefits of climate agreements, such as job growth in clean energy industries and cost savings in the long term. It is important to consider the full economic picture when evaluating the impact of climate agreements.

fact_checked_segment: “In pushing too hard for the case that global warming is universally bad for everything, the administration’s report undermines the reasonable case for climate action.”
comment_by_fact-checker: As seems to always be the case with Lomborg (cf his previous WSJ’s article reviewed by Climate Feedback), he picks up a few studies that support his position. Note, first, that the report’s claim about projected heat-related deaths outweighing cold ones applies to the US: different regions might have different responses… Second, when reviewing the literature on the topic, the IPCC report indicates (WGIIAR5-Chap11, p.721): “it is not clear whether winter mortality will decrease in a warmer, but more variable, climate (Kinney et al., 2012; Ebi and Mills, 2013). Overall, we conclude that the increase in heat-related mortality by mid-century will outweigh gains due to fewer cold periods, especially in tropical developing countries with limited adaptive capacities and large exposed populations” So the US report does not appear wildly at odds with the literature on the topic, or to be “pushing too hard”. Also, it does not say that warming is universally bad, just that the bad outweighs the good on this particular topic.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: Climate action is still necessary despite potential benefits of global warming

FACT1: While some aspects of global warming may have potential benefits, such as longer growing seasons in some regions, the negative impacts far outweigh any positives. These negative impacts include rising sea levels, more frequent and severe natural disasters, and harm to human health and the economy.

MYTH: The administration's report suggests that global warming may have some benefits and therefore undermines the case for climate action.
