FALLACY: This argument is a false dichotomy, presenting the idea that either global warming is universally bad or it is not a problem at all. In reality, while there may be some potential benefits, the negative impacts of global warming are significant and require action to mitigate.

FACT2: It is important to acknowledge the potential benefits of global warming, but this should not be used as an excuse to ignore the urgent need for climate action. Let's not let the potential benefits distract us from the very real and pressing need to address the negative impacts of global warming.

fact_checked_segment: “In responding to the IPCC report, our message as scientists is simple:
comment_by_fact-checker: This might give the impression that the authors of this statement are separated from the IPCC community. It’s more complicated than that: some of the authors here are also IPCC contributors. They may have felt, however, that not enough emphasis was placed in the latest IPCC discussions and report on the role of forest protection and restoration as a mitigation option to climate change. So it’s more a matter of nuances than opposition.
label: false authority
debunk:
FACT1: The IPCC report is a comprehensive assessment of the current state of climate science, based on the work of thousands of scientists from around the world.

MYTH: None mentioned.

FALLACY: None mentioned.

FACT2: As individuals, we can take action to reduce our carbon footprint and advocate for policies that address climate change. Let's work together to protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “Scientists just discovered a massive, heretofore unknown, source of nitrogen”
comment_by_fact-checker: That the rocks in the crust of the planet contain nitrogen has been known for in excess of a century.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: New Source of Nitrogen Discovered
FACT1: Scientists have discovered a new source of nitrogen that was previously unknown. The source is a type of rock called serpentinite, which can release nitrogen when exposed to water and carbon dioxide. This discovery could have important implications for our understanding of the nitrogen cycle and its role in the environment.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: None.

FACT2: Let's continue to support scientific research and exploration, as it can lead to important discoveries that can benefit our understanding of the world around us.

fact_checked_segment: “Pollard and DeConto are the first to admit that their model is still crude, but its results have pushed the entire scientific community into emergency mode.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Many people in the glaciology community are working to improve computer models of ice sheet change. I actually think that many scientists already felt that humans should be in “emergency mode”. For reference, consider the “World Scientists’ Warning to Humanity”, first written in 1992 and reprised this year. But I agree that the possibility of marine ice-cliff instability raised another alarm bell.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Antarctic Ice Sheet Melting is a Scientific Emergency
FACT1: The melting of the Antarctic ice sheet is a scientific emergency that requires immediate attention. The melting of the ice sheet is causing sea levels to rise, which poses a significant threat to coastal communities around the world. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is important for individuals, governments, and businesses to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change. Let's work together to protect our planet and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “Global warming and climate change, even if it is 100% caused by humans, is so slow that it cannot be observed by anyone in their lifetime. Hurricanes, tornadoes, floods, droughts and other natural disasters have yet to show any obvious long-term change.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement is far too broad to be supportable, and is misleading in a few ways. Among the many aspects and impacts of climate change, some are evolving slowly and others more quickly (quickly enough to be detected within a 70-year human lifetime). There is a very important difference between saying “there has been no change”, versus “the data records are not long enough to formally detect a change”. For example, our present records of hurricanes do in fact show very large and statistically significant increasing trends in a number of measures since the 1800s. But we also know that the older data are of a lower quality than modern data, so we are uncertain of what part of the trends are due to the data issues and what part may be due to human influences. The scientific community has established a very strict set of rules for formally establishing whether or not a trend has been detected, and we constrain our statements within this rigid framework. The author’s statement here violates those rules and is unsupportable
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change is Happening Faster Than You Think
FACT1: Climate change is happening at an alarming rate, and its effects are already being felt around the world. The Earth's temperature has already risen by 1 degree Celsius since pre-industrial times, and this has led to more frequent and severe heatwaves, droughts, wildfires, and extreme weather events. The Arctic sea ice is melting at an unprecedented rate, and sea levels are rising faster than previously predicted. 
MYTH: Climate change is too slow to be observed in a lifetime, and natural disasters have not shown any long-term change.
FALLACY: This myth is based on the false assumption that climate change is a slow and gradual process that will only affect future generations. In reality, climate change is already happening at an alarming rate, and its effects are being felt around the world. The increase in global temperature has led to more frequent and severe natural disasters, such as hurricanes, tornadoes, floods, and droughts. These events are becoming more intense and more frequent, and they are causing significant damage to communities and ecosystems around the world. 
FACT2: It is important to recognize that climate change is happening now, and that we need to take action to address it. We can all play a role in reducing our carbon footprint and advocating for policies that will help to mitigate the effects of climate change. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends, and instead work together to create a more sustainable future for ourselves and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: People who study the impacts of global warming have found that if ECS is low — say, less than two — then the impacts of global warming on the economy will be mostly small and, in many places, mildly beneficial.
comment_by_fact-checker: This is not necessarily true, as the amount of future warming depends as much on future emissions trajectories as it does on climate sensitivity. A world with 1000 ppm CO2 and an equilibrium climate sensitivity of 2 would still be quite unpleasant.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
FACT1: The impacts of global warming on the economy depend on the value of Equilibrium Climate Sensitivity (ECS). If ECS is low, less than two, then the impacts of global warming on the economy will be mostly small and, in many places, mildly beneficial.

MYTH: There is no relationship between the value of Equilibrium Climate Sensitivity (ECS) and the impacts of global warming on the economy.

FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, as it only considers the impacts of global warming on the economy when ECS is low. It ignores the fact that if ECS is high, the impacts of global warming on the economy will be severe and potentially catastrophic. This fallacy misleads people into thinking that global warming is not a significant threat to the economy.

FACT2: It is important to consider the full range of possible ECS values when assessing the impacts of global warming on the economy. Let's not ignore the potential for severe and catastrophic impacts and take action to mitigate the effects of global warming.

fact_checked_segment: “While France and other G7 countries lamented the U.S. exit from the Paris climate accord, America’s air is already cleaner than that of any other country in the G7, except Canada with its scant population.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The Breitbart author must know that the Paris Agreement is about climate change, not about air quality.
label: red herring
debunk:
FACT1: The United States has made progress in reducing air pollution, with some of the cleanest air among G7 countries, second only to Canada.
MYTH: The myth is that the United States does not need to participate in the Paris climate accord because its air is already cleaner than any other G7 country except Canada.
FALLACY: This statement uses a false equivalence fallacy by equating air pollution with greenhouse gas emissions. While the US has made progress in reducing air pollution, it is still one of the largest emitters of greenhouse gases in the world. The Paris climate accord aims to address this issue by setting targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
FACT2: While the US has made progress in reducing air pollution, it still needs to take action to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions. Let's not use progress in one area as an excuse to ignore the need for action in another.

fact_checked_segment: since 1979 to the most reliable observations — those made by satellites and weather balloons over the vast tropics.
comment_by_fact-checker: These are hardly the most reliable measurements. For a description of the tortured history of the satellite measurements, see page 8 of this document. In fact, the surface temperature record is much more reliable and the models agree well with it. It’s as likely that unresolved errors in the satellite record are responsible for the errors as problems in the models.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: The Most Reliable Observations of Global Temperature Trends
FACT1: Satellites and weather balloons provide the most reliable observations of global temperature trends since 1979. These observations cover the vast tropics and are not subject to the biases and errors that can occur with surface temperature measurements.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's trust the most reliable observations of global temperature trends and use them to inform our understanding of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The Northern Hemisphere jet stream […] flow is stronger when that temperature difference is large. But when the Arctic warms up faster than the equator does […] the jet stream’s flow can become weakened and elongated. That’s when you can get the resultant weather extremes.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Very nice description for the lay-audience.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Arctic Warming Weakens the Jet Stream, Causing Extreme Weather
FACT1: The jet stream is a high-altitude, fast-moving air current that circles the Earth from west to east. It separates cold air in the north from warm air in the south. The jet stream's flow is stronger when the temperature difference between the Arctic and the equator is large. 
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: However, when the Arctic warms up faster than the equator, the jet stream's flow can become weakened and elongated. This can cause extreme weather events such as heatwaves, droughts, and cold snaps. It is important to understand the impact of Arctic warming on the jet stream to better predict and prepare for extreme weather events.

fact_checked_segment: At one point, Smith showed a slide of two charts that he said demonstrated how the rate of sea-level rise does not equal the sharp spike in the consumption of fossil fuels.
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement is blatantly false: sea-level rise in the 20th century is faster than any time during the last 3000 years[1], while the present-day rate is already three times faster than the 20th-century rate[2]. [1] Kopp et al (2016). Temperature-Driven Global Sea-Level Variability in the Common Era, PNAS [2] Dangendorf et al (2017) Reassessment of 20th Century Global Mean Sea Level Rise, PNAS
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Sea-level rise is not caused by fossil fuel consumption alone
FACT1: While fossil fuel consumption is a significant contributor to climate change, it is not the only factor that affects sea-level rise. Other factors such as melting glaciers and thermal expansion of seawater also play a role in sea-level rise.
MYTH: Fossil fuel consumption is the sole cause of sea-level rise.
FALLACY: This myth is an oversimplification of the complex factors that contribute to sea-level rise. While fossil fuel consumption is a significant contributor, it is not the only factor. Ignoring other factors can lead to a misunderstanding of the causes and potential solutions to sea-level rise.
FACT2: Let's not oversimplify the complex issue of sea-level rise. It is important to consider all the factors that contribute to it in order to develop effective solutions.

fact_checked_segment: “a constant swarm of out-of-control typhoons and tornadoes and floods and droughts”
comment_by_fact-checker: Not to nitpick—we don’t really know what a +6 °C world would look like in detail—but the connection between tornadoes and warming is unclear, at least in the observable record. Daniel Swain, Researcher, UCLA, and Research Fellow, National Center for Atmospheric Research: While there is still some uncertainty regarding the response of tropical cyclones (i.e. typhoons and hurricanes) to global warming, there is now evidence that frequency in many ocean basins may actually decrease, but maximum intensity will likely increase. There is indeed evidence that the frequency and intensity of floods/droughts is increasing over much of the globe*, and will continue to do so as the climate warms. This is not necessarily true universally–there will still be quite a bit of spatial and temporal diversity in the response of precipitation extremes to global warming, even in a six-degree-warmer world. But in general, it’s true that there will be dramatically more flood and drought events on a global basis with multiple degrees of warming. Diffenbaugh et al (2017) Quantifying the influence of global warming on unprecedented extreme climate events, PNAS
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding Extreme Weather Events
FACT1: Extreme weather events such as typhoons, tornadoes, floods, and droughts are natural occurrences that have been happening for millions of years. These events are not constant, but rather occur sporadically and are influenced by various factors such as climate patterns, ocean currents, and atmospheric conditions. 
MYTH: Extreme weather events are constantly occurring and are out of control. 
FALLACY: This myth is an example of exaggeration and catastrophizing, which involves presenting a situation as much worse than it actually is. It also uses emotional language to create fear and panic, which can lead to irrational decision-making. Extreme weather events are not out of control, but rather are influenced by natural and human factors that can be studied and managed. 
FACT2: Understanding the causes and patterns of extreme weather events can help us prepare and adapt to their impacts. Let's not spread misinformation and fear, but instead educate ourselves on the science behind these events and take action to mitigate their effects.

fact_checked_segment: “El Niño is now waning, but the extremes continue to be seen, with temperature records tumbling in the US in February and polar heatwaves pushing ice cover to new lows.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is especially striking in the Antarctic where sea ice extent has been increasing gradually for many years. We are now seeing historic lows in sea ice extent.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: El Niño and Temperature Records
FACT1: El Niño is a natural climate pattern that occurs every few years, characterized by warmer than average sea surface temperatures in the Pacific Ocean. It can cause extreme weather events around the world, including heatwaves, droughts, and floods. 
MYTH: El Niño is a myth or a hoax.
FALLACY: The myth that El Niño is a hoax is based on a misunderstanding of what El Niño is and how it affects the climate. It is a real phenomenon that has been observed and studied by scientists for decades. While El Niño is a natural event, human activities such as burning fossil fuels can exacerbate its effects and make extreme weather events more frequent and severe.
FACT2: Let's not dismiss the reality of El Niño and its impact on the climate. It is important to understand and prepare for the potential consequences of this natural phenomenon, as well as the ways in which human activities can contribute to its effects.

fact_checked_segment: The latest U.N. science compendium asserts that the latter half-degree is at least half manmade.
comment_by_fact-checker: The recent US National Climate Assessment1 finds that it is extremely likely that more than half of the temperature rise since 1951 is human-caused, and the likely human contribution is 93% to 123%. More than 100% means that the human caused warming would be higher, except that other unrelated changes caused cooling that partially offset the warming. 1- Fourth National Climate Assessment (2018) Part 1, Chapter 3
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The Latest U.N. Science Compendium on Climate Change
FACT1: The latest U.N. science compendium on climate change asserts that at least half of the latter half-degree of global warming is caused by human activities. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: Deadly heat conditions across West Africa persist for over 100 days a year
comment_by_fact-checker: The deadly heat projections (this, and the one from the previous paragraph) come from Mora et al (2017)1. It should be clarified that “deadly heat” here means heat and humidity beyond a two-dimension threshold where at least one person in the region subject to that heat and humidity dies (i.e., not everyone instantly dies). That said, in my opinion, the projections in Mora et al are conservative and the methods of Mora et al are sound. I did not check the claims in this report against Mora et al but I have no reason to think they are in error. 1- Mora et al (2017) Global risk of deadly heat, Nature Climate Change
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: West Africa experiences deadly heat conditions for over 100 days a year

FACT1: West Africa is experiencing deadly heat conditions for over 100 days a year, according to a new study. The region is particularly vulnerable to heatwaves due to its high levels of humidity, which can make it difficult for the body to cool down. This can lead to heat exhaustion, heatstroke, and even death.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: The deadly heat conditions in West Africa are a result of climate change, which is caused by human activities such as burning fossil fuels. The study found that the region is experiencing more frequent and intense heatwaves, which are likely to continue unless action is taken to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

FACT2: Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and support policies that address climate change. This can include reducing our energy consumption, using public transportation, and supporting renewable energy sources. We can also advocate for policies that prioritize climate action and support vulnerable communities that are most affected by the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Federal scientists have documented a sharp jump in this nuisance flooding — often called ‘sunny-day flooding’ — along both the East Coast and the Gulf Coast in recent years.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a tricky one. Nuisance flooding on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts is the result of relative sea-level rise. Relative sea-level rise has a variety of components that give the rise a spatial signature. For example along the mid US Atlantic coast one-third of the rise is due to glacial isostatic adjustment with the remainder dominated by climatically driven sea-level rise. But in the Mississippi Delta the dominant driving force is subsidence. However, in the coming century these components will decrease in importance relative to climatically driven sea-level rise.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Nuisance Flooding on the Rise
FACT1: Nuisance flooding, also known as "sunny-day flooding," has increased significantly along the East Coast and Gulf Coast in recent years, according to federal scientists. This type of flooding occurs during high tides and heavy rainfall, causing water to overflow onto streets and into buildings. It can cause property damage, disrupt transportation, and impact public health.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's take action to address the root causes of sea-level rise and climate change to prevent further increases in nuisance flooding. This includes reducing greenhouse gas emissions, investing in renewable energy, and implementing coastal adaptation measures.

fact_checked_segment: “Without human intervention, the concentration of CO2 has climbed as high as 7,000 parts per million (ppm) in prior eras, whereas at present the concentration is just over 400 ppm.”
comment_by_fact-checker: But those worlds were rather different to those that humans inhabit. They had things like palm trees and crocodiles in the Arctic, and arguably land in the Tropics was completely sterile because of the heat.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
FACT1: CO2 concentrations have been much higher in the past, but this does not mean that current levels are safe or that human activity is not contributing to the increase.

MYTH: The fact that CO2 concentrations have been higher in the past means that current levels are not a cause for concern.

FALLACY: This is a false equivalence fallacy, which assumes that because CO2 concentrations have been higher in the past, current levels are not a problem. However, this ignores the fact that current levels are increasing rapidly due to human activity, and that this increase is causing significant changes to the climate.

FACT2: It is important to recognize that while CO2 concentrations have been higher in the past, current levels are still a cause for concern and are largely the result of human activity. Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Since 1880, NOAA’s records show only one other instance when global temperature records were set three years in a row: in 1939, 1940 and 1941.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The start of the second world war also changed the composition of the fleet making the sea surface temperature observations and with it the measurement methods used changed quickly. Climatologists have made adjustments to account for this problem, but it is well possible that this was incomplete. Uncertainties in this period are larger than in the decades before and after. Thus it could well be that these three records in a row are due to remaining problems. I would not have emphasised it.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: Consistent Global Temperature Records
FACT1: Global temperature records have been consistently broken in recent years. In fact, since 1880, there has only been one other instance where global temperature records were set three years in a row.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: Let's acknowledge the reality of climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: [data] show only slight warming, mostly at night and in winter
comment_by_fact-checker: This is something that is also simulated in climate models (larger warming in the minimum daily temperature than the maximum daily temperature). The article the authors reference tends to focus on smaller spatial scales where natural variability plays a larger role. On a global scale, the seasonal asymmetry in warming rates appears to be small. Taking global GISTEMP trends over 1950 – 2018 the range of trends for all seasons is 0.13 – 0.15 degrees C per decade. Lewis and Karoly (2013) Evaluation of Historical Diurnal Temperature Range Trends in CMIP5 Models, Journal of Climate
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: Temperature data shows variations in warming patterns
FACT1: Temperature data shows that warming patterns vary across different times of day and seasons, with some areas experiencing more warming at night and in winter than during the day and in summer.
MYTH: Temperature data shows only slight warming.
FALLACY: The myth is an example of cherry-picking, where only a small subset of data is selected to support a particular argument while ignoring the larger trend. By focusing on specific times of day and seasons, the myth misleads by ignoring the overall trend of global warming.
FACT2: It is important to consider the larger trend of global warming, which is supported by a vast body of scientific evidence. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and instead focus on the facts and the need for action to address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “The human contribution can be up to 30 percent or so of the total rainfall coming out of the storm”
comment_by_fact-checker: A reference here would have been useful as it’s unclear exactly where this number comes from. We know that human-caused climate change can increase both the moisture content of the atmosphere, as described by the Clausius-Clapeyron relation, and the energetics of the storm, as there is increased latent heat release. Both of these climate change-influenced drivers have the potential to cause increased precipitation.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: Human activities can affect rainfall from storms
FACT1: Human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation can affect the amount of rainfall that comes out of a storm. This is because these activities can alter the temperature and moisture levels in the atmosphere, which can impact the formation and behavior of storms. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: The statement is generally true, but it is important to note that the extent of human influence on rainfall from storms can vary depending on a number of factors, including the location and intensity of the storm, as well as the specific human activities in question. Additionally, while human activities can contribute to changes in rainfall patterns, they are not the only factor at play. 
FACT2: Let's be mindful of the impact our actions have on the environment and take steps to reduce our carbon footprint and protect natural ecosystems.

fact_checked_segment: A “Hothouse Earth” scenario plays out that sees Earth’s temperatures doomed to rise by a further 1°C (1.8°F) even if we stopped emissions immediately.
comment_by_fact-checker: This word choice perhaps reveals a bias on the part of the author of the article. A temperature can’t be doomed. And while I certainly do not encourage false optimism, assuming that humanity is doomed is lazy and counterproductive.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: The Inevitable Temperature Rise of Earth
FACT1: Earth's temperature is set to rise by 1°C (1.8°F) even if we stopped emissions immediately. This is due to the "hothouse earth" scenario, where feedback loops in the climate system cause temperatures to continue to rise even if we reduce emissions to zero.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: The "hothouse earth" scenario is a result of positive feedback loops in the climate system, such as melting permafrost releasing methane, which causes further warming. This means that even if we stopped emissions immediately, the warming would continue due to these feedback loops. This fallacy is the belief that stopping emissions immediately would prevent any further warming.
FACT2: Let's continue to reduce emissions and work towards a sustainable future to prevent further temperature rise.

fact_checked_segment: “If our climate conversation managed to include the good along with the bad, we would have a much better understanding of our options.”
comment_by_fact-checker: True, but the author should set the example and have a balanced view here, showing the bad along with the good. Something he dramatically failed to do.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The Importance of a Balanced Climate Conversation
FACT1: A balanced climate conversation should include both positive and negative aspects of climate change. This approach can help people better understand the situation and the available options for addressing it. 
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: This statement highlights the importance of a balanced conversation about climate change. When people only hear about the negative impacts of climate change, they may feel overwhelmed and helpless, leading to inaction. On the other hand, focusing only on the positive aspects of climate change can lead to complacency and a lack of urgency to address the issue. A balanced conversation that includes both positive and negative aspects can help people understand the complexity of the issue and the need for action. 
FACT2: Let's strive for a balanced conversation about climate change that includes both the good and the bad, so that we can make informed decisions and take action to address this critical issue.

fact_checked_segment: “In Albany, New York, the high temperature of 74 degrees on Thursday was the warmest temperature on record for any day during the months of December, January and February.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Seasonal records like this are even more impressive and much more robust as they are composed of much larger sample sizes than the individual day’s values.
label: hasty generalization
debunk:
TITLE: Record High Temperature in Albany, New York
FACT1: On Thursday, the temperature in Albany, New York reached a high of 74 degrees, which is the warmest temperature ever recorded during the months of December, January, and February.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: While a single weather event cannot be attributed to climate change, the increasing frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, such as heat waves, are consistent with the scientific understanding of climate change. Let's continue to educate ourselves on the science of climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: “Policy makers who want to help the residents of the Marshall Islands today should look at improving the islands’ resilience”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a classic technique in Lomborg’s articles: he focuses on one small aspect of climate change – here the Marshall Islands, other times maybe polar bears or heat-related human deaths – that i) he passes off as the main concern about global warming, and ii) that he can provide some seemingly contradictory information about… All the other consequences of global warming are conveniently set aside… Red herring.
label: red herring
debunk:
FACT1: The Marshall Islands are a low-lying island nation in the Pacific Ocean that is particularly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, including sea level rise, storm surges, and ocean acidification. 

MYTH: Climate change is not a pressing issue for the Marshall Islands, and policy makers should focus on other priorities. 

FALLACY: This argument is a false dichotomy, suggesting that policy makers must choose between addressing climate change and addressing other issues. In reality, climate change is a pressing issue that exacerbates many other challenges faced by the Marshall Islands, including food and water security, public health, and economic development. Improving the islands' resilience to climate change is therefore a critical priority for policy makers. 

FACT2: By investing in renewable energy, improving infrastructure, and supporting local communities, policy makers can help the Marshall Islands adapt to the impacts of climate change and build a more sustainable future. Let's prioritize the needs of vulnerable communities and take action to address the urgent threat of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “In other words, we have, trapped in Arctic permafrost, twice as much carbon as is currently wrecking the atmosphere of the planet, all of it scheduled to be released at a date that keeps getting moved up, partially in the form of a gas that multiplies its warming power 86 times over.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Most work on studying the dynamics of greenhouse gas balance in degrading permafrost systems, both as based on field measurements and as represented in ecosystem models for making climate feedback projections, seems to point to methane release being a relatively minor pathway for permafrost carbon to be released to the atmosphere, at least for terrestrial permafrost sources (which comprise most of the carbon mentioned here). It is true that terrestrial permafrost systems emit methane, but most of that methane is from recently photosynthesized carbon rather than older permafrost sources, and most of the carbon released from the older permafrost sources is released as either carbon dioxide or dissolved organic carbon rather than methane. So, while uncertainty on this issue remains high, and permafrost thaw is a potentially strong feedback process, this feedback seems likely to be dominated by carbon dioxide rather than methane. A specifically misleading thing about these numbers, which are a metric called “global warming potential”, is that their units are based on the mass of the gas. Since the question here is whether a given atom of carbon will be emitted to the atmosphere contained within either a molecule of carbon dioxide or a molecule of methane, you have to take into account the fact that the molecule of carbon dioxide is much heavier, because of the two oxygen atoms it picks up in the transformation to that gas, versus the four hydrogen atoms it would acquire in becoming methane. What this means in practice is that you have to divide the global warming potential by the ratio of the weight of the molecules, which is 44/16 or 2.75. So strictly speaking, the 34 and 86 ought to read 12 and 31. This is a separate issue from the timescale one that others point out, and which further makes this comparison misleading.
label: cherry picking
debunk:
TITLE: The Arctic Permafrost and Carbon Trapped in it
FACT1: The Arctic permafrost contains twice as much carbon as is currently present in the Earth's atmosphere. This carbon is scheduled to be released in the future, and it includes a gas that multiplies its warming power 86 times over. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: It is crucial to take action to reduce carbon emissions and prevent the release of carbon from the Arctic permafrost. Let's work towards sustainable solutions to mitigate the effects of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “the adjusted data”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is surprising that, despite adjusted data being the crux of the arguments made here and in the study referred to, the author never explains why one may need to adjust measurements made on the ground or by satellites. There has been significant media coverage recently of some of the adjustments relating to temperature measurements made by satellites. Simply from a practical standpoint, it is beneficial to consider what is involved in sustaining the orbit of a satellite. Once put into orbit, a satellite will slowly “decay” away from its intended orbit as it is pulled nearer to Earth by gravity and other effects. Unless it has its own propulsion to correct for this, it will eventually be pulled out of orbit. This decay affects the exact time of day during which the satellite repeats measurements over one location. For example, from 1995 to 2005, the time of day that a NOAA satellite (NOAA-14) passed over the equator changed by more than 6 hours. The temperature in Quito at 12pm local time versus 6pm local time is quite different, so the satellite measurement must be corrected for this and other effects. More details from this excellent article by Zeke Hausfather.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding Adjusted Data in Science
FACT1: Adjusted data is a common practice in scientific research to correct for errors and biases in raw data. Scientists use statistical methods to adjust data to account for factors such as changes in measurement techniques, instrument calibration, and environmental conditions. Adjusted data is often more accurate and reliable than raw data.
MYTH: Adjusted data is manipulated to fit a predetermined conclusion.
FALLACY: The fallacy underlying this myth is cherry-picking. Critics of adjusted data often focus on specific adjustments that they claim are unjustified or biased, while ignoring the overall scientific consensus that adjusted data is necessary for accurate research. This cherry-picking misleads people into thinking that adjusted data is unreliable.
FACT2: Adjusted data is a necessary and common practice in scientific research. It helps to correct for errors and biases in raw data, making it more accurate and reliable. Let's trust the scientific process and the experts who use adjusted data to advance our understanding of the world.

fact_checked_segment: “Moreover, its warming impact decreases sharply after the first 20 or 30 ppm. Adding more CO2 molecules to the atmosphere is like painting over a red wall with white paint — the first coat does most of the work of concealing the red. A second coat of paint has much less of an effect, while adding a third or fourth coat has almost no impact at all.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The effects of CO2 do not decrease sharply after the first 20 or 30 ppm. The radiative effects of CO2 are logarithmic, so they increase slightly less the higher CO2 gets but they don’t decrease sharply.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Diminishing Returns of CO2
FACT1: CO2 has a diminishing warming effect as its concentration increases in the atmosphere. The first 20-30 ppm of CO2 has the most significant impact on warming, while additional CO2 has a decreasing effect. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: This statement is an accurate representation of the scientific understanding of the warming effect of CO2. However, it is important to note that while the warming effect of CO2 may diminish with increasing concentrations, it does not disappear entirely. Even small increases in CO2 concentrations can have significant impacts on the climate. 
FACT2: It is crucial to continue reducing greenhouse gas emissions to limit the warming of the planet and avoid the worst impacts of climate change. Let's take action to reduce our carbon footprint and transition to cleaner energy sources.

fact_checked_segment: it still has not been shown that human emissions of carbon dioxide drive ­global warming.
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement is wrong. CO2 is a greenhouse gas and human emissions are increasing its concentration. Human emissions therefore drive global warming1. This can be measured, it can be explained theoretically and it can be seen in the past evolution of temperatures and CO2. 1- Stips et al (2016) On the causal structure between CO2 and global temperature, Scientific Reports
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Role of Human Emissions in Global Warming
FACT1: Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas that traps heat in the Earth's atmosphere, contributing to global warming. Human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, deforestation, and industrial processes, have significantly increased the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
MYTH: It still has not been shown that human emissions of carbon dioxide drive global warming.
FALLACY: This statement is a form of denialism, which ignores the overwhelming scientific evidence that human activities are the primary cause of global warming. It is a false equivalence fallacy, as it implies that there is an equal amount of evidence supporting both sides of the argument, when in fact, the scientific consensus is clear. This myth also relies on cherry-picking data and ignoring the vast body of research that supports the link between human emissions and global warming.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. The scientific consensus is clear: human emissions of carbon dioxide are the primary cause of global warming. It is important to take action to reduce our carbon footprint and mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “Not everyone is convinced that the evidence is in that climate change is responsible for extreme swings between drought and deluge.”
comment_by_fact-checker: There is a considerable and growing body of scientific evidence (see above references) demonstrating that California will likely experience increasingly large swings between extreme wet and extreme dry conditions. The evidence that climate change has already caused such an increase is somewhat less strong—mainly because there are relatively few extreme events in the historical record from which to draw such conclusions. Therefore, this statement is imprecise, and may be misleading if it is intended to convey that scientists substantially disagree regarding the likely future increase in California precipitation extremes. Whether such an increase is yet detectable in the historical record is indeed uncertain; there is much greater certainty regarding the likely direction of future change.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Climate change and extreme weather events
FACT1: Climate change is causing more frequent and severe extreme weather events, such as droughts and floods. These events can have devastating impacts on communities, economies, and ecosystems.
MYTH: Not everyone is convinced that the evidence is in that climate change is responsible for extreme swings between drought and deluge.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of cherry-picking, where a selective interpretation of the evidence is used to support a particular viewpoint. While it is true that not everyone agrees on the extent of the role of climate change in extreme weather events, the overwhelming scientific consensus is that climate change is a major contributing factor. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has stated that it is "very likely" that human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, are causing climate change and increasing the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events.
FACT2: Let's not ignore the scientific consensus on climate change and its impacts on extreme weather events. It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to the changing climate to protect our planet and future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “[Gavin Schmidt:] ‘We don’t expect record years every year, but the ongoing long-term warming trend is clear.’”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a really important point, especially as 2017 is likely to not break the 2016 record. We expect year-to-year variability, so we may not break the 2016 record for a few years, but the overall trend is upwards.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Long-term warming trend is clear
FACT1: The Earth's temperature has been increasing over the past century, with the 10 warmest years on record occurring since 2005. This warming trend is supported by multiple lines of evidence, including rising sea levels, melting glaciers, and changes in plant and animal behavior.
MYTH: Global warming stopped in [insert year]
FALLACY: Cherry Picking - This myth selectively focuses on a single year or short-term trend while ignoring the long-term warming trend. It is important to look at the overall trend over a longer period of time to understand the impact of human activities on the climate.
FACT2: Let's not be misled by short-term fluctuations in temperature. Instead, let's focus on the long-term trend and take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions to mitigate the impacts of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “But the differences between NOAA and NASA aren’t that significant, Schmidt further argued, in the context of the bigger picture. ‘Getting hung up on the exact nature of the records is interesting, and there’s lots of technical work that can be done there, but the main take-home response there is that the trends we’ve been seeing since the 1970s are continuing and have not paused in any way,’ he said.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Daniel Swain, Researcher, UCLA, and Research Fellow, National Center for Atmospheric Research: This section accurately portrays the overall context of the 2016 record, and the fact that the modest differences between datasets do not change the “big picture” conclusion that the Earth is warming and that 2016 was an extraordinary year even in that context.
label: no fallacy
debunk: NOAA and NASA have slightly different temperature records, but this does not change the overall trend of global warming. Focusing on minor differences in the data can be interesting, but it does not change the fact that the Earth's temperature has been steadily increasing since the 1970s. This is a case of the Blowfish fallacy, where a minor issue is blown out of proportion to distract from the main conclusion. Let's not get distracted by minor differences in the data and instead focus on the bigger picture of the ongoing trend of global warming.

fact_checked_segment: The idea that climate change is producing heat records across the Earth is among the most egregious manipulations of data in the absurd global warming debate.
comment_by_fact-checker: Just to be clear, the main claim of climate science is that the global average temperature is increasing. The increase of heat waves is one of the many consequences of this. The article confusingly uses the term “record” in two meanings. The term records can be used for the observations that were recorded by meteorologists over the last centuries. The term “records” is mostly used for the highest or lowest value ever seen. In an article about the highest and lowest temperatures, it is best to avoid using the term records for the recorded data. The article also confusingly keeps on jumping between claims about local records in daily mean temperatures and claims about the long-term global mean temperature. Local temperatures are by their nature more variable than global average temperatures, daily temperatures are by their nature more variable than long-term average temperatures, records are by their nature more random than averages. With all the extra variability in the local daily records the authors can easily cherry pick a few data points that fit their narrative. What would make their case stronger would be if they actually analysed all the data, engaged with the existing scientific literature and made their own contribution to our scientific understanding by publishing a scientific paper. The cherry picking exercise in this Western Journal article does not contribute to our scientific understanding of the world.
label: vagueness
debunk:
TITLE: Debunking the Manipulation of Data in the Climate Change Debate
FACT1: Climate change is causing an increase in heat records across the Earth, with many regions experiencing record-breaking temperatures in recent years. This is supported by scientific evidence and data from multiple sources, including NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).
MYTH: The idea that climate change is producing heat records across the Earth is a manipulation of data in the global warming debate.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of the "conspiracy theory" fallacy, which proposes that a secret plan exists to implement a nefarious scheme such as hiding the truth. It also uses the "false equivalence" fallacy by claiming that the manipulation of data is equivalent to the scientific consensus on climate change. The myth misleads by ignoring the overwhelming evidence that supports the link between climate change and heat records.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation to our friends. Instead, let's rely on scientific evidence and data to understand the impact of climate change on our planet.

fact_checked_segment: “Any reasonable person can recognize both positives and negatives among the policy proposals of both Tories and Labour.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Lomborg seems to imply here that the assessment of the impacts of climate change should follow the same “balance” with which we consider political ideas. But the assessment of the global impacts of climate change is something scientific in nature. It’s not a matter of values or preferences, like political leaning. All things considered, it just so happens, as the IPCC points out, that the global impacts of climate change appear negative.
label: strawman
debunk:
FACT1: Political policies are complex and can have both positive and negative aspects. It is possible to recognize the strengths and weaknesses of policies from different political parties.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: This statement is not a fallacy, but it is important to recognize that political policies are often presented in a polarized way, with one party being portrayed as entirely good and the other as entirely bad. This can lead to a lack of critical thinking and a failure to recognize the nuances of different policies.

FACT2: It is important to evaluate policies based on their individual merits rather than blindly supporting or opposing a particular political party. Let's strive to engage in thoughtful and nuanced discussions about political policies.

fact_checked_segment: “The IPCC reports also don’t fully account for the albedo effect (less ice means less reflected and more absorbed sunlight, hence more warming); more cloud cover (which traps heat); or the dieback of forests and other flora (which extract carbon from the atmosphere). Each of these promises to accelerate warming”
comment_by_fact-checker: “More cloud cover (which traps heat)” is a gross over-simplification regarding the role of clouds as a tuning knob for Earth’s climate. While it is true that clouds can act as a blanket and trap more heat, they also serve to reflect sunlight (see the prior sentence regarding the albedo effect). Which cloud effect ultimately wins out has to do with the optical thickness of the cloud (how reflective it is) and (as a rough approximation), the cloud height. As a quick rule: Higher clouds will act better as a blanket since they are both colder (and therefore radiate less energy to space) and typically optically thin. Conversely, lower clouds act more as a reflector since they are warmer and optically thick. The IPCC report does generally show a net positive cloud feedback, indicating global cloud feedbacks will lead to additional warming, but cloud feedbacks are extremely complicated and highly uncertain.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: IPCC Reports and Climate Change

FACT1: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is a scientific body established by the United Nations to provide policymakers with regular assessments of the scientific basis of climate change, its impacts, and future risks. The IPCC reports are based on the best available scientific evidence and are subject to rigorous review and scrutiny by experts from around the world.

MYTH: The IPCC reports do not fully account for the albedo effect, more cloud cover, or the dieback of forests and other flora, which will accelerate warming.

FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, where a few factors are highlighted while ignoring the many other factors that are considered in the IPCC reports. The IPCC reports do take into account the albedo effect, cloud cover, and the role of forests and other flora in carbon sequestration. However, the exact impact of these factors on climate change is complex and uncertain, and the IPCC reports reflect this uncertainty.

FACT2: The IPCC reports are an important source of information for policymakers and the public to understand the science of climate change and its impacts. It is important to rely on credible sources of information and to avoid cherry-picking or misrepresenting scientific evidence. Let's continue to educate ourselves on the science of climate change and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: “Some experts, such as UN climate scientist Dr. Indur Goklany, have defended rising CO2 levels as a good thing for humanity. Goklany has argued that the rising level of carbon dioxide in the earth’s atmosphere ‘is currently net beneficial for both humanity and the biosphere generally.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Technically, there is no such thing, really, as a UN climate scientist. There are climate scientists, worldwide, working for universities or national research organizations, and who contribute to the UN’s IPCC review process when it produces its report, every 7 years or so. Dr. Goklany is listed (Wikipedia) as working for the US Department of Interior as a science and technology policy analyst. His PhD is in electrical engineering, and beyond opinion pieces, he doesn’t seem to have published in the field of climate sciences. So I am not sure why his opinion is relevant at all—it goes without saying that it goes against the assessment of most of the scientific community working on climate change issues.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: The Benefits and Drawbacks of Rising CO2 Levels
FACT1: Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas that traps heat in the Earth's atmosphere, leading to global warming. However, it also has some benefits, such as promoting plant growth and increasing crop yields.
MYTH: Rising CO2 levels are entirely beneficial for humanity and the environment.
FALLACY: This statement is an oversimplification of the complex effects of rising CO2 levels. While it is true that increased CO2 can have some benefits, such as promoting plant growth, it also has negative consequences, such as contributing to global warming and ocean acidification. Additionally, the benefits of increased plant growth may be offset by other factors, such as water availability and nutrient availability.
FACT2: It is important to consider both the benefits and drawbacks of rising CO2 levels and to take action to mitigate the negative consequences. Let's work towards reducing our carbon footprint and promoting sustainable practices to protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: Do we really believe that one bellowing fan in a crowd of 85,000 at the MCG can completely change the course of a game?
comment_by_fact-checker: Do we really believe that one player in a stadium with an audience of 85,000 can make a difference? Naturally also small concentration can matter. Many substances are, for example, poisonous at much smaller concentrations. What matters is the amount of CO2. That there are also inert molecules in the atmosphere does not change the radiative influence of CO2. It is pretty amazing that Plimer states in this same article that “Over the past 30 years, planet Earth has greened due to a slight increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide.” Suddenly it is no problem that CO2 is a trace gas.
label: false cause
debunk:
TITLE: The Power of One Fan: Fact or Fiction?
FACT1: The noise level of a single fan in a crowd of 85,000 is unlikely to significantly impact the outcome of a game. 
MYTH: The belief that one bellowing fan in a crowd of 85,000 can completely change the course of a game.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of the fallacy of oversimplification, as it reduces the outcome of a complex game to the actions of a single fan. It also ignores the fact that the outcome of a game is determined by the performance of the players and the strategies of the coaches, not the noise level of the crowd.
FACT2: Let's not underestimate the power of a supportive crowd, but it's important to recognize that the outcome of a game is determined by many factors, not just the actions of a single fan.

fact_checked_segment: “Before the end of this century, 80% of the world’s population would be wiped out.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The late Stephen Schneider, one of the giants of modern climate science, once said that in his opinion “the ‘end of the world’ and ‘good for you’ are the two lowest probability outcomes” when discussing climate change. Lovelock seems to be swapping from one extreme largely unsupported by the bulk of existing scientific evidence to the opposite. In reality, our best evidence suggests that unmitigated climate change would be very detrimental to society (and the natural world), but that we can address it through difficult concerted action. The worst potential outcomes of climate change occur in scenarios where CO2 triples relative to pre-industrial levels, and while we still have a long way to go, the actions that countries around the world committed to in Paris will help avoid some of the most disastrous outcomes.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The Misleading Prediction of Mass Extinction
FACT1: While climate change poses significant risks to human populations and ecosystems, the prediction that 80% of the world's population will be wiped out by the end of the century is not supported by scientific evidence. 
MYTH: A warning that a misleading prediction is coming: "Beware of the claim that 80% of the world's population will be wiped out." 
FALLACY: This claim is an example of a slippery slope fallacy, which suggests that taking a minor action will inevitably lead to major consequences. It also uses fear-mongering to manipulate people's emotions and distract from the real issue of climate change. 
FACT2: Let's focus on the real risks of climate change and take action to mitigate them. We can reduce our carbon footprint, support renewable energy, and advocate for policies that address climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “There was, he said, an ‘inherent bias’ in scientific journals which predisposed them to publish ‘doom and gloom stories’.”
comment_by_fact-checker: The words “inherent bias” do not appear in my article. Rather, I refer to “publication bias”. In research, an “inherent bias” is one which is inextricably tied to the core nature of the phenomenon being studied and cannot, therefore, be eliminated by increasing the sample size or choosing a different estimator. “Publication bias”, on the other hand, refers to the general (across all of science) phenomenon by which studies presenting positive results – supporting the hypothesis being tested – are more likely to be published than those reporting negative results. This sometimes creates a situation where published studies may be systematically different from unpublished studies – for example, studies showing an impact of ocean acidification might be published more easily and in higher profile journals than studies showing no impact. However, I only allude to this possibility in the introduction; I do not asses it quantitatively (something that would, in fact, be very difficult to do). Finally, the words “doom and gloom” do not appear in my introduction.
label: strawman
debunk:
TITLE: Scientific Journals and Bias
FACT1: Scientific journals are a crucial part of the scientific process, providing a platform for researchers to share their findings with the wider scientific community. They are peer-reviewed, meaning that other experts in the field assess the quality and validity of the research before it is published. 
MYTH: Scientific journals have an inherent bias towards publishing "doom and gloom stories."
FALLACY: This statement is an example of the cherry-picking fallacy, as it focuses on a small selection of articles that may have a negative tone, while ignoring the vast majority of research that is published in scientific journals. Additionally, the peer-review process is designed to ensure that research is of high quality and is not biased towards any particular outcome.
FACT2: Let's not dismiss the importance of scientific journals in advancing our understanding of the world around us. They provide a rigorous and transparent process for evaluating research, and help to ensure that scientific findings are reliable and trustworthy.

fact_checked_segment: “What we don’t hear from her is that fewer people will die from cold.”
comment_by_fact-checker: “While it’s true that cold may kill more people today than heat, Lomborg’s assertion that climate change will result in fewer overall deaths in the U.S. this century from extreme temperatures is not supported by available evidence.”
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The Benefits of Addressing Climate Change
FACT1: Addressing climate change can have numerous benefits, including reducing air pollution, improving public health, and creating new job opportunities in the renewable energy sector.
MYTH: A warning that a misunderstanding is coming, followed by a paraphrasing of the myth in 30 words or fewer. Only the myth. Don't debunk. Don't deny it yet. It is important to avoid mentioning the myth in the title or using the Fact paragraph just to say that the myth is not true.
MYTH: Addressing climate change will only have negative consequences, such as more people dying from cold.
FALLACY: This statement is an example of a false choice fallacy, as it presents two options as the only possibilities when there are other possibilities. It also uses anecdotal evidence to support a claim that is not supported by scientific evidence. While it is true that addressing climate change may lead to changes in temperature patterns, it is not accurate to claim that it will only have negative consequences. In fact, addressing climate change can have numerous benefits, including reducing air pollution, improving public health, and creating new job opportunities in the renewable energy sector.
FACT2: Addressing climate change is important for the health of our planet and future generations. Let's not spread misinformation that undermines the urgent need for action.

fact_checked_segment: In 2004, two NOAA scientists, Richard Feely and Christopher Sabine, produced a chart showing a strong correlation between rising atmospheric CO2 levels and falling oceanic pH levels. But then, just over a year ago, Mike Wallace, a hydrologist with 30 years’ experience, noticed while researching his PhD that they had omitted some key information[…] his results were surprising: there has been no reduction in oceanic pH levels in the last -century.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This statement just flies in both the face of observational facts and a basic understanding of chemistry. I would love to hear a cogent explanation of how atmospheric CO2 levels could rise over the course of a century without producing a decrease in ocean pH. Observations near Hawaii and several other open ocean environments show clear decreasing trends in ocean pH. See, for example this report from the European Environment Agency. It is one thing to challenge future projections, but rejecting well-established scientific facts is another thing entirely. Figure: Decline in pH measured at the Aloha station as part of the Hawaii Ocean time-series. Source
label: no fallacy
debunk: Ocean acidification is not a significant problem, according to some skeptics. They claim that the correlation between rising atmospheric CO2 levels and falling oceanic pH levels is not supported by evidence. This myth is based on cherry-picking data and ignoring the overwhelming scientific consensus that ocean acidification is a real and pressing problem. By focusing on a single study that contradicts the consensus, skeptics are committing the cherry-picking fallacy. They are also ignoring the fact that the vast majority of scientific research supports the idea that ocean acidification is a serious threat to marine ecosystems. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and instead trust the scientific consensus on this issue.

fact_checked_segment: CO2 is not powerful in that sense, the only thing it does in the system is make the planet greener.
comment_by_fact-checker: This may be true for certain regions in the mid-latitudes, but it presents a limited view of the Earth system. For regions experiencing drying, plant growth will be limited by the availability of water. Reafforestation at high latitudes (due to a combination of warming and less grazing) changes the albedo, which feeds back to warming the local climate. See for instance Wramneby et al (2010)1: “In the Scandinavian Mountains, reduced albedo resulting from the snow‐masking effect of forest expansion enhanced the winter warming trend. In central Europe, the stimulation of photosynthesis and plant growth by “CO2 fertilization” mitigated warming, through a negative evapotranspiration feedback associated with increased vegetation cover and leaf area index. In southern Europe, increased summer dryness restricted plant growth and survival, causing a positive warming feedback through reduced evapotranspiration.” (abstract) 1- Wramneby et al (2010) Hot spots of vegetation‐climate feedbacks under future greenhouse forcing in Europe, Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: CO2's Role in the Climate System

FACT1: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is a greenhouse gas that plays a significant role in regulating the Earth's temperature. It traps heat in the atmosphere, which keeps the planet warm enough to support life. Without greenhouse gases like CO2, the Earth would be too cold to support life as we know it.

MYTH: CO2 is not powerful in that sense, the only thing it does in the system is make the planet greener.

FALLACY: This myth is an oversimplification of the role of CO2 in the climate system. While it is true that CO2 is essential for plant growth and can contribute to greening the planet, it is also a potent greenhouse gas that traps heat in the atmosphere. The more CO2 there is in the atmosphere, the more heat it traps, leading to global warming and climate change.

FACT2: Understanding the role of CO2 in the climate system is crucial for addressing climate change. Let's not spread misinformation to our friends and instead educate ourselves on the science of climate change.

fact_checked_segment: “All this could play out in a mere 20 to 50 years — much too quickly for humanity to adapt.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This is a statement that is difficult to justify without a reference to scientific evidence. The current knowledge of time scales involved with rapid ice sheet loss is poor (i.e., solely based on ice sheet models that are crude)—that’s the primary reason why the “How Much How Fast” US-UK program was established.
label: evading the burden of proof
debunk:
TITLE: The rapid pace of climate change poses a threat to human adaptation
FACT1: Climate change is happening at an unprecedented rate, with global temperatures rising at an alarming pace. This rapid pace of change is making it difficult for humans to adapt to the new conditions.
MYTH: None
FALLACY: Slippery Slope. The statement implies that the pace of climate change is too fast for humans to adapt, which could lead to catastrophic consequences. However, this does not mean that adaptation is impossible or that humanity will not be able to cope with the changes.
FACT2: It is important to take action to slow down the pace of climate change and to develop strategies to help humans adapt to the new conditions. Let's work together to reduce our carbon footprint and protect our planet for future generations.

fact_checked_segment: “Can the “uncertainty monster” in climate research, and particularly climate modeling, be acknowledged?”
comment_by_fact-checker: The scientific community has been scrupulously careful to report uncertainties in terms of “likely” or “confidence”. The planet has warmed; that is unequivocal. Humans have contributed; that is more than 95% assured. See: IPCC 5th Assessment Report
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Understanding Uncertainty in Climate Research
FACT1: Climate research involves a complex system of interactions between the atmosphere, oceans, land, and ice, making it difficult to predict future climate changes with complete certainty. However, scientists use a range of methods to quantify and communicate uncertainty in their research.
MYTH: The uncertainty in climate research and modeling is too great to make accurate predictions about future climate changes.
FALLACY: This is an example of ambiguity, as it uses vague language to suggest that uncertainty means that climate research is unreliable. In reality, uncertainty is a normal part of scientific research and is accounted for in climate modeling.
FACT2: By acknowledging and quantifying uncertainty, scientists can improve their understanding of the climate system and make more accurate predictions about future changes. Let's trust in the scientific process and continue to support research that helps us better understand our changing climate.

fact_checked_segment: on average, the projected heating by the models is three times what has been observed.
comment_by_fact-checker: As suggested in the last comment this statistic is quite uncertain (1.5 – 3.3). Some climate models simulate less warming than some satellite datasets. The reason that the average of the CMIP5 models exhibits more warming than observations is in part due to natural variability and problems with the forcing (aerosols, solar changes, etc.) in the models.
label: false authority
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Models vs. Observations: Understanding the Discrepancy
FACT1: Climate models are complex computer simulations that use mathematical equations to predict future climate conditions based on various factors, such as greenhouse gas emissions and solar radiation. However, these models are not perfect and can have discrepancies with actual observations.
MYTH: Climate models overestimate global warming by a factor of three.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, where a single study or observation is used to make a broad conclusion about climate models as a whole. While some studies have found discrepancies between climate model projections and actual observations, others have found good agreement. Additionally, climate models are constantly being updated and improved to better reflect real-world conditions.
FACT2: While there may be some discrepancies between climate model projections and actual observations, the overall consensus among climate scientists is that human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, are causing the Earth's climate to warm at an unprecedented rate. Let's continue to support scientific research and take action to reduce our carbon footprint.

fact_checked_segment: “While the United States must remain vigilant to keep the level of real, dangerous pollutants to a minimum, it may take some consolation in the fact that among G7 nations, it has the cleanest air of all.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Carbon dioxide is a well-mixed greenhouse gas—its concentrations are roughly 407 ppm everywhere across the globe. The national concentration bears absolutely no relevance to the country’s emissions.
label: red herring
debunk:
TITLE: The US has the cleanest air among G7 nations
FACT1: The United States has the cleanest air among the G7 nations, according to a report by the World Health Organization. The report measured the levels of fine particulate matter, which can cause respiratory and cardiovascular problems, in the air of G7 nations. The US had the lowest levels of these pollutants among the group.

MYTH: None.

FALLACY: The statement uses a red herring fallacy by implying that the US should take consolation in having the cleanest air among G7 nations, rather than focusing on the need to reduce dangerous pollutants to protect public health. It also uses a cherry-picking fallacy by focusing on one aspect of air quality (fine particulate matter) while ignoring other pollutants that may be present in the air.

FACT2: While it is true that the US has the cleanest air among G7 nations, it is important to remember that air pollution can still have negative health effects even at low levels. It is important to continue efforts to reduce air pollution and protect public health. Let's continue to prioritize clean air for all.

fact_checked_segment: “[Sea ice] also helps regulate the planet’s temperature by influencing the circulation of the atmosphere and ocean. It can affect weather in the U.S.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Sea ice cover is also better at reflecting energy from the sun than open ocean. This makes sea ice an important player in keeping the ocean surface from taking up additional heat.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: The Importance of Sea Ice in Regulating the Planet's Temperature
FACT1: Sea ice plays a crucial role in regulating the planet's temperature by influencing the circulation of the atmosphere and ocean. It helps to cool the planet by reflecting sunlight back into space, and it also helps to regulate the temperature of the ocean by controlling the exchange of heat between the ocean and the atmosphere. 
MYTH: None
FALLACY: None
FACT2: Let's recognize the importance of sea ice in regulating the planet's temperature and take action to protect it. This includes reducing greenhouse gas emissions and supporting policies that promote the conservation of sea ice habitats.

fact_checked_segment: “Consider where they move. Migration patterns show people heading for warm states like Texas and Florida, not snowy Minnesota and Michigan.”
comment_by_fact-checker: This focuses on average climate rather than on extremes, and such patterns of migration are based on our knowledge of the past. As the frequency of extreme hot days increases, as the number of extreme hurricanes increases, and as sea levels rise, people may find that Florida is not so attractive after all.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Migration patterns do not disprove global warming
FACT1: Migration patterns are influenced by many factors, including job opportunities, cost of living, and family ties. People move to warmer states for a variety of reasons, not just because of climate change.
MYTH: Migration patterns disprove global warming because people are moving to warmer states, not colder ones.
FALLACY: This argument is a false equivalence fallacy because it assumes that migration patterns are solely determined by climate change. It also ignores the fact that global warming is a global phenomenon, not just limited to the United States. Additionally, it ignores the fact that many people cannot afford to move, even if they wanted to.
FACT2: Let's not use migration patterns as evidence for or against global warming. Instead, let's look at the scientific evidence and listen to the consensus of climate scientists who have studied the issue extensively.

fact_checked_segment: Climate change? Global warming? What do we call it? […]You can think of global warming as one type of climate change. The broader term covers changes beyond warmer temperatures, such as shifting rainfall patterns.”
comment_by_fact-checker: It is also worth noting that global warming refers to global average temperature rising, but this does not necessarily mean that all locations across the globe are warming at all times.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Climate Change vs Global Warming: What's the Difference?
FACT1: Climate change and global warming are not interchangeable terms. Global warming refers specifically to the increase in Earth's average surface temperature, while climate change encompasses a broader range of changes to Earth's climate system, including changes in precipitation, sea level, and more.
MYTH: Climate change and global warming are the same thing.
FALLACY: Ambiguity. Using the terms interchangeably can lead to confusion and misunderstandings about the full scope of changes occurring in Earth's climate system.
FACT2: Let's use the correct terminology to accurately describe the changes happening to our planet. By understanding the difference between global warming and climate change, we can better communicate the full extent of the changes occurring and take appropriate action to mitigate their impacts.

fact_checked_segment: “Before human burning of fossil fuels triggered global warming, the continent’s ice was in relative balance”
comment_by_fact-checker: Yes. Research suggests that the ice sheet was likely near balance up until close to the turn of the 21st century.
label: no fallacy
debunk:
TITLE: Antarctica's Ice Balance Before Human Burning of Fossil Fuels
FACT1: Antarctica's ice balance was not in relative balance before human burning of fossil fuels. The continent's ice has been losing mass since the 1990s, and the rate of ice loss has been accelerating in recent years. This is due to a combination of factors, including warming ocean temperatures and changes in wind patterns.
MYTH: Antarctica's ice was in relative balance before human burning of fossil fuels.
FALLACY: This myth is an example of cherry-picking, as it selectively focuses on a specific period of time to support a false claim. It also ignores the overwhelming evidence that Antarctica's ice has been melting at an accelerating rate due to human-caused climate change.
FACT2: Let's not spread misinformation about Antarctica's ice balance. The evidence shows that human-caused climate change is causing significant ice loss in Antarctica, which has serious implications for global sea level rise.

fact_checked_segment: “Already, scientists know enough to be concerned. About 120,000 years ago, before the last ice age, the planet went through a natural warm period, with temperatures similar to those expected in coming decades. The sea level was 20 to 30 feet higher than it is today, implying that the ice sheets in both Greenland and Antarctica must have partly disintegrated, a warning of what could occur in the relatively near future if the heating of the planet continues unchecked.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Sea level and temperatures were higher in the previous interglacial, but the Earth climate system generally had a longer time frame to adjust to these conditions.
label: false analogy
debunk:
TITLE: Rising Sea Levels and the Last Natural Warm Period
FACT1: About 120,000 years ago, the Earth experienced a natural warm period with temperatures similar to those expected in the coming decades. During this time, the sea level was 20 to 30 feet higher than it is today, indicating that the ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica partially disintegrated.
MYTH: None.
FALLACY: None.
FACT2: It is important to take action to address climate change and prevent further warming of the planet to avoid the potential consequences of rising sea levels, such as flooding and displacement of coastal communities. Let's work towards reducing our carbon footprint and promoting sustainable practices.

fact_checked_segment: “Another consequence of the fast melting Arctic raises the possibility that there may be even worse extreme weather to come, according to a few scientists: titanic Atlantic superstorms and hurricanes barreling across Europe.”
comment_by_fact-checker: Daniel Swain, Researcher, UCLA, and Research Fellow, National Center for Atmospheric Research: This statement does not accurately describe an outcome that is widely supported in the scientific literature. It is certainly true that Arctic sea ice is decreasing at a rapid rate, and that further sea ice loss is highly likely in the future. It is also plausible, and supported by existing research, that present and future sea ice loss may alter the atmospheric circulation in ways that affect the likelihood of certain kinds of weather events*. But the claim regarding “Atlantic superstorms” and “hurricanes barreling across Europe” seems fairly hyperbolic. Overland et al. (2016) Nonlinear response of mid-latitude weather to the changing Arctic, Nature Climate Change Kug et al.
